PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a complete recodification of the ordinances of the City of Gulfport, Mississippi of a general and permanent nature. 
    Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1963 Code, as supplemented through December 16, 1986, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the city council. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this volume, the reader can locate any section of the 1963 Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
    The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Footnotes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state laws have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this volume. 
Numbering System 
    The numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and municipal codes. Each section number consists of two component parts separated by a dash, the figure before the dash referring to the chapter number and the figure after the dash referring to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the first section of Chapter 4 is numbered 4-1 and the third section of Chapter 6 is 6-3. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and, at the same time, new sections or even whole chapters can be inserted in their proper place, simply by using the decimal system for amendments. By way of illustration: If new material consisting of three sections that would logically come between sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new sections would be numbered 6-1.1, 6-1.2 and 6-1.3, respectively. New chapters may be included in the same manner. If the new material is to be included between Chapters 4 and 5, it will be designated as Chapter 4.5. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject, the next successive number being assigned to the article or division. 
Index 
    The index of the Code has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of the headings being couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology and still others in language generally used by government officers and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which he is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this Code to which the attention of the user is especially directed is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing for the Code. With this system, the Code will be kept up-to-date periodically. Upon the final passage of amendatory ordinances, they will be properly edited and the appropriate page or pages affected will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the Code, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
    Successfully keeping this Code up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the volume. As revised sheets are received it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted-pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
    The publication of this Code was under the direct supervision of Milton E. Lefkoff, Supervising Editor, and Ronald K. McLaughlin, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
    The publisher is most grateful to Mr. James K. Wetzel, City Attorney, Mr. Raymond M. Mathers, Chief Administrative Officer, and Ms. Sandra E. Baylor, Deputy City Clerk, for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this Code. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs. 
MUNICIPAL CODE CORPORATION 
Tallahassee, Florida 
ADOPTING ORDINANCE 
ORDINANCE NO. 1826 
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING AND ENACTING A NEW CODE OF ORDINANCES OF THE CITY OF GULFPORT, MISSISSIPPI; ESTABLISHING THE SAME; PROVIDING FOR THE REPEAL OF CERTAIN ORDINANCES NOT INCLUDED THEREIN, AND PROVIDING WHEN THIS ORDINANCE SHALL BECOME EFFECTIVE. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE MAYOR AND CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF GULFPORT, MISSISSIPPI: 
    Section 1. That this ordinance, consisting of Chapters 1 through 11, each inclusive, is hereby adopted and enacted as the "Code of Ordinances of the City of Gulfport, Mississippi," and shall be treated and considered as a new and original comprehensive ordinance which shall supersede all other general and permanent ordinances, except such as by reference thereto are expressly saved from repeal or continued in force and effect for any purpose. 
    Section 2. That all provisions of such Code shall be in full force and effect on and after the 3rd day of January, 1989, and all ordinances of a general and permanent nature of the City of Gulfport not in such Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein are hereby repealed from and after the effective date of this ordinance. 
    Section 3. That the repeal provided for in Section 2 hereof shall not affect any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this ordinance; nor shall such repeal affect any ordinance or resolution of the City promising or guaranteeing the payment of money by or to the City, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the City, or any evidence of the City's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed or incurred by the City; nor shall such repeal affect the administrative ordinances or resolutions not in conflict or inconsistent with the provisions of this Code; nor shall such repeal affect any right or franchise granted by any ordinance or resolution to any person, firm or corporation; nor shall such repeal affect any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the City; nor shall such repeal affect any ordinance making appropriations; nor shall such repeal affect any ordinance levying or imposing taxes; nor shall such repeal affect any ordinance providing for local improvements and making assessments therefor; nor shall such repeal affect the zoning ordinances, amendments and variances; nor shall such repeal affect any salary ordinance or resolution; nor shall such repeal affect any ordinance establishing, extending or otherwise affecting the boundaries of the City; nor shall such repeal affect any ordinance relating to employee classifications of the City or creating, abolishing, fixing the duties for or establishing the compensation for any position in the employment of the City, nor inconsistent with this Code; nor shall such repeal affect any ordinance or resolution pertaining to the Gulfport Municipal Separate School District; nor shall such repeal be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance which is repealed by this ordinance. 
    Section 4. That a copy of such Code shall be kept on file in the office of the City Clerk, preserved in looseleaf form, or in such other form as the City Clerk may consider most expedient. It shall be the express duty of the City Clerk or someone authorized by him to insert in their designated places all amendments or ordinances which indicate the intention of the City to make the same a part of such Code when the same have been printed or reprinted in page form and to extract from such Code all provisions which may be from time to time repealed. This copy of such Code shall be available to all persons desiring to examine the same and shall be considered the official Code of Ordinances of the City. 
    Section 5. That in case of the amendment of any section of such Code for which a penalty is not provided, the general penalty, as provided in Section 1-9 of this Code, shall apply to the section as amended; or in case such amendment contains provisions for which a penalty, other than the aforementioned general penalty, is provided in another section of such Code, the penalty so provided in such other section shall be held to relate to the section so amended, unless such penalty is specifically repealed therein. 
    Section 6. That it shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to change or alter by additions or deletions, any part of portion of such Code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the City of Gulfport to be misrepresented thereby. Any person, firm or corporation violating this section shall be punished as provided in Section 1-9 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Gulfport. 
    Section 7. That all ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are, to the extent of such conflict, hereby repealed. 
    Section 8. That this ordinance shall be in force and take effect the 3rd day of January, 1989. 
    The above and foregoing Ordinance, after having been first reduced to writing and read by the Clerk, was introduced by Peden, seconded by McDaniel, and was adopted by the following roll call vote, to wit: 
Yeas Absent Nays Jenkins Turnbough None McDaniel Peden Sinopoli  
    The President thereby declared the motion carried and the Ordinance adopted, this the 3rd day of January, 1989. 
(SEAL)

SUPPLEMENT HISTORY TABLE 
    The table below allows users of this Code to quickly and accurately determine what ordinances have been considered for codification in each supplement. Ordinances that are of a general and permanent nature are codified in the Code and are considered "Included." Ordinances that are not of a general and permanent nature are not codified in the Code and are considered "Omitted." 
    In addition, by adding to this table with each supplement, users of this Code of Ordinances will be able to gain a more complete picture of the Code's historical evolution.

PART I - HISTORICAL DOCUMENTS[1] 
1898 Petition of Electors for Incorporation 
Gulfport, Miss., Feb. 8, 1898 
To the honorable, A. J. McLaurin 
Governor State of Miss. 
Jackson, Miss. 
    The undersigned, citizens and legal voters of Gulfport, Harrison County, Mississippi, respectfully petition your excellency to grant them the privilege of incorporation as provided by statute and the laws of the state applicable to the incorporation of cities, towns and villages. We desire to be incorporated under the name and style of the Town of Gulfport, Mississippi. Our present population exceeds five hundred (500) souls. 
    The limits of said town shall be as follows: Beginning at a point on the seashore three quarters of a mile east of the center of the track of the Gulf and Ship Island Railroad, where said railroad enters the waters of the gulf or Mississippi Sound, thence due south one (1) mile into the said Mississippi Sound; thence in a westerly direction parallel with the shore and one (1) mile therefrom to a point opposite the seashore, thirteen hundred and twenty (1,320) feet from and west of the dividing line of section[s] eight and nine of township eight south, range eleven west; thence due north to the said point on the seashore, and thence due north one mile and a half (11/2) or thereabouts; thence east to and along the northern boundary as per plat of the Town of Gulfport on file in the chancery clerk's office until a point due north of the point of beginning is reached; thence south to the place of beginning on said seashore of Mississippi Sound. 
    Your petitioners would most respectfully ask your excellency to appoint the following named parties as mayor and alderman [sic] of said town, to serve under this incorporation until their successors shall be elected and installed, viz[.]: F. B. Hewes, Mayor; A. McAlpin, O. T. Cassibey, J. J. Thornton, [and] E. M. Lake, Aldermen. 
    And as in duty bound your petitioners will every pray. 
    H. E. Richardson, J. T. Miller, W. S. Champlain, Jos. B. Leger, J. S. Richardson, T. G. Bailey, E. C. Harris, E. Langnulty, J. F. Mahoney, W. C. Palmes, W. E. Richardson, Jas. Tunney, A. D. Pierce, T. P. Gary, A. L. Thornton, Thos. E. Goode, J. R. Kelly, W. T. Crane, S. Howard, J. S. Havard, T. E. McCreary, A. J. Courtright, S. McNeil, S. O. Lee, W. S. Hughes, Allen E. Cameron, Chas. McNeil, Chas. Barnard, A. McAlpin, Wm. T. Moorman, G. E. Forstall, E. M. Lake, W. S. Cooper, J. E. Cruthunds, F. W. Odom, L. G. Seukee, S. T. Bullis, E. J. Younghams, S. Simonson, J. W. Jackson, A. Murdock, P. L. Barnes, Thos. Cauham. 
1898 Incorporation Proclamation 
State of Mississippi 
Executive Department 
To all to whom these presents shall come-Greetings: 
    Whereas, a petition signed by two-thirds of the electors residing within the proposed limits of the Town of Gulfport, in the County of Harrison, has been presented to me setting forth the metes and bounds of said town, and stating the number of inhabitants to be five hundred (500), and the said petition having been published for three (3) weeks as required by law: 
    Now therefore, I, A. J. McLaurin, governor of the State of Mississippi by virtue of the authority vested in me by the constitution and laws of the state do issue this my proclamation declaring the said Town of Gulfport in the County of Harrison, incorporated with metes and bounds as follows, to wit: Beginning at a point on the seashore, three quarters of a mile east of the center of the track of the Gulf and Ship Island Railroad, where said railroad enters the waters of the gulf or Mississippi Sound, thence due south one (1) mile into the said Mississippi Sound; thence in a westerly direction parallel with the shore, and one (1) mile therefrom to a point opposite the seashore thirteen hundred and twenty (1,320) feet from and west of the dividing line of sections eight and nine of township eight south, range eleven west; thence due north to the said point on the seashore, and thence due north one mile and a half (11/2) or thereabouts; thence east to and along the northern boundary line as per plat of Gulfport on file in the chancery clerk's office, until a point due north of the point of beginning is reached; thence south to the place of beginning on said seashore of Mississippi Sound. 
    And the name of the said proposed town is hereby fixed as the Town of Gulfport and shall exercise all the rights and powers conferred by Chapter 93 of the Annotated Code of Mississippi of 1892, and amendatory acts thereto. 
    In testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my hand, and caused the great seal of the State of Mississippi to be affixed. 
    Done at the capitol, in the City of Jackson, this the twenty-eighth day of July, in the year of our Lord, 1898. 
By the governor       A. J. McLaurin 
 J. L. Power 
Secretary of state 
1904 Proclamation Changing Town to City 
Recorded Nov. 14, 1904. 
State of Mississippi, 
 Executive office, Jackson. 
To all to whom these presents shall come, greeting: 
    Whereas, the board of mayor and aldermen of the Town of Gulfport, Harrison County, Mississippi, have certified to me that under the census taken by authority of the board of mayor and aldermen of the Town of Gulfport, that it appears that the town has increased in population to the number of four thousand one hundred twelve (4,112) thereby taking said municipality out of the class to which it has heretofore belonged. 
    Now therefore, I, Jas. K. Vardaman, governor of the State of Mississippi, by virtue of the authority vested in me by the constitution and laws of the state do issue this my proclamation changing the name of said Town of Gulfport to the City of Gulfport and assigning it to the first class, and it shall from and after this date be known and designated as the City of Gulfport, and shall exercise all the rights and privileges conferred upon municipalities of the first class by Chapter 93 of the Annotated Code of 1892 and amendments thereto. 
    In testimony whereof I have hereunto set my hand and caused the great seal of the State of Mississippi to be affixed. Done at the capitol in the City of Jackson this the tenth day of November in the year of our Lord, 1904. 
By the governor:       Jas. K. Vardaman 
 Joseph W. Powers, secretary of state. 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Certain historical documents are included in this part. Subsequent to the time of such documents, a charter for the city, not included herein, was approved in a city election on December 12, 1911, for a commission form of government. The governor approved the charter on January 16, 1912. Such charter was issued by the secretary of state of Mississippi pursuant to Chapter 108, Laws of Mississippi, 1908. At a special election held on January 29, 1985, the city adopted a mayor-council form of government in place of the mayor-commissioner form. Then, on July 1, 1985, the mayor-council form of government (Miss. Code Ann. 1972, Title 21, Chapter 8) became effective and replaced the city charter provisions. 

Chapter 1 - GENERAL GOVERNMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Parks, grounds and beautification, Ch. 8; water and sewers, Ch. 11; dock master, § 2-78; plumbing board generally, § 3-63 et seq.; plumbing board, functions as to mechanical installations, § 3-151 et seq.; electrical examining board, § 3-201 et seq.; health officer designated, § 4-1; city-county hospital, § 4-7; garbage collection and disposal, § 4-166 et seq.; traffic division established, § 6-3; Keep Gulfport Beautiful Commission, § 8-26 et seq.; park commission, § 8-51 et seq.; planning commission, § 9-28; sign inspector, § 9-119; fire prevention and protection, § 10-26 et seq.; bureau of fire prevention, § 10-49; administration of zoning ordinance, App. A, § VIII; administration of flood control ordinance, App. B, Art. IV. 
State Law reference- Municipalities, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 21-1-1 et seq.; mayor-council form of government, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 21-8-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated, cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters shall constitute and be designated as the Code of Ordinances of the City of Gulfport, Mississippi, and may be so cited. It may also be cited as the Gulfport Code. 
(Code 1963, § 1-1) 
State Law reference- Revision and codification of ordinances, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 21-13-15. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and interpretation. 
    In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council: 
    City council, council. The term "city council" or "council" shall mean the city council of the City of Gulfport, Mississippi. 
    City, municipality. The words "the city," "this city," "the municipality," or "this municipality" shall be construed as if the words "of Gulfport, Mississippi" followed it. 
    Computation of time. The time within which an act is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first and including the last day, and if the last day be Sunday or a legal holiday that day shall be excluded. 
State Law reference- How time computed where a number of days is prescribed in statutes, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 1-3-67. 
    County. The words "the county" or "this county" shall mean the County of Harrison, in the State of Mississippi. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision requires or authorizes an officer or employee of the city to do some act or perform some duty, it shall be construed to authorize the officer or employee to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the act or duty unless the terms of the provision designate otherwise. 
    Gender. Words importing the masculine gender shall include the feminine and neuter. 
State Law reference- Gender construed in statutes, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 1-3-17. 
    Miss. Code Ann. 1972. The term "Miss. Code Ann. 1972" shall mean the official code of the State of Mississippi, as amended. 
    Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
State Law reference- "Month" defined, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 1-3-29. 
    Number. Words used in the singular shall include the plural, and the plural shall include the singular number. 
State Law reference- Number construed in statutes, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 1-3-33. 
    Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
State Law reference- "Oath" and "sworn" construed, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, §§ 1-3-35, 1-3-53. 
    Owner. The word "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The word "person" shall include a corporation, firm, partnership, association, organization and any other group acting as a unit, as well as an individual. 
State Law reference- "Person" defined, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 1-3-39. 
    Personal property. The term "personal property" shall include goods, chattels, effects, evidences of rights of action, and all written instruments by which any pecuniary obligation, or any right, title, or interest in any real or personal estate, shall be created, acknowledged, transferred, incurred, defeated, discharged, or diminished. 
State Law reference- "Personal property" defined, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 1-3-41. 
    Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following" shall mean next before and the next after, respectively. 
    Property. The word "property" shall include real and personal property. 
State Law reference- "Property" defined, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 1-3-45. 
    Real property. The term "real property" shall include every estate, interest or right in lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean that portion of a street between curblines, or the lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property lines intended for the use of pedestrians. 
State Law reference- "Sidewalk" defined, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 63-3-125(d). 
    Signature, subscription. The word "signature" or "subscription" shall include a mark when the person cannot write. 
    State. The words "the state" or "this state" shall mean the State of Mississippi. 
    Street. The word "street" shall mean the entire width between property lines of every way or place of whatever nature when any part thereof is open to the use of the public, as a matter of right, for purposes of vehicular traffic. 
State Law reference- "Street" defined, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 63-3-125(a). 
    Tenant. The word "tenant" or "occupant," applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense shall include the future as well as the past and present. 
    Writing, written. The words "writing" and "written" shall include printing, engraving, lithographing and any other mode of representing words and letters. 
State Law reference- "Written" defined, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 1-3-61. 
    Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year. 
State Law reference- "Year" defined, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 1-3-63. 
(Code 1963, § 1-2) 
Sec. 1-3. - General severability provision. 
(a)  If any section, paragraph, sentence, clause, phrase or any other part of this Code is declared to be unconstitutional or void, or if for any reason is declared to be invalid or of no effect, the remaining sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses, phrases or parts hereof shall be in no manner affected thereby but shall remain in full force and effect. 
(b)  Unless the contrary intent shall clearly appear in the particular ordinance in question, every ordinance passed after the effective date of this Code shall be read and construed as though the provisions of subsection (a) form an integral part thereof, whether expressly set out therein or not. 
(Code 1963, § 1-3) 
State Law reference- Severability of statutes, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, §§ 1-1-31, 1-3-77. 
Sec. 1-4. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of such sections, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(Code 1963, § 1-4) 
Sec. 1-5. - Effect on existing ordinances. 
    The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as those ordinances existing at the time of the effective date of this Code, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. 
(Code 1963, § 1-5) 
State Law reference- Statutes brought forward deemed to be continuations, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 1-1-19. 
Sec. 1-6. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinance in force before or at the time the ordinance repeal took effect. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or matter covered under the ordinance repealed. 
(Code 1963, § 1-6) 
State Law reference- Effect of statutes, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 1-1-21 et seq. 
Sec. 1-7. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code, may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion herein. In the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section _______ of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Gulfport, Mississippi, is hereby amended to read as follows:...." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(c)  In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code, is to be added, the following language shall be used: "That the Code of Ordinances of the City of Gulfport, Mississippi, is hereby amended by adding a section, article or chapter to be numbered _______, which said section reads as follows:...." The new section shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(d)  All sections, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed must be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be. 
(Code 1963, § 1-7) 
State Law reference- Style of ordinances, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 21-13-7. 
Sec. 1-8. - Altering Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to change or alter by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented. 
(Code 1963, § 1-8) 
Cross reference- Offenses and miscellaneous provisions, Ch. 7. 
Sec. 1-9. - General penalty. 
    Wherever in this Code or in any ordinance of the city, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or the doing of any act is required, or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provisions of this Code or ordinance of the city shall be punished by a fine not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or by imprisonment not exceeding ninety (90) days, or both. Every day any violation of this Code or any such ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1963, § 1-9) 
State Law reference- Penalty for violation of ordinances, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 21-13-1; misdemeanors under state penal laws as criminal offenses against municipalities, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 21-13-19. 
Sec. 1-10. - Working city prisoners; credit against fine. 
(a)  Persons imprisoned for the violation of city ordinances may be required to work upon the streets, avenues, and alleys of the city under the direction of the chief of police. 
(b)  Every prisoner for each day's work he is required to do shall receive credit on his fine and cost assessed against him of thirty dollars ($30.00) per day, until such fine and cost are fully paid. And in case the prisoner is serving a sentence of imprisonment, each day that he works in serving such sentence shall entitle him credit for equal time on his sentence of imprisonment, but in no instance shall a prisoner receive credit on the fine and cost and on the time sentenced to imprisonment for the same work. 
(c)  The chief of police shall file a report with the court clerk of each prisoner working out a fine, and the latter shall credit the result of such labor to the fine assessed against such prisoner as the same appears upon his court docket. 
(Code 1963, § 1-10) 
State Law reference- Credit allowed for labor of convicts, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 47-1-47. 
Sec. 1-11. - Custody of prisoners. 
    All persons convicted of any violation of any ordinance of the city and sentenced to imprisonment for any period of time or being fined and in default of paying such fine and cost, shall be committed to prison until the payment of such fine and cost shall be made and remain in the custody of the chief of police and by him confined in such prison within the corporate limits as may be provided by the mayor and city council, or in the event the chief of police should have at any time any person so convicted and imprisoned in his custody, and for any cause there should fail to be a sufficient prison or jail provided by the mayor and city council, for the safe keeping of the prisoner he may, with the consent of the mayor, make arrangements with the sheriff of the county for the safe keeping of the prisoner, until the mayor and city council shall have provided a safe and sufficient prison for such prisoners. 
(Code 1963, § 1-11) 
Sec. 1-12. - Remission of fines and imprisonment. 
    The mayor shall have the power to remit fines and forfeitures, and to vacate and annul penalties of all kinds, for offenses against the ordinances of the city, with the consent of the city council. However, a fine, forfeiture or penalty shall not be remitted, vacated or annulled unless the reasons therefor be entered on the minutes by the clerk, together with and as a part of the order so doing. 
(Code 1963, § 1-12) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 21-15-15.

ARTICLE II. - MAYOR AND COUNCIL 

Sec. 1-36. - Ward districts created. 
    In accordance with the 2011 Redistricting Plan of the City of Gulfport, the City of Gulfport, Mississippi, be, and it is hereby redistricted, reapportioned, realigned, reconstituted and divided into seven (7) districts, known as "WARDS", within which one (1) Council person shall be elected from each ward ("single member wards") as hereinafter provided in sections 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, and 9, [of Ordinance No. 2731], and as shown and identified on the map of the City of Gulfport submitted herewith as Exhibit "A" to take effect as hereinafter provided.

    Ward 1 shall be bounded, and include all territory within its bounds in the City of Gulfport, First Judicial District of the County of Harrison, State of Mississippi, particularly described, as follows: 
    Following are the boundaries of Ward 1 of the City of Gulfport, Mississippi: Beginning at the Northwest corner of Section 31, Township 7 South, Range 11 West, said point being on the Western municipal limits of the City of Gulfport; thence run East to and along the centerline of Harrison Drive to the point of intersection with the centerline of Hawthorne Street; thence run South along the centerline of Hawthorne Street to its intersection with the centerline of Pearl Street; thence run East along the centerline of Pearl Street and Meadowlark Drive to its intersection with the centerline of 34th Avenue; thence run South along the centerline of 34th Avenue 150 feet, more or less, to a point in line with the North line of Section 33, Township 7 South, Range 11 West; Sec. 1-37. - Exercise of executive and administrative powers and duties. 
    The executive and administrative powers duties of the municipality shall be exercised by the mayor. 
(Code 1963, § 2-17) 
State Law reference- Mayor to exercise executive power, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 21-8-15. 
Sec. 1-38. - Compensation of mayor. 
    The salary paid to the mayor shall be ninety-two thousand, one hundred eighty-four dollars four cents ($92,184.04) per annum and shall be paid in biweekly installments of three thousand, five hundred forty-five dollars fifty-four cents ($3,545.54) on alternating Thursdays as established by the city, in addition to the use and maintenance of an automobile and coverage pursuant to a health insurance policy. 
    Proviso: The current salary paid to the mayor of seventy-two thousand two hundred forty-two dollars ($72,242.00) per annum will remain in effect until after the municipal election of 2009, at which time the increase adopted by this section shall become effective (i.e., when the next elected mayor takes office). 
(Code 1963, § 2-18; Ord. No. 2042, § 1, 2-21-96; Ord. No. 2606, § 2, 9-15-08) 
State Law reference- Compensation of mayor, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 21-8-21. 
Sec. 1-39. - Compensation of council members. 
    The salary paid to the members of the city council beginning with commencement of the term of office of the council in 2009 shall be twenty-three thousand, one hundred ninety-two dollars ($23,192.00), and shall be paid in biweekly install ments of eight hundred ninety-two dollars ($892.00) on alternating Thursdays as established by the city. 
    Said compensation shall be in addition to coverage pursuant to a health insurance policy for each such council member. 
    If the first pay period begins or the last pay period ends on a day other than the first or last day of the pay period, the payment shall be adjusted to conform with the salary fixed herein. 
    Proviso: The current salary paid to council members of twenty-one thousand three hundred eight dollars twenty-eight cents ($21,308.28) per annum will remain in effect until after the municipal election of 2009, at which time the increase adopted by this section shall become effective (i.e., when the next elected council takes office). 
(Code 1963, § 2-19; Ord. No. 2042, § 2, 2-21-96; Ord. No. 2263, § 2, 12-5-00; Ord. No. 2606, § 3, 9-15-08) 
State Law reference- Compensation of members of the council, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 21-8-21. 
Sec. 1-40. - Chief administrative officer. 
(a)  The chief administrative officer shall be appointed by the mayor, with the advice and consent of the council; such chief administrative officer shall serve at the will and pleasure of the mayor, shall be answerable solely to the mayor in the performance of his functions, and shall be subject to dismissal at the pleasure of the mayor. The chief administrative officer shall coordinate and direct the operations of the various departments and functions of municipal government, and may exercise any authority, power, or duty delegated to him by the mayor. The chief administrative officer shall be excluded from the coverage of any ordinance or general law providing for a civil service system in the municipality. The position of chief administrative officer shall be a nonclassified position. 
(b)  The qualifications of the position of chief administrative officer shall include a law degree, or a degree in business, public administration, accounting, or a comparable discipline, or five (5) years of experience in business, administration, municipal planning, municipal management, or a comparable administrative profession. 
(Code 1963, § 2-20) 
State Law reference- Chief administrative officer, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 21-8-25. 
Sec. 1-41. - Time, place of regular council meetings, and call of special council meetings. 
(a)  Meeting place. All regular and special public meetings of the council and mayor shall be held in the council room of the city hall located at 2309 15th Street unless adjourned to, or scheduled in advance, to be held in another location. 
(b)  Scheduled regular and special public meetings. Regular public meetings shall be held on the first and third Tuesdays after the first Monday of each month commencing at 1:30 p.m. A majority of the members of the council, or a majority of the members of the council present at any meeting, may cancel or reschedule any scheduled regular or special meeting, provided that no less than one (1) regular meeting is held each month. 
(c)  Special called meetings. Special called public meetings of the council and mayor may be called at times other than the scheduled meetings by the mayor or a majority of the members of the council. 
(Code 1963, § 2-21; Ord. No. 2203, § II, 11-16-99; Ord. No. 2780 , § 2, 7-2-13) 
State Law reference- Regular and special meetings of council, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 21-8-11. 
Sec. 1-42. - Responsibility and authority of council president and mayor; finalizing of agenda. 
    The council president shall be responsible for determining the order of each part of the agenda (each subagenda) for each meeting. All matters to be placed on the agenda by any member of the city council shall be authorized by the president of the council as provided herein. The president shall be required to place all matters presented by a councilmember as prescribed herein on the agenda at the earliest possible opportunity for council action. All matters to be placed on the agenda by any member of the executive branch of government shall be authorized by the mayor as prescribed herein. The council president and the mayor shall determine the items to be placed on the agenda for submission to the clerk of council no later than 2:00 p.m. on the Monday preceding by seven (7) days the Monday immediately prior to the next regular or recessed council meeting. 
(Code 1963, § 2-22; Ord. No. 2012, § 1, 3-7-95) 
State Law reference- Council president, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 21-8-11. 
Sec. 1-43. - Request for legislative action. 
    Any member of the city council wishing to place a matter on the agenda shall provide a draft of his request for legislative action to the council president no later than 2:00 p.m. on the Monday preceding by seven (7) days the Monday immediately prior to the next regular or recessed council meeting. The council shall take no official action on any matter requested to be placed on the agenda by an individual councilmember until such time as a staff and/or legal review has been made. Staff and/or legal review shall be completed as quickly as practically possible and, upon approval of the submitting councilmember, shall thereafter be placed by the president on the agenda for official action, provided that if staff and/or legal review has not been completed within seven (7) working days, then the initiating councilmember shall have the right to either wait for the completion of review, or place the matter upon the agenda without completion of review. Nothing in this section is intended to prevent any member of the council from informally seeking the assistance of the city attorney or the executive branch, through the mayor, in the preparation of the draft for legislation of the councilmember. All items initiated by councilmembers shall appear on the agenda by title. 
(Code 1963, § 2-23; Ord. No. 2177, § 2, 6-8-99) 
State Law reference- How certain actions are to be taken, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 21-13-3. 
Sec. 1-44. - Arrangement of agenda as presented by president. 
(1)  The first item to be considered on the agenda shall be the agenda order, which sets the order of the agenda to be considered by the council during the meeting. 
(2)  The second item to be considered on the agenda shall be the presentation agenda, during which the mayor and city administration, by and through the mayor and/or chief administrative officer or their designee(s), shall present a report or status on the affairs of the city administration. 
(3)  The third item to be considered on the agenda shall be policy issues, which are items or matters that require affirmative action of the city council as the city's legislative authority following any applicable discussion and/or deliberation. 
(4)  The fourth item to be considered on the agenda shall be the routine agenda, during which items or matters are presented and considered by the city council for ratification or otherwise for acceptance into the minutes of the council. 
(5)  The fifth item to be considered on the agenda shall be the public forum, during which time members of the public may be permitted to give comment within prescribed time limits. Prospective speakers during this forum must submit a written or documented request to the city council clerk by way of a pre-printed card in the possession of the city council clerk at any time prior to commencement of the public forum. 
(Code 1963, § 2-24; Ord. No. 2012, § 2, 3-7-95; Ord. No. 2177, § 3, 6-8-99; Ord. No. 2275, §1, 4-3-01; Ord. No. 2304, § 1, 12-5-01; Ord. No. 2424, § 1, 3-23-05; Ord. No. 2632, § 2, 7-7-09) 
State Law reference- Voting in council meetings, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 21-8-11; notice of meetings, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 25-41-13. 
Sec. 1-45. - Citizens agenda meeting. 
    Citizens agenda meeting. The city council may hold a citizens agenda meeting on dates and at times and locations set by a majority of the members of the council. During this citizens agenda meeting, members of the public may be permitted to give comment or input within prescribed time limits. Prospective speakers at this hearing may submit to the city council clerk a request by way of a preprinted card in the possession of the city council clerk or by way of an equivalent documented request no later than seven (7) days prior to the date of the subject citizens agenda meeting, if the meeting is set with seven (7) days or more prior notice and which request shall contain the name and address of the prospective speaker and detailed description of the anticipated or intended topics to be discussed by the speaker. At any citizens agenda meeting, the city council may take such action as is appropriate under the circumstances on any matter found on the agenda for that meeting. The agenda for the citizens agenda meeting shall give notice that official action may be taken on matters found on the agenda. 
(Ord. No. 2632, § 4, 7-7-09; Ord. No. 2659, § 2, 11-18-09; Ord. No. 2701, § 2, 10-5-10) 
Secs. 1-46-1-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ADMINISTRATION[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal officers and records, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 21-15-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 1-66. - When city hall closed. 
    The city hall shall be closed on Saturday and Sunday, except when required by law to remain open. 
(Code 1963, § 2-1) 
State Law reference- Legal holidays, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 3-3-7. 
Sec. 1-67. - Manner of disposing of real property acquired by city. 
    All real property owned by the city and any and all real property that may be acquired by the city, through tax sales, purchase, condemnation proceedings and/or other methods of acquisition may be leased, sold or disposed of in the manner prescribed in Miss. Code Ann. 1972, Section 21-17-1. 
(Code 1963, § 2-2) 
Sec. 1-68. - Social Security, retirement for city employees. 
(a)  Adopted. It is hereby declared to be the policy of the city to extend the provisions of Articles 1 and 3 of Chapter 11 of Title 25 of the Miss. Code Ann. of 1972, being Section 25-11-1 et seq., providing Social Security and state retirement to eligible employees and officers of the city, except as provided in subsection (b) hereof. In pursuance of such policy, and for that purpose, the officers of the city shall take such action as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(b)  Agreements authorized; exemptions. The mayor and city clerk are hereby authorized and directed to execute an agreement with the public employees' retirement system of Mississippi to secure coverage of eligible employees as provided in subsection (a) hereof; provided that the agreement relating to Social Security shall be made effective as of March 1, 1951, as provided by Section 25-11-1 et seq., as amended. 
(c)  Withholdings. Withholdings from salaries or wages of employees for the purposes provided in subsection (a) hereof are hereby authorized to be made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state and federal laws and regulations, and shall be paid over to the state agency in such amounts and at such times as are designated by state laws and regulations. 
(d)  Employer contributions, expenses. Employer contributions and administrative expenses shall be paid to the state agency in accordance with applicable state laws and regulations from amounts appropriated for such purposes. 
(e)  Records, reports. The city clerk shall maintain such records and submit such reports as may be required by applicable state and federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1963, § 2-3) 
State Law reference- Social Security coverage of local employees, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 25-11-11; membership in state retirement system, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 25-11-105. 
Sec. 1-68.1. - Civil service coverage for all full-time city employees; exceptions; requirements. 
(a)  The benefits of the civil service coverage of the city as set out in Section 21-31-1 et seq., Miss. Code Ann. of 1972, as amended, is extended to all full-time employees of the city with the exception that said coverage shall not extend to any appointed member or employee specifically excluded from coverage by state law, including, but not necessarily limited to, the chief administrative officer as set out in Section 21-8-25, Miss. Code Ann., all directors of departments as set out in Section 21-8-23, Miss. Code Ann., and it is further provided hereby that as appointees serving as extra members excluded from coverage as provided by Section 21-31-13, Miss. Code Ann., are the mayor's administrative assistant, if any, appointed by the mayor, and the secretary II position, if any, appointed by the mayor, and the public relations officer, if any, appointed by the mayor, and officer in charge of reserves, appointed by the chief of police with approval of the mayor. 
(b)  The city council adopts the current personnel policy, excluding the grievance procedure, along with the current employee classification, job description, pay grades and pay-step charts which are currently in effect and established as of March 31, 1989, and provides, further, that all employees to whom civil service benefits are extended for the first time on September 1, 1989, shall be under a probationary period of six (6) months from and after September 1, 1989. Employees hired after September 1, 1989, shall be under a probationary period of one (1) year from and after the beginning of their employment, unless such period is extended up to one hundred eighty (180) days on consent of the mayor, the appointing authority. 
(c)  All employees currently employed in accordance with residency requirements in effect when they were employed will continue to be allowed employment with the city; however, all new employees who accept employment with the city after enactment of this paragraph shall be residents and electors of Harrison County, or if outside of Harrison County, then of one of the following counties: Hancock, Jackson, Stone, Pearl River or George as a prerequisite to employment. 
(d)  The civil service commission shall adopt further rules and regulations concerning the enforcement and effect of the provisions of the civil service commission; however, the Gulfport City Council specifically requests that said rules and regulations be first approved by the city council, and that any change in the current personnel policy employee classification be first approved by the city council before the same shall be in full force and effect. 
(e)  For good cause being shown and the interest and welfare of the city and the citizens thereof, this section shall be in full force and effect from and after September 1, 1989, and shall be published according to law. 
(Ord. No. 1833, §§ 1-5, 4-18-89; Ord. No. 1850, § 1, 8-22-89; Ord. No. 20-89, § 1, 8-5-97; Ord. No. 2108, § 1, 10-22-97; Ord. No. 2296, § 2, 10-3-01; Ord. No. 2762 , § 2, 10-2-12) 
Sec. 1-68.2. - Civil service coverage no longer to extend to incoming employees other than police and fire. 
(a)  Civil service coverage of the city as set out in Miss. Code Ann. 1972, §§ 21-31-1 et seq., as amended ("the Civil Service Act") shall not be extended to employees, other than full-time fire and police employees, after September 3, 2005. 
(b)  Civil service benefits and coverage shall continue in effect for qualifying police and fire full-time employees pursuant to the Civil Service Act. 
(c)  Civil service benefits and coverage shall remain in effect for all full-time employees to which it extended that commenced employment on or before September 3, 2005. 
(d)  No later than November 8, 2005, the city's personnel grievance policy shall be reviewed and revised as determined needed for all employees not provided civil service coverage and benefits. 
(Ord. No. 2448, § 2, 9-3-05) 
Sec. 1-69. - Civil service commission. 
(a)  A civil service commission for the city is hereby created and established with all powers, rights and duties set forth and authorized in Section 21-31-1 et seq. of the Miss. Code Ann. of 1972, as amended. 
(b)  The members of the civil service commission shall be seven (7) in number and shall be appointed with one (1) member of the commission being a resident from each ward of the municipality. No person shall be appointed a member of such commission who is not a citizen of the United States. Except for appointees from Wards 6 and 7, no person shall be appointed who has not been a resident of the city for at least five (5) years immediately preceding such appointment. After January 4, 1999, no person shall be appointed from Wards 6 and 7, who has not been a resident of the City of Gulfport for at least five (5) years immediately preceding such appointment. No person shall be appointed a member of the civil service commission who is not an elector of Harrison County. Appointment of members of the commission by the governing authority under this paragraph (b) shall be made by the mayor with the confirmation of an affirmative vote of a majority of the city council present and voting at any meeting. 
    The expiring terms of appointees to the civil service commission shall be on the thirty-first day of December on the following years, to-wit: 
Year 1999 Ward 3 Year 2000 Ward 2 Year 2001 Ward 4 Year 2002 Ward 6 Year 2003 Ward 5 Year 2004 Ward 1 Year 2004 Ward 7  
    Thereafter, all appointments shall be for terms of six (6) years, expiring on successive six-year anniversary dates. 
(c)  Any member of such commission may be removed from office for incompetency, incompatibility, dereliction of duty or other good cause by the appointing power. However, no member shall be removed until charges have been preferred in writing and a full hearing had before the appointing power. Any member being so removed shall have the right of appeal, any time within thirty (30) days thereafter, to the circuit court and may demand a jury trial; such trial shall be confined to the determination of whether the order of removal, made by the appointing power, was or was not made in good faith and for cause. 
(d)  A majority of the members of the commission shall constitute a quorum. 
(e)  The civil service commission shall maintain a record of attendance of the commissioners for each official commission meeting, and shall report absences each month. Compensation for services shall cease as herein provided on December 31, 2009, with final payment for December services to be issued January, 2010. 
(Ord. No. 2136, § 2, 5-5-98; Ord. No. 2161, § 1, 12-8-98; Ord. No. 2660, §§ 2, 3, 12-9-09) 
State Law reference- Publicly owned or leased vehicles to be marked, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 25-1-87. 
Sec. 1-70. - Departments placed under county civil defense director in emergency. 
    The department of public works, the department of parks and recreation, the department of police and the department of fire and rescue shall be subject to complete direction and control of the county civil defense director in time of emergency the activities and control of such departments shall be under the direct control of the county civil defense director, effective upon passage of an order declaring an emergency by the mayor and city council. 
(Code 1963, § 2-5) 
Sec. 1-71. - City-owned or leased vehicles or equipment to display official city logo. 
    All city-owned and/or leased vehicles and equipment shall display the official logo of the city as required by state statute. 
(Code 1963, § 2-6) 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 6. 
State Law reference- Publicly-owned or leased vehicles to be marked, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 25-1-87. 
Sec. 1-72. - Airport; regulation of fixed-base operation. 
    All fixed-base operators on the Gulfport Municipal Airport are required to meet the rules and regulations regarding their operations provided by the Gulfport-Biloxi Airport Authority and state law. 
(Code 1963, § 3-1) 
State Law reference- Aviation, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 61-1-1 et seq.; Municipal Airport Law, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 61-5-1 et seq.; operation and use privileges at municipal airports, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 61-5-11; municipal ordinances, regulations, etc., relating to airports, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 61-5-13. 
Secs. 1-73-1-95. - Reserved.

(b)  The department of finance and administration shall be vested with the authority and shall have the responsibility for administration, supervision, management, operation and direction of the following areas of municipal government: Accounting comptroller, data processing, insurance, licenses, payroll, parking garage personnel, purchasing, tax collecting, voter registration and water billing, harbor administration and maintenance, and grants administration. 
(c)  The city's purchasing manager is hereby authorized to establish and maintain procurement policies and procedures consistent with Mississippi law for all city procurement, including any departmental supply purchases, and any construction or service contracts. 
(d)  The procurement policies and procedures established by the purchasing department shall be followed by all city departments with all city purchasing completed centrally under the direct authority of the purchasing manager. 
(Code 1963, § 2-41; Ord. No. 1832, § 1, 3-28-89; Ord. No. 1880, §§ 1, 2, 6-26-90; Ord. No. 2094, § 1, 8-19-97; Ord. No. 2588, § 2, 5-6-08; Ord. No. 2665, §§ 2, 3, 1-19-10)

(b)  The department of legal administration shall have the responsibility of representing and advising the mayor in all matters for the city in all legal actions brought by or against the city, and he shall attend all meetings of the city council and shall also carry out all duties and responsibilities as set out in the personnel manual classification and shall handle all bond issues without additional compensation therefor. (b)  The department of economic development shall have the responsibility for planning, developing, organizing and supervising economic activities, and for identifying, creating, pursuing and developing economic development opportunities, and marketing those opportunities to encourage quality businesses, tourism, and desirable industrial development in and relocation to Gulfport, and to seek such other goals as may be directed by the mayor and or the chief administrative officer (CAO) to be administered and supervised by the department to increase the number of good job opportunities and to expand and improve civic and recreational resources for citizens and visitors, and to increase the financial base to support public services and an improved quality of life in the city. The services of the department of economic development shall be further administered by the Main Street division. 
(Ord. No. 2778 , § 3, 5-22-13)

(Ord. No. 2781 , § 2, 7-16-13)
