DIVISION 2. - GENERAL PRIVILEGE TAXES 

Sec. 1-141. - Violating privilege tax provisions. 
    Any person who shall exercise any of the privileges herein taxed without paying the tax and procuring the privilege license as required or who shall violate any of the privilege tax provisions of this division shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1963, § 24-24) 
Sec. 1-142. - Local Privilege Tax Law adopted. 
    Pursuant to the authority conferred by Miss. Code Ann. 1972, Section 27-17-5, the Local Privilege Tax Law (Miss. Code Ann. 1972, Section 27-17-1 et seq.) is adopted by the city as its privilege tax law on items and all things covered thereby. The city clerk is hereby authorized and directed to levy and college privilege taxes for the city in the maximum amounts allowed under the provisions thereof. 
(Code 1963, § 24-17) 
Sec. 1-143. - Privilege tax on alcoholic beverages. 
    Pursuant to the authority conferred by Miss. Code Ann. 1972, Section 27-71-345, the city hereby adopts Miss. Code Ann. 1972, Sections 27-71-301 through 27-71-347 as its privilege tax law on all items and things covered therein. The city clerk is authorized and directed to levy and collect privilege taxes in the amount allowed under the provisions of Miss. Code Ann. 1972, Section 27-71-345. 
(Code 1963, § 24-18) 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, § 5-226 et seq. 
Sec. 1-144. - Reserved. 
Sec. 1-145. - Privilege tax on weighing, postage stamp, merchandise, etc., machines. 
    Miss. Code Ann. 1972, Sections 27-27-301-27-27-305 are hereby adopted as the privilege tax law on all items and things set out therein and the city clerk is authorized and directed to levy and collect privilege taxes in the maximum amount allowed under the provision of such sections. 
(Code 1963, § 24-20) 
Sec. 1-146. - Reserved. 
Sec. 1-147. - Privilege tax on tobacco dealers. 
(a)  Wholesale. There is hereby levied and imposed an annual privilege tax of fifty dollars ($50.00) upon each person in the business of distributing or selling at wholesale cigars, cigarettes or smoking tobacco, provided however, that the warehouse or wholesale business be located in the city. 
(b)  Retail. There is hereby levied and imposed an annual privilege tax of five dollars ($5.00) upon each person selling cigars, cigarettes or smoking tobacco at retail where the business is located in the city; provided that this tax shall be paid for each place of business operated by such retailers. 
(Code 1963, § 24-22) 
State Law reference- The Tobacco Tax Law, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 27-69-1 et seq.; state license fee, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 27-69-7; municipal privilege tax, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 27-69-69. 
Secs. 1-148-1-165. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PRIVILEGE LICENSE TAXES ON SLOT AMUSEMENT MACHINES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2007, adopted Dec. 20, 1994, amended Div. 3, §§ 1-166-1-174, which pertained to license taxes on slot amusement machines, in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, Div. 3 pertained to the same subject matter and derived from the 1963 Code, §§ 24-31-24-34, 24-37, 24-39. 
State Law reference- Amusement tax, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 27-11-1 et seq.; slot amusement machine tax, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 27-27-1 et seq.; authority for municipal tax, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 27-27-5. 

Sec. 1-166. - Definitions. 
    The words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them herein. 
    Slot amusement machine or machine means any mechanical device or contrivance which is operated, played, worked, manipulated, or used by inserting or depositing any coin, slug, token or thing of value, in which may be seen any picture or heard any music, or wherein any game may be played, or any form of diversion had. 
    Officer collecting the tax means the city clerk of the City of Gulfport, or such other official or employee of the city who collects taxes for the municipality by whatever title(s) he may be known. 
    Person means and includes any individual, firm, partnership, joint venture, association, corporation, estate, trust, or other group or combination acting as a unit and includes the plural as well as the singular in number. 
(Ord. No. 2007, 12-20-94) 
State Law reference- Definitions relating to slot amusement machine taxes, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 27-27-3. 
Sec. 1-167. - Tax levied. 
    The city shall levy, assess and collect annual license taxes on machines taxable according to this division located for operation within the corporate limits of the city according to the following schedules: 
(1)  For each machine wherein may be seen any picture or heard any music, a license tax for each such machine in the sum of twenty-seven dollars ($27.00). 
(2)  For each machine (not elsewhere specifically taxed in this division) wherein or whereby any game may be played or any form of diversion had, a license tax for each such machine in the sum of forty-five dollars ($45.00). 
(3)  For each machine (not elsewhere specifically taxed in this division) wherein or by means of which children may obtain a ride upon a "hobby horse" or the figure of any animal, or upon the figure of a boat, airplane, rocket, or other such machine, a license tax of eighteen dollars ($18.00) for each machine. 
(Ord. No. 2007, 12-20-94) 
Sec. 1-168. - License. 
(a)  Every person engaged in the business of owning or placing on location for the purpose of operation any slot amusement machine shall file an application for a license with the officer collecting the tax on forms furnished by said officer for that purpose. The application shall contain such information as may be required and shall be accompanied by a remittance for the amount of tax and any penalty required. 
(b)  The tax levied shall be due and payable annually on January 1, and all licenses issued under the provisions of this division shall expire annually on December 31. A license may be renewed and stickers affixed to the machine without penalty during the month of January. The amount of the license tax to be paid for a period of less than twelve (12) months shall be that proportionate to the annual license tax that the number of months or fractional part thereof, remaining until January 1 next bears to twelve (12) months. 
(c)  The officer collecting the tax shall issue a license or sticker on a form to be prescribed by that officer. Such license or stickers shall be securely affixed or attached to the machine to which it applies in such a manner as to be readily visible and shall be affixed before the machine is operated or played. The absence of a proper license or sticker affixed to a machine shall be prima facie evidence of failure to pay the tax levied for operation of the machine. 
(d)  The license shall entitle the owner or the person placing the machine on the location for the purpose of operation to operate a machine of the type specified until December 31 next. 
(e)  When ownership of a machine upon which a valid license or sticker is attached is transferred to another person, no additional tax shall be required. If the machine is moved to a location in the city from a county or municipality within the State of Mississippi in which the machine has been properly licensed, then no additional license or tax shall be required or due until the expiration of the current license. In no case may a license be transferred from one machine to another machine. 
(f)  No refund shall be allowed for failure or inability to exercise the privilege granted after the license has been issued. 
(Ord. No. 2007, 12-20-94) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 27-27-7. 
Sec. 1-169. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person engaged in the business of owning or placing on location for the purpose of operation, any slot amusement machine without the payment of the tax imposed herein, shall be liable for the amount of tax and fifty (50) percent of the amount of the tax as penalty. 
(b)  Any person who has paid the tax for the operation of a machine, but who has failed to affix the license or sticker to the machine shall also be liable for fifty (50) percent of the amount of tax as penalty. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place on location any machine in the city without paying the tax herein levied. 
(Ord. No. 2007, 12-20-94) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 27-27-9. 
Sec. 1-170. - Exemptions. 
    This division shall not apply to any machine operated for legal gaming purposes at a gaming establishment licensed by the Mississippi Gaming Commission, to bingo or pull-tab machines which are located on the premises of charitable bingo licensees, to any machine kept at a regular place of business of distributors or manufacturers for sale or lease without being operated, to any pool table operated in any place of business commonly known as a pool hall or billiard parlor when the gross income from the operation of such pool table is taxable under the Mississippi Sales Tax Law, or to any antique coin machine as defined in § 27-27-12, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, and amendments thereunto. 
(Ord. No. 2007, 12-20-94) 
State Law reference- Exemptions, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 27-27-11. 
Sec. 1-171. - Seizure; penalty for interference with officer; custody. 
(a)  The officer collecting the tax or any agent appointed by said officer shall have full and complete authority, without an order from any court, to take possession of any slot amusement machine, and keep, seal or otherwise prevent the operation of such machine for failure to pay the license tax and any penalty, or for operation of such machine without a proper license or sticker affixed thereto. 
(b)  When such machine shall have been seized or possession taken to prevent further unlawful use thereof, the same shall remain under the exclusive jurisdiction of such officer or agent seizing same until released by said officer or agent upon payment of the proper tax, penalty and costs, or until same is disposed of under a writ of venditioni exponas issued by the proper court for the collection of the taxes due, together with penalties and costs. 
(c)  Any operation of any machine after seizure of same, or any disturbance of possession or notice of seizure posted by an agent or officer, shall be unlawful, and any person violating this provision shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof, may be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned in the county jail for not more than six (6) months, or may be fined and imprisoned in the discretion of the court within the limitations aforesaid. 
(Ord. No. 2007, 12-20-94) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 27-27-15. 
Sec. 1-172. - Administration. 
(a)  The administration of this division is vested in and shall be exercised by the officer collecting the tax who may act through his or her duly appointed and qualified deputies or agents, who shall serve under said officer and perform such duties as may be required. 
(b)  The officer collecting the tax may promulgate such regulations, not inconsistent with this division, as (s)he may deem necessary to enforce its provisions. The officer collecting the tax shall keep full and accurate records of all monies received by such officer and shall preserve all applications for slot amusement machine licenses and copies of licenses issued therefrom for a period of three (3) years. Said applications and copies of the licenses shall be open to inspection by the public. 
(Ord. No. 2007, 12-20-94) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 27-27-19. 
Sec. 1-173. - Payment into the general fund. 
(a)  All taxes levied and penalties imposed by this division and required to be paid shall be payable in cash or by personal check, cashier's check, money order, or bank exchange which shall be deposited in the general fund of the city on the same day in which they are collected. No remittances other than cash shall be final discharge of liability for the tax and penalty imposed. 
(b)  The taxes and penalties collected shall be paid into the general fund of the city in the same manner as other taxes collected by the officer collecting the tax. 
(Ord. No. 2007, 12-20-94) 
Secs. 1-174-1-184. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - TAX INCENTIVE PROGRAM FOR CENTRAL BUSINESS AND HISTORIC DISTRICT PRESERVATION AND REVITALIZATION 

Sec. 1-185. - Purpose and goals of tax exemption program. 
    The purpose of the ad valorem tax exemption program is for the promotion of business, commerce or industry and/or for the promotion of historic preservation in the designated district. Some downtown development goals of the program are as follows: 
 Promote rehabilitation and preservation of historic buildings; 
 Enhance the aesthetic appeal of downtown buildings and common properties; 
 Increase downtown employment; 
 Attract quality retail businesses, restaurants, hotels, entertainment, and cultural activities; 
 Develop high-quality office space that will increase business and professional use; 
 Develop attractive and highly functional residential units that attract permanent residents; 
 Accommodate safe and friendly vehicular access, parking, and pedestrian movement in an appropriate urban context. 
(Ord. No. 2580, Art. I(§ 1.1), 3-18-08) 
Sec. 1-186. - Establishment of "central business and historic preservation district" for tax incentives. 
(1)  The district established under the former tax exemption plan (Ord. No. 2122) was derived to include and preserve the heritage of the historic Gulfport downtown business district and surrounding historic preservation area, which includes, but is not limited to, "The Harbor Square Historic District" as listed in the National Register of Historic Places. For purposes of this division, it is found that with minor changes, the district included in the former tax exemption plan with any additions or deletions thereto that may be officially made from time to time by the governing authority should be identified as the official district for this program. 
(2)  The district boundaries for purposes of this tax incentive ordinance are identified, as follows: 
Begin at the intersection of Beach Boulevard (U.S. Highway 90) and 15 th Street and including all parcels fronting on 15 th Street running West to 20 th Avenue, then run North along the center line of 20 th Avenue to the South margin of CSX Railroad right of way; then run westerly along CSX Railroad Right of Way to the west line of alley between 22 nd Avenue and 23 rd Avenue, then run north along the west line of alley to the center line of 19 th Street, then run west along the center line of 19 th Street to the east line of Kansas City Southern Railroad (KCS) Right of Way, then run south along the east line of KCS Right of Way to the intersection of the KCS Right of Way and the south line of CSX Railroad Right of Way, then run west along the south line of CSX Right of way to the center line of 31 st Avenue; then run south along the center line of 31 st Avenue to the intersection with the north line of 11 th Street, then run east along the north line of 11 th Street to the east line of alley between 31 st Avenue and 30 th Avenue then run north along the East line of Alley to the center line of 13 th Street; then run east along the center line of 13 th Street to the intersection with the east line of the extension of KCS Right of Way; then run southerly along the east line of the extension with KCS Right of way to its intersection with the center line of Beach Boulevard (U.S. Highway 90); then run east along the center line of Beach Boulevard (U.S. Highway 90) to the intersection of center line of Beach Boulevard (U.S. Highway 90) and center line of 15 th Street at the place of beginning. The District lies within the boundaries hereinabove defined. It includes the property of former location of "The Chimneys" restaurant at the east extremity of the District and includes properties on both sides of street and avenues named above, but only on the interior side of the district where bounded by alleys or railroad right of ways. 
(Ord. No. 2580, Art. II(§§ 2.1, 2.2), 3-18-08) 
Sec. 1-187. - Tax exemptions qualifying for the program. 
(1)  Authority. Only applications for municipal ad valorem tax exemptions within the above identified district authorized by MCA 1972 § 17-21-5, (1996 Supp.) qualifying according to the terms of this division shall be considered by the city council for approval under this division. The governing authority ("city council and mayor") shall have sole discretion to approve each and every qualifying and conforming application for tax exemption, but shall not withhold approval without cause. [Examples of cause to withhold would be for submittal of an incomplete, nonqualifying, or untimely application, failure to perform construction according to city regulations, guidelines or historical or architectural regulations or guidelines in effect, etc.] 
(2)  General criteria for tax exemptions. Tax exemptions shall not apply for school district taxes, and under this division are applicable for ad valorem taxes assessed for the city on the increased assessed value of a structure located in the district, renovated or improved, or new structure eligible under this division, and calculated as hereinafter provided. Failure to comply with any existing requirements for preservation of historical buildings, structures or sites, or any architectural standards regulated by the city, or any municipal zoning or subdivision ordinances in effect shall disqualify the application. 
(3)  Calculation of the increase in assessed value. The increase in assessed value qualifying for tax exemption shall be calculated by taking the assessed value of the improvements (if any) on the parcel for the year prior to the renovation, restoration, or new construction being completed and assessed, and subtracting that from the assessed value of the improvements completed and assessed on the parcel for the then current year (after completion and re-assessment). The tax rate applicable to the land, and the assessed value of the land for any individual year shall not be affected by the exemption of the increased value of improvements. No separately assessed personal properties or mobile units shall be included in the increased tax assessment qualifying for exemption under this division. 
(4)  Applicable period of tax increase. 
(a)  Tax exemptions granted by the governing authority under this division shall specify the time period of the exemption, not to exceed a period of seven (7) consecutive years. 
(b)  This division shall automatically expire as repealed on and after December 31, 2012. No applications shall be received for tax exemption for structures not complete and certified by the city as ready for occupancy and full service after December 31, 2012. 
(5)  Effective date. This division shall be in full force and effect upon its official passage and enactment according to law. 
(Ord. No. 2580, Art. II(§§ 3.1-3.5), 3-18-08) 
Sec. 1-188. - Eligible projects and application requirements. 
(1)  Eligible building projects. 
(a)  To be eligible for the program, renovations and improvements to existing buildings or construction of new buildings shall be within the geographic boundaries of the district described above. 
(b)  Buildings to be restored and renovated, if more than sixty (60) years old, of architecture typical of historic buildings in Gulfport, plans or certifications should be presented for review to establish that the building is being restored to resemble its original exterior design and architecture unless justifiable reason for changes in appearance from the original is given. For new building structures or renovation of buildings less than sixty (60) years old, to the extent feasible, the building exteriors should comply with city architectural standards in effect and should be built or restored to be in harmony with downtown historical or typical buildings and with the smart code plan then in effect. 
(2)  Investment value required. 
(a)  To be eligible for tax exemption under the program, the improvements to the structure, not to include personal furnishings or personal property shall exceed fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) in increased assessment of improvements. 
(b)  For a new structure to be eligible for tax exemption under the program, the new improvements, not to include personal furnishing or personal property, shall exceed one hundred fifty thousand dollars ($150,000.00) in increased assessment for improvements. 
(3)  Government codes and regulations. For structures to be approved for tax exemption under this program they shall be in compliance with all applicable building and zoning codes, and any and all applicable federal, state or local environmental or use regulations. 
(4)  Applications. 
(a)  After enactment application forms may be obtained from, and completed forms submitted to, the Department of Economic Development, City of Gulfport, or such other office of the city as may be hereafter designated by the mayor. 
(b)  Applications for tax exemptions under this program shall be submitted for process and city council approval no earlier than sixty (60) days prior to application of a building permit, and no later than sixty (60) days after completion of the building project. 
(c)  The governing authority may order such other uniform application or approval requirements as it deems proper from time to time to determine eligibility for the tax exemption to meet the purposes, goals and intentions of this division. 
(5)  Severability. If any provision or clause of this division is determined to be legally unenforceable, and if the division can be properly amended by removal of the unenforceable part, it shall be severed from the ordinance and the remaining provisions shall continue in full force and effect. 
(6)  Conflicting ordinances. Any ordinance or provision related to the district or any part of the district herein provided for in conflict with this division is hereby repealed and this division shall control. 
(Ord. No. 2580, Art. IV(§§ 4.1-4-6), 3-18-08) 
Secs. 1-189-1-191. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - TAX INCENTIVE PROGRAM FOR URBAN RENEWAL DISTRICT TO PROMOTE REDEVELOPMENT AND REVITALIZATION 

Sec. 1-192. - Purpose and goals of the tax exemption program. 
    The purpose of the ad valorem tax exemption program is to promote business, commerce, and new residences in the designated districts. The goals of the tax exemption program are: to facilitate the reconstruction and redevelopment of areas of the city that were affected directly or indirectly by Hurricane Katrina; to help increase quality retail businesses, restaurants, other businesses, and residences that increase the local tax base and/or create jobs within the city; and to create synergy of related development that is essential to the success of neighboring businesses. 
(Ord. No. 2702, § 3(art. I, § 1.1), 10-5-10) 
Sec. 1-193. - Establishment of redevelopment district boundaries. 
    For the limited purpose of promoting business, commerce or industry, as contemplated in Miss. Code Ann. § 17-21-5(2), as amended, this program shall apply in the area North of U.S. Highway 90, South of the CSX Railroad, and from the Eastern boundary of the properly currently identified as Centennial Plaza, to the Western edge of Venetian Gardens (as identified in Exhibit "B") in Gulfport Mississippi (hereinafter "Mississippi City Map", and shall be designated as a "Redevelopment District" in the City of Gulfport. 
(Ord. No. 2702, § 3(art. II, § 2.1), 10-5-10; Ord. No. 2791 , § 2, 5-6-14) 
Sec. 1-194. - Tax exemptions qualifying for the program. 
(a)  Authority. Only applications for municipal ad valorem tax exemptions within the above identified district authorized by MCA § 17-5-21, as amended, qualifying according to the terms of this division shall be considered by the city council for approval. The governing authority shall have sole discretion to approve each and every qualifying and conforming application for tax exemption, but shall not withhold approval without cause. [Examples of cause to withhold would be for submittal of an incomplete, nonqualifying, or untimely application; failure to perform construction according to city regulations, guidelines or historical or architectural regulations or guidelines in effect; failure of a structure to comply with the stated and intended goals, etc.] 
(b)  General criteria for tax exemptions. Tax exemptions shall not apply for school district taxes, and under this division are applicable for ad valorem taxes assessed for the city on the increased assessed value of a structure located in the district, renovated or improved, or new structure eligible under this division, and calculated as hereinafter provided. Failure to comply with any existing requirements for preservation of historical buildings, structures or sites, or any architectural standards regulated by the city, or any municipal zoning or subdivision ordinances in effect shall disqualify the application. 
(c)  Calculation of increased value. The increase in assessed value qualifying for tax exemption shall be calculated by taking the assessed value of the improvements (if any) on the parcel for the year prior to the renovations, restoration, or new construction being completed and assessed, and subtracting that from the assessed value of the improvements completed and assessed on the parcel for the then-current year (after completion and reassessment). The tax rate applicable to the land and the assessed value of the land for any individual year shall not be affected by the exemption of the increased value of improvements. No separately assessed personal properties or mobile units shall be included in the increased tax assessment qualifying for exemption under this division. 
(d)  Investment value required. Only new or renovated structures over fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) in aggregate improvements, not including personal furnishings or personal property, found to be aiding and implementing the promotion of business or commerce in the designated redevelopment district may qualify for an exemption under this division. 
(e)  Calculation of the abatement. Structures will be eligible based upon amounts approved by the governing authority for the city ad valorem exemption only up to percentages listed below: 
(1)  Structures only for commercial businesses. Up to ninety (90) percent; 
(2)  Structures only for retail businesses. Up to one hundred (100) percent; 
(3)  Structures only for residential use. Up to seventy (70) percent; 
(4)  Structures for mixed use. Figured on bottom floor use as a percentage of the bottom floor. For instance if sixty (60) percent of the bottom floor is used as retail and the balance is used as residential, then sixty (60) percent (percentage of the type used) × one hundred (100) percent (exemption for type) = sixty (60) percent of the total improvement plus forty (40) percent percentage of the type used) × seventy (70) percent (exemption for type) = twenty-eight (28) percent of the total improvement for a total of a potential eighty-eight (88) percent exemption. 
(f)  Limitations on exemptions. No exemption shall be granted except upon written application to the Gulfport Redevelopment Commission and then upon their written recommendation for such exemption to the governing authority that the construction, renovation, or improvement of the subject property meets the requirements set forth in this division. The governing authority of the city shall have the sole and final authority to determine the status of any exemption and to define the amount, if any, of the exemption. The decision of the governing authority shall be final in this matter and no appeal by the applicant will be allowed. 
(g)  Fees for application. Applications shall first be submitted to the Gulfport Redevelopment Commission for review. Payment of not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) may be charged by said commission to the property owner to cover the direct expenses incurred by the agency in review of the application. 
(Ord. No. 2702, § 3(art. III, §§ 3.1-3.7), 10-5-10; Ord. No. 2765 , § 2, 11-6-12) 
Sec. 1-195. - Terms of tax exemption. 
(a)  Term of exemption. 
(1)  Tax exemptions granted by the governing authority under this division shall specify the time period of the exemption, not to exceed a period of seven (7) consecutive years. 
(2)  This division shall automatically expire as repealed on and after ________________. No applications shall be received for tax exemption for structures not completed and certified by the city as ready for occupancy and full service after January 1, 2016. 
(b)  Qualification. To qualify for this exemption an applicant must have obtained a building permit after January 1, 2008, and must receive or have received a certificate of occupancy within two (2) years of pulling a building permit. All applicants are required to file their application for exemption within one (1) year of the date of completion of the proposed improvements or renovations, or, for properties completed and occupied prior to the passage of this division within twelve (12) months of the passing of this division. 
(c)  Restriction. Tax exemptions for improvements made prior to January 1, 2010, shall be granted only for properties where any existing improvements, if existed, were totally destroyed, removed, and the land had no structure on it at the time the building permit was pulled. For purposes of defining a structure, a concrete foundation or slab without framing members or walls will not be considered a structure for purposes of this section. 
(d)  Government codes and regulations. For structures to be approved for tax exemption under this program, they shall be in compliance with all applicable building and zoning codes, and any and all applicable federal, state or local environmental or use regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2702, § 3(art. IV, §§ 4.1-4.4), 10-5-10) 
Sec. 1-196. - Taxes included in exemption. 
    Exemptions granted pursuant to this division shall be from the municipal ad valorem taxes designated in MCA § 17-21-5(2), as amended, which specifically prohibits exemption from ad valorem taxes for school purposes. Exemptions may not be granted for taxes previously pledged pursuant to any tax increment finance plan and associated TIF bonds. 
(Ord. No. 2702, § 3(art. V, § 5.1), 10-5-10) 
Sec. 1-197. - Reservation of authority to suspend or terminate the economic incentive plan. 
(a)  The city hereby reserves the right to suspend or terminate this economic development program at any time with or without cause. 
(b)  Suspension or termination of this economic development program shall not invalidate or revoke exemptions previously granted, which will survive the suspension or termination of the program and shall continue for the remainder of their designated terms. However, no new ad valorem tax exemptions shall be granted during any such period of suspension or after termination regardless of the project or the fact that without suspension or termination the applicant would have been granted the exemption. 
(c)  This division shall not be construed as a guarantee of an exemption or the grant to any person or entity of a property right in an exemption. The city reserves the right to revoke the remainder of any terms of an exemption upon a proper showing that the applicant did not meet or no longer meets the eligibility requirements under this program. 
(Ord. No. 2702, § 3(art. VI, §§ 6.1-6.3), 10-5-10) 
DIVISION 6. - TAX INCENTIVE PROGRAM FOR DOWNTOWN REDEVELOPMENT DISTRICT TO PROMOTE COMMERCIAL AND RESIDENTIAL REDEVELOPMENT AND REVITALIZATION[6] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 1-198. - Purpose and goals of the tax exemption program. 
    The purpose of the ad valorem tax exemption program is to promote business, commerce, and new residences in the designated district. The goals of the tax exemption program are: to facilitate the reconstruction and redevelopment of areas of the City of Gulfport that were affected directly or indirectly by Hurricane Katrina and continue to be affected by the current economic climate and high cost of insurance; to help increase quality retail businesses, restaurants, other businesses, and residences that increase the local tax base and / or create jobs within the city; and to create synergy of related development that is essential to the success of neighboring businesses. 
(Ord. No. 2804 , § 2(art. I), 12-2-14) 
Sec. 1-198.1. - Establishment of redevelopment district boundaries. 
    For the limited purpose of promoting business, commerce or industry, as contemplated in Miss. Code Ann. § 17-21-5(2), as amended, this program shall apply in the area designed as a redevelopment district in the City of Gulfport, which boundaries are incorporated herein and attached hereto as Exhibit "A". 
(Ord. No. 2804 , § 2(art. II), 12-2-14) 
Sec. 1-198.2. - Tax exemptions qualifying for the program. 
(a)  Authority: Only applications for municipal ad valorem tax exemptions within the above identified district authorized by Miss. Code Ann. § 17-5-21, as amended, qualifying according to the terms of this division shall be considered by the city council for approval. The governing authority shall have sole discretion to approve each and every qualifying and conforming application for tax exemption, but shall not withhold approval without cause. [Examples of cause to withhold would be for submittal of an incomplete, non-qualifying, or untimely application, failure to perform construction according to city regulations, guidelines or historical or architectural regulations or guidelines in effect, failure of a structure to comply with the stated and intended goals, etc.] 
(b)  General criteria for tax exemptions: Tax exemptions shall not apply for school district taxes, and are applicable for ad valorem taxes assessed for the City of Gulfport on the increased assessed value of a structure located in the district, renovated or improved, or new structure eligible under this division, and shall be calculated as hereinafter provided. Failure to comply with any existing requirements for preservation of historical buildings, structures or sites, or any architectural standards regulated by the City of Gulfport, or any municipal zoning or subdivision divisions in effect shall disqualify the application. 
(c)  Calculation of increased value. The increase in assessed value qualifying for tax exemption shall be calculated by taking the assessed value of the improvements (if any) on the parcel for the year prior to the renovations, restoration, or new construction being completed and assessed, and subtracting that from the assessed value of the improvements completed and assessed on the parcel for the then current year (after completion and re-assessment). The tax rate applicable to the land and the assessed value of the land for any individual year shall not be affected by the exemption of the increased value of improvements. No separately assessed personal properties or mobile units shall be included in the increased tax assessment qualifying for exemption under this Division. 
(d)  Investment value required . 
    Subject to approval by the governing authority for the city, structures will be eligible for abatement of ad valorem taxes based on the following criteria: 
Property Minimum Amount Expended (excluding the price of the land) Abatement 
Period New Commercial or Residential Development 1 $2,000,000 Seven (7) Years Renovated Structure $250,000 Seven (7) Years  
(e)  Limitations on Exemptions. No exemption shall be granted except upon written application to the City of Gulfport Director of Economic Development, or authorized designee, and then upon his written recommendation for such exemption to the governing authority that the construction, renovation, or improvement of the subject property meets the requirements set forth in this division. The Governing Authority of the City of Gulfport shall have the sole and final authority to determine the status of any exemption and to define the amount, if any, and period of the exemption. The decision of the governing authority shall be final in this matter and no appeal by the applicant will be allowed. 
(f)  Fees for application. Applications shall first be submitted to the City of Gulfport Director of Economic Development for review. Payment of not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) may be charged by the City of Gulfport to the property owner to cover the direct expenses incurred by the agency in review and processing of the application. 
(Ord. No. 2804 , § 2(art. III), 12-2-14) 
Sec. 1-198.3. - Terms of tax exemption. 
(a)  Term of exemption. (1) Tax exemptions granted by the governing authority under this division shall specify the time period of the exemption, not to exceed a period of seven (7) consecutive years. In the discretion of the governing authority, and based on the recommendation of the director of economic development as herein provided, the period of abatement may be less than the seven years allowed by law. (2) This division shall automatically expire as repealed on and after December 31, 2021. No applications shall be received for tax exemption for structures not completed and certified by the city as ready for occupancy and full service by December 31, 2021. 
(b)  Qualification. All applicants are required to file their application for exemption within sixty (60) days of the date of completion of the proposed improvements or renovations. 
(c)  Government codes and regulations. For structures to be approved for tax exemption under this program, they shall be in compliance with all applicable building and zoning codes, and any and all applicable federal, state or local environmental or use regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2804 , § 2(art. IV), 12-2-14) 
Sec. 1-198.4. - Taxes included in exemption. 
    Exemptions granted pursuant to this division shall be from the municipal ad valorem taxes designated in Miss. Code Ann. § 17-21-5(2), as amended, which specifically prohibits exemption from ad valorem taxes for school purposes. Exemptions may not be granted for taxes previously pledged pursuant to any tax increment finance plan and associated TIF bonds. 
(Ord. No. 2804 , § 2(art. V), 12-2-14) 
Sec. 1-198.5. - Reservation of authority to suspend or terminate the economic incentive plan. 
(a)  The City of Gulfport hereby reserves the right to suspend or terminate this economic development program at any time with or without cause. 
(b)  Suspension or termination of this economic development program shall not invalidate or revoke exemptions previously granted, which will survive the suspension or termination of the program and shall continue for the remainder of their designated terms. However, no new ad valorem tax exemptions shall be granted during any such period of suspension or after termination regardless of the project or the fact that without suspension or termination the applicant would have been granted the exemption. 
(c)  This division shall not be construed as a guarantee of an exemption or the grant to any person or entity of a property right in an exemption. The city reserves the right to revoke the remainder of any terms of an exemption upon a proper showing that the applicant did not meet or no longer meets the eligibility requirements under this program. 
(Ord. No. 2804 , § 2(art. VI), 12-2-14) 
DIVISION 7. - TAX INCENTIVE PROGRAM FOR REDEVELOPMENT DISTRICT TO PROMOTE COMMERCIAL AND RESIDENTIAL REDEVELOPMENT AND REVITALIZATION[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 2805, adopted Dec. 2, 2014 added provisions to the Code, but did not specify manner of inclusion. Therefore, at the discretion of the editor, said provisions have been included as §§ 1-199-1-199.5. 

Sec. 1-199. - Purpose and goals of the tax exemption program. 
    The Purpose of the ad valorem tax exemption program is to promote business, commerce, and new residences in the designated district. The goals of the tax exemption program are: to facilitate the reconstruction and redevelopment of areas of the City of Gulfport that were affected directly or indirectly by Hurricane Katrina; to help increase quality retail businesses, restaurants, other businesses, and residences that increase the local tax base and/or create jobs within the city; and to create synergy of related development that is essential to the success of neighboring businesses. 
(Ord. No. 2805 , § 2(art. I), 12-2-14) 
Sec. 199.1. - Establishment of redevelopment district boundaries. 
    For the limited purpose of promoting business, commerce or industry, as contemplated in Miss. Code Ann. § 17-21-5(2), as amended, this program shall apply in the area designated as a "Redevelopment District" containing properties South of the CSX Railroad track, from the western city boundary to the eastern city boundary, in Gulfport, Mississippi. The district shall exclude the downtown district and the property identified as Centennial Plaza. A map of the redevelopment district is incorporated herein and attached hereto as Exhibit "A". 
(Ord. No. 2805 , § 2(art. II), 12-2-14) 
Sec. 1-199.2. - Tax exemptions qualifying for the program. 
(a)  Authority: Only applications submitted by eligible applicants for municipal ad valorem tax exemptions within the above identified district authorized by Miss. Code Ann. Section 17-5-21, as amended, qualifying according to the terms of this division shall be considered by the city council for approval. For purposes of this division, an eligible applicant (hereinafter referred to as "applicant") shall be the person or entity owning the subject real property at the time of 1) issuance of the certificate of occupancy and 2) application for exemption. The governing authority shall have sole discretion to approve each and every qualifying and conforming application for tax exemption, but shall not withhold approval without cause. [Examples of cause to withhold would be for submittal of an incomplete, non-qualifying, or untimely application, failure to perform construction according to city regulations, guidelines or historical or architectural regulation or guidelines in effect, failure of a structure to comply with the state and intended goals, etc.] 
(b)  General criteria for tax exemptions: Tax exemptions shall not apply for school district taxes, and under this division are applicable for ad valorem taxes assessed for the City of Gulfport on the increased assessed value of a structure located in the district, renovated or improved, or new structure eligible under this division, and calculated as hereinafter provided. Failure to comply with any existing requirements for preservation of historical buildings, structures or sites, or any architectural standards regulated by the City of Gulfport, or any municipal zoning or subdivision ordinances in effect shall disqualify the application. 
(c)  Calculation of Increased Value. The increase in assessed value qualifying for tax exemption shall be calculated by taking the assessed value of the improvements (if any) on the parcel for the year prior to the renovations, restoration, or new construction being completed and assessed, and subtracting that from the assessed value of the improvements completed and assessed on the parcel for the then current year (after completion and re-assessment). The tax rate applicable to the land and the assessed value of the land for any individual year shall not be affected by the exemption of the increased value of improvements. No separately assessed personal properties or mobile units shall be included in the increased tax assessment qualifying for exemption under this division. 
(d)  Investment Value Required. 
    For the purpose of determining qualification under this division, investments shall be calculated based on aggregate improvements and shall not include personal furnishings or personal property. Subject to approval by the governing authority for the city, structures may be eligible for abatement of ad valorem taxes based on the following criteria: 
Property Minimum Amount Expended (excluding the price of the land) Abatement 
Period Residential Lots Fronting Highway 90 $400,000 Seven (7) Years Residential Lots that do not front Highway 90 $100,000 Seven (7) Years Multifamily Development $3,000,000 Seven (7) Years Commercial Development $1,000,000 Seven (7) Years  
(e)  Limitations on exemptions. No exemption shall be granted except upon written application to the City of Gulfport Director of Economic Development, or authorized designee, and then upon his written recommendation for such exemption to the governing authority that the construction, renovation, or improvement of the subject property meets the requirements set forth in this division. The Governing Authority of the City of Gulfport shall have the sole and final authority to determine the status of any exemption and to define the amount, if any, and period of the exemption. The decision of the governing authority shall be final in this matter and no appeal by the applicant will be allowed. 
(f)  Fees for application. Applications shall first be submitted to the City of Gulfport Director of Economic Development for review. Payment of not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) may be charged by the City of Gulfport to the property owner to cover the direct expenses incurred by the agency in review and processing of the application. 
(Ord. No. 2805 , § 2(art. III), 12-2-14; Ord. No. 2945, § 3, 6-5-18 ) 
Sec. 1-199.3. - Terms of tax exemption. 
(a)  Term of exemption. (1) Tax exemptions granted by the governing authority under this division shall specify the time period of the exemption, not to exceed a period of seven (7) consecutive years. In the discretion of the governing authority, and based on the recommendation of the director of economic development, the period of abatement may be less than the seven years allowed by law. (2) This division shall automatically expire as repealed on and after December 31, 2021. No applications shall be received for tax exemption for structures not completed and certified by the city as ready for occupancy and full service by December 31, 2021. 
(b)  Qualification . Applications for abatement shall be filed within the six (6) months following the completion of the proposed improvements or renovations. For purposes of this ordinance, the completion date of the improvements or renovations shall be the date that the improvements or renovations pass final inspection by the city's department of urban development. 
(c)  Government codes and regulations. For structures to be approved for tax exemption under this program, they shall be in compliance with all applicable building and zoning codes, and any and all applicable federal, state or local environmental or use regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2805 , § 2(art. IV), 12-2-14; Ord. No. 2893, § 3, 3-21-17 ) 
Sec. 1-199.4. - Taxes included in exemption. 
    Exemptions granted pursuant to this division shall be from the municipal ad valorem taxes designated in Miss. Code Ann. § 17-21-5(2), as amended, which specifically prohibits exemption from ad valorem taxes for school purposes. Exemptions may not be granted for taxes previously pledged pursuant to any TAX INCREMENT FINANCE PLAN AND ASSOCIATED TIF BONDS. 
(Ord. No. 2805 , § 2(art. V), 12-2-14) 
Sec. 1-199.5. - Reservation of authority to suspend or terminate the economic incentive plan. 
(a)  The City of Gulfport hereby reserves the right to suspend or terminate this economic development program at any time with or without cause. 
(b)  Suspension or termination of this economic development program shall not invalidate or revoke exemptions previously granted, which will survive the suspension or termination of the program and shall continue for the remainder of their designated terms. However, no new ad valorem tax exemptions shall be granted during any such period of suspension or after termination regardless of the project or the fact that without suspension or termination the applicant would have been granted the exemption. 
(c)  This division shall not be construed as a guarantee of an exemption or the grant to any person or entity of a property right in an exemption. The city reserves the right to revoke the remainder of any terms of an exemption upon a proper showing that the applicant did not meet or no longer meets the eligibility requirements under this program. 
(Ord. No. 2805 , § 2(art. VI), 12-2-14) 
ARTICLE V. - PUBLIC RECORDS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2592, §§ 1-10, adopted July 8, 2008, amended Art. V in its entirety and enacted similar provisions as set out herein. The former Art. V derived from Ord. No. 2432, §§ 1-8, adopted June 8, 2005. 

Sec. 1-200. - Mississippi Public Records Act adopted. 
    The Mississippi Public Records Act of 1983, as amended, is hereby incorporated herein by reference, and each and every definition, term and condition set forth therein is adopted for the use of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2592, § 1, 7-8-08; Ord. No. 2684, § 2, 6-22-10) 
Sec. 1-201. - Request for records. 
    Any person requesting a public record held or controlled by the city shall do so in writing on the approved form provided by the city. Any such request shall be clear and concise as to the documents requested and shall include only one subject matter per form. The city clerk shall see that each request bears the date of its receipt in a prominent place on its face. The request date, for purposes of compliance, shall be the date of receipt as stamped received by the city clerk or his/her designee. 
(Ord. No. 2592, § 2, 7-8-08) 
Sec. 1-202. - Request forms. 
    The city shall receive requests for information, on the approved form provided by the city, to the city clerk at the address shown: 
In person 1410 24th Avenue Gulfport, MS 39501 By mail: City Clerk, P.O. Box 1780 Gulfport, MS 39502 By fax: (228) 214-2244 By Email: cityclerk@gulfport-ms.gov  
    Requests may also be received in all city departments and forwarded to the city clerk for approval. As noted in section 1-201, the date of receipt by the city clerk is the official request date. Requests made in person shall be during business hours (8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.) on regular working days (Monday through Friday except legal holidays). 
(Ord. No. 2592, § 3, 7-8-08; Ord. No. 2684, § 3, 6-22-10) 
Sec. 1-203. - Approval or denial of request. 
    It shall be the duty of the city clerk or his/her designee to evaluate and approve or deny all requests for information. This matter may be assigned to the legal department for evaluation and an opinion as to whether the information requested is a public record or exempt from the Public Records Act under Mississippi or federal law. 
(Ord. No. 2592, § 4, 7-8-08) 
Sec. 1-204. - Production of records. 
    If the information is approved, the city clerk or his/her designee shall cause the public records to be reproduced by the department that created the requested documents. That department shall provide the requested information in timely manner to ensure that the documents are submitted to the requestor within seven (7) working days of official request date. 
    If the city is unable to produce the requested record by the seventh working day after the request is made, the city clerk or his/her designee or representative shall provide a written explanation to the person making the request why the record cannot be produced during the seven-day period. In no case, unless agreed upon by the parties, shall any approved record be released more than fourteen (14) working days from the receipt of the request by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2592, § 5, 7-8-08; Ord. No. 2684, § 4, 6-22-10) 
Sec. 1-205. - Payment of cost. 
    A fee based on an established fee schedule will be assessed for the total cost of compliance with the request. The city shall collect all fees from the person requesting the records prior to providing the requested documents. Any such charges paid by a person requesting public records or public information shall be reasonably calculated to reimburse the city for the actual cost of providing the records. 
(Ord. No. 2592, § 6, 7-8-08) 
Sec. 1-206. - Denial of request. 
    If the request is denied, a detailed written explanation of the reason(s) for denial must be sent to the requestor within seven (7) working days of the official request date. 
(Ord. No. 2592, § 7, 7-8-08; Ord. No. 2684, § 5, 6-22-10) 
Sec. 1-207. - Maintenance of files. 
    The city clerk shall maintain a file of all written denials of requests for public records. All records kept and maintained concerning denials of requests for access to records are to be preserved for a period of three (3) years from the date of the denial of such request. 
(Ord. No. 2592, § 8, 7-8-08) 
Sec. 1-208. - Monthly report. 
    The city clerk shall deliver to the governing authority a monthly report of all actions taken for the previous month including date, name of requestors and information requested. Such report shall be recorded in the minutes of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2592, § 9, 7-8-08) 
Sec. 1-209. - Payment, pickup. 
    Should payment for and/or pickup of requested records not be made within forty-five (45) days of notification of cost and/or availability for pickup, a new public records request will be required to request those records. 
(Ord. No. 2592, § 10, 7-8-08) 
Sec. 1-210. - Public inspection. 
    A copy of any ordinance governing the release of public records shall be made available for public inspection upon request at the office of the city council or city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2592, § 10, 7-8-08; Ord. No. 2684, § 6, 6-22-10) 
Secs. 1-211-1-224. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - MUNICIPAL COURT 

Sec. 1-225. - Short title. 
    This article may be known and cited as the Gulfport Municipal Court Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 1918, § 1, 2-26-93) 
Sec. 1-226. - Ratification of established municipal court system. 
(a)  Statutory authority. The municipal court system of the city was established and does operate according to the laws of the state requiring the establishment of a municipal court in all municipalities of the state (MCA 1972, § 21-23-1 et seq., as amended). 
(b)  Confirmation and application of state law. This article confirms the established municipal court system in the city and provides that the municipal court and its officers shall operate and manage the court according to said state law, and any provision of this article declared invalid or in conflict with any state law shall not due to its invalidity affect the validity of any other provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1918, § 2, 2-26-93) 
Sec. 1-227. - Purpose and intent. 
    This article shall codify the established municipal court system for the city and shall enable the Municipal Court of Gulfport to adapt to a more efficient system with more full-time personnel for the municipal court, and shall provide for an enlargement and separation of duties, responsibilities and powers. 
(Ord. No. 1918, § 3, 2-26-93) 
Sec. 1-228. - Municipal judges. 
(a)  Appointments. A municipal judge with full-time employee status shall be appointed by the governing authority and be subject to removal from office in the manner provided for directors or department heads of the municipality. Additional full-time judges may be appointed if required by the business of the municipal court. If more than one (1) full-time judge is appointed, each judge shall have the same functions, duties, powers and responsibilities, except that only one (1) judge shall be designated by the governing authority as chief judge of the court. 
(b)  Assistant or pro-tempore judges. In addition to one (1) or more full-time judges, the governing authority as provided by law shall appoint such additional judge or judges to serve as assistant or pro-tempore judge as may be required by the business of the court. The assistant or pro-tempore judge shall hear such cases and handle such business of the court as may be assigned by the chief judge, or as may be required by absence or conflict of interest of the full-time judges. If the caseload or business of the court requires the holding of court or administration of business by the court by the assistant or pro-tempore judge simultaneously with that of the full-time judge or judges, then the assistant or pro-tempore judge shall be deemed to be serving in the place of and with the same power and authority as the chief or other full-time municipal judge. 
(c)  Powers, duties and qualifications of municipal judges. The municipal judges of the city shall be licensed attorneys in the state and shall qualify as other employees to work for the city, and shall be vested with the same powers and perform the duties provided for municipal judges in the state (MCA 1972 § 21-23-7 et seq. as amended, and related laws). 
(d)  Court rules. The chief judge of the court shall have the power to make rules for the administration of the Court's business, to be in writing filed with the clerk of the court, and the rules of court shall be furnished to and followed by all other judges of the municipal court, prosecuting attorneys and other court personnel and officers of the court as may be directed by the judge. 
(Ord. No. 1918, § 4, 2-26-93) 
Sec. 1-229. - Court administrator. 
(a)  Court administrator position established; appointment. The governing authority of the city established the position of court administrator by resolution adopted on April 7, 1992, and this article shall ratify, codify and take precedence over all prior actions of the governing authority pertaining to the position of court administrator and court clerk. The court administrator shall be appointed by the governing authority and be subject to removal from office in the manner provided for directors and department heads of the municipality. 
(b)  Intent and purpose. The purpose and intent of establishing the position of court administrator is to establish a full-time person in the municipal court system of the city to serve as clerk of court and to enlarge upon the duties as clerk to the effect that the court administrator shall manage and coordinate all of the functions of the municipal court as an officer of and subject to the oversight of the municipal court judge and judges. This position is intended to function separate from and in cooperation with the police department, with all of the powers required for the clerk of court and administrator of the court to function effectively. 
(c)  Powers and duties. The court administrator shall also be known as and sign all documents required of the "city clerk" and shall have all powers and responsibilities provided by state law for the clerk of the municipal court (MSA 1972 § 21-23-11 et seq., as amended, and related laws). In addition to the duties as court clerk, the court administrator shall manage and coordinate the functions of the municipal court and court personnel and all other business related to the court as may be assigned by the municipal judge or judges and the mayor. The court administrator shall follow and seek administratively to enforce the written rules of court, and to process and enforce the writs and orders issued by the court. 
(Ord. No. 1918, § 5, 2-26-93) 
Sec. 1-230. - Capias officer of the municipal court. 
(a)  Appointment. The governing authority shall appoint a qualified person upon recommendation by the mayor to serve as capias officer of the municipal court, also known as "warrant officer." 
(b)  Qualification and status. The capias officer must have a working knowledge of the court system and must have had satisfactory training or be qualified by experience and training to act as an officer of the court to perform the duties and responsibilities hereinafter designated. The position requires sufficient knowledge to locate cases on the docket, and be able to testify accurately and knowledgeably under oath. The capias officer shall be a full time employee of the municipal court and shall be commissioned by the mayor, and is not required to be a member of the police department. 
(c)  Duties. The capias officer shall have such responsibilities as may be assigned by the court administrator for collection of fines and as may be assigned by the municipal judges or the court administrator to enforce writs or orders issued; and shall assist in the validation of capias and warrants for contempt of court, in checking the card files, dockets, and work sheets, then making reasonable attempts to serve and return these capias and warrants or writs and to collect the outstanding fines and indebtedness payable to the city. The work of the officer shall include filling out custody reports and confinement of persons in contempt subject to arrangements for payment of said debt or for release, and the officer shall use available means to locate persons, to investigate contempt cases, and to prepare for and testify in contempt of court matters, and to assist in the transport of prisoners. 
(Ord. No. 1918, § 6, 2-26-93) 
Sec. 1-331. - Separation of duties. 
(a)  The capias/warrant officer shall be an officer of the court under the direction of the court administrator and the municipal judges with duties and responsibilities separate and apart from that of the police officer serving as court bailiff, marshal or police officer of the court, and the duties of the capias officer shall not interfere with or take the place of the duties of the police officer of the court except as such officer may be assigned by the court to assist one another; and the duties of the capias officer shall be limited to the business of the court, or such other administrative process duties as the mayor may approve of or assign to the capias officer. 
(b)  The court bailiff shall be a police officer designated by the chief of police, and the court bailiff or chief of police or other police officer designated by the chief of police shall serve as executive officer of the court to perform such duties as may be required by the court in the line of duty according to law (MSA 1972, § 21-23-13, and related laws). The duties and powers of the police officer of the court shall be separate from and not interfere with those of the capias officer, except as such officers may be assigned by the court to assist one another. 
(Ord. No. 1918, § 1, 2-26-93)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
