When any evidence is found indicating the presence of rats or openings through which rats may again enter business buildings the county health department shall give written notice and/or orders to the owners or occupants to abate the conditions found, which conditions shall be abated within ten (10) days after receipt of such notice. 
(Code 1963, § 14-46) 
Sec. 4-89. - Elimination of extensive harborages. 
    Whenever conditions inside or under business buildings provide such extensive harborage for rats that the county health department deems it necessary to eliminate such harborage, it may require the owner to install suitable cement floors in basements or to replace wooden floors or ground floors or require the owner to correct such other interior rat harborage as may be necessary in order to facilitate the eradication of rats in a reasonable time and thereby to reduce the cost thereof. 
(Code 1963, § 14-47) 
Sec. 4-90. - Removing ratproofing, making new openings. 
    It shall be unlawful under the provisions of this article for the occupant, owner, contractor, public utility company, plumber, or any other person to remove the ratproofing from any business building for any purpose and fail to restore the same in a satisfactory condition or to make any new openings that are not closed or sealed against the entrance of rats. 
(Code 1963, § 14-48) 
Sec. 4-91. - Storage of animal feed. 
    All food and feed kept within the city for feeding chickens, cows, pigs, horses, and other animals, shall be kept and stored in rat-free and ratproof containers, compartments, or rooms, unless kept in a ratproof building. 
(Code 1963, § 14-49) 
State Law reference- Mississippi Commercial Feed Law of 1972, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 75-45-151 et seq. 
Sec. 4-92. - Disposal of dead animals, garbage, etc., on which rats may feed. 
(a)  Within the city, all garbage or refuse consisting of waste, animal or vegetable matter upon which rats may feed, and all small dead animals, shall be placed and stored until collected by the sanitary department, in suitable and sufficient watertight cans or receptacles, each having a tight-fitting cover; and it is hereby declared unlawful for any person to dump or place on any premises, land or waterway, any dead animals, or any waste, vegetable or animal matter of any kind. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place, leave or dump, or permit to accumulate any garbage, rubbish or trash in any building or premises in the city, so that same shall or may afford food or harborage for rats. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to permit to accumulate on any premises, improved or vacant, and on all open lots and alleys in the city, any lumber, boxes, barrels, bricks, stones, or similar materials that may be permitted to remain thereon, unless same shall be placed on open racks that are elevated not less than eighteen (18) inches above the ground, and evenly piled or stacked so that these materials will not afford harborage for rats. 
(Code 1963, § 14-50) 
State Law reference- Disposal of certain animals dying of diseases, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 97-27-3. 
Sec. 4-93. - Precautions on vessels in harbor. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any vessel, or watercraft, except harbor boats to lie alongside of any wharf or dock in the city, and such vessels or watercraft shall be fended off from the wharf or dock in such manner that no part of such vessel, or watercraft, shall be nearer than eight (8) feet from the nearest point of said wharf, or dock, by a floating fender or spars of sufficient strength to maintain said distance of eight (8) feet. Each such spar and each such chain, hawser, rope, or line of any kind extending from any such vessel or watercraft to said dock or wharf shall be equipped with and have properly and securely attached thereto a rat shield or guard of such design and in such manner as shall be accepted by the health officer, except harbor boats which shall be fumigated once every sixty (60) days within the discretion of the health officer. 
(b)  No gang plank, staging, or other structure, whereon or whereby rats may leave or board such vessel or watercraft, shall be extended therefrom to the wharf or dock, except during such time as loading or unloading is in progress and when being loaded or unloaded a competent person, specially detailed for that purpose by the owner, master or officer in charge of such vessel or watercraft, shall be stationed at each such gang plank, staging, or other structure, whose duty it shall be to prevent rats from boarding or leaving vessel, or watercraft, and, if possible, to destroy same. 
(c)  After the hours of sunset all such gang planks, staging, or other structure, provided for in subsection (b), shall be removed from such wharf or dock; provided, that when unloading or loading is required to be done after sunset, the same shall be done in the manner provided by subsection (b); and provided further, that such light or lights shall be furnished by the owner, master or other officer in charge of such vessel or watercraft, and so placed at or sufficiently near to each such gang plank, staging, or other structure as to so light such gang plank, staging, or other structure that the presence of rats may be easily and readily seen, and such additional competent persons as may be necessary shall be detailed in the manner and for the purpose provided for in subsection (b). The end of each such gang plank, staging, or other structure shall be kept lighted at all times when in use for a length of ten (10) feet. 
(d)  It is hereby made the duty of the owner, agent, and master, or other officer in charge of any vessel or watercraft to comply with all the provisions of this section. 
(e)  The officers and employees on the wharf dock are requested to assist in the enforcement of this section by reporting any infraction thereof to the proper municipal officers, and all police officers shall strictly enforce the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1963, § 14-51) 
Cross reference- Boats, docks, waterways and beaches, Ch. 2. 
Secs. 4-94-4-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - MOSQUITO CONTROL[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Animals, § 7-56 et seq. 
State Law reference- Municipal vermin control, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 17-17-19; mosquito control, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 41-27-1 et seq.; services to municipalities by mosquito control commissions, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 41-27-9. 

Sec. 4-116. - Water suitable for breeding prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to have, keep, maintain, cause or permit within the corporate limits of the city, any collection of standing or flowing water in which mosquitoes breed or are liable to breed, unless such collection of water is treated so as effectively to prevent such breeding. The collections of water prohibited by this section shall be held to be those contained in ditches, ponds, pools, excavations, holes, depressions, open cesspools, privy vaults, fountains, cisterns, tanks, shallow wells, barrels, troughs, defective house roof gutters, tanks of flush toilets, urns, cans, boxes, bottles, tubs, buckets, or other similar water containers. 
(Code 1963, § 14-62) 
State Law reference- Rice field mosquito control, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 41-27-101 et seq. 
Sec. 4-117. - Method of treating water. 
    The method of treatment of any collections of water directed toward the prevention of mosquitoes shall be approved by the health officer and may be any of the following: 
(1)  Screening with wire netting of at least eighteen (18) meshes to the inch each way or any other material which will effectively prevent the ingress or egress of mosquitoes. 
(2)  Complete emptying every seven (7) days of unscreened containers, together with their thorough drying or cleaning. 
(3)  Using a larvacide approved by and applied under the direction of the health officer. 
(4)  Completely covering the surface of the water with kerosene, petroleum, or paraffin oil every seven (7) days. 
(5)  Cleaning and keeping sufficiently free of vegetable growth and other obstructions and stocking with mosquito-destroying fish; absence of half grown mosquito larvae shall be evidence of compliance with this measure. 
(6)  Filling or draining to the satisfaction of the health officer. 
(7)  Proper disposal of tin cans, tin boxes, broken or empty bottles, and similar articles likely to hold water. 
(Code 1963, § 14-63) 
Sec. 4-118. - Obstructing flow in ditches, drains, streams prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to throw or deposit tin cans, boxes, paper, rubbish or any other material into any ditch, drain, or stream or in any way to interfere with or obstruct the flow in such ditch, drain, or stream. 
(Code 1963, § 14-64) 
State Law reference- Depositing refuse in levees, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 97-15-21; obstructing waterways, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 97-15-39 et seq. 
Sec. 4-119. - Larvae evidence of breeding; failure to correct after notice. 
    The natural presence of mosquito larvae in standing or running water shall be evidence that mosquitoes are breeding there, and failure to prevent such breeding within three (3) days after notice by the health officer shall be deemed a violation of this article. 
(Code 1963, § 14-65) 
Sec. 4-120. - Correction of violations by health officer. 
    If any person responsible for conditions giving rise to the breeding of mosquitoes shall fail or refuse to take the necessary measures to prevent the same within three (3) days after due notice has been given them, the health officer is hereby authorized to do so and all necessary cost incurred by him for this purpose shall be a charge against the property owner or other person offending as the case may be and shall be collected by appropriate proceedings. 
(Code 1963, § 14-66) 
Sec. 4-121. - Enforcement by health officer, right of entry; violations. 
    The health officer shall enforce the provisions of this article, and for this purpose the health officer and any person acting under his authority may at all reasonable times enter in and upon any premises within his jurisdiction; and any person charged with any of the duties imposed by this article failing within the time designated by this article or within the time stated in the notice of the health officer, as the case may be, to perform such duties, or carry out the necessary measures to the satisfaction of the health officer, shall be deemed guilty of violation of this article, and each day after the expiration of the time that such person fails to comply with this article shall be deemed guilty of a separate violation of this article. 
(Code 1963, § 14-67) 
Sec. 4-122. - Responsibility of owner, agent, trespasser. 
    The person held under this article to be responsible for the correction of conditions on premises giving rise to or likely to give rise to breeding of mosquitoes shall be the owner, and in his absence the agent of owner of such premises; provided any tenant causing such condition shall also be held responsible. Where a trespasser or other person is known to cause or to have caused such conditions without consent of the owner, agent or tenant, then such person will be held responsible for causing the same. 
(Code 1963, § 14-68) 
Secs. 4-123-4-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - GARBAGE, TRASH AND WEEDS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Garbage and trash disposal in trailer camps, § 5-89; depositing garbage or refuse in sewer fixtures, § 11-7; supplementary zoning regulations, App. A, § IV. 
State Law reference- Solid Wastes Disposal Law of 1974, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 17-17-1 et seq.; municipal powers as to the disposal of garbage and rubbish, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, §§ 17-17-5, 21-19-1; hauling of solid wastes, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 17-17-11; power of city to cut weeds on private property, lien, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 21-19-11; municipally owned utilities, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 21-27-11 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 4-141. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Ashes shall include the waste products of coal and other fuel used for heating and cooking from all public and private establishments and from all residences. 
    Containers shall mean locally approved metal, heavy-duty paper or plastic receptacles used for the disposal and storage of solid waste. 
    Garbage shall include all putrescible wastes, except sewage and body wastes, including vegetable and animal offal and carcasses of dead animals, but excluding recognized industrial byproducts, and shall include all refuse or accumulation of animal, fruit or vegetable matter, liquid or otherwise that attends the preparation, use, cooking, consumption, merchandising or storing of meat, fish, fowl, fruits or vegetables. 
    Litter shall mean any quantity of uncontainerized paper, metal, plastic, glass or miscellaneous solid waste which may be classed as trash, debris, rubbish, refuse, garbage or junk. 
    Private property shall mean, but not be limited to, the following exterior locations owned by private individuals, firms, corporations, institutions or organizations: yards, grounds, driveways, entranceways, passageways, parking areas, working areas, storage areas, vacant lots and recreation facilities. 
    Public property shall include, but not be limited to, the following exterior locations: streets, street medians, roads, road medians, catch basins, sidewalks, strips between streets and sidewalks, lanes, alleys, public rights-of-way, public parking lots, school grounds, municipal housing project grounds, municipal vacant lots, parks, beaches, playgrounds, other publicly-owned recreation facilities, and municipal waterways and bodies of water. 
    Refuse shall include garbage, rubbish, ashes and other putrescible and nonputrescible wastes except sewage, from all residences. 
    Trash shall include all nonputrescible waste, including grass and leaves, from all public and private establishments and from all residences. 
(Code 1963, § 13-1) 
State Law reference- Definitions relating to solid wastes disposal, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 17-17-3. 
Sec. 4-142. - City sanitary landfills and trash dumps. 
(a)  Designation. The mayor and city council shall, by appropriate resolution, designate from time to time property or properties owned or leased and used by the city as city sanitary landfills and trash dumps. 
(b)  Unauthorized use prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to bring material from outside the city into the city for the purpose of depositing or dumping the materials on the city sanitary landfills and trash dumps. Entry upon or in the city sanitary landfills and trash dumps for any purpose not authorized herein is prohibited. 
(c)  Hours dumping permitted. It shall be unlawful for any person to bring materials from within the city and place same on the areas designated as city sanitary landfills and trash dumps, except during the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday, inclusive, of each week or at such times as may be designated from time to time by the director of public works. 
(Code 1963, § 13-2) 
State Law reference- Powers of state as to solid wastes disposed of by landfill, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 17-17-35. 
Sec. 4-143. - Littering prohibited. 
(a)  Pedestrians and motorists. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, discard, place or deposit litter in any manner or amount on any public or private property within the corporate limits of the city, except in containers or areas lawfully provided therefor. 
(2)  In the prosecution charging a violation of subsection (a)(1) above from a motor vehicle, proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was the origin of the litter, together with proof that the defendant named in the compliant was at the time of such violation the registered owner of the vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a presumption that the registered owner was the person who committed the violation. 
(3)  It shall be the duty of every person distributing commercial handbills, leaflets, flyers and any other advertising or informational material to take whatever measures may be necessary to keep such materials from littering public or private property. 
(4)  To facilitate proper disposal of litter by pedestrians and motorists, such publicly-patronized or used establishments and institutions as may be designated by the municipal department in charge of solid waste management shall provide, regularly empty, and maintain in good condition, adequate containers that meet standards prescribed by the department. This requirement shall be applicable, but not limited to, fast-food outlets, shopping centers, convenience stores, supermarkets, service stations, commercial parking lots, mobile canteens, motels, hospitals, schools and colleges. 
(b)  Vehicles transporting loose materials. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to transport any loose cargo by truck or other motor vehicle within the corporate limits of the city, unless the cargo is covered and secured in such manner as to prevent depositing of litter on public or private property. 
(2)  The duty and responsibility imposed by subsection (b)(1) above shall be applicable alike to the owner of the truck or other vehicle, the operator thereof, and the person from whose residence or establishment the cargo originated. 
(3)  In the prosecution charging a violation of subsection (b)(1) above, lack of adequate covering and securing shall in itself constitute proof a violation has been committed. 
(c)  Loading and unloading operations. 
(1)  Any owner or occupant of an establishment or institution at which litter is attendant to the packing and unpacking and loading and unloading of materials at exterior locations shall provide suitable containers for the disposal and storage of such litter and shall make appropriate arrangements for the collection thereof. 
(2)  It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant to remove at the end of each working day any litter that has not been containerized at these locations. 
(d)  Construction/demolition projects. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for the owner, agent or contractor in charge of any construction or demolition site to cause, maintain, permit or allow to be caused, maintained or permitted the accumulation of any litter on the site before, during or after the completion of the construction or demolition project. 
(2)  It shall be the duty of the owner, agent or contractor to have on the site adequate containers for the disposal of litter and to make appropriate arrangements for the collection thereof or for transport to an authorized facility for final disposition. 
(3)  The owner, agent or contractor may be required at any time to show proof of appropriate collection and final disposition at an authorized facility. 
(e)  Keeping property clean. 
(1)  It shall be the duty of the owner, agent, occupant or lessee to keep exterior private property free of litter. This requirement applies not only to removal of loose litter, but to materials that are trapped at such locations as fence and wall bases, grassy and planted areas, borders, embankments and other lodging points. 
(2)  Owners, agents, occupants or lessees whose properties face on municipal sidewalks, alleys, and strips between streets and sidewalks shall be responsible for keeping those sidewalks, alleys and strips free of litter, garbage, trash, refuse and ashes. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful to sweep or push litter into streets, alleys, or rights-of-way. Such litter must be picked up and put into household or commercial solid waste containers. 
(4)  It shall be the duty of every nonresident owner of a vacant lot or other vacant property to appoint a resident agent who shall have responsibility for keeping that lot or other property free of litter. 
(Code 1963, § 13-3) 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 6. 
State Law reference- Putting glass or other injurious material on highway, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 63-3-1211. 
Sec. 4-144. - Offensive accumulations prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make, use, or permit in any dwelling house, shop, store, factory, outhouse, cellar, yard, lot or any other place within the city, any noisome or offensive liquid, or substance of any character whatever prejudicial to the health, or so offensive to the right or smell as to be a nuisance to the neighborhood or liable to become so. 
(Code 1963, § 13-4) 
Sec. 4-145. - Unsightly accumulations on vacant lots. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner, occupant or any other person, to place or store, or permit to be placed or stored, on any vacant part of a lot, or parcel of land situated within R-1, R-2, R-0, R-B, B-1, B-2 and B-3 districts of the city any junked automobile, automobile parts, junk refrigerators, stoves, or any stack or quantity of barrels, boxes, paper, trash or rubbish, and to permit the same to so remain for over a period of twenty-four (24) hours. 
(Code 1963, § 13-5) 
State Law reference- Junkyards near certain highways, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 49-25-1 et seq.; sale of abandoned motor vehicles, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 63-23-1 et seq. 
Sec. 4-146. - Penalty for violation of any provisions of article VI. 
    Violation of any ordinance provisions against littering or unauthorized dumping as specified in sections 4-141 through 4-145, inclusive, shall be a separate misdemeanor for each violation thereof, and each and every offender shall be punished for each violation by a fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) (the court, in its discretion, may suspend a portion of the fine) or by imprisonment not exceeding ninety (90) days, or by both fine and imprisonment. Any such violation punished and not cured within thirty (30) days after being found or pled guilty of the offense or after final adjudication of the offense by a court of competent jurisdiction, whichever shall be later, shall constitute a separate and repeat offense in which the fine provided for herein shall be imposed (no portion may be suspended) and imprisonment not to exceed ninety (90) days shall be imposed. 
(Ord. No. 2502, § 3, 10-18-06; Ord. No. 2703, § 2, 10-19-10) 
Secs. 4-147-4-165. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - COLLECTION; DISPOSAL 

Sec. 4-166. - Authority of city. 
    The city may provide for the collection and disposal of garbage, refuse and trash, regulate the manner and times of such collection and disposal, establish the rates to be charged therefor, and otherwise make such rules and regulations pertaining to garbage, refuse and trash as may be desirable to ensure the public health and welfare. 
(Code 1963, § 13-11) 
State Law reference- Municipal powers as to the disposal of garbage and rubbish, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, §§ 17-17-5, 21-19-1. 
Sec. 4-167. - Removable garbage and recyclable material containers. 
(a)  When and where garbage and/or recycle materials are collected for disposal by a provider contracted by the city or by a district or county authority that provides or requires a specific garbage container and/or recyclable material container, it shall be the duty of every owner, occupant or lessee of every building, residence or place of business in the city to use the contract provider's specified container for garbage and/or recyclable material collection. 
(b)  Excluding any waste management contract requiring bin or container, it shall be the duty of every owner, occupant or lessee of every building, residence or place of business in the city to provide a sufficient number of corrugated metal or plastic containers of not more than forty (40) gallons capacity in which garbage, refuse or trash may be accumulated. Such containers shall be equipped with tight-fitting metal or plastic covers and with handles or bails to facilitate the handling thereof. Worn out or rusted metal or plastic cans are prohibited. Plastic bags of the type known as (garbage bags( are also permitted if tied or closed. 
(c)  All recyclable materials placed in approved recyclable material containers shall be free of contamination of any kind of foreign substances or of any contents of containers to be recycled. Recyclable material containers placed for collection shall not be overfilled or contain broken glass or other items that are not adequately contained therein or be loaded or damaged in any manner that will prevent free discharge of its contents or may cause injury to the person manually emptying the same. 
(d)  It shall be the duty of every owner, occupant or lessee placing garbage or recyclable material containers under (a), (b) or (c) of this section for collection to locate the specified containers on or near the street curb line in front of his/her residential or business property, or in the rear of the property if the rear of the property fronts on a paved public street or alleyway accessible to the collector's trucks, or such other place as may be designated by the director of public works or his/her representative. 
(e)  All refuse capable of holding water placed in containers of any kind allowed under this section must be drained before being deposited in such containers. 
(f)  All garbage and/or recyclable material containers allowed under this section and placed for collection and disposal or removal of its contents as provided by this section shall be placed at the designated collection area no more than twenty-four (24) hours prior to 12:00 (noon) on the day scheduled for collection, and all such containers must be removed from the collection location and also from the front yard of the property no later than twenty-four (24) hours after 12:00 (noon) of the day the garbage and recyclable materials were collected. 
(g)  No person seventy-one (71) years of age or older, offering documentary proof of age, or otherwise offering documentary evidence of disability as the reason for inability to comply with subsection (f) above shall not be charged or prosecuted either civilly or criminally with violation of subsection (f), which will not then apply to them. 
(Code 1963, § 13-12; Ord. No. 2714, § 2, 3-8-11) 
Sec. 4-168. - Containers: unauthorized handling, moving and rummaging in prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person without authority or permission from the property owner, occupant or lessee having custody of the container to move, remove, handle, rummage in, or to disturb the garbage or recyclable containers being used or placed for collection as provided for by section 4-167 above. This section shall not apply to city, county, state or federal employees or designees performing duties within the scope of their employment, except in those instances where the said employees or designees, in the performance of their duties, cause garbage to be strewn about and do not return it to the garbage or recyclable retainer. 
(Ord. No. 2714, § 2, 3-8-11; Ord. No. 2716, § 2, 3-22-11) 
Sec. 4-169. - Collection of boxes. 
    Cardboard or wooden boxes shall be flattened and tied into bundles not exceeding forty (40) pounds in weight. Such bundles shall also count as a single container. 
(Code 1963, § 13-14) 
Sec. 4-170. - Accumulation prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner, occupant or lessee of any building, yard, or lot of ground within the city to allow garbage, refuse or rubbish of any kind to accumulate or remain in such building or upon such yard or lot, except where garbage, trash, or refuse is placed in a corrugated metal or plastic container as provided in section 4-167. 
(Code 1963, § 13-15) 
Sec. 4-171. - Removal of garbage, etc., from food-handling establishments. 
    All hotels, restaurants, public boardinghouses and other food-handling establishments are required to remove daily all garbage, kitchen refuse and decaying matter incident to such business. 
(Code 1963, § 13-16) 
State Law reference- State health standards to be established for food-handling establishments, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 41-3-15(3)(i). 
Sec. 4-172. - Trash cans or bins. 
    Trash cans or bins for use by commercial establishments shall have a capacity sufficient to hold three (3) days' accumulation of trash. All such cans or bins shall have tight-fitting covers and shall be balanced to remain open at any height to permit the emptying thereof. 
(Code 1963, § 13-17) 
Sec. 4-173. - Placing garbage, etc., on property of another prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dump or place or cause to be dumped or placed any garbage, refuse or trash of any kind whatsoever upon any public or private property of another located within the city without prior consent of the owner thereof. 
(Code 1963, § 13-18) 
State Law reference- Trespass, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 95-5-1 et seq. 
Sec. 4-174. - Large or excessive loads of trash, refuse, and garbage. 
    Special pickups of excessive loads of trash, refuse, and garbage may be scheduled through the department of public works. It shall be the duty of the owner, agent, occupant or lessee to transport or have transported to the designated city sanitary landfills and trash dumps, large or excessively heavy items such as, but not limited to, refrigerators, freezers, television sets, motors, motor vehicles, furniture, and other items of personal property not normally classified as trash, refuse and garbage. Special pickups of excessive loads of trash, refuse and garbage shall be arranged by contacting the department of public works. 
(Code 1963, § 13-19) 
Sec. 4-175. - Fees for collection of garbage, trash and refuse. 
(a)  Each household and commercial establishment within the city receiving municipal garbage collection services shall pay the following amount each month for the collection and disposal of garbage, trash and refuse: 
(1)  Household (single or multi-family (4 units or less) residential): 
 Sixteen dollars and seventy-five cents ($16.75) per month (effective October 1, 2017); 
 Sixteen dollars and eighty cents ($16.80) per month (effective October 1, 2018); 
 Sixteen dollars and eighty-six cents ($16.86) per month (effective October 1, 2019); 
 Sixteen dollars and ninety-one cents ($16.91) per month (effective October 1, 2020); 
 Sixteen dollars and ninety-seven cents ($16.97) per month (effective October 1, 2021); and 
 Seventeen dollars and two cents ($17.02) per month (effective October 1, 2022). 
(2)  Commercial establishments: 
 Twenty dollars and seventy-five cents ($20.75) per month (effective October 1, 2017); 
 Twenty dollars and eighty cents ($20.80) per month (effective October 1, 2018); 
 Twenty dollars and eighty-five cents ($20.85) per month (effective October 1, 2019); 
 Twenty dollars and ninety-one cents ($20.91) per month (effective October 1, 2020); 
 Twenty dollars and ninety-six cents ($20.96) per month (effective October 1, 2021); and 
 Twenty-one dollars and two cents ($21.02) per month (effective October 1, 2022). 
(b)  The fees herein provided for the collection of garbage, trash and refuse shall be included with, and be in addition to, each household and commercial establishment's monthly water and/or sewer service bill. 
(c)  Nonpayment of the fee for collection of garbage, trash and refuse, shall result in the discontinuance of the collection service. In addition to discontinuance of the collection service, the city shall be authorized to use all available legal remedies, whether at law or equity, to collect delinquent garbage, trash and refuse collection fees. 
(Code 1963, § 13-22; Ord. No. 2062, § 1, 9-12-96; Ord. No. 2152, § 1, 10-9-98; Ord. No. 2556, § 2, 9-14-07; Ord. No. 2697, § 2, 9-14-10; Ord. No. 2832, § 2, 9-8-15 , ; Ord. No. 2920, § 2, 9-19-17 ) 
State Law reference- Fees relating to hazardous waste disposal, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, §§ 17-17-15, 17-17-53. 
Sec. 4-176. - Penalties, continuing violations, public nuisances, and abatement pertaining to specific sections. 
(a)  Unless otherwise stated, it shall be unlawful for any person or party to violate any provisions of sections 4-167, 4-168, 4-169, 4-170, 4-171, 4-172 and 4-173, and any such violation shall constitute a misdemeanor, punishable upon conviction according to the general penalty provision of section 1-9 of the Code of Ordinances, and for the cost of prosecution, except that for a first offender of sections 4-167 and 4-169, the penalty for violating provisions of section 4-167 and 4-169 shall not exceed a fine of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) without imprisonment. 
(b)  In addition to or as an alternative to the penalties provided in subsection (a), any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of said sections 4-167, 4-168, 4-169, 4-170, 4-171, 4-172 and 4-173 shall be deemed a public nuisance and may be abated as such by the city by applicable remedy at law or in equity against the violator. 
(Ord. No. 2714, § 2, 3-8-11) 
Sec. 4-177. - Other ordinances, severability. 
    If any word, sentence, phrase, clause, paragraph or section of chapter 4, article VI, division 2, sections 4-166 through 4-190, inclusive, or the application thereof to any person or circumstances be legally declared, adjudged or held to be unconstitutional, illegal, invalid, or unenforceable by a court of competent jurisdiction, or by application of existing or newly enacted laws or case decisions having effect, such finding or declaration of invalidity shall not invalidate or affect the validity or enforceability of any other provision hereof or the remainder hereof as a whole, but the invalid portion shall be severed from the remainder. 
(Ord. No. 2714, § 2, 3-8-11) 
Secs. 4-178-4-179 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - DISPOSAL OF EXCRETA[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Water and sewers, Ch. 11. 
State Law reference- Municipal regulation of privy vaults, cesspools, sewers and other facilities affecting health, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 21-19-1; municipal regulation of individual on-site wastewater disposal systems, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 41-67-15. 

Sec. 4-191. - Property owner to provide required facilities. 
    It shall be the duty of the property owners to provide the facilities required by this article. 
(Code 1963, § 14-19) 
Sec. 4-192. - Occupants to maintain facilities. 
    It shall be the duty of the occupants of each premises to see that each toilet device shall be kept in a sanitary condition at all times, and it shall be unlawful for anyone to abuse or misuse such property. 
(Code 1963, § 14-20) 
Sec. 4-193. - Sanitary method required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to throw out, deposit, or in any other way dispose of human excreta other than into a sanitary water closet, a properly constructed septic tank, or other sanitary toilet device approved by the state board of health. 
(Code 1963, § 14-21) 
State Law reference- Power of state board of health to make and publish rules and regulations, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 41-3-17. 
Sec. 4-194. - Connecting to storm sewers, drainage ditches prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any line of any kind or character, including an open ditch, from a sanitary water closet, septic tank or other sanitary device approved by the state board of health to be connected with any storm sewer and/or drainage ditch. 
(Code 1963, § 14-22) 
Sec. 4-195. - Connecting cesspools, septic tanks to sanitary sewers prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to connect a cesspool or septic tank to the sanitary sewerage system. 
(Code 1963, § 14-23) 
State Law reference- Individual on-site wastewater disposal systems, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 41-67-1 et seq. 
Sec. 4-196. - Constructing buildings without inside toilets prohibited; sewer connection or septic tank required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to and no person shall construct any residence or building for the housing of humans within the city without furnishing and installing therein an inside toilet or inside toilets. Disposal from such toilets and other fixtures using water shall be by connecting same with sewerage line if required by Chapter 11 and if not then by connecting the same with a septic tank, cesspools being especially prohibited. 
(b)  All installation of toilets, septic tanks, sewerage connections, etc., shall be done and made in strict accordance with Article III of Chapter 3 and shall also meet the requirements and regulations of the state board of health. 
(c)  The only exception to be permitted to subsections (a) and (b) of this section is that if water under pressure is not available or cannot be made available, then an outside privy may be constructed but a special permit shall first be obtained. 
(d)  In addition to any penalty for violation hereof the city shall have the option to enforce the provisions of this section by injunction or adequate and proper court proceedings. 
(Code 1963, § 14-24) 
Sec. 4-197. - Connections required when sewers extended. 
    Whenever new lines or extensions of the sanitary sewerage system are installed, all property owners owning property so located that a sewer connection is required by Chapter 11 shall connect with the sewers. 
(Code 1963, § 14-25) 
Sec. 4-198. - When sewer connection permitted if plumbing doesn't meet requirements. 
    Where a building that is desired to be connected to the sanitary sewer of the city has installed therein plumbing that does not meet the requirements of Article III of Chapter 3, the building may nevertheless be connected to the sewer system without the necessity of the plumbing in the building being reworked, if the plumbing inspector of the city determines that same should be done, by installing in the line between the house connections and the sewer line connection a house trap situated near the building and provided with a vent on the sewer main side of the trap, which vent shall extend above roof level of the house and away from any window and may consist of two-inch pipe of approved material, and also, if the building is entirely unvented, provided with fresh air inlet on the house side of the trap, which fresh air intake shall also extend above roof level but shall terminate at least twelve (12) inches from sewer vent. Where both sides of house trap are vented, additional four-inch cleanout will be provided. 
(Code 1963, § 14-26) 
Sec. 4-199. - Permit, inspection required to alter or install system. 
    Any property owner intending to alter or install a method of excreta disposal on any property shall apply to the county health department for a certificate of approval for such alteration or installation, and the county health department shall cause an inspection to be made of the property to determine which one of the methods of excreta disposal shall be employed, and shall issue to the property owner a certificate of approval for the alteration or installation, stating therein the method of excreta disposal to be employed. It shall be the duty of the property owner to comply with the provisions of said certificate of approval, provided, however, that this section shall in no wise relieve the property owner or the party doing the work from securing the regular permit from the city clerk for doing such work. 
(Code 1963, § 14-27) 
Sec. 4-200. - Maintaining privies near residences. 
(a)  Prohibited. No person shall maintain a privy vault, also commonly referred to as an outside privy or toilet, within the city within three hundred (300) feet of the residence of any other person who shall complain in writing to the mayor and city council regarding the same. 
(b)  Complaint required. This section shall be enforced only upon written complaint filed with the mayor and city council by some resident citizen residing on premises within three hundred (300) feet of the premises on which the privy vault is located. 
(c)  Enforcement; penalties. Upon the filing with the mayor and city council of a written complaint regarding privy vaults as provided herein, it shall be the duty of the proper officials of the city to give written notice to the person against whom the complaint has been filed, to cease the use of the privy vault and to remove the same from the premises and to provide the premises with such sanitary sewage facilities as are duly authorized and permitted within the city. In the event the party after notification by proper officials does not comply with the notice within thirty (30) days from the date of the notice, such person shall then be in violation of this section, which violation shall be a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1963, § 14-28) 
ARTICLE VIII. - SLABS AND PILINGS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Sections 1-8 of Ord. No. 2830 , adopted July 7, 2015 added provisions to the Code, but did not specify manner of inclusion. Therefore, at the discretion of the editor, said provisions have been included as §§ 4-201-4-207. 

Sec. 4-201. - Findings. 
    The City Council of the City of Gulfport hereby finds that the recitals in the preamble of this article are true. 
(Ord. No. 2830 , § 1, 7-7-15) 
Sec. 4-202. - Nuisance declared. 
    Old, pre-used slabs and/or pilings, and other objectionable, unsightly or unsanitary matter are hereby declared to be a nuisance. Any slab, piling, or property that is in a state of dilapidation, deterioration, damage, decay, or disrepair, is of faulty or insufficient construction, is open to intrusion, abandoned, damaged by fire, storm, hurricane, or neglect to the extent as not to provide shelter, is extremely unsound, in danger of collapse or failure, constitutes a fire hazard, causes flooding or drainage problems, violates any flood prevention ordinance, and/or violates the city's adopted building codes, and that constitute a threat to the public health, safety and welfare are hereby declared to be a nuisance. No person shall allow, erect, contrive, cause, continue, maintain or permit any such slab, piling, and/or nuisance outside, on, or in any property within the city. 
(Ord. No. 2830 , § 2, 7-7-15) 
Sec. 4-203. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall have the following meanings, unless context clearly indicates that a different meaning is intended: 
    Developed property shall mean any premises that have been improved by the installation of a building, home, or other physical improvements, including, but not limited to, streets, utilities, etc. 
    Owner shall mean any person or other entity who owns the premises, real property, or physical premises. 
    Person shall include and be applicable to any individual person, firm, partnership, corporation, association, and business entity. 
    Premises shall include all real property within the City of Gulfport, Mississippi. 
    Person in charge shall mean the owner, lessee, occupant, or person who has real or apparent authority to act on behalf of the premises or the agent in charge of or responsible for the premises. 
    Slab shall mean any concrete or masonry (block or brick) foundation (including piers) or pavement which is old (constructed prior to August 29, 2005) and pre-used (previously served as the foundation for a structure). This definition of slab shall not include concrete or masonry driveways, concrete or masonry sidewalks, concrete or masonry patios, concrete or masonry retaining walls or concrete or masonry parking pads. Further, in Business or Industrial zones (as defined in the city's zoning ordinance), this definition of slab shall not include any area of concrete or masonry which would otherwise meet the definition of slab but which has been prepared as an area for parking in accord with applicable building codes and city standards and ordinances AND which 1. is open for public parking OR 2. is under contract for reserved parking. 
    Structure shall mean any object constructed or installed by a person including, but not limited to, buildings, towers, smoke stacks, windmills, and flag poles. 
    Undeveloped property shall mean any premises that have never been improved by the installation of a building, home, or other structural improvements. 
    Vacant property shall mean any premises that at any time within the twenty (20) years preceding the adoption of this ordinance had improvements, such as a building, home, or other structural improvements, and whose building(s), home(s), or other structural improvement(s) are no longer existing or standing. For the purposes of this article, any premises that within the twenty (20) years preceding the adoption of this ordinance had improvements such as a building, home, or other structural improvement and only has a foundational slab of such building, home, or other structural improvement remaining, shall be considered "Vacant Property. 
(Ord. No. 2830 , § 3, 7-7-15; Ord. No. 2943, § 2, 4-3-18 ) 
Sec. 4-204. - Developed property and vacant property; duties of owner, occupant, or person(s) in charge. 
    The owner, occupant, or person(s) in charge of developed property and vacant property shall keep such premises free of old, pre-used and uncovered slabs and/or pilings. Every person in charge who shall allow any such slabs, pilings, or property in such a state shall be deemed in violation of this article. This section shall not apply to undeveloped property. 
(Ord. No. 2830 , § 4, 7-7-15) 
Sec. 4-205. - Provisions applying to persons in charge regarding possible violations. 
    Upon discovery and inspection by the City of Gulfport Code Enforcement Office of any premises or property conditions in violation of section 4-204 supra., the inspector of the City of Gulfport Code Enforcement Office, or a city official appointed by such office, shall give notice to the person in charge of the apparent violation. Any person violating any provision of this article may be charged with a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and may be punished by a fine therefore in an amount not to exceed the maximum allowed by Mississippi law. Notice of such a misdemeanor charge shall comply with the notice requirements of Mississippi law. The procedure for such a misdemeanor charge shall be as with other misdemeanors. The City of Gulfport Municipal Court shall have original jurisdiction over said misdemeanor trial. Upon any conviction of a misdemeanor under this ordinance, the owner, occupant, or person(s) found guilty of that violation shall be compelled to abate the nuisance within thirty (30) days. 
    Alternative or prior to charging the owner, occupant, or person(s) in charge with a misdemeanor, the inspector of the City of Gulfport Code Enforcement Office, or a city official appointed by such office, may give notice to the owner, occupant, or person(s) in charge to appear for a hearing before the city council at a time and place to be fixed by said notice, and the person in charge shall then and there have an opportunity to show cause why the accused violation shall not be declared a nuisance and an order issued requiring the nuisance to be abated. 
    For owner, occupant, or person(s) in charge whose address is known, such notice as described in the first paragraph to this section shall be written notice by U.S. registered mail or certified mail, return receipt requested, two (2) weeks before the date of the appearance and hearing before the City Council of the City of Gulfport or written notice by service by a police officer or other designated municipal employee at least two (2) weeks before the date of the appearance before the City Council of the City of Gulfport. 
    If the owner, occupant, or person(s) in charge or their address is unknown, notice as described in the first paragraph to this section may be had by two (2) weeks' written notice in a newspaper having general circulation in the City of Gulfport, and by written notice by U.S. registered mail or certified mail, return receipt requested, two (2) weeks before the date of the appearance to the owner, occupant, or person(s) in charge's last known address, if the owner, occupant, or person(s) in charge are known. 
    Written notice, as used in this section, shall require the letter and/or publicized notice of appearance to include minimally a phrase in substantially the following form: 
Owner, occupant, or person(s) in charge of (here describe the premises in the City of Gulfport) : 
You are hereby noticed to appear before the City Council of the City of Gulfport, located at (list address of the City Council of the City of Gulfport) , on the ____ day of _________, 20__ for a hearing to determine whether there exist slab, pilings and/or other objectionable, unsightly, or unsanitary matter on the above described property, and/or that violates the City's adopted building codes such that the property is a nuisance in violation of City of Gulfport Ordinance No. 2830. 
You are hereby put on notice to appear at such hearing and take such part as you deem necessary. You are also put on notice that should such property be declared at that hearing to be a nuisance in violation of City of Gulfport Ordinance No. 2830, then you must either cure such nuisance or you will be charged with a misdemeanor. 
Please contact at (228) should you have any questions. 
(Ord. No. 2830 , § 5, 7-7-15) 
Sec. 4-206 - Procedure for hearing. 
    Upon sufficient notice upon the owner, occupant, or person(s) in charge, as outlined in section 4-205 supra., the City Council of the City of Gulfport will proceed with a hearing, at the time and date of hearing described in the notice, to determine whether the premises described in the notice are in violation of section 4-204 of this article, and whether such premises are a nuisance to the City of Gulfport. At such hearing, the owner, occupant, or person(s) in charge shall be afforded opportunity to show or explain why the premises are not in violation of section 4-204 of this article; and the owner, occupant, or person(s) in charge shall be afforded opportunity to show or explain why the premises should not be deemed and declared a nuisance. 
    Upon a showing and finding by the City Council of the City of Gulfport that the premises are in violation of section 4-204 of this article, the City Council of the City of Gulfport shall declare whether or not the premises are a nuisance as outlined in this article. Should the City Council of the City of Gulfport declare the premises to be such a nuisance, the City Council of the City of Gulfport shall order the owner, occupant, or person(s) in charge to fully abate the nuisance within thirty (30) days of the order. 
(Ord. No. 2830 , § 7, 7-7-15) 
Sec. 4-207. - Penalty for failure to comply with an order from the city council of the city of gulfport. 
    In the event that the code enforcement office, after that thirty (30) day notice period, find and determine that the premises have not been so fully abated of all violations, the owner, occupant, or person(s) in charge shall be charged with a misdemeanor under this ordinance, with each day after any order of violation upon which a nuisance continues deemed a separate misdemeanor violation. Upon such a charge, the owner, occupant, or person(s) shall be tried for a misdemeanor under this ordinance for each day of the charged continuing violation, with each day a separate misdemeanor charge. A finding of guilt for any such misdemeanor for a continuing violation shall be punished for each daily occurrence up to the maximum allowed by law. Upon conviction, the owner, occupant, or person(s) found guilty shall again be ordered to fully abate the nuisance. If the nuisance is not abated within thirty (30) days the City of Gulfport will abate the nuisance and will levy the cost to the property's tax for the coming year. 
(Ord. No. 2830 , § 8, 7-7-15) 
ARTICLE IX. - PROPER DISPOSAL OF TIRES AND THE REGISTRATION OF CERTAIN TIRE BUSINESSES AND TIRE HAULERS[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 2759, adopted Aug. 21, 2012 added provisions to the Code, but did not specify manner of inclusion. Therefore, at the discretion of the editor, said provisions have been included as §§ 4-208-4-220. 

Sec. 4-208. - Purpose and intent. 
    It is declared to be the purpose and intent of the city to protect the public health, safety, and welfare of its citizens, prevent the spread of disease and creation of nuisances, and to protect and enhance the quality of its environment. The purpose of this article is to institute and maintain a city-wide program of standards related to tires which will assure that the storage, transportation, collection, processing and disposal of tires does not adversely affect the health, safety, and well-being of the general public and does not degrade the quality of the environment, potential of economic development, and the value of real properties. 
(Ord. No. 2759 , § 2(§ 1), 8-21-12) 
Sec. 4-209. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meaning ascribed to them herein: 
    Dump shall mean to throw, discard, place, deposit, discharge, bury, or dispose of. 
    Person shall mean any and all persons, natural or artificial, including any individual, firm or association. 
    Tire shall mean a continuous solid or pneumatic rubber covering encircling the wheel of a bicycle, motorcycle, automobile, truck, trailer, tractor or other vehicle. 
    Waste tire shall mean a tire that is no longer suitable for its original intended purpose because of wear, damage, or defect. Waste tire also includes any tire that is destined for a tire disposer or reprocessor (i.e., recapper). 
    Waste tire hauler shall mean any person engaged in the business of picking up or transporting waste tires for the purpose of removal to a tire recycling facility, waste tire disposer, processor, end user, or disposal facility, or other location, or anyone transporting tires from a waste tire generator to any location; whether or not licensed by the MDEQ . 
    Waste tire disposer shall mean any person who is approved by the Mississippi Department of Environment Quality to receive waste tires from waste tire generators or waste tire haulers for the purpose of waste tire processing, shredding or otherwise facilitating recycling or resource recovery techniques for waste tires. 
    Waste tire generator shall mean any person or entity that generates waste tires. Generators may include, but are not limited to, retail tire dealers, retreaders, waste tire disposers not approved by MDEQ, automobile dealers, private company vehicle maintenance shops, garages, service stations. 
    Store shall mean to cause a tire to rest or stay in a location. 
(Ord. No. 2759 , § 2(§ 2), 8-21-12) 
Sec. 4-210. - Tire business permits. 
    All tire businesses located within the city limits engaging in the resale of tires or the generation of waste tires shall be issued a permit annually by the City of Gulfport, by and through the department duly designated to handle such permits, for a non-refundable fee of twenty-five ($25.00) dollars. Tire businesses with multiple locations must purchase a permit for each location. Tire businesses that have their own trucks utilized to transport waste tires will receive one (1) decal included with the permit fee. A separate decal must be purchased by such business location for any additional truck utilized by the tire business to transport waste tires at a cost of $15 per decal. The city shall conduct random inspections of such tire businesses for the sake of monitoring compliance with the foregoing requirement. 
(a)  Application. Every person, firm or corporation obligated to comply with the permit requirement set forth herein shall make written application to the city. The application shall be made on a form obtained from the City of Gulfport setting forth, among other things, the following: 
(1)  Name, physical address, telephone, email address, and facsimile number of the applicant; 
(2)  Tax identification number or tax payer identification number; 
(3)  Proof of current City of Gulfport Business License, issued to the applicant at the proposed business address; 
(4)  City of Gulfport Occupancy Certificate; 
(5)  Name, mailing address, telephone and facsimile number of the owner of the tire business (if different from number 1 above); 
(6)  The estimated number of tires that will be stored on site; 
(7)  The current physical address of the site; 
(8)  A statement setting forth and describing the available space for properly accommodating and protecting all tires; 
(9)  Proof of public general liability insurance in amounts as determined by the City of Gulfport Building Code Services; 
(10)  Such other and further information as the City of Gulfport may require. 
(b)  Annual Fees. 
(1)  All permit and decal fees are due annually by July 1st, of each calendar year at the City of Gulfport. These annual fees shall be paid in advance of the issuance of such permit and decal and shall be prorated as necessary. 
(2)  A current valid permit or decal may be replaced by the City of Gulfport for a fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00). 
(c)  Issuance. The City of Gulfport shall issue a permit and decal to a tire business which submits the required and completed application, pays to the city the fee as required in this article, and has demonstrated compliance with this article and all applicable city ordinances. Each tire business registered in accordance with the provisions of this article shall immediately post such permit and decal in a prominent manner, or cause such permit to be posted in a conspicuous place within the premises where such tire business is thereby authorized to be established, maintained or operated. The decal shall be conspicuously displayed on each vehicle owned by such tire business that is utilized to transport used or waste tires. Any permit or decal issued hereunder shall not be sold, assigned, mortgaged or otherwise transferred and shall expire upon termination of the existence of the tire business or revocation of such business' permit. 
(d)  Effective Period. The permit shall be effective beginning on October first until the next ensuing thirtieth day of September, on and after which date it shall be null and void. 
(Ord. No. 2759 , § 2(§ 3), 8-21-12) 
Sec. 4-211. - Tire hauler permit. 
    All tire haulers, not affiliated with a tire business that is properly permitted as required herein, transporting used or waste tires within the city limits shall be required to possess a permit and decal issued annually by the City of Gulfport, by and through its department duly designated to issue said permits, for a non-refundable fee of twenty-five ($25.00) dollars. Tire haulers with multiple locations must purchase a permit for each location. Tire haulers will receive one (1) decal included with the permit fee. A separate decal must be purchased by such hauler for any additional vehicles utilized by the hauler to transport waste tires at a cost of fifteen ($15.00) dollars per decal. 
(a)  Application. Every person, firm or corporation obligated to comply with the permit and decal requirement set forth herein shall make written application to the city. The application shall be made on a form obtained from the City of Gulfport setting forth, among other things, the following: 
(1)  Name, physical address, telephone and facsimile number of the applicant; 
(2)  Tax identification number or tax payer identification number (if applicable); 
(3)  Proof of current City of Gulfport business license, issued to the applicant at the proposed business address; 
(4)  Proof of public general liability insurance and automobile insurance; 
(5)  Such other and further information as the may require. 
(b)  Annual fees. 
(1)  All permit and decal fees are due annually by July 1st, of each calendar year at the City of Gulfport. These annual fees shall be paid in advance of the issuance of such permit, such fee shall be prorated as necessary. 
(2)  A current valid permit or decal may be replaced by the City of Gulfport for a fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00). 
(c)  Issuance. The City of Gulfport shall issue a permit and decal to a tire hauler who submits the required and completed application, pays to the city the fee as required in this article, and has demonstrated compliance with this article and all applicable city ordinances. Each waste tire hauler registered in accordance with the provisions of this article shall conspicuously post and maintain such decal in his/her vehicle which is used for transporting tires, at all times. Any permit or decal issued hereunder shall not be sold, assigned, mortgaged or otherwise transferred and shall expire upon termination of the tire hauler's business or revocation of such hauler's permit. 
(d)  Effective Period. The permit shall be effective beginning on October first until the next ensuing thirtieth day of September, on and after which date it shall be null and void. 
(e)  Permit Exemptions. The following persons are exempt from the tire hauler permit requirements set forth herein: 
(1)  A tire hauler who is regulated or licensed by, and is currently in compliance with, state or federal agencies such as the Department of Transportation; or 
(2)  A private individual transporting the individual's own waste tires to an approved tire disposal or tire recycling facility. 
(Ord. No. 2759 , § 2(§ 4), 8-21-12) 
Sec. 4-212. - Denial of permit or renewal; suspension or revocation of permit. 
    In addition to the penalties set forth in this article, the City of Gulfport may refuse to issue or renew a tire business or tire hauler permit or may suspend or revoke such permit if: 
(a)  The applicant or permit holder refuses to allow entry into the tire business by the authorized representatives of the city or otherwise willfully obstructs city inspection of the tire business; or 
(b)  There are repeated or any single serious violation(s) of any city ordinance by the tire business or tire hauler; or 
(c)  The tire business or tire hauler fails to comply with any provisions of this article and/or any other applicable city ordinance(s); or 
(d)  The tire business or tire hauler fails to comply with any applicable state or federal law, rule or regulation; 
(e)  The tire business knowingly authorizes a tire hauler who is not properly permitted as required in this article to transport tires on behalf of such business. 
(Ord. No. 2759 , § 2(§ 5), 8-21-12) 
Sec. 4-213. - Destruction of tires. 
    Any tire that is no longer suitable for its original intended purpose or deemed unfit for resale by a tire business shall be rendered unusable and properly disposed of at an authorized tire disposal or recycling facility. Each tire business and tire hauler shall have one (1) month from the effective date of this article to comply with this provision. Failure to comply with this requirement shall be grounds for revocation of the permit holder's permit. 
(Ord. No. 2759 , § 2(§ 6), 8-21-12) 
Sec. 4-214. - Storage of tires. 
    Tires shall be properly stored in accord with local, state and federal law. To eliminate potential nuisances of litter, insect breeding, fire hazards and other health risks, at all times during storage: 
(a)  If a business: During hours of operation, store tires in covered or enclosed areas, or under an impermeable cover, in accordance with applicable health and safety laws, including but not limited to the city's fire prevention code, to prevent the accumulation of water; During hours the business is closed, no tires may be left outdoors unless in systems that totally protect the tires from the elements of weather and from the view of the public. Detached structures enclosing tires shall be structures designed for the purpose of such storage and structures approved by the Gulfport Building Code department; with the intention that all such structures meet the structural requirements of the city and shall comply with any building or construction standards or codes. Painted plywood structures are specifically not permitted. 
(b)  Neither tire businesses, tire haulers or individuals shall not store tires outdoors for more than one (1) day. Neither individuals nor tire businesses may use tires as structural members of any kind. 
(c)  Tires shall be secured at tire business facilities to prevent easy access or theft. Lock, chain, or store inside a building or other securable structure; 
(d)  Waste tires shall be accumulated in piles hidden from the view of public and in accordance with the city's fire prevention code; 
(e)  Tires shall be isolated from other stored materials that may create hazardous products if there is a fire, including, but not limited to, lead acid batteries, fuel tanks, solvent barrels, and pesticide containers. 
(f)  Tire businesses shall store no more than one hundred (100) tires in each vehicle service bay or one hundred (100) tires per one thousand five hundred (1,500) square feet of inside storage space, whichever is less. 
(Ord. No. 2759 , § 2(§ 7), 8-21-12) 
Sec. 4-215. - Place for disposal of tires. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or tire business to cause, suffer or allow the dumping of tires at any place in the City of Gulfport including, without limitation, in or on any public highway, road, street, alley, or thoroughfare, including any portion of the right-of-way thereof, any public or private property in the cty or any waters in the city. Notwithstanding the foregoing, residential property owners within the city may properly discard up to four (4) rimless used or waste tires on the curbside immediately in front of the property owner's residence for normal trash pick-up without violating this provision; provided that such tires are discarded for removal within twenty-four (24) hours of the property owner's designated day for trash pick-up. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person or tire business to cause, suffer, or to knowingly allow the disposal of whole tires in an unapproved landfill. 
(c)  Tires shall be properly disposed of in accordance with this article by the delivery and manifesting of tires to an authorized tire disposal or tire recycling facility designated by the State of MS Department of Environmental Quality or equivalent agency of another state. Tire businesses contracting with a tire hauler(s) for the proper disposal of tires generated by such business shall require such hauler(s) utilize a transmittal manifest documenting the pick-up and delivery of the tires to an authorized tire disposal or tire recycling facility. 
(Ord. No. 2759 , § 2(§ 8), 8-21-12) 
Sec. 4-216. - Disposal records/transmittal manifest. 
(a)  Tire businesses shall keep disposal records in the form of a transmittal manifest, as prescribed by the state and in also in accordance with this article, at each business location for a minimum of three (3) years and make such records readily available upon request at reasonable hours for inspection by representatives of the city. The manifest must be maintained and signed off in triplicate and clearly state, in addition to any requirements imposed by state and federal regulations, the following: 
(1)  Name, address, telephone number, permit number and authorized signature of the tire hauler; and 
(2)  Name, address, telephone number, and authorized signature of the tire business who is contracting for the removal of the tires along with the permit number for such business; and 
(3)  Date of removal/transport and the number of tires being transported; and 
(4)  Name, address, and telephone number of the location where the tires are to be delivered; and 
(5)  Upon delivery, the name and signature of the person accepting the tires, including the date of acceptance. 
(b)  The manifest required by this section shall at all times accompany tires while in transit. Any tire business operating in the city, whether based in Gulfport or not, directly delivering waste or used tires generated at its business location to a tire disposal or tire recycling facility must also utilize the transmittal manifest and make such manifest available for production or inspection by representatives of the city, upon request. The original manifest shall be maintained by the tire business evidencing all information and signatures required herein, notwithstanding the use of a tire hauler or direct delivery by the tire business. A tire hauler contracted to deliver tires to a recycling facility or disposal facility must maintain a duplicate copy of the manifest reflecting the delivery of such tires for proper disposal. The tire recycling or tire disposal facility shall sign the manifest upon acceptance of the tires and also maintain a copy of the manifest for the facility's records. 
(Ord. No. 2759 , § 2(§ 9), 8-21-12) 
Sec. 4-217. - Administration/enforcement. 
(a)  Administration and enforcement of this article shall be the responsibility of the City of Gulfport. The city, by and through its authorized representatives, is hereby authorized to enter any property regulated by this article, at reasonable or necessary times in order to properly inspect for violations. 
(b)  The City of Gulfport is hereby authorized to promulgate all such rules and regulations considered necessary and proper to effectuate the implementation and enforcement of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2759 , § 2(§ 10), 8-21-12) 
Sec. 4-218. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  In addition to the penalties set forth in this article, any tire business or tire hauler violating or failing to comply with any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, subject to a civil penalty of up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per offense. Each day of continued violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  The improper storage of one (1) or more tires shall constitute a separate offense per tire and be punishable by a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00) per improperly stored tire. Each day of continued violation of this subsection constitutes a separate offense. 
(c)  The transport of one (1) or more tires without the required permit and decal shall constitute a separate offense per tire and be punishable by a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each tire being transported in violation of this article. Each day of continued violation of this subsection constitutes a separate offense. 
(d)  The improper dumping of a tire by a person, business, entity, or other shall constitute a separate offense per tire and be punishable by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per tire found improperly dumped that is related back to a specific business, entity, or person. Each day of continued violation of this subsection constitutes a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2759 , § 2(§ 11), 8-21-12; Ord. No. 2996, § 2, 5-7-19 ) 
Sec. 4-219. - Injunctive relief. 
    In addition to, and cumulative of, all other penalties herein provided, and except in the case of superseding laws to the contrary, the city shall have the right of injunctive relief, for any violation(s) of this article, or the right to request injunctive relief if the violator is not based in Gulfport and/or is protected by superseding law. Such relief shall be requested by the city administration through a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 2759 , § 2(§ 12), 8-21-12) 
Sec. 4-220. - Tire fee fund. 
    All funds received by the city pursuant to this article shall solely be budgeted to such accounts within the city as deemed fit by the governing authority for beautification purposes including but not limited to landscaping, grass cutting, planting, clearing, watering, cleaning, decorative water fountains, sprinklers and irrigation systems, and other such uses. 
(Ord. No. 2759 , § 2(§ 13), 8-21-12) 
Chapter 5 - LICENSES AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes:
