ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 5-1. - Application, permit required for carnivals and fairs. 
    Before any carnival, circus or street fair shall be permitted to obtain a license or to operate, the manager thereof shall make written application to the mayor and city council for a permit on a blank application furnished by the city on which shall be written the number and character of each separate tent, enclosure or place where an admission fee is charged or collected, either directly or indirectly, to see or hear any performance, or where anything whatsoever may be exhibited, and shall bind itself not to show or permit on its grounds any character of gambling device or show of immoral character or tendency. Provided, however, such application shall be submitted a minimum of thirty (30) days prior to a scheduled event in order to allow action by the city council. 
(Code 1963, § 5-1) 
State Law reference- Municipal regulation of circuses, shows, theaters and other amusements, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 21-19-33; local privilege tax on street fairs, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 27-17-369; carnivals, circuses and fairs, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 75-75-1 et seq. 
Sec. 5-2. - Regulations and requirements for buyers of gold and silver. 
(a)  License required. It shall be unlawful for any buyer to conduct, pursue or carry on the business of purchasing or trading gold, silver or secondhand gold or silver, whether in the form of jewelry, household articles or furnishings, personal effects, bric-a-brac, settings for gems, watches, flatware, service sets or other articles of like kind in the city without first paying to the city clerk the license tax hereinafter prescribed and procuring a license from the city clerk. 
(b)  Buyer defined. The term "buyer" as used herein shall be construed to mean any person engaged in the buying or trading of gold and/or silver in any form described in subsection (a) hereof, within the corporate limits of the city or the police jurisdiction thereof, excluding however: 
(1)  Where such buying or trading is incident to the sale at retail or wholesale of gold and/or silver in the forms described in subsection (a) hereof in finished form; or 
(2)  When substantially all of the buying or trading of gold and/or silver is in the form of finished articles of the form described in subsection (a) hereof, and such articles are ultimately sold or transferred in their finished form to a party other than a "buyer" as defined in this subsection. 
(c)  Amount of license tax. The license tax hereby levied against buyers shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(d)  Application for license. Applicants for license under this section shall file with the city clerk a sworn application in writing, in duplicate, on a form to be furnished to the chief of police prior to opening the business, which shall contain the following: 
(1)  Name and description of the applicant, including social security number, date of birth and place of birth; 
(2)  Full local address of the applicant, and the length of time the applicant has resided within the city; 
(3)  If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the relationship; 
(4)  A description of the nature of the gold or silver buying to be done; 
(5)  The length of time for which the right to do gold or silver buying is desired and the location where such buying is to be done, to include actual days and hours to be open; 
(6)  A photograph of the applicant, taken immediately prior to the date of filing the application, which picture shall be two (2) inches by two (2) inches, showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner; 
(7)  The fingerprints of the applicant, and the names of at least two (2) reliable property owners of the county who will certify as to the applicant's good character and business respectability or, in lieu of the names of such references, such other available evidence as to the good character and business respectability of the applicant, as will enable an investigator to properly evaluate such character and business responsibility; 
(8)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crimes, misdemeanor or violation of any municipal criminal ordinance, in any state, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor. 
All applications must be approved by and all data contained in subsection (d) shall be maintained by the chief of police. Any false statement on the application or conviction of a felony will automatically disqualify the applicant and will result in the forfeiture of the five-hundred-dollar fee. The application fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) will be paid in full at the time of applying for an application. 
(e)  Investigation fee. At the time of filing the application for the permit required by subsection (d), a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be paid to the city clerk to cover the cost of an investigation of the facts stated therein. 
(f)  Investigation of applicant; denial or approval of license; issuance of license. Upon receipt of an application for the license required by subsection (d), the original shall be referred to the chief of police, who shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business and moral character to be made as he deems necessary for the protection of the public good. If, as a result of such an investigation, the applicant's character or business responsibility is found to be unsatisfactory or if he does not otherwise qualify under the provisions of this section, the chief of police shall endorse on such application his disapproval and the reason for the same and return the application to the city clerk who shall notify the applicant that his application his disapproved and that no permit will be issued. If, as a result of such investigation, the character and business responsibility of the applicant are found to be satisfactory, and he otherwise qualifies under this section, the chief of police shall endorse on the application his approval, and return the application to the city clerk who shall deliver to the applicant his license, in the same manner as to other licensees of the city. Applicant shall not operate the business until all articles in subsections (d), (e) and (f) have been satisfactorily completed and approved. 
(g)  Contents of license. The license required by this section shall contain the signature of the city clerk and shall show the names, addresses and photographs of the licensee, the date of issuance and length of time and same shall be operative, as well as the license number and the chief of police shall maintain a copy of same. 
(h)  Record of licenses issued. The city clerk shall keep a permanent record of all licenses issued under this section. 
(i)  Record of purchases. Each applicant who secures a license under this section for purchasing or trading gold or silver in any form set out in this section shall keep a book in which shall be entered promptly at the time of purchase a description of the articles or property purchased, description of which is set forth by the chief of police, the date and hour of the purchase and a description of the person from whom the purchase is made, together with the address of such person and including full name, sex, race, social security number, date of birth, place of birth, driver's license number and state. Each entry of such transaction shall be serially numbered on the book at the time of making the entry. Such buyer shall, on every day except Sunday, before the hour of 10:00 a.m., deliver to the chief of police, upon a form provided by him, a legible transcript of the business done during the business day immediately preceding the filing of the transcript. The report on Monday shall cover the transcript of the book covering Saturday's purchases and Sunday's, if any. 
(j)  Registration of licensees. Each licensee under this section shall promptly, prior to the beginning of business, register with the chief of police, in the book kept for that purpose, his name, address and every place where he carries on business or stores property. 
(k)  Licensee's records to be open for inspection by chief of police. The books and records kept by each licensee of the articles described in this section shall be open for inspection by the chief of police or by any officer of the police department of 
the city at all times and the licensee and his agents and employees shall at all times exhibit the book to such officers on request. 
(l)  Identification of articles. Each licensee under this section purchasing or trading gold or silver in any form set out in this section shall attach to or place on each such article purchased a tag or other identifying mark or label numbered to correspond with the serial number of the book required by subsection (i) to be kept; except, where small articles are bought in bulk and are too numerous to conveniently tag or mark, an identifying number shall be placed on the container or wrapper in which the articles are kept or placed and the chief of police shall be notified prior to purchasing such bulk items, or any item altered from its original form. 
(m)  Holding period before disposal of property permitted. The property of the kind described in subsection (a) shall be held in the same form, shape or condition in which they are purchased, without mutilation, melting, reduction to block or lump form, or destruction of the form thereof, for a period of five (5) days after the hour when the licensee reports the purchase to the chief of police, during which time the article shall be open to inspection or examination by the chief of police, or such officer of the police department as may be delegated to make such examinations or inspections. 
(n)  Definition of "applicant." The word "applicant" when used herein shall include the plural where applicable, and all agents, officers, servants or employees of the applicant in the city, if the applicant is other than a sole proprietor. 
(o)  Applicability of section; violation. The provisions of this section shall be binding upon every employee or agent of the buyer of the articles described in this section, and it shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any such licensee or his agents, servants, officers or employees to fail or refuse to carry out the provisions of this section. Any person who shall violate any provision of this section or do business within the city, as defined in this section, without first obtaining a permit or license as provided herein shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1963, § 17-25) 
Secs. 5-3-5-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[2] 

Footnotes:

No. 1829, § 1, 1-31-89; Ord. No. 1943, 3-16-93; Ord. No. 2018, § 1, 6-20-95; Ord. No. 2572, § 2, 1-8-08; Ord. No. 2595, § 2, 7-22-08. 

Sec. 5-26. - [Rules and regulations.] 
    The Rules and Regulations of the Motor Vehicle for Hire Authority, as adopted by the authority and on file in the offices of the city clerk and the clerk of the city council, are hereby adopted and incorporated herein by reference and shall regulate and govern the operation of motor vehicles for hire (as that term is defined in the said Rules and Regulations) in the City of Gulfport.

Every day any violation of the Rules and Regulations of the Motor Vehicle for Hire Authority shall continue shall constitute a separate offence.

ARTICLE III. - TRAILER CAMPS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Supplementary zoning regulations, App. A, § IV. 
State Law reference- Local privilege taxes on tourist camps and trailer parks and courts, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 27-17-381; sanitary code for house trailers, house trailer camps and tourist camps, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 41-25-13; The Uniform Standards Code for Factory Manufactured Movable Homes Law, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 75-49-1 et seq.; violation of law or rules as to movable homes, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 75-49-19. 

Sec. 5-86. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    House trailer, mobile home or trailer shall mean a vehicle without power that must be towed by an automobile or truck having a power plant or any vehicle having its own power plant, and which house trailer, mobile home or trailer can be used as a dwelling unit by one (1) or more persons; and should a vehicle with or without its own power plant such as described hereinabove which is not now suited for the habitation of one (1) or more persons be altered in such manner that same would become habitable, then in such event, it would come within the definition of trailer or house trailer or mobile home as set forth and intended herein. No combination of one (1) or more of such units, nor any modification or alteration thereof, nor any attempt to convert such house trailers, mobile homes or trailers to permanent dwelling units shall prevent same from coming within this definition. Any questions as to whether or not such dwelling unit does come within the definition as set forth herein shall be decided by the building official of the city subject to the right of the interested parties to appeal such decision to proper governing bodies or authorities. 
    Trailer camp shall mean any premises where more than one (1) house trailer is parked for living or sleeping purposes or any premises used or hired out for the purpose of supplying to the public a parking space for more than one (1) house trailer used for living or sleeping purposes. In the event a trailer camp is located in the city, it shall contain a minimum of fifty thousand (50,000) square feet and shall constitute a business use of such land comparable to a public garage, and as such shall be located only as authorized in the zoning ordinance (Appendix A). No trailer units or mobile homes situated in a trailer park shall be located nearer than five (5) feet from the property line on the front, sides and rear of such property. 
(Code 1963, §§ 26-1, 26-3) 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 6; zoning, App. A. 
State Law reference- Definitions relating to movable homes, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 75-49-3. 
Sec. 5-87. - Parking in trailer camp or park; storage of merchandise. 
    Overnight parking of house trailers, mobile homes or trailers shall be prohibited in any street or on any property in the city, public or private, or in any residential section of the city except in an approved trailer camp or park; provided further, that no house trailers, mobile homes or trailers shall be used for permanent storage of merchandise on premises at any time. 
(Code 1963, § 26-2) 
State Law reference- Power of city to adopt local zoning regulations to lesser congestion in the streets, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 17-1-9. 
Sec. 5-88. - Access, area and setback requirements. 
    If a trailer camp site is constructed, it shall have access to public streets by directly abutting thereon, or by means of a private hard surface road not less than twenty (20) feet wide, to which every trailer unit located therein shall have direct access. If such trailer camp shall be subdivided into trailer units, each unit shall contain not less than one thousand (1,000) square feet of ground area and shall not be less than twenty-five (25) feet in width, and the boundaries thereof shall be plainly and permanently marked. No trailer or towing vehicle shall be closer than five (5) feet to the side boundary of its rented unit in a trailer camp. 
(Code 1963, § 26-4) 
Sec. 5-89. - Garbage and trash disposal. 
    An adequate system for the collection and safe disposal of garbage and trash shall be made available and provided for by the owners of each trailer camp and such shall be located and situated in such manner that it would be detached from the trailer units and the camp building. 
(Code 1963, § 26-5) 
Cross reference- Garbage, trash and weeds, § 4-141 et seq. 
Sec. 5-90. - Underground gasoline storage. 
    There shall be standard underground storage in the handling of gasoline as required by ordinances of the city and by the laws of the state. 
(Code 1963, § 26-6) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, § 10-26 et seq. 
State Law reference- Gasoline and petroleum products, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 75-55-1 et seq. 
Sec. 5-91. - Electric wiring and equipment. 
    The trailer camp's electric wiring and equipment shall comply with the codes of the city regulating and governing same. Camp operators shall provide at each unit a means of connecting the trailer frame grounding terminal to an effective ground when outside current is provided for and connected to such house trailer or mobile home. 
(Code 1963, § 26-7) 
Cross reference- Electricity, § 3-176 et seq. 
Sec. 5-92. - Sewer facilities. 
    Suitable sewer facilities shall be provided, and such facilities shall be connected to the regular sanitary sewer system of the city where available, or to approved septic tanks in areas where the sewer system of the city is not available. 
(Code 1963, § 26-8) 
Cross reference- Water and sewers, Ch. 11. 
Secs. 5-93-5-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS AND TRANSIENT VENDORS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal regulation of transient vendors and photographers, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 21-19-35. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 5-101-5-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS 

Sec. 5-111. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Peddler means any person, whether a resident of the city or not, traveling by foot, wagon, automotive vehicle or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, carrying, conveying, or transporting goods, wares, merchandise, meat, fish, vegetables, fruits, truck garden or farm products or provisions, offering and exposing them for sale, or making sales and delivering articles to purchasers. The word peddler shall include the words hawker and huckster. 
    Solicitor means any person, whether a resident of the city or not, traveling either by foot, wagon, automobile, or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, taking or attempting to take orders, subscriptions, contributions, or who without necessarily having the intention of making a direct sale, distributes literature, pamphlets, handbills, or samples. Solicitors shall also include persons or organizations who solicit contributions for charitable, religious, educational, community, recreation or similar, nonprofit purposes which have qualified for exemption from federal income tax under Section 501(c) and (d) of the Internal Revenue Code. Charitable or nonprofit organizations which do not qualify for such exemption must have a local sponsor in order to solicit within the city. To qualify as a local sponsor, one (1) must be a resident of the city and have resided within the city for at least one (1) year. 
(Code 1963, § 19-1) 
Sec. 5-112. - Applicability. 
(a)  The provisions of this division shall not apply to any person or to any member of his immediate household going from place to place, person to person, house to house, or dealer to dealer and selling or offering to sell dairy, poultry, orchard or farm products raised, produced or grown by him or his immediate household in the city or seafood caught by him or his immediate household. 
(b)  The provisions of this division shall not apply to any "transient vendor," as defined in section 5-123. 
(Code 1963, § 19-1) 
Sec. 5-113. - License. 
(a)  Required. Any and all peddlers and solicitors shall apply for and be in receipt of a license before engaging in any activity in the city. 
(b)  Filing of application. Application for a license shall be made in writing to the office of the city clerk. 
(c)  Approval, denial. The city clerk shall have five (5) working days from the date of the application to approve or deny the issuance of a license. There shall automatically be a five-day waiting period before out-of-town solicitors will be allowed to solicit within the city, in order that the police department may conduct an investigation into the character and background of the applicant. The city clerk shall furnish a copy of the license to the chief of police. 
(d)  Qualifications of applicant. No license shall issue to any person or firm or any employee, or agent thereof, who has been convicted of a violation of this division, or who has had his or its penal bond forfeited either voluntarily, or through appropriate legal proceedings. 
(e)  Highway hold-up activities. No solicitation will be allowed by conducting highway hold-up activities within the city, except when an applicant has applied for an exception to this provision to be granted by the city council only after a hearing in which the applicant shows that a general public interest would be served by such solicitation. A highway hold-up activity is defined as solicitation conducted for any purpose along any street, avenue, boulevard, road, alley, lane, viaducts and all other public thoroughfares in the city. 
(f)  Residential areas. Only those persons who are citizens of the state, or who are agents of corporations domiciled in the state, or who are agents of foreign corporations qualified to do business in the state shall be allowed to solicit in residential areas. 
(g)  Basis for denial. In order to protect the local citizenry against crime and preserve the private property, peace and comfort of the citizens from those persons who are not known, or easily identifiable or traceable, the city clerk may deny the issuance of a license upon the determination that such activity would endanger the public health, welfare, and safety. 
(Code 1963, § 19-2) 
Sec. 5-114. - Contents of license application. 
    Applicants for peddler's license must file with the city clerk a sworn application giving the following information: 
(1)  Name and description of applicant; 
(2)  Address, legal and local; 
(3)  A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be sold; 
(4)  If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the exact relationship; 
(5)  If a vehicle is to be used, a description of the same, together with license number or other means of identification; 
(6)  A photograph of the applicant, taken within sixty (60) days immediately prior to the date of the filing of the application, which picture shall be two (2) inches by two (2) inches showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner; 
(7)  Evidence as to the good character and business responsibility of the applicant as will enable an investigator to properly evaluate such character and business responsibility. 
(Code 1963, § 19-3) 
Sec. 5-115. - Licenses not transferable. 
    No peddler's license shall be used at any time by any person other than the one to whom it was issued. 
(Code 1963, § 19-4) 
Sec. 5-116. - Duty to exhibit license. 
    Peddlers are required to exhibit their license at the request of any citizen. 
(Code 1963, § 19-5) 
Sec. 5-117. - Altering licenses prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to alter or deface any license issued pursuant to this division. 
(Code 1963, § 19-6) 
State Law reference- Altering licenses deemed to be forgery, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 97-21-35. 
Sec. 5-118. - Expiration of licenses. 
    Unless otherwise provided by law, all peddlers' licenses shall expire one (1) year from the date of issuance. 
(Code 1963, § 19-7) 
Sec. 5-119. - License fee; bond. 
(a)  Amount of license fee. Upon every person, agent, or employee of such person or organization operating as a peddler or solicitor, there is hereby levied an annual license fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). All persons employed by the solicitor or peddler must have separate licenses. 
(b)  Nonprofit organizations. No fee shall be levied, nor a bond required if the solicitation is for the purpose of seeking donations or gifts for an eligible charitable, religious, educational, community or similar nonprofit purpose, provided, however, that a permit must first be obtained and carried at all times. Provided, further, when solicitation is conducted by a group or organization composed predominantly of minors, the adult sponsor or leader may carry only one (1) permit for the whole group. 
(c)  Bond. Peddlers and solicitors shall, in advance of making any solicitation, furnish and make payable to the city a good and sufficient penal bond in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) conditioned that if such solicitors, or any employees, officers, or agents thereof, shall comply with all of the provisions of this division relating to peddlers and solicitors, the obligations shall be void, otherwise, to remain in full force and effect. 
(Code 1963, § 19-8) 
State Law reference- Bond of transient vendors and traveling photographers, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 21-19-35. 
Sec. 5-120. - Prohibited acts, exceptions; revocation of license; failure to comply. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for a peddler or solicitor or any person in his behalf to: 
(1)  Shout, make any outcry, blow a horn, ring a bell, or use any sound device or musical instrument, including any loud speaking radio or sound amplifying system, or permit such action, for the purpose of attracting attention to any goods, wares, or merchandise which such licensee proposes to sell. 
(2)  Peddle or solicit from the hours of darkness till 8:00 a.m. or any time when a sign has been posted on a building or residence stating "No Peddlers or Solicitors" or words to that effect. 
(3)  Make any representations to persons being solicited of any facts in conflict with the statements on the application filed with the city clerk, or to omit advising the person solicited of the exact name of the soliciting organization or person and the purpose for which the donation is requested. 
(4)  Peddle or solicit from any stationary position except as otherwise authorized; nor claim any exclusive right to any transitory or stationary location in the public streets, or upon public property, and he shall not be permitted to operate in any congested area or public streets or sidewalks where his operations impede or inconvenience the public. 
(b)  The prohibitions herein contained shall not preclude the peddling from door-to-door or from vehicles of fresh food products of farm or garden, nor bona fide deliveries of goods, wares, merchandise or food made on a regular route to regular customers, nor shall it preclude the delivery and sale of any items that have been previously ordered. 
(c)  Failure to adhere to any of these provisions shall result in the revocation of the vendor's license with no refund of any of the charges herein imposed. 
(Code 1963, §§ 17-19, 19-9) 
Sec. 5-121. - Appeals. 
    Any person aggrieved by the action of the chief of police or the clerk in the denial of an application for a peddler's permit as or in the decision with reference to the revocation of a peddler's permit as provided herein shall have the right of appeal to the city council. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the city council, within fourteen (14) days after notice of the action complained of has been mailed to such person's last known address, a written statement setting forth fully the grounds for the appeal. The city council shall set a time and place for a hearing on such appeal and written notice of such hearing shall be given to the appellant. Appeals from revocation of a license shall be in the same manner as provided in this section. 
(Code 1963, § 19-12) 
Sec. 5-122. - Temporary peddlers license for parades and special events. 
    Organizations and individuals desiring to peddle and/or sell food and/or other items at parades and/or certain special events (events limited to two (2) days in duration) may obtain a temporary peddler's license by applying therefore as set forth in this division. Requirements and regulations of this division set forth in sections 5-113, 5-114, 5-115, 5-116, 5-117, 5-118, 5-119, 5-120 and 5-121 shall apply to the application and the temporary license granted pursuant to this section except as otherwise stated herein. The temporary license shall allow the holder to sell and/or peddle food and/or other items for a period of two (2) days (consecutive or nonconsecutive) at parades and/or special events held on public property, including the rights-of-way of the city. The days that the temporary license is valid shall be marked on the face thereof by the city clerk. Peddlers in possession of a temporary license may peddle at any time during a parade or event and, where the event is held at night, until one hour after the close of the parade or event. 
(Ord. No. 2713, § 2, 3-8-11) 
DIVISION 3. - TRANSIENT VENDORS 

Sec. 5-123. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Transient business means any business conducted for the sale of merchandise or services that is carried on in any building, structure, motor vehicle, railroad car or real property for a period of less than six (6) months in each year. 
    Transient vendor means any person who transacts transient business in this city either in one (1) locality or by traveling from place to place in this city. The term includes a vendor who for the purposes of carrying on such business hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, motor vehicle, railroad car or real property. 
Sec. 5-124. - Applicability. 
(a)  The provisions of this division shall not apply to: 
(1)  Civic and nonprofit organizations, wholesale sales to retail merchants by commercial travelers, or agents selling in the usual course of business; 
(2)  Wholesale trade shows or conventions; 
(3)  Sales of goods, wares, services or merchandise by sample, catalogue or brochure for future delivery; 
(4)  Fairs and convention center activities conducted primarily for amusement or entertainment; 
(5)  Any general sale, fair, auction or bazaar sponsored by a church or religious organization; 
(6)  Garage sales held on premises devoted to residential use; 
(7)  Sales or repairs of crafts or sales or repairs of items made by hand by the person making the crafts or items; 
(8)  Duly licensed flea markets operating from a fixed location; 
(9)  Sales of agricultural, dairy, poultry, seafood or forest management products or services related to forest management or silvicultural activities, except nursery products and foliage plants; or 
(10)  Sales made by a seller at residential premises under an invitation issued by the owner or legal occupant of the premises unless the sales are made by a transient vendor or his agent at the premises. 
(b)  A transient vendor not otherwise exempted from this division is not exempted from this division because of a temporary association with a local dealer, auctioneer, trader, contractor or merchant, or by conducting the transient business in connection with or in the name of any local dealer, auctioneer, trader, contractor or merchant. 
Sec. 5-125. - Compliance generally. 
    A transient vendor may not transact business in this city unless the vendor, and the owner of the merchandise or provider of the services to be offered if the merchandise is not owned or the services are not provided by the vendor, has secured a license in accordance with this division and otherwise complied with this division. 
Sec. 5-126. - License. 
    A transient vendor who desires to transact business in this city shall apply for and obtain a license in this city. A license issued by the city authorizes a transient vendor to transact business within the city. 
Sec. 5-127. - Contents of license application. 
(a)  A license application under this division shall be filed with the city tax collector and must include: 
(1)  The name and permanent address of the transient vendor making the application; 
(2)  A statement describing the kind of business to be conducted, the length of time for which the applicant desires to transact the business, and the proposed location of the business; 
(3)  The name and permanent address of the applicant's registered agent or office; and 
(4)  Proof that the applicant has acquired all other required city, county and state permits and licenses. 
(b)  If the applicant is an association or a corporation, the applicant must also include the names and addresses of the members of the association or the officers of the corporation. If the applicant is a corporation, the application must state the date of incorporation and the state in which it was incorporated. If the applicant is a corporation organized under the laws of another state, the applicant must state the date on which the corporation qualified to transact business as a foreign corporation in this state. 
Sec. 5-128. - License forms. 
    License applications, license certificates and license renewals issued under this division shall be on uniform forms prepared by the state tax commission. 
Sec. 5-129. - Registered agent; city records; service of process. 
(a)  Each applicant for a transient vendor license shall designate a registered agent on the license application. The registered agent must be a resident of the city and shall be the agent on whom any process, notice or demand required or permitted by law to be served on the licensee may be served. The registered agent must agree in writing to act as the agent. The license applicant shall file a copy of the agreement with the license application. 
(b)  The city tax collector shall maintain an alphabetical list of all transient vendors in the city and the names and addresses of their registered agents. 
(c)  If a transient vendor who does business in the city fails to have or to maintain a registered agent in the city or if the designated registered agent cannot be found at the stated permanent address, the city tax collector is the agent of the transient vendor for service of process, notices or demands. Service on the tax collector is made by delivering to his office duplicate copies of the process, notice or demand. If such a process, notice or demand is served on the tax collector, he shall immediately forward one (1) copy by registered or certified mail to the permanent address of the transient vendor. 
(d)  This section does not limit or otherwise affect the right of any person to serve a process, notice or demand in any other manner authorized by law. 
Sec. 5-130. - License fee; bonds. 
(a)  Each applicant for a transient vendor license shall include a license fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) with the application, which fee shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. The applicant shall also execute a cash bond or a surety bond issued by a corporate surety authorized to do business in this state in an amount that is the lesser of either two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) or five (5) percent of the wholesale value of any merchandise or service to be offered for sale by the applicant. The surety bond shall be issued in favor of the state and shall be conditioned upon payment of: 
(1)  All taxes due from the applicant to the state or to the city; 
(2)  Any fines assessed against the applicant or the applicant's agents or employees for a violation of this division; and 
(3)  Any judgment rendered against the applicant or the applicant's agents or employees in a cause of action commenced by a purchaser of merchandise or services not later than one (1) year after the date the merchandise or services were sold by the applicant. 
(b)  The transient vendor shall maintain such bond during the period that the vendor conducts business in the city and for a period of one (1) year after the termination of the business. After the transient vendor furnishes satisfactory proof to the city tax collector that the vendor has satisfied all claims of purchasers of merchandise from or services offered by the vendor and that all sales taxes and other applicable taxes have been paid, the bond shall be released. 
(c)  Transient vendors and traveling photographers shall, in advance of any solicitations, furnish to the city a good and sufficient penal bond in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) conditioned that if such transient vendors and traveling photographers shall comply with all of the provisions of the city ordinances relating to transient vendors and traveling photographers such obligation shall be void, otherwise, to remain in full force and effect. 
Sec. 5-131. - Issuance, transfer, validity, expiration and renewal of license. 
(a)  The city tax collector shall issue a transient vendor license under this division only if all requirements of this division have been met. The license is not transferable and is valid only within the territorial limits of the city. A license expires ninety (90) days after the day of issuance. 
(b)  A license may be renewed on payment of a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) renewal fee and filing for renewal with the city tax collector before the expiration of the current license. 
Sec. 5-132. - Postings; vendor's record. 
    While transacting his business, a transient vendor shall post in a prominent place, so that they may clearly be seen by purchasers of the merchandise or services which he is offering, his state sales tax number, his transient vendor license number, and a statement that he is required to give purchasers, at the time of payment, receipts for purchases that include sales tax. The postings required in this section shall be written in bold, legible letters and numbers not less than one (1) inch in height. The transient vendor shall keep a running total of his sales. 
Sec. 5-133. - Violations. 
    Any person who knowingly or intentionally operates a transient business without a valid license as provided by this division or who knowingly or intentionally advertises, offers for sale, or sells any merchandise or services in violation of this division shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or be imprisoned not more than ninety (90) days, or be both fined and imprisoned. Such person may also be proceeded against by suit, and the city tax collector may seize and sell any property of the person liable for the tax and penalty in the same manner as property of taxpayers delinquent for the payment of ad valorem taxes due on personal property may be distrained and sold. 
Secs. 5-134, 5-135. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SECONDHAND DEALERS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Pawnbrokers, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 75-67-1 et seq. 

Sec. 5-136. - Definitions. 
    A "dealer in secondhand personal property," when used in this article, is defined as any person engaged, either wholly or in part, in the business of buying secondhand or used personal property for the purpose of resale and reuse as such. "Secondhand personal property," above referred to, shall be defined to be the following articles: Secondhand or used furniture, household and business equipment or accessories, garden tools, plumbing equipment and building materials. 
(Code 1963, § 22-1) 
Sec. 5-137. - Records, reports required. 
    Any such dealer purchasing such secondhand or used personal property shall keep a book and write therein or cause to be written therein, in plain and legible hand in the English language, the true name and address of all persons from whom such dealer has acquired such personal property, and the character and quantity of such personal property. Such dealer, in addition to the foregoing requirements, shall have a printed form statement and report, in duplicate, which shall be supplied by the police department and shall be accurately filled out by the dealer at the time of the making of such purchase, and one (1) of which statement and report shall be delivered by the dealer to the police department within twenty-four (24) hours after the making of such purchase, setting forth in the statement and report the name of the dealer, the name of the vendor an his place of residence, a statement of the character and quantity of the personal property so purchased, the price paid therefor, the name of the party from whom such vendor acquired such personal property. Such statement and report shall be signed by the dealer and countersigned by the vendor of the property. All records of such dealer, pertaining to the purchase of such personal property and required by this article, shall be kept by him on file in his place of business for a period of not less than one (1) year from the date of the transaction, and shall at all times be open to the inspection and examination of the police officers of the city. 
(Code 1963, § 22-2; Ord. No. 1805, § 1, 5-17-88) 
State Law reference- Books kept by pawnbrokers, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 75-67-11 et seq.; inspection of books, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 75-67-15. 
Sec. 5-138. - Purchases from certain minors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any such dealer to purchase, buy, or barter or otherwise take from any person under eighteen (18) years of age any personal property, unless he shall first obtain from the parents of such minor a written consent to acquire the same. If such minor has no parents, then the written consent of the person standing in the relation of parent shall be obtained, or if such minor has no parent or persons standing in the relation of parent, then the matter must be submitted to the chief of police and his consent obtained in writing. 
(Code 1963, § 22-3) 
State Law reference- Persons eighteen years of age or older competent to contract in matters affecting personal property, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 93-19-13. 
Secs. 5-139-5-155. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - RESERVED[6]
