(a)  Definitions. "Grade crossing" as used in this article shall mean any intersection at grade of a railroad with a street of the city which now or at any time hereafter: 
(1)  Is used by at least three thousand (3,000) motor vehicles in any twenty-four-hour period; or, 
(2)  Is the location of as many as two (2) motor vehicle-train collisions within any twenty-four-month period. 
(b)  Signals required. All railroads entering the city are hereby required to erect and maintain at all grade crossings on their main lines flashing red signal lights and bells so equipped as to operate automatically at any time a train is approaching within one thousand (1,000) feet of such grade crossing and continue to operate until such train has passed through the grade crossing. 
(c)  Signals to be in addition to any others required. All lights and bells required by this article shall be in addition to any other signs, lights or warnings required by any other ordinance or statute. 
(d)  Additional installations. In the installation of lights and bells required by subsection (c), there shall be a separate installation on each side of the city street in order that there will be at least one (1) such installation facing oncoming motor vehicular traffic from each direction. On city streets of four (4) traffic lanes or more divided by a neutral ground or median strip, there shall be provided at least two (2) additional installations in the neutral ground or median strip so that there will be at least one (1) additional installation facing oncoming motor vehicular traffic from each direction. 
(e)  Violations. Failure to erect and maintain lights and bells as required by subsections (b) and (c) shall be a misdemeanor and each day that such violation continues without a reasonable effort to correct same shall be a separate offense. Any person who operates a train through an intersection required to be equipped, but which is not equipped in the manner required by subsections (b) and (c) hereof, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Any person who operates a train through an intersection equipped in the manner required by this article at a time when such equipment is not operating in the manner required by subsections (b) and (c) hereof shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1963, § 21-22) 
State Law reference- Railroad crossing signs, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 77-9-247; obedience to signal indicating approach of train, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 77-9-249. 
Sec. 6-424. - Stops at railroad tracks in obedience to signal indicating approach of train. 
(a)  Whenever any person driving a vehicle approaches a railroad grade crossing and a clearly visible electric or mechanical signal device gives warning of the immediate approach of a train, the driver of such vehicle shall stop within fifty (50) feet but not less than ten (10) feet from the nearest track of such railroad and shall not proceed until he can do so safely. 
(b)  The driver of a vehicle shall stop and remain standing and not traverse such a grade crossing when a crossing gate is lowered or when a human flagman gives or continues to give a signal of the approach or passage of a train. 
(Code 1963, § 25-119) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 63-3-1007. 
Secs. 6-425-6-440. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVIII. - PROCEDURE ON ARREST[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Traffic violations procedure, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 63-9-1 et seq. 

Sec. 6-441. - Traffic tickets. 
(a)  All traffic tickets shall be printed in the original and at least two (2) copies and such other copies as may be prescribed by the state auditor. All traffic tickets shall be uniform as prescribed by the state auditor and the attorney general; provided, however, that the state auditor and the attorney general may alter the form and content of traffic tickets to meet the varying requirements of the different law enforcement agencies. The state auditor and the attorney general may also prescribe a separate traffic ticket to be used only for violations of the "Mississippi Implied Consent Law." 
(b)  Every traffic ticket issued by any police officer for any violation of traffic or motor vehicle laws shall be issued on the uniform traffic ticket consisting of an original and at least two (2) copies and such other copies as may be prescribed by the state auditor. Such traffic ticket shall show, among other necessary information, the name of the issuing officer, the name of the court in which the cause is to be heard, and the date and time such person is to appear to answer the charge. The uniform traffic ticket shall make provision thereon for information which will constitute a complaint charging the offense for which the ticket was issued, and when duly sworn to and filed with a court of competent jurisdiction prosecution may proceed thereunder. 
(c)  All traffic tickets shall be bound in book form, shall be consecutively numbered and each traffic ticket shall be accounted for to the officer issuing such book. Such traffic ticket books shall be issued to each police officer by the clerk of the municipal court. 
(d)  The clerk of the municipal court shall keep a record of all traffic ticket books issued and to whom issued, accounting for all books printed and issued. 
(e)  The original traffic ticket shall be delivered by the officer issuing the traffic ticket to the clerk of the court to which it is returnable to be retained in that court's records and the number noted on the docket. The officer issuing the traffic ticket shall also give the accused a copy of the traffic ticket. The clerk of the court shall file a copy with the state auditor within forty-five (45) days after judgment is rendered showing the amount of the fine and cost or, in cases in which no judgment has been rendered, within one hundred twenty (120) days after issuance of the ticket. Other copies that are prescribed by the state auditor shall be filed or retained as may be designated by the state auditor. All copies shall be retained for at least two (2) years. 
(f)  Failure to comply with the provisions of this section shall constitute a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1963, §§ 25-318, 25-320, 25-323) 
State Law reference- Uniform Traffic Ticket Law, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 63-9-21. 
Sec. 6-442. - Duties of arresting officers. 
    Except when authorized or directed under state law to immediately take a person before a magistrate for the violation of any traffic laws, a police officer who halts a person for such violation other than for the purpose of giving him a warning or warning notice and does not take such person into custody under arrest, shall take the name, address, and operator's license number of such person, the registered number of the motor vehicle involved, and such other pertinent information as may be necessary, and shall issue to him a traffic ticket containing the information described in section 6-441. The officer, upon receiving the written promise of the alleged violation to answer as specified in the citation, shall release such person from custody. 
(Code 1963, § 25-319) 
Sec. 6-443. - Disposition of tickets, charges. 
(a)  Upon the filing of an original traffic ticket in the municipal court as provided in section 6-441, the ticket may be disposed of only by trial in such court or by other official action by a judge of such court, including forfeiture of bail. 
(b)  The chief of police shall maintain or cause to be maintained in connection with every traffic ticket issued by a member of the police department a record of the disposition of the charge by the municipal court. 
(c)  The chief of police shall also maintain or cause to be maintained a record of all warrants issued by the municipal court or by any other court on the traffic violation charges and which are delivered to the police department for service, and of the final disposition of all such warrnts. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful and official misconduct for any member of the police department or other officer or public employee to dispose of, alter, or deface a traffic ticket or any copy thereof, or the record of the issuance or disposition of any traffic ticket, complaint, or warrant, in a manner other than as required in this article or state law. 
(Code 1963, § 25-320) 
Sec. 6-444. - Illegal cancellation of tickets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cancel or solicit the cancellation of any traffic citation in any manner other than as provided by this article. 
(Code 1963, § 25-321) 
Sec. 6-445. - Audit of records and reports. 
(a)  Every record of traffic tickets, complaints thereon, and warrants issued therefor required in this article may be audited at least annually by the city clerk who may submit a report of such audit together with a summary thereof to the mayor. 
(b)  For the purpose of this article, the city clerk or his duly authorized representatives shall have access at all times to all necessary records, files and papers of the municipal court, its traffic violations bureau, and the police department. 
(Code 1963, § 25-322) 
Sec. 6-446. - Failure to obey citation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate his written promise to appear given to an officer upon the issuance of a traffic citation regardless of the disposition of the charge for which such citation was originally issued. 
(Code 1963, § 25-324) 
State Law reference- Trial in the absence of the accused, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 99-17-9. 
Sec. 6-447. - Citation required on illegally parked vehicle. 
    Whenever any motor vehicle without driver is found parked or stopped in violation of any other restrictions imposed by ordinance or regulation or by state law, the officer finding such vehicle shall take its registration number and may take any other information displayed on the vehicle which may identify its user and shall conspicuously affix to such vehicle a traffic citation, on a form provided by the city clerk, for the driver to answer to the charges against him on or before the court date specified in such traffic citation and at a place specified in the citation. 
(Code 1963, § 25-325; Ord. No. 1881, § 1, 7-17-90) 
Sec. 6-448. - Failure to comply with citation on parked vehicle. 
    If a violator of the restrictions on stopping, standing or parking under the traffic laws, ordinances or regulations does not appear in response to a traffic citation affixed to such motor vehicle on or before the court date specified in such citation, the traffic violations bureau shall send to the owner of the motor vehicle to which the traffic citation was affixed a letter informing him of the violation and warning him that, in the event such letter is disregarded for a period of ten (10) days, a warrant of arrest will be issued. 
(Code 1963, § 25-326; Ord. No. 1881, § 2, 7-17-90) 
Sec. 6-449. - Presumption in reference to illegal parking. 
(a)  In any prosecution charging a violation of any law or regulation governing the standing or parking of a vehicle, proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked in violation of any such law or regulation, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was at the time of such parking the registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle was the person who parked or placed such vehicle at the point where, and for the time during which, such violation occurred. 
(b)  The foregoing stated presumption shall apply only when the procedure as prescribed in sections 6-441 and 6-446 has been followed. 
(Code 1963, § 25-327) 
Sec. 6-450. - When warrant to be issued. 
    In the event any person fails to comply with a traffic citation given to such person or attached to a vehicle or fails to make appearance pursuant to a summons directing an appearance in the municipal court or traffic violations bureau, or if any person fails or refuses to deposit bail as required and within the time permitted, the municipal court shall secure and issue a warrant for his arrest. 
(Code 1963, § 25-328) 
Sec. 6-451. - Record of traffic cases; report of convictions to department of public safety. 
(a)  The municipal judge shall keep or cause to be kept a full record of the proceedings of every case in which a person is charged with any violation of law regulating the operation of vehicles on the highways, streets or roads of this city. 
(b)  Unless otherwise sooner required by law, within forty-five (45) days after the conviction of a person upon a charge of violating any law regulating the operation of vehicles on the highways, streets or roads of this city, the judge or clerk of the municipal court shall prepare and immediately forward to the department an abstract of the record of said court covering the case in which the person was so convicted, which abstract must be certified by the person so authorized to prepare the same to be true and correct. 
(c)  Such abstract must be made upon a form approved by the department, and shall include the name and address of the party charged, the registration number of the vehicle involved, the nature of the offense, the date of hearing, the plea, the judgment, and if the fine was satisfied by prepayment or appearance bond forfeiture, and the amount of the fine or forfeiture, as the case may be. 
(d)  The failure by refusal or neglect of any such judicial officer to comply with any of the requirements of this section shall constitute misconduct in office and shall be grounds for removal therefrom. 
(Code 1963, § 25-329) 
State Law reference- Convictions to be reported to department of public safety, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 63-9-17. 
Sec. 6-452. - Disposition of fines and forfeitures. 
    All fines or forfeitures collected upon conviction or upon the forfeiture of bail of any person charged with a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or other traffic law, ordinance or regulation shall be paid into the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1963, § 25-330) 
State Law reference- Court maintained by county, disposition of fines and forfeitures, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 63-9-13. 
Sec. 6-453. - Authority to impound vehicles. 
(a)  Towing away abandoned or illegally parked vehicles. The police department and all members thereof assigned to traffic duty and all municipal law enforcement officers are hereby authorized to remove and tow away, or have removed and towed away, by commercial towing service, any currently licensed car, trailer, or other vehicle which is left unattended on a public street, road or highway, other public property, or in any other area where it may be by any other ordinance of the city illegally parked for a period of at least three (3) days; or any unattended unlicensed or expired licensed car, trailer, or other vehicle illegally parked in any public parking facilities or facilities provided by the city; or in any place where such parked or abandoned vehicle creates or constitutes a traffic hazard, public safety concern, blocks the use of a fire hydrant or obstructs or may obstruct the movement of any emergency vehicle; or in any other area where it may be by any other ordinance of the city illegally parked. The police department and all municipal law enforcement officers are hereby authorized to remove and tow away immediately, or have removed and towed away immediately, by commercial towing service, mobile homes and oversized loads abandoned on a public street, road or highway or other public property. Said vehicle removed from a street or highway shall be removed to the nearest garage or other place of safety, or to a garage designated or maintained by the police department or, otherwise, maintained by the city, or to the nearest garage or other properly zoned place of safety and within the city limits that is owned, leased, or maintained by the commercial towing service. When a vehicle is removed from either public or private property as authorized herein, the owner of said vehicle will be responsible for all towing costs, storage and other expenses associated with the removal of same. 
(b)  Notice in writing. Whenever an officer removes a vehicle from a street, as authorized in this section, and the officer knows or ascertains from the registration records in the vehicle the name and address of the owner thereof, such officer shall, within five (5) days, unless said vehicle is redeemed prior to said five-day period, give, or cause to be given, notice in writing to such owner of the fact of such removal and the reasons therefor and of the place to which such vehicle has been removed. In the event that any such vehicle is stored in a public garage, a copy of such notice shall be given to the proprietor of such garage. 
(c)  Whenever any officer removes a vehicle from a street under this section and does not know or is not able to ascertain the name of the owner, or for any other reason is unable to give the notice to the owner as hereinabove provided, and in the event that the vehicle is not returned to the owner within a period of five (5) days, then, in that event, the officer shall by mail immediately send, or cause to be sent, a written report of such removal to the state department, whose duty it is to register motor vehicles, and shall file a copy of such notice with the proprietor of any such public garage in which the vehicle may be stored. Such notice shall include a complete description of the vehicle, the date, time and place from which it was removed, the reasons for such removal, and the name of the garage or place where the vehicle is stored. 
(Code 1963, § 25-331; Ord. No. 1799, § 1, 3-23-88; Ord. No. 2825 , § 2, 3-3-15) 
State Law reference- Officers authorized to remove illegally stopped vehicles, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 63-3-905. 
Secs. 6-454-6-469. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIX. - GULFPORT POLICE DEPARTMENT TOWING PERMIT ORDINANCE 

Sec. 6-470. - General order permitting and regulating wrecker businesses towing vehicles at the request of the Gulfport Police Department. 
(a)  A general order shall be established and uniformly administered and enforced by the Gulfport Police Department to permit and regulate wrecker businesses towing vehicles at the request of the Gulfport Police Department for call on a rotation basis, and to regulate the storage of and access to such vehicles, and to regulate maximum charges for such services that are fair and reasonable to the owner and the wrecker service operator. 
(b)  The general order shall be enforceable by authority of this article only after the general order has been officially approved by the city council and mayor. All subsequent amendments to the general order shall be approved by the city council and mayor prior to taking effect, and the department shall furnish all wrecker companies on the rotation list with copies of said amendments. 
(c)  The general order shall specify mandatory requirements for a towing operator to qualify to be placed on the rotation list to provide towing services on call by the Gulfport Police Department, and for each wrecker vehicle to be used by the operator for such service. 
(d)  Maximum Rates. The general order shall provide a schedule identified as Exhibit "A" of the general order listing maximum rates that may be charged for towing, storage and related charges for services provided under the general order, and no charges shall be assessed by the operator providing services at the request of the department under the general order in excess of, or not specifically provided by said schedule. The maximum rates provided are determined by the Gulfport Police Department to be consistent with maximum rates ordinarily charged in the City of Gulfport when an individual requests services, and the rate schedule may be amended from time to time by approval of the city council and mayor. 
(Ord. No. 2276, § 2, 4-18-01) 
Sec. 6-471. - Applicability and compliance with the general order. 
    Any wrecker/tow business operator or company applying for a permit to be included under the general order on the City of Gulfport Police Department wrecker rotation list and whose permit is granted shall fully comply with the requirements of this article and the requirements and qualifications specified by the general order. A copy of this article and the general order shall be obtained from the communications division of the Gulfport Police Department by applicants as a prerequisite to applying for a permit to provide service under the general order. Any operator applying for a permit to be placed on the rotation list shall be deemed to have read, understood, and agreed to abide by the conditions of this article and the general order. Misrepresentation by an applicant shall be grounds for immediate disqualification for no less than six (6) months before a new application will be received. 
(Ord. No. 2276, § 2, 4-18-01) 
Sec. 6-472. - Violations of the general order are prohibited by this ordinance. 
    Violation of any provision, condition or requirement of this article or of the general order of the police department in effect under this article, or failure to perform any act required by this article or by the general order is hereby declared to be unlawful and punishable as a misdemeanor in violation of the ordinances of the City of Gulfport under § 1-9 of The Code of Ordinances of the City of Gulfport, notwithstanding any action, including, but not limited to suspension or revocation from the rotation list, that may be taken against the wrecker business or operator under provision of the general order. 
(Ord. No. 2276, § 2, 4-18-01) 
Sec. 6-473. - Provisions are severable. 
    Any provision or clause of this article, or of the general order in effect hereunder that may be hereafter rendered or determined to be legally unenforceable, shall be severed from the remainder of this article and the general order, and this article and the general order shall be applied and enforced separate from the severed part. If any provision of the general order is in conflict with a provision of this article, the ordinance provision of this article shall control. 
(Ord. No. 2276, § 2, 4-18-01) 
Sec. 6-474. - Issuance of permit. 
    The chief of police of the Gulfport Police Department, or his designated representative, shall issue a permit for each wrecker proposed to be operated by the applicant filing a complete application upon finding that all provisions of the general order have been complied with, and that the applicant and wrecker are fully qualified according to this article and the general order, and upon being satisfied by the city clerk that the applicant towing or wrecker operator or company has procured all required city licenses and paid all required license fees. 
(Ord. No. 2276, § 2, 4-18-01) 
Sec. 6-475. - Officer in charge and authority to tow. 
    When one (1) or more vehicles have been involved in a collision whether with another motor vehicle or with an object and such collision warrants a response by the Gulfport Police Department, the Gulfport police officer in charge of the scene shall have the ultimate authority to direct all activities concerning the removal of vehicles and any cleanup activities, including requesting the towing of a vehicle. No wrecker company shall be allowed to clean up, load, unload, or otherwise handle the cargo or contents of any wrecked or disabled vehicle beyond that which is necessary to properly tow the vehicle and clean the street or highway of debris as necessary without the express consent of the police officer in charge of the scene and the owner of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2276, § 2, 4-18-01) 
Sec. 6-476. - Appeal from denial of permit to the rotation list or from suspension or revocation from the rotation list. 
(a)  Administrative appeals. Any tow operator or company filing a complete application and being denied a permit to tow on the rotation list under the provisions of the general order, or any operator or company believing it is aggrieved by suspension (of permit), temporary or indefinite, or by revocation (of permit) from the rotation list to tow under the general order, or because its wrecker is not permitted, shall be entitled to assert all administrative appeal relief provided for by the general order. 
(b)  Notice of appeal to council and mayor. If after asserting all available administrative appeal relief, the appealing party deeming it is aggrieved may appeal to the city council and mayor. To appeal to the city council and mayor, a notice of appeal stating the action appealed from, and the reason it believes it is aggrieved, shall be filed by the aggrieved operator or company with the clerk of the city council within fifteen (15) days after the date of the final notice or order from the final administrative authority provided in the general order. 
(c)  Record of administrative appeal. A copy of the notice of appeal shall be furnished by the council clerk to the chief of police. If a record of proceedings is available, it shall be copied for the city council deliberations. If not available, it shall be noted in writing by the chief of police or his designee. The council president in consultation with the city attorney shall determine whether the record of the administrative appeals and findings are sufficient for appeal on the record, and if not, then the hearing shall be de novo. Operator shall be given notice in writing five (5) days or more prior to council consideration of the time of the appeal and whether the same shall be limited to the record or de novo. 
(d)  Costs of the record on appeal to council. If the appealing operator is unsuccessful in its appeal to the mayor and city council, it shall be assessed the costs to the City of Gulfport of copying the record for the city council. 
(Ord No. 2276, § 2, 4-17-01) 
ARTICLE XX. - ILLEGAL PARKING 

Sec. 6-476.5. - Parking violations branch established. 
    The City of Gulfport Police Department in conjunction with the City of Gulfport Municipal Court shall establish and maintain the parking violations branch for the processing of parking tickets and for the convenient payment of fines, penalties and cash bonds relating to parking violations. The City of Gulfport Municipal Court shall hear all matters dealing with disputes of parking violations. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-477. - Municipal court function, powers and duties. 
(a)  The City of Gulfport Municipal Court shall: 
(1)  Accept admissions to and hear and determine contests of parking violations under this article; 
(2)  Issue subpoenas to compel the attendance of a person to give testimony at hearings and to compel the production of relevant books, papers and other things; 
(3)  Adjudicate all parking violations for which a parking citation has been issued under this article; 
(4)  Compile and maintain complete and accurate records relating to all citations, violations and/or dispositions of parking violations and citations; 
(5)  Answer within a reasonable period of time all relevant and reasonable inquiries made by a person charged with a parking violation or his attorney concerning the notice of violation served on that person; 
(6)  Furnish at the scheduled municipal court hearing, to the person charged, on his request, a copy of the original notice of violation including all information contained thereon which shall be the Gulfport Municipal Court's only obligation under this subsection to provide a copy of the original notice of violation to the person charged; 
(b)  Failure by the Gulfport Municipal Court to comply with the provisions of this section or any part of the provisions of this section, within seven (7) days of such inquiry, forwarded to the City of Gulfport Municipal Court by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, will result in an automatic dismissal of all charges relating to that violation to which the inquiry was made upon the request of the person charged. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-478. - Regulation of parking and stopping violations. 
    The City of Gulfport, Mississippi's regulation of parking and stopping (hereinafter sometimes referred to as "parking") shall be governed by this article. Any parking violation prohibited in this article shall be a criminal misdemeanor for violation of a municipal ordinance. For purposes of this article, a parking violation is the violation of any provision of this article or any other municipal ordinance providing for or regulating the parking or stopping of a vehicle. Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to repeal, restrict or amend any other section of this chapter which other section shall continue to remain and remain in full force and effect as if this article had not been adopted. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-479. - Parking citation forms. 
    The parking citation shall be the notice of violation for purposes of this article. The parking citation shall contain information concerning the nature, date, time and location of the alleged violation, the state vehicle license plate number, and make of car. In those cases where a license plate is not visible and/or legible, either the vehicle identification number or the brake inspection tag number shall be in lieu of the state vehicle license plate number. In the case of delivery vehicles, the certificate of public necessity and convenience number (CPNC) shall be in lieu of the state vehicle license plate number. The parking citation shall also contain information advising the person charged of the manner and the time in which he may contest the violation charged in the notice. The parking citation shall also provide that a failure to timely answer or appear before the City of Gulfport Municipal Court shall be considered a prima facie admission of the violation set forth in the parking citation, in which event the City of Gulfport Municipal Court may assess the appropriate fine or fines and all penalties incidental thereto and collect the same and issue receipts. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-480. - Parking citations-Service. 
(1)  A parking citation shall be served personally upon the operator of a vehicle who is present at the time of service. If the operator is not so served, or is not present, the parking citation shall be served upon the registered owner of the vehicle by affixing the parking citation to the vehicle in a conspicuous place thereon. The original parking citation shall be signed by the issuing officer who shall affirm the truth of the facts set forth therein. An operator of a vehicle who is not the owner thereof, but who uses or operates the vehicle with permission of the owner, express or implied, shall be considered the agent of the owner to receive a parking citation required to be served upon the operator or registered owner of a vehicle in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(2)  If the registered owner or operator of a vehicle drives the vehicle away from or in any manner leaves the site of the violation while the issuing officer is preparing the parking citation, or refuses service of the parking citation and drives away from or in any manner leaves the site of the violation, this fact shall be duly noted on the original and all copies of the parking citation. This original and all copies of a parking citation shall constitute a business record of the city and shall constitute prima facie evidence that the parking citation was issued and that an attempt at service thereof was made in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-481. - Same-Disposition. 
(1)  The original parking citation shall be signed by the issuing officer, and shall be processed in accordance with this article and such other procedures as may be established and promulgated by the City of Gulfport Municipal Court. 
(2)  A parking citation may be dismissed by the appropriate authority at the City of Gulfport Municipal Court prior to an adjudication hearing only upon a written statement for good cause shown, which statement shall be made a part of the disposition record thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-482. - Citation as legal demand and prima facie evidence. 
    The original parking citation or any true copy thereof shall constitute an ordinary business record of the city and prima facie evidence of the facts contained therein. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-483. - Responsibility of owner and operator. 
(1)  Except as provided in subsections (2) or (4) of this section, the owner and the operator, when not the same, shall be solidarily liable to the city for parking violations, unless the owner can prove that the vehicle was operated without his consent, express or implied. An owner who pays any parking fine, costs, or administrative fees pursuant to this article shall have the right to recover the same from the operator. 
(2)  An owner of a vehicle who is engaged in the business of renting or leasing vehicles under written rental or leasing agreements ("lessor") shall not be liable for parking fines and penalties imposed by a local authority on the lessor of such rented or leased vehicles, if within fifteen (15) days after receiving written notice of the parking violation, the lessor provides, in affidavit form, the true name, address and driver's license number and state of issuance of the person in possession of the vehicle ("lessee") at the time of the issuance of the citation, or provides a true copy of the lease or rental agreement. 
(3)  A lessor who fails to comply with the foregoing provisions shall be treated as any other owner and shall be solidarily liable with the operator. 
(4)  If any owner of a motor vehicle receives a notice of violation for a period during which the illegally parked vehicle was reported to any police department as having been stolen, it shall be a valid defense to any charge of a parking violation that the motor vehicle has been reported to the police as stolen prior to the time the violation occurred and had not been recovered by such time. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-484. - Answering parking citation. 
(1)  A person to whom a parking citation has been issued under this article may answer to the same in the manner and within the delays indicated on the citation. An answer may take the form of: 
(a)  Admission of the violation with payment of the scheduled civil penalty; 
(b)  A written denial of liability and promise to appear at an adjudicatory hearing date; or 
(c)  A written admission of liability with explanation and promise to appear at an adjudicatory hearing. 
(2)  Payment of the civil penalty may be made by mailing to the Gulfport Municipal Court the parking citation accompanied by a payment of the fine provided therein. Such payment may be made only by money order or cashier's check made out to the City of Gulfport. Payment of the civil penalty established herein shall operate as a final disposition of the case. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-485. - Failure to answer parking citation, additional delinquent penalties. 
    If the owner, his agent or the operator fails to appear on or prior to the administrative hearing date, there shall be assessed additional delinquent penalties, as listed herein. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-486. - Notice of hearing. 
    The parking citation shall provide information as to the time and place of a hearing. The form and content of such hearing shall be prescribed by the City of Gulfport Municipal Court judge and shall contain a warning to advise the person that failure to appear on the date designated, or on any subsequent date, to which the hearing is adjourned, shall be deemed an admission of liability. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-487. - Adjudication by mail. 
(1)  In cases where a person charged with a parking violation shows good cause prior to the hearing date for not attending a hearing, either personally or through a representative, a Gulfport Municipal Court judge may permit the matter to be adjudicated by mail which adjudication shall be made within sixty (60) days of the date of the citation. Letters, memoranda, affidavits, photographs or other documentary materials shall be admissible as evidence for the purposes of adjudications by mail. The Gulfport Municipal Court judge may exclude from consideration any material which is not relevant to the adjudication of the alleged violation. Failure of the person charged to proceed with an adjudication by mail after requesting and receiving permission to adjudicate by mail shall constitute an admission by the person charged of liability of the parking violation and shall subject the person who requested the adjudication by mail to the appropriate fines and costs assessed by the parking adjudication bureau. 
(2)  If a Gulfport Municipal Court judge determines that an adjudication cannot proceed by mail, the parking adjudication bureau shall advise the person charged by first-class mail that he must appear to answer the charge at a hearing. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-488. - Hearings for disposition of parking citations. 
(1)  Every hearing for the adjudication of a charge of parking violation under the authority of this article shall be held before a Gulfport Municipal Court judge. 
(2)  The conduct of hearings of parking violations charged under this article shall be governed by those procedures established by the City of Gulfport Municipal Court. 
(3)  The person who appears in response to any citations issued under this article shall have the burden of rebutting the violation. However, proof that a particular vehicle described in the parking citation was in violation of any law or ordinance, together with proof that the person was, at the time of the violation, the registered owner of such vehicle as shown in the latest records of the motor vehicle department of safety and corrections (which may be in the form of a computer printout and shall constitute an ordinary business record of the city), shall constitute a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle or his authorized agent was the person who parked or placed such vehicle at the point where, and for the time during which, the violation occurred. 
(4)  The officer or other duly authorized person who issued the parking citation shall not be required to appear at the hearing unless the person charged with a violation herein has denied that the offense occurred by his commission and the Gulfport Municipal Court judge determines that the officer's or duly authorized person's presence is required. 
(5)  At the conclusion of the contradictory hearing the Gulfport Municipal Court judge shall immediately render a decision, either finding a person cited liable and assessing the fine and/or penalty or declaring the violation unproven and/or invalid. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-489. - Failure to appear at hearing, consequences. 
    Failure to appear at a hearing other than the original hearing when required to appear shall constitute an admission of liability of the parking violation and shall subject the person charged with the violation herein to the appropriate fines and costs assessed by the City of Gulfport Municipal Court. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-490. - Schedules of fines. 
    The following is the minimum schedule of fines which may be paid to the Gulfport Municipal Court or such other agent as may be designated by the City of Gulfport Municipal Court judges: 
(a)  Parking in a yellow curb area ..... $100.50 
(b)  Parking in a handicapped area in violation of City of Gulfport Code of Ordinances section 6-206 ..... $101.00 
(c)  Parking in an emergency access area ..... $100.50 
(d)  Parking tractor-trailer rigs in violation of City of Gulfport Code of Ordinances section 6-353 ..... $100.00 
(e)  Violating safe sight distance in violation of City of Gulfport Code of Ordinances section 6-354 ..... $100.00 
(f)  All other violations as codified in the City of Gulfport Code of Ordinances sections 6-301-6-415 ..... $10.50 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-491. - Judicial review. 
    Any person aggrieved by any decision may file a petition for judicial review in the Harrison County County Court in accordance with Miss. Code Ann. 1972 § 11-51-81. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-492. - Method of notice. 
    Any notice permitted or required to be given under this article shall be considered given when mailed by United States mail, postage prepaid, to the operator, if known, or to the registered owner at the address appearing on the registry of the office of motor vehicles of the department of safety and corrections, or to a lessee at the address provided by the lessor, or in the case of an out of state owner or operator, to such address as may be shown at the appropriate registration office. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-493. - Disposition of monetary penalties. 
    The monies collected pursuant to this article shall be forwarded to the director of the department of finance who shall deposit the same to the credit of the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-493.5. - Excessive and unpaid penalties and fines. 
    The City of Gulfport Police Department shall have the authority to seize and tow vehicles for excessive unpaid parking fines and penalties. Excessive unpaid parking penalties are any unpaid parking penalties in excess of three (3). 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-494. - Failure to appear at properly noticed hearing. 
(1)  A person who fails to appear at a hearing when required to do so or, having admitted liability for a parking offense fails to pay the fines and penalties assessed by the City of Gulfport Police Department or the Gulfport Municipal Court, or, having been found liable for the parking offense fails to pay the fines and penalties assessed by the parking adjudication bureau, or fails to contest or pay the fines/penalties and tow fee for a tow-related citation for which an ROR bond was posted, the vehicle against which the parking citation was issued shall be immediately immobilized, or towed and impounded, or both, by any police officer or other person duly authorized. All vehicles will be towed in accordance with article XIX, chapter 6 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Gulfport. 
(2)  Such vehicle shall be surrendered or released only to the duly registered owner of such vehicle or his agent thereof upon: 
(a)  Payment of all outstanding fines and penalties assessed by the Gulfport Municipal Court recorded against such vehicle plus any towing, immobilization or storage fees; or 
(b)  Such person depositing a cash or surety bond in the amount of all outstanding fines and penalties assessed by the Gulfport Municipal Court recorded against such vehicle plus any towing, immobilization or storage fees. 
(c)  If the person whose vehicle has been immobilized or impounded deposits a bond as provided in subsection (b), such person shall be issued a notice to appear for a hearing. The scope of the hearing provided under this subsection shall be limited to the determination as to whether the vehicle immobilized or booted belongs to the owner or his agent who failed to appear at a hearing when required to do so or, having admitted liability for a parking offense has failed to pay the fines and penalties assessed by the Gulfport Municipal Court, or, having been found liable for the parking offense has failed to pay the fines and penalties assessed by the Gulfport Municipal Court. Any person whose vehicle has been impounded or immobilized under the provisions of this section and desires an expedited hearing shall be afforded a hearing within three (3) business days of his written request therefor. 
(d)  If a vehicle is immobilized for unpaid fines and penalties as provided in subsection (a) of this section, an immobilization fee of fifteen ($15.00) dollars shall be assessed. If such fee is deposited in the form of a cash bond and the responsible person is found not liable for all parking fines and penalties for which his vehicle was immobilized, such bond will be returned to the depositor or his agent. 
(e)  If the vehicle impounded has not been reclaimed within twenty-four (24) hours of the time of impoundment, the Gulfport Police Department shall notify the vehicle's last owner of record (as determined by the license tags thereof) of the place of impoundment of the vehicle. 
(f)  If a person whose vehicle has been impounded or immobilized deposits a bond as provided in subsection (b), such a bond will be subject to forfeiture if he fails to pay fines and/or penalties assessed by the Gulfport Municipal Court within thirty (30) days after assessment. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01; Ord. No. 2372, § 2, 12-16-03) 
Sec. 6-495. - Damaging or removal of immobilization devices prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to release, deface, injure, tamper with, break, destroy, remove, impair the usefulness of, or cause any person to release, deface, injure, tamper with, break, destroy, remove or impair the usefulness of any immobilization device which has been attached to a vehicle in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-496. - Removal of immobilized vehicles prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to move or cause any person to move any vehicle, wherever immobilized, which has an immobilization device attached to it in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-497. - Disposition of unclaimed vehicles. 
    All unclaimed or unidentified motor vehicles in the possession and custody of a towing company shall be subject to a storage charge of not more than fifteen dollars ($15.00) per day, as long as they are in the possession or custody of the towing company; provided, however, that such storage charge shall not begin until twenty-four (24) hours after the vehicle has been towed into the pound. The storage fee shall not exceed seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-498. - Notification of owners and lienholders. 
(1)  Whenever any motor vehicle is found to be abandoned by reason of the illegal parking or the stationing of such motor vehicle on a public street, way, road or highway within the city, the city shall send a registered or certified letter, return receipt requested, to the last known owner of such vehicle at his last known address informing him to remove such vehicle within ten (10) working days from date of receipt of notice. The city shall notify the owner of such vehicle that, in lieu of removal, such owner may remit fifteen dollars ($15.00), together with a completed certificate of authority to the city to remove and dispose of such abandoned motor vehicle. The certificate of authority shall be on a form prescribed and furnished by the city along with a self-addressed return envelope. 
(2)  If the abandoned motor vehicle is not removed within seven (7) working days from date of receipt of notice and the fifteen dollar ($15.00) removal fee has not been returned as provided above, the motor vehicle may be removed and disposed of by the city forthwith, and in such case the city may assess a penalty in the amount of twenty dollars ($20.00) for the failure of an owner to remove an abandoned motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-499. - Sale if unclaimed. 
(1)  The City of Gulfport Police Department shall retain custody and possession of all unclaimed motor vehicles for a period of not less than thirty (30) days from the date possession thereof is obtained by the department, unless such motor vehicles are sooner released by furnishing bond or legal process. 
(2)  All unidentified or unclaimed motor vehicles remaining in the possession of the department after the department has made all efforts to locate the rightful owners, or has located the rightful owners, and the vehicles remain unclaimed shall be sold pursuant to Miss. Code Ann. §§ 63-23-1-11. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-500. - Method of parking. 
    The method of parking vehicles shall conform to article XII of the City of Gulfport City Ordinance [Code of Ordinances] sections 6-301-6-320. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-501. - Stopping, standing or parking of vehicles. 
    The stopping, standing, and parking of vehicles shall conform to article XIII of the City of Gulfport City Ordinance [Code of Ordinances] sections 6-321-6-345. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-502. - Stopping for loading or unloading. 
    The stopping of vehicles for loading or unloading shall conform to article XIV of the City of Gulfport City Ordinance [Code of Ordinances] sections 6-346-6-370. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-503. - Stopping, standing, parking restricted or prohibited on certain streets. 
    The stopping, standing, and parking of vehicles on certain streets shall conform to Article XV of the City of Gulfport City Ordinance [Code of Ordinances] sections 6-371-6-415. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Sec. 6-504. - Repeal of conflicting provisions. 
    This article repeals section 6-447 of the City of Gulfport Code of Ordinances and any and all other conflicting provisions of the City of Gulfport Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2303, § 2, 11-20-01) 
Secs. 6-505-6-515. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XXI. - NONCONSENSUAL TOWING 

Sec. 6-516. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(a)  Fuel surcharge (computed on the basic tow and recovery rate) is based on the average price of self-service fuel, as determined, based upon the price reported by the U.S. Department of Energy for the Petroleum Administration for Defense District 3 (Gulf Coast). http://www.eia.doe.gov/ 
Fuel Prices

(b)  Private property means all property privately owned regardless of whether the property is open to public access. 
(c)  Light-duty towing is defined as the towing, transport, and recovery of motor vehicles with a gross vehicle weight rating of fifteen thousand (15,000) pounds or less. 
(d)  Light-duty vehicle [means] a motor vehicle with a gross vehicle weight rating of fifteen thousand (15,000) pounds or less. 
(e)  Person means any natural person, partnership, corporation, association, organization, trust or other entity. 
(f)  Tow means to haul, carry, pull along, or otherwise transport or remove a motor vehicle by means of another vehicle. 
(g)  Towing service includes any person or other entity, whether licensed or not, that engages in or who owns or operates a business which engages, in whole or in part, in the towing or removal of motor vehicles for compensation. 
(h)  Trespass towing means the towing or removal of a vehicle, without the consent of the vehicle's owner or operator, that is parked on a private parking lot without the property owner or agent's consent. 
(Ord. No. 2643, § 2-1, 9-22-09) 
Sec. 6-517. - Towing of trespass vehicles for compensation. 
    No towing service shall conduct a trespass tow of a light-duty vehicle from a private parking lot for compensation where the point of origin of the tow is within the jurisdictional limits of the City of Gulfport without complying with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2643, § 2-2, 9-22-09) 
Sec. 6-518. - Impoundment within city limits. 
    In the event the owner or person in charge of private property has authority to seek removal of a motor vehicle from such private property, such owner or person in charge is authorized to secure a private wrecker service of his/her choice, provided that when such vehicle is removed from such private property for storage or impoundment, such storage or impoundment shall be in or upon an impoundment or storage lot within the city limits of the City of Gulfport for a least ten (10) days. After the passage of ten (10) days, if the vehicle is moved to a storage yard outside of the city limits but within Harrison County, Mississippi, no relocation fees may be charged to the owner. 
(Ord. No. 2643, § 2-3, 9-22-09) 
Sec. 6-519. - Authorization required. 
    No motor vehicle may be towed by a towing service from any public street or way, public alley or other public property except pursuant to explicit authorization from a law enforcement officer, owner of said vehicle or duly authorized driver of said vehicle. It shall be unlawful for any towing service to make a payment of any kind to any peace officer or law enforcement in return for authorization to tow a vehicle. 
    Before a towing service may remove an unauthorized vehicle from private property, the towing service must first obtain a written request from the property owner, the property owner's authorized agent or the lessee of the property to remove the vehicle in question, unless the towing service has been given written authorization by one (1) of the aforementioned persons to remove all unauthorized vehicles from said private property. This written request can be in the form of signing the towing company's invoice at the time of each tow. It shall be unlawful for any towing service to make a payment of any kind to any property owner, lessee, or owner's authorized agent in return for permission to tow any vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2643, § 2-4, 9-22-09) 
Sec. 6-520. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of removing trespass vehicles from private property by means of towing and storing such vehicles without a valid city license issued by the city clerk. 
    Each towing company shall maintain a valid liability insurance policy issued by a surety company authorized to issue policies of insurance covering risks in the state. 
    The name, address and telephone number of the towing company shall be permanently affixed to the tow truck or vehicle and displayed in letters clearly visible from one hundred (100) feet on both sides of the vehicle. The letters for the name shall be at least four (4) inches high and letters for the address and telephone numbers shall be at least two (2) inches high. 
(Ord. No. 2643, § 2-5, 9-22-09) 
Sec. 6-521. - Trespass towing of vehicles from private parking lots; signs required. 
(a)  No vehicle, of any size or weight, shall be towed from a private parking lot for designated parking violations unless a sign is conspicuously posted and clearly visible from all vehicle entrances to the property. Such notice shall fulfill the following requirements: 
(1)  A notice, in the form of a sign structure not less than twenty-four (24) inches by twenty-four (24) inches in size, shall be prominently placed on the private property at each access or curb cut allowing vehicular access to the property, within five (5) feet of the street right-of-way line. If there are no curb or access barriers, signs shall be posted not less than one sign each fifty (50) feet of the frontage to the public street. The maximum size for any sign shall be four square feet. 
(2)  The notice shall clearly display the following: 
a.  In not less than two-inch-high letters on a contrasting background, the words "tow-away" or "tow-away zone" or "towing enforced." 
b.  In not less than one-inch-high letters on a contrasting background, a statement indicating that parking by unauthorized vehicles is prohibited by the use of any of the following phrases: "private property", "leased parking", "no parking", "parking for customers only", "parking for residents only", or a similar phrase indicating that parking is limited or otherwise restricted. If parking by unauthorized vehicles is not prohibited on a twenty-four-hour continuous basis, the days of the week and hours of the day during which unauthorized parking is prohibited shall be posted. 
(b)  Pedestrian safety and vehicle movement should be taken into consideration when locating freestanding signs. 
(c)  For purposes of nonconsensual towing only, a property owner or lessee of a residential structure is not required to post a sign in advance of removing a vehicle from the driveway, lawn or what is commonly understood to be the yard. In addition, a sign is not required where the vehicle blocks a private entrance, exit, drive or loading area, or where a vehicle is abandoned on private property for at least twenty-four (24) hours or is disabled to such an extent that it is not capable of moving under its own power. 
(d)  This section shall not apply to statutory parking violations such as handicap parking and fire lane parking violations; nor shall it apply to nonconsensual tows directed by a code and/or law enforcement officer. 
(e)  Nothing in this article shall relieve an owner or lessee of property from complying with all safety and traffic codes, regulations, ordinances and laws. 
(Ord. No. 2643, § 2-6, 9-22-09) 
Sec. 6-522. - Establishment of rates for trespass towing. 
    The maximum rate for the trespass towing and storage for a light-duty vehicle from a private parking lot when the point of origin of the tow is within the city limits shall be as follows: 
(1)  For any light-duty vehicle one hundred thirty-five dollars ($135.00) and fuel surcharge. The storage fee shall be twenty dollars ($20.00) a day uncovered or twenty-five dollars ($25.00) a day covered (only if necessary), which shall be on a twenty-four-hour day and shall begin to accumulate when the vehicle is unhooked from the tow truck in the proper storage yard. For purposes of this section a day is considered to be a twenty-four-hour period. 
(2)  There shall be no additional charges for locating the vehicle in the storage facility, removal of items from the vehicle, or for any other similar activity which does not require towing or moving of the vehicle during business hours. 
(3)  Vehicles (unpaid or not released) that remain in storage will only have an owner's personal effects released to the owner or his/her designee (prescriptions, eye glasses, medical equipment, tools, house keys, pets, etc.). All property physically attached to the vehicle remains as part of the vehicle. 
(4)  For vehicles that have a gross weight over fifteen thousand (15,000) pounds, the fee for towing and storage shall be established by the towing service. 
(5)  The maximum rates established in subsection (a)(1) shall be a flat fee which shall be inclusive of all towing charges. A towing charge includes any fees for: 
a.  Special equipment such as, but not limited to, a double hookup, vehicle entry when locked, dropping transmission linkage, axle or drive shaft removal, dollies, skates, trailer or flatbed, lift, slim-jims, go jacks, removing bumpers, airing up brakes, and mileage. 
b.  Time spent on the scene of the tow. 
(6)  No fee other than the above enumerated fees for towing and storage shall be assessed as a condition for release of a light-duty vehicle to the vehicle owner or authorized driver. 
(Ord. No. 2643, § 2-7, 9-22-09) 
Sec. 6-523. - Return of light-duty vehicle to owner prior to a trespass tow. 
    No vehicle may be towed by any person from private property if the owner or other person entitled to possession of the vehicle is present, or arrives at the scene prior to the vehicle's removal from such private property, exhibits the ignition key of said vehicle, and offers to remove such vehicle voluntarily prior to the time such person attempting to tow actually removes such vehicle from the private property in question, provided that such other person removes the vehicle immediately. No fee may be charged to the vehicle owner except where any piece of equipment involved in the towing process has been affixed to the vehicle prior to the arrival of the person, in which case a fee not to exceed one hundred thirty-five dollars ($135.00) plus applicable fuel surcharges and taxes may be charged. 
(Ord. No. 2643, § 2-8, 9-22-09) 
Sec. 6-524. - Return of light-duty vehicle to owner after a trespass tow. 
(a)  [Identification.] The owner or authorized agent of the owner of the towed vehicle shall be identified by a valid driver's license and an ignition key which operates the vehicle towed; or, in the instance of rented vehicles, the renter may be identified by presentation of a rental contract or agreement and the driver's license of the renting party named in the rental contract or the rental company may be identified by presentation of the vehicle title or other documentation indicating the rental company is the owner of the vehicle. 
(b)  [Methods of payment.] The towing service shall accept the following methods of payment for such fees and charges: 
(1)  United States currency. 
(2)  A major credit card. No towing company may charge an extra fee for payment by credit card. 
(c)  [Release of vehicle.] The towing service shall immediately release a towed motor vehicle to the owner upon tender of the lawfully authorized fee. Failure of the towing company to release a vehicle within forty-five (45) minutes of the payment of the fee shall be a violation of this article. 
(d)  [Reason for towing.] The towing service shall provide a reason for the vehicle being towed. 
(e)  Hours for release of vehicles. A towing company must be open for release of vehicles from Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Saturday 8:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. by appointment only, excluding city holidays. There will be no additional charge for conducting business during this appointment. During nonbusiness hours, a towing company must make a reasonable attempt to release vehicles upon demand upon payment of an additional late-release fee of forty-five dollars ($45.00). 
(f)  [Posting of rates.] Private trespass towing and storage rates shall be posted in a conspicuous place, visible to the customers, at the tow truck company location. 
(Ord. No. 2643, § 2-9, 9-22-09) 
Sec. 6-526. - Trespass towing notice to police required. 
    Any towing service operating within the city shall, within fifteen (15) minutes of the removal of the vehicle from a private parking lot, notify the non-emergency number of the Gulfport Police Department of the towing, the trespass location and person authorizing tow, the storage site, the time the vehicle was towed or removed, and the make, model, year, color, vehicle identification number (VIN), license plate number of the vehicle; and shall obtain and retain the Gulfport Police Department's case number or call number assigned to the call. 
(Ord. No. 2643, § 2-10, 9-22-09) 
Sec. 6-527. - Enforcement. 
(a)  This article shall be enforced by the chief of police or an authorized designee. 
(b)  The chief of police or his or her designee shall have the power and authority, subject to law, to enter upon the wrecker/storage premises to ascertain whether the premises are in compliance with this article. 
(c)  Any person who desires to register a complaint under this article may initiate enforcement with the police department. 
(Ord. No. 2643, § 2-11, 9-22-09) 
Sec. 6-528. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  Any violations of the provisions of this article or a failure to comply with any of its requirements shall subject the offender to a misdemeanor, punishable by: 
(1)  A fine not exceeding two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for a first violation. 
(2)  A fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) for a second violation with[in] one (1) year. 
(3)  A fine not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for the third and for each subsequent violation within one (1) year. 
(b)  Any violation of this article shall be considered a separate and distinct violation. 
(Ord. No. 2643, § 2-1, 9-22-09) 
Secs. 6-529-6-549. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XXII. - VEHICLE IMMOBILIZATION 

Sec. 6-550. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, whenever used in this article, shall, for the purposes of this article, have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Whenever any words and phrases used in this article are not defined in this section, but are defined in the state laws regulating vehicle immobilization devices, any such definition in the state law shall be deemed to apply to such words and phrases used in this article, except when the context otherwise requires. 
    Boot means any lockable wheel clamp or any other similar device designed to be placed on a parked vehicle to prevent the operation of or to immobilize the vehicle until the device is unlocked and removed. 
    Immobilize means to impede or prevent movement of a parked vehicle by the use of a boot or other immobilization device. 
    Impoundment means the removal of a booted or immobilized vehicle to an impound lot by a city-approved towing company. 
    Owner means the person registered with the state as the owner of a vehicle in the most current registration records available to the city, or any transferee not designated in such records, provided that the parking official has received actual notice of the transfer. 
    Person means any natural person, partnership, corporation, association, organization, trust or other entity. 
    Private property means all property privately owned regardless of whether the property is open to public access. 
    Tow means to haul, carry, pull along, or otherwise transport or remove a motor vehicle by means of another vehicle. 
    Towing service means any person or entity, whether licensed or not, that engages in or who owns or operates a business which engages, in whole or in part, in the towing or removal of motor vehicles for compensation. 
    Vehicle means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, except devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Ord. No. 2677, § 1, 5-18-10) 
Sec. 6-551. - Authority to immobilize. 
    The chief of police, or authorized officers or personnel of the Gulfport Police Department, shall have the authority to immobilize any vehicle found parked upon any street or in any off street parking in the city when the record title owner of the vehicle has accrued unpaid parking or traffic penalties and fines in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00) This authority shall also extend to any vehicle stopped by any officer of the Gulfport Police Department on or along any public street. 
(Ord. No. 2677, § 2, 5-18-10) 
Sec. 6-552. - Procedure. 
(a)  The chief of police, or authorized designee, having immobilized a vehicle under this section, shall conspicuously affix a notice to such vehicle for the owner to pay the fines or penalties specified. Such notice shall also inform the owner of the vehicle that: 
(1)  Such vehicle has been immobilized pursuant to and by the authority of this section; and 
(2)  The owner of such immobilized vehicle or otherwise duly authorized person shall be permitted to repossess or secure the release of the vehicle upon payment to the city of the total amount owed, including delinquent fines, for each violation, immobilization service charge of seventy-five dollars ($75.00), and wrecker and storage fees, if the vehicle is towed and stored in accordance with chapter 6, article XIX, of the City of Gulfport's Code of Ordinances, also known as or referred to as the "Gulfport Police Department Towing Permit Ordinance". 
(b)  If the owner of such vehicle immobilized under the provisions of this article, or other duly authorized person does not make arrangements for the removal of the immobilization device within twenty-four (24) hours of the time such motor vehicle was immobilized, the police department may remove such vehicle by having the vehicle towed by a preapproved towing service. Any towing service charges incurred pursuant to this section shall be additional costs to be assessed to the registered owner of such motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2677, § 3, 5-18-10) 
Sec. 6-553. - Liability of the city. 
    Neither the city nor any officer or employee thereof shall be held responsible for any damages caused by the lawful immobilization of any vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2677, § 4, 5-18-10) 
Sec. 6-554. - Damaging or removing immobilization device. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to release, deface, injure, tamper with, break, destroy, remove, impair the usefulness of, or cause any person to release, deface, injure, tamper with, break, destroy, remove or impair the usefulness of any immobilization device which has been attached to a vehicle in accordance with the provisions of this article. No person, except as may be authorized by the chief of police, or his designee, shall revoke or attempt to remove, tamper with or in any way damage or alter an immobilization device. No person shall tow or move an immobilized vehicle from the location at which the vehicle was immobilized, unless authorized by the chief of police, or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 2677, § 5, 5-18-10) 
Sec. 6-555. - Impoundment of immobilized vehicles. 
    Any vehicle immobilized pursuant to this article shall be subject to impoundment until lawfully claimed or disposed of in accordance with state law. An impounded vehicle shall be held at a city impound lot or stored by an approved towing company in accordance with chapter 6, article XIX of the City of Gulfport Code of Ordinances, also known as or referred to as the "Gulfport Police Department Towing Permit Ordinance". 
(Ord. No. 2677, § 6, 5-18-10) 
Sec. 6-556. - Notice to owner. 
(a)  Vehicle immobilization notice. The following notice, printed on highly visible paper or other material, shall be attached to the vehicle in a conspicuous place, outside of the driver's line of sight, and shall read substantially as follows: 
WARNING: 
DO NOT MOVE THIS VEHICLE 
ATTEMPTS TO OPERATE THIS VEHICLE WHILE THE IMMOBILIZATION DEVICE IS ATTACHED MAY RESULT IN SERIOUS DAMAGE TO THE VEHICLE OR SERIOUS BODILY INJURY TO THE PERSON ATTEMPTING TO OPERATE THE VEHICLE 
    This vehicle has been immobilized by the City of Gulfport for violations of the Municipal Code and/or State Law for failure to pay traffic and/or parking fines totaling over Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00). To secure the release of this vehicle, payment shall be made in full for all outstanding parking and traffic fines. You may also be subject to impoundment or immobilization fees. 
    Arrangements for the release of this vehicle may be made by calling the: 
    Parking Enforcement Section at (228) 868-5959 between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday; or 
    The Gulfport Police Department Desk Sergeant at (228) 868-5985 at all other hours, 
    Including Saturdays, Sundays and Holidays. 
    ATTENTION VEHICLE OWNER: You are hereby advised of your rights to request a prompt hearing to determine the validity of the immobilization and any related fees. You may obtain details on such a hearing by contacting the Gulfport Municipal Court at (228) 868-5855. Failure to respond to this Notice within twenty-four hours shall result in your vehicle being towed. 
    CITY OF GULFPORT 
MUNICIPAL COURT (228) 868-5855 
(b)  Impound notice. The police department, having impounded a vehicle under this article, shall cause to be posted, in three (3) public places in the city, notice that said vehicle has been recovered. Such notice shall contain an accurate and detailed description of said vehicle, and a copy of such notice shall be mailed to the record title owner of the vehicle in addition to being posted as herein required. The record title owner of the impounded vehicle or otherwise duly authorized person shall be permitted to repossess or secure the release of the impounded vehicle upon payment to the city of the total amount owed, including delinquent fines, for each violation, immobilization service charge of seventy-five dollars ($75.00), and wrecker and storage fees, if the vehicle is towed and stored in accordance with chapter 6, article XIX, of the City of Gulfport's Code of Ordinances, also known as or referred to as the "Gulfport Police Department Towing Permit Ordinance". 
(c)  Removal of notice. It shall be unlawful to remove or relocate any notice placed on an immobilized vehicle, unless the person is a police officer or authorized representative, the owner of the vehicle, or an individual authorized by the owner of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2677, § 7, 5-18-10) 
Sec. 6-557. - Disposition of unclaimed vehicles. 
    All unclaimed vehicles in the possession and custody of the Gulfport Police Department shall be subject to a storage charge of not more than twenty dollars ($20.00) per day for uncovered storage or twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per day for covered storage (only if necessary), which shall be on a twenty-four-hour day and shall begin to accumulate when the vehicle is unhooked from the tow truck in the proper storage yard. For purpose of this section a day is considered to be a twenty-four-hour period. Charges shall continue to accrue as long as the vehicle is in the possession or custody of the Gulfport Police Department. Storage fees shall not exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), or the statutorily authorized maximum charge. 
(a)  Notice of sale and/or disposal of impounded vehicles. Prior to the sale and/or disposal of an impounded vehicle, notice of such sale must be posted in three (3) public places in the city at least ten (10) days preceding the date of such sale. The notice shall contain a detailed and accurate description of the property to be sold and shall be addressed to the record title owner of the impounded vehicle or otherwise duly authorized person. The notice shall also set forth the date, time and place such sale is to be conducted and shall designate the person who is to make the sale, which person shall be officially designated by the governing authorities of the city. 
(b)  Sale and/or disposal of impounded vehicles. 
1.  If the record title owner of an impounded vehicle or otherwise duly authorized person does not retrieve the impounded vehicle within ninety (90) days from the vehicle's recovery by the city or its police chief or his or her designee, the governing authorities of the city shall cause the same to be sold as authorized by and provided for in accordance with state law. 
2.  The person or officer designated and making the sale of such property shall promptly upon completion of the sale deliver to the city clerk a copy of the notice authorizing the sale, a list of the property sold, the amount paid for each item sold, the person to whom each item was sold, and all monies received from such sale, whereupon, the city clerk shall deposit the monies in the general fund of the municipality and shall record the information regarding the sale in the official minutes of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2677, § 8, 5-18-10) 
Sec. 6-558. - Penalties. 
    Any violation of this article shall be a considered a misdemeanor and a violator may be fined up to the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or sentenced to serve thirty (30) days in jail, or both. 
(Ord. No. 2677, § 9, 5-18-10) 
Sec. 6-559. - Enforcement. 
    This article shall be enforced by the chief of police or authorized designee. 
(Ord. No. 2677, § 10, 5-18-10) 
Chapter 7 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Altering Code, § 1-8; defrauding a taxicab driver, § 5-39; damaging or defacing fire alarm, giving false alarm, § 10-26; tampering with fire hydrant, § 11-4; damaging sewage works, § 11-97. 
State Law reference- Crimes, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 9-1-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7-1. - State misdemeanors adopted. 
    All offenses under the penal laws of the state which are misdemeanors are hereby declared to be offenses against the city when such offenses are committed within the corporate limits of the city and upon conviction thereof the same punishment shall be imposed by the city as provided by the laws of the state with regard to such offense against the state to the extent authorized by the laws of the state. 
(Code 1963, § 17-1; Ord. No. 2423, § 2, 2-23-05) 
State Law reference- Misdemeanors under state penal laws are criminal offenses against the city, penalties, judgments, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 21-13-19; power of city to make all needful police regulations for good order, peace, the protection of property, etc., Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 21-19-15. 
Sec. 7-2. - Abandoning iceboxes, refrigerators, airtight containers. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to leave outside of any building or dwelling in a place accessible to children any abandoned, unattended or discarded icebox, refrigerator or any other container of any kind which has an airtight door, or lock, which may not be released for opening from the inside of such icebox, refrigerator or container. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to leave outside of any building or dwelling in a place accessible to children any abandoned, unattended or discarded icebox, refrigerator or any other container of any kind which has an airtight snap lock door or other device thereon without first removing the snap lock or doors from such icebox, refrigerator or container. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to leave in any place accessible to children, any abandoned, unattended or discarded icebox, refrigerator or any other container of any kind, as denominated in this section, without first dealing with such in the manner hereinbefore set out in this section. 
(Code 1963, § 17-2) 
State Law reference- Abandonment of iceboxes etc., Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 97-5.9. 
Sec. 7-3. - Begging. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person known as a beggar or mendicant to solicit alms or aid, either directly or indirectly, upon any of the streets or sidewalks within the city. 
(Code 1963, § 17-5) 
State Law reference- Tramps, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 97-35-29 et seq.; vagrants, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 97-35-37 et seq. 
Sec. 7-4. - Defacing public property, telegraph, telephone poles, railroad depots. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to, in any way, deface or to write or cause to be written with chalk or other substance, or to print or past any letter or picture, or other thing, for any purpose whatever, upon any sidewalk, street pavement, or upon any public building or property in the city, on any telegraph or telephone pole within the city, or on the walls of any railroad depot. 
(Code 1963, § 17-7) 
State Law reference- Malicious mischief, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 97-17-67. 
Sec. 7-5. - Digging, removing dirt. 
(a)  Prohibited in subdivisions. It shall be unlawful for anyone to excavate and/or remove dirt from any lot in a platter subdivision within the city so as to leave the property or any portion thereof from which such dirt was removed at a lower level than the surrounding property in that area. 
(b)  Prohibited in residential areas. It shall be unlawful for anyone to excavate or remove dirt from any land situated within a residential area within the city so as to leave the property or any portion thereof from which the dirt was removed at a lower level than the surrounding property in that area. 
(c)  Prohibited if natural drain level lowered.
