Sec. 10-47. - Definitions. 
(a)  Wherever the word "municipality" is used in the fire prevention code, it shall be held to mean the City of Gulfport. 
(b)  Wherever the term "corporation counsel" is used in the fire prevention code, it shall be held to mean the city attorney. 
(Code 1963, § 11-16) 
Sec. 10-48. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the code hereby adopted or fail to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any order made thereunder, or who shall build in violation of any detailed statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any certificate or permit issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been taken, or who shall fail to comply with such an order as affirmed or modified by the mayor and city council, or by a court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed herein, shall severally for each and every such violation and noncompliance, respectively, be guilty of a misdemeanor. The imposition of one (1) penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue, and all such persons shall be required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time. 
(b)  The application of any penalty shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. 
(Code 1963, § 11-23.4) 
Sec. 10-49. - Establishment and duties of bureau of fire prevention. 
(a)  The fire prevention code shall be enforced by the bureau of fire prevention in the fire department of the city, which is hereby established and which shall be operated under the supervision of the chief of the fire department. 
(b)  The chief (or fire marshal) in charge of the bureau of fire prevention shall be appointed by the mayor and city council on the basis of examination to determine his qualifications. 
(c)  The chief of the fire department may detail such members of the fire department as inspectors as shall from time to time be necessary. The chief of the fire department shall recommend to the mayor and city council the employment of technical inspectors, who, when such authorization is made, shall be selected through an examination to determine their fitness for the position. The examination shall be open to members and nonmembers of the fire department, and appointments made after examination shall be for an indefinite term with removal only for cause. 
(d)  A report of the bureau of fire prevention shall be made annually and transmitted to the mayor; it shall contain all proceedings under this code with such statistics as the chief of the fire department may wish to include therein; the chief of the fire department shall also recommend any amendments to the code which, in his judgment, shall be desirable. 
(Code 1963, § 11-15) 
Cross reference- General government, Ch. 1. 
Sec. 10-50. - Amendments. 
    The fire prevention code adopted by the provisions of this division is amended and changed in the following respects: 
Chapter 3, Recognized Standards and Publications, Section 301: 
    National Fire Protection Association Standards. 
    101, Life Safety Standard, 1991. 
(Code 1963, § 11-23; Ord. No. 1564, § 1, 5-5-81; Ord. No. 1927, § 2, 3-2-93) 
Cross reference- Adoption of life safety code § 10-25. 
Sec. 10-51. - Modifications. 
    The chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall have the power to modify any of the provisions of the fire prevention code adopted by the provisions of this article upon application in writing by the owner or lessee, or his duly authorized agent, when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the code; provided that the spirit of the code shall be observed when such modification is granted or allowed and the decision of the chief of the bureau of fire prevention thereon shall be entered upon the records of the department and a signed copy shall be furnished the applicant. 
(Code 1963, § 11-23.1) 
Sec. 10-52. - Appeals. 
    Whenever the chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall disapprove an application or refuse to grant a permit applied for, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the code do not apply, or that the true intent and meaning of the code have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant may appeal from the decision of the chief of the bureau of fire prevention to the mayor and city council within thirty (30) days from the date of the decision appealed. 
(Code 1963, § 11-23.2) 
Sec. 10-53. - New materials, processes or occupancies which may require permits. 
    The mayor and city council, the chief of the fire department and the chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall act as a committee to determine and specify, after giving affected persons an opportunity to be heard, any new materials, processes or occupancies, which shall require permits, in addition to those now enumerated in said code. The chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall post such list in a conspicuous place in his office, and distribute copies thereof to interested persons. 
(Code 1963, § 11-23.3) 
Sec. 10-54. - Smoking and fires on piers, wharves, vessels. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to ignite any substance or originate a fire by any means on public piers or wharves, provided that this prohibition shall not apply to the use of fire in the necessary operation, repair or construction of railroads on such piers or wharves, and/or in the repair or construction of such piers or wharves, and provided further this section shall not apply to the use of fire for heating or cooking purposes in enclosed buildings on such piers or wharves; and it shall also be unlawful for any person to build fires in open ovens or other open contrivance on the unenclosed deck of any craft or vessel moored against or lashed to any such pier or wharf. 
(Code 1963, § 11-24) 
Cross reference- Boats, docks, waterways and beaches, Ch. 2. 
Sec. 10-55. - Fireworks. 
(a)  Selling, giving away. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, give or permit to be sold, within the city, any firecrackers, Roman candles, torpedoes, sky rockets, or any explosive commonly known and referred to as fireworks, which includes the pyrotechnics known as "snap-pops"; except that the term "fireworks" shall not include toy pistols, toy canes, toy guns, or other devices in which paper caps manufactured in accordance with United States Interstate Commerce Commission regulations for packing and shipping of toy paper caps are used, or toy pistol paper caps manufactured as provided in this subsection, the sale and use of which shall be permitted. 
(b)  Exploding. It shall be unlawful for any person to explode, use or shoot any fireworks as described in subsection (a) above within the city. 
(c)  Public displays. Public displays of fireworks may be had and made under the written authority first obtained from the mayor. In every case where permission for such display is given, the street, avenue, and the particular part thereof, or the vacant lot or other place where the display is permitted, the time when and also the organization or citizens in charge of the display, must be designated in the written permit, and receive the prior approval of the mayor and city council, and all necessary and reasonable precautions must be taken by the city, as well as by the persons in charge, to prevent fire or other injury from such display. 
(d)  Possession, sale or use of smoke bombs, stink bombs, and aerosol spray products during parades. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, give or permit to be sold, or to possess, use or explode smoke bombs, stink bombs, and the aerosol spray product commonly known as "spray or silly string", or other matter or substances similar thereto at or near parade routes, prior to, during, or after parades permitted and held within the City of Gulfport. 
(Code 1963, § 17-9; Ord. No. 2011, § 1, 2-21-95) 
State Law reference- Power of municipal governing authorities to prohibit or regulate the sale or use of fireworks, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, §§ 21-19-15, 45-13-11, 45-13-13. 
Sec. 10-56. - Amendments, revisions. 
(a)  The following sections are hereby revised: 
    Section 101.1. Insert: "City of Gulfport, Mississippi" 
    Section 109.1. Board of appeals established. Delete "board of appeals" and insert in its place "Construction Board of Adjustment and Appeals (hereinafter "board of appeals")". 
    Section 110.4. Violation penalties. Delete: "[specify offense], punishable by a fine of not more than [amount] dollars or by imprisonment not exceeding [number of days], or both such fine and imprisonment. Each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served shall be deemed a separate offense." Insert in its place: "misdemeanor in accordance with Section 1-9 General Penalty of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Gulfport, MS." 
    Section 112.4. Stop Work Orders. Failure to Comply. Delete in last portion of sentence in paragraph: "liable to a fine of not less than (amount) dollars or more than (amount) dollars." Insert in its place: "guilty of a misdemeanor in accordance with Section 1-9 of the code of Ordinances of the City of Gulfport, MS." 
(b)  The limits referred to in certain sections of the 2003 International Fire Code are hereby established as follows: 
    Section 3204.3.1.1 (limits in which the storage of flammable cryogenic fluids in stationary containers is prohibited). As determined by the Fire Chief 
    Section 3404.2.9.5.1 (limits in which the storage of class I and class II liquids in above-ground tanks outside of buildings is prohibited). As determined by the Fire Chief 
    Section 3406.2.4.4 (limits in which the storage of class I and class II liquids in above-ground tanks is prohibited). As determined by the Fire Chief 
    Section 3804.2 (limits in which the storage of liquefied petroleum gas is restricted for the protection of heavily populated or congested areas). As determined by the Fire Chief 
(Ord. No. 2501, §§ 2, 3, 10-18-06; Ord. No. 2814, § 2, 12-2-14 ; Ord. No. 2965, § 2, 8-7-18 ) 
Cross reference- International Fire Code adopted, § 10-46. 
Secs. 10-57-10-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ALARM SYSTEMS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2776, § 2, adopted May 8, 2013, repealed the former Art. III., §§ 10-76-10-83, and enacted a new Art. III as set out herein. The former Art. III pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the 1963 Code and Ord. No. 2163, §§ 2-7, 9, 10, 3-16-99. 

Sec. 10-76. - Purpose and scope. 
(a)  The purpose of this article is to encourage alarm system users and alarm businesses to assume increased responsibility for maintaining the reliability and the proper use of alarm systems, to reduce unnecessary police and fire emergency response to false alarms, and thereby to protect the emergency response capability of the city from misuse. 
(b)  This article governs burglary and/or robbery alarm systems and fire alarm systems, provides for fines for excessive false alarms, and provides for punishment for violations. 
(Ord. No. 2776 , § 2, 5-8-13) 
Sec. 10-77. - Definitions. 
    Act of God. An unusual, extraordinary, sudden, and unexpected manifestation of the forces of nature, which cannot be prevented by reasonable human care, skill, or foresight. 
    Activation. An act whereby the alarm system becomes operational for purposes other than testing that may result in a Gulfport Police Department and/or Gulfport Fire Department response to that site. 
    Alarm agent. Any person who is employed by an alarm business either directly or indirectly, whose duties include any of the following: maintaining, servicing, and/or repairing any alarm or alarm system in or on any building, place, or premises. Any person whose duties consist solely of resetting an alarm following activation shall not be deemed to be an alarm agent. 
    Alarm system. Any assembly of equipment or devices, mechanical or electrical, arranged or used for the detection of a hazardous condition or an unauthorized entry or attempted entry into a building, structure, or facility, or for alerting person(s) of a hazardous condition or the commission or attempted commission of an unlawful act within or upon a building, structure, or facility, and which emits a sound, or transmits a signal or message when activated, to which annunciation, the Gulfport Police Department and/or Gulfport Fire Department may be summoned to respond. For purposes of this article, an alarm system shall not include: 
(1)  An alarm installed on motor vehicles, motor homes, boats, or other movables not connected/attached to a fixed property site and not used as a primary or secondary residence. 
(2)  An alarm installed upon premises occupied by the United States Government, by the State of Mississippi, by the County of Harrison, or by the City of Gulfport. 
(3)  Any device or system designed solely to give notice or alert of a medical emergency. 
    Alarm system user. The person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, or other entity which owns, leases, controls, or occupies any building, structure, or facility wherein an alarm system is maintained. 
    Audible alarm system. An alarm system that emits an audible sound or message which can be heard off the premises. Such an audible local area alarm may or may not be monitored by an alarm system monitoring company, and such audible sound is intended to alert neighbors or other residents of the local area to summon the police department and/or fire department. (See "local alarm") 
    Dispatch. To direct police and/or fire units to a location where there has been a report made, by whatever means, that police and/or fire department assistance or investigation is needed. 
    False alarm. An alarm signal eliciting a response by police and/or fire personnel when a situation requiring such response does not exist, including but not limited to, the activation or transmission of any alarm signal caused by human error, mechanical or electronic malfunction, negligence of the alarm system user or user's agent or employee, whether or not the exact cause of the alarm activation is determined, or any other activation or transmission of any alarm signal where no actual police and/or fire emergency exists. Severe weather, power outages in excess of four (4) hours, transmission line malfunctions, acts of God, malicious acts of persons not under the control of the alarm system user, or any other cause clearly beyond the control of the alarm system user may be considered in determining if an alarm activation was false and whether any fine, warning, or other action will be taken against the alarm system user as provided for by this section. An alarm that is false and is canceled prior to the response of Gulfport Police and/or Fire Department units will not be included in the false alarm count for that alarm system site. A panic alarm, as defined in this article, which is activated for purposes other than an armed robbery in progress or a fire at that alarm site, will be classified as a false alarm and included in the false alarm count for that alarm site. 
    Local alarm. An alarm system which, when activated, causes an audible or visual signaling device to be activated only on the premises upon which the system is installed and which is intended to be heard or seen by others outside of the protected premises. 
    Panic alarm. An alarm activation which, for purposes of this article, elicits a response from Gulfport Police Department and/or Gulfport Fire Department personnel for an armed robbery in progress or a fire at that alarm site. 
    Response. The arrival of police and/or fire department personnel at the premises where an alarm system has been activated which indicates a police and/or fire emergency at those premises. 
    Site. Each location requiring an individual alarm system. An alarm system site is determined by each separate and distinct municipal address. 
(Ord. No. 2776 , § 2, 5-8-13) 
Sec. 10-78. - False alarms. 
(a)  Alarm system operation and maintenance. An alarm system user shall: 
(1)  Maintain the premises containing an alarm system in a manner than ensures proper operation of the alarm system; 
(2)  Maintain the premises and the alarm system in a manner that will minimize or eliminate false alarm responses; 
(3)  Make every reasonable effort to respond or cause a contact person(s) to respond to the alarm system's location within a reasonable period of time when notified by the alarm monitoring service, the Gulfport Department of Urban Development, the Gulfport Police Department, or the Gulfport Fire Department to deactivate a malfunctioning alarm system, to provide access to the premises or to provide security for the premises; 
(4)  Not manually activate an alarm system for any reason other than the occurrence of an event for which the alarm system was intended to be activated; 
(5)  Instruct all personnel who are authorized to place the system or device into operation of the appropriate method of its operation. 
(b)  Audible alarms (local alarms). All audible alarms shall be set/programmed for a maximum amount of ten (10) minutes per activation for the emission of the audible alarm sound or message upon such activation. After three (3) immediately consecutive activations, the audible alarm system shall automatically reset, so that the audible alarm will not be reactivated based on the occurrence which triggered that series of alarm activations. 
(c)  Penalties for false alarms. The sending of four (4) or more false alarms in a calendar year, as determined by the city's false alarm count, is herby declared to be unlawful and a misdemeanor and shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) for each such false alarm. 
(d)  False alarm annual count. At the end of the calendar year, the false alarm count for residential alarm users and businesses/commercial establishments will revert to zero. Alarms that are false and are canceled prior to the arrival of Gulfport Police and/or Fire Department units will not be included in the false alarm count. An alarm which is false, and which is verified by the alarm business or alarm system monitoring company as being false, and which alarm is not transmitted to the dispatch office for the Gulfport Police and/or Fire Department, will not be included in the false alarm count for that alarm system site. 
(Ord. No. 2776 , § 2, 5-8-13) 
Sec. 10-79. - No liability of the City of Gulfport. 
    The City of Gulfport assumes no liability in the operation of any alarm system or transmission of signals, for any failure or neglect of any person associated with the installation, operation, or maintenance of an alarm system, for any failure or neglect of any alarm system user, for the transmission or receipt of alarm signals, or any failure or neglect to respond upon receipt of an alarm from any source. No special duty other than that owed to the general public shall be created by virtue of this article or as a result of the transmission to or receipt of alarm signals by the Gulfport Police Department and/or Gulfport Fire Department. 
(Ord. No. 2776 , § 2, 5-8-13) 
Secs. 10-80-10-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - WIRELESS RADIO COMMUNICATION PROGRAM 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-91. - Wireless radio communications. 
(a)  The City of Gulfport is hereby authorized to participate in a wireless radio communications program for purposes of public safety with all rights, privileges and obligations granted and required under § 63-9-31, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, as amended. 
(b)  The Gulfport Municipal Court pursuant to § 63-9-31 Miss. Code Ann. 1972, be, and it is hereby ordered, to assess ten dollars ($10.00) as a surcharge on each person upon whom said court imposes a fine or other penalty for each violation of Title 63, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, except offenses related to vehicular parking or registration; and the court is ordered to deposit the proceeds from said surcharges according to § 63-9-31 Miss. Code Ann. 1972, into the special fund in the department of public safety's office of public safety planning. 
(c)  The funds returned to the City of Gulfport by the department of public safety shall be utilized for funding of the wireless communications program to acquire related computers, software and other technology needed for the program and approved by the Mississippi Department of Information Technology Services in accordance with said § 63-9-31, Miss. Code Ann. 1972. 
(Ord. No. 2319, §§ 2-4, 5-21-02) 
Secs. 10-92-10-114. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - THE EMERGENCY RADIO SYSTEM COVERAGE ORDINANCE 

Sec. 10-115. - Title. 
    The title of this article [division] shall be: "The Emergency Radio System Coverage Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 2536, § 1.0, 5-9-07) 
Sec. 10-116. - Purpose. 
(a)  The purpose of this division is to provide minimum standards to insure a reasonable degree of reliable emergency services communications from within certain buildings and structures located within the city between public safety users and emergency communications centers. 
(b)  It is the responsibility of the Harrison County Emergency Communications Commission to get the signal to and from the building site. 
(Ord. No. 2536, § 2.0, 5-9-07) 
Sec. 10-117. - Definitions. 
(a)  Owner: Building owner. 
(b)  County or municipality: City of Gulfport. 
(c)  FCC: Federal Communications Commission. 
(d)  Public safety services: Those services including, but not limited to, police, fire, EMS, and public works departments. 
(e)  Building: Any structure, enclosed or open, public or private, which is owned by owner. 
(f)  Building amplifier: Any system which is designed to receive a radio signal outside of the building and radiate it throughout the building and, conversely, receive a radio signal generated within the building and reradiate a signal outside of the building. 
(g)  Battery: An electrochemical storage device consisting of either nickel metal hydride (NiMH), nickel cadmium (NiCad), or lead (Pb). 
(h)  Battery charger: Device designed to automatically monitor the charge level of the battery, and to maintain the charge level of the battery to greater than or equal to ninety (90) percent of the battery capacity. 
(i)  Antenna: Device designed to convert electrical signals from a cable to electromagnetic radiation in the air. 
(j)  Talk-out: The ability of a public safety radio network infrastructure site to transmit a radio signal of sufficient strength as to be clearly received by a public safety radio user in the field. 
(k)  Talk-back: The ability of a public safety radio user located in the field to transmit a radio signal of sufficient strength as to be clearly received by a public safety radio network infrastructure site. 
(l)  Sufficient strength: As defined by this division, a minimum received radio signal level of ninety-five (95) dBm measured either at the public safety radio infrastructure site, or received in the field by a public safety radio user. 
(Ord. No. 2536, § 3.0, 5-9-07) 
Sec. 10-118. - Radio coverage. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided, no person shall erect, construct, or modify any building or structure or any part thereof, or cause the same to be done which inhibits or degrades adequate radio coverage for public safety services. A certificate of occupancy may not be issued for any building or structure which fails to comply with this requirement. 
(b)  The frequency range which must be supported shall be 806 through 870MHz, or as otherwise established and required in writing by the Harrison County Emergency Communications Commission as being necessary for public safety purposes. 
(c)  For the purposes of this division, adequate radio coverage shall include the following: 
(1)  A minimum signal strength of -95 dBm available in ninety (90) percent of the area of each floor of the building when transmitted from the closest public safety radio network site (PSRNS). 
(2)  A minimum signal strength of -95 dBm received at the closest PSRNS when transmitted from ninety (90) percent of the area of each floor of the building. 
(3)  A ninety (90) percent reliability factor. 
(Ord. No. 2536, § 4.0, 5-9-07) 
Sec. 10-119. - Amplification system allowed. 
(a)  Buildings and structures shall be equipped with any of the following in order to achieve adequate radio coverage. 
(1)  A radiating cable system; 
(2)  An internal multiple antenna system with FCC type accepted (CFR part 47,90.219) bi-directional amplifiers as needed to encompass the frequency range stated above or frequency range subsequently established by the Harrison County Emergency Communications Commission; or 
(3)  A system that has been approved by the Harrison County Emergency Communications Commission as being capable of providing amplification to meet the requirements of this division. 
(b)  The system shall be capable of operating on an independent battery and/or generator system for a period of at least 12 hours without external power input. 
(1)  The battery system shall automatically charge in the presence of external power input. 
(2)  If a battery standby system is used, these batteries shall be replaced and disposed of properly by the owner once every twenty-four (24) months after initial system installation. 
(3)  Documentation shall be retained and made available for immediate inspection to assure that batteries have been replaced in accordance to this division. 
(c)  There shall be no connectivity between the amplification system and fire alarm system. 
(d)  In the event that a signal booster is employed: 
(1)  It shall be fully encased within a dust- and water-resistant case with a NEMA 4 rating or better. 
(2)  It shall have a four-hour safety survivability rating or greater. 
(3)  It shall be painted red and bear the lettering as follows: Harrison County Emergency Communications Commission Equipment. 
(e)  All proposed building amplifier systems must provide the following information to the Harrison County Emergency Communications Commission and the City of Gulfport: 
(1)  A building blueprint showing name and address of contractor; name of owner and occupant; location, including street address; point of compass; full height cross section of schematic diagram including ceiling construction and method of protection for nonmetallic piping; location of partitions; location of fire walls; occupancy class and use of each area or room; a graphic representation of the scale used on all plans. 
(2)  Make, type, model and size of all cable, amplifiers, antennas, batteries, etc. (specification sheets). 
(3)  Drawings indicating the locations of the amplification equipment and associated antenna systems, cables, antennas, hangers, sleeves braces, methods of securing cables, which includes a view showing building access to the equipment. 
(4)  Schematic drawings of the electrical, backup power, antennas system and any other associated equipment relative to the amplification equipment, including panel locations and labeling. 
(f)  All communications equipment including building amplification systems, cable and antenna systems shall be grounded with a single point ground sustem of five (5) ohms or less. The ground system must include an internal tie point within three (3) feet of the amplification equipment. 
(g)  System transient suppression for the telephone circuits, AC power, radio frequency (RF) cabling and grounding protection are required as needed. 
(Ord. No. 2536, § 5.0, 5-9-07) 
Sec, 10-120. - Owner responsibility. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the owner of a building or structure which currently holds a certificate of occupancy or allows the building or structure to be used for any purpose other than construction to be in compliance with this division. 
(Ord. No. 2536, § 6.0, 5-9-07) 
Sec. 10-121. - Inadequate radio coverage. 
(a)  The owner of any building or structure found to have inadequate public safety radio coverage must submit to the Harrison County Emergency Communications Commission and the City of Gulfport for approval of a plan to correct the radio coverage deficiency. 
(b)  This plan must be submitted within ninety (90) days from the date the radio coverage is found to be inadequate. 
(c)  The approved plan must be put into place by the owner within one hundred twenty (120) days after the plan has been approved by the Harrison County Emergency Communications Commission and the City of Gulfport. 
(Ord. No. 2536, § 7.0, 5-9-07) 
Sec. 10-122. - Existing buildings and structures. 
    Any building or structure existing, under construction, or for which a building permit application is pending or has been approved as of the effective date of this division, shall not be required to comply with the provisions of this division unless the building has been modified, altered, or repaired and the costs of same exceed fifty (50) percent of the assessed value of the existing building and are made within any twelve-month period or the usable floor area is expanded or enlarged by more than fifty (50) percent. 
(Ord. No. 2536, § 8.0, 5-9-07) 
Sec. 10-123. - Evaluation process. 
(a)  [Two-phase minimum.] The evaluation process for determining the need for in-building amplification is conducted in a minimum of two phases: pre-construction and acceptance/implementation. 
(b)  Pre-construction phase. 
(1)  Before the construction of the new building, basic information can be gathered to begin the process of determining the need, type and actual implementation of augmentation to the radio system. In most cases, the following information must be known to properly design and cost estimate an in-building radio system. 
a.  New building information. 
1.  Type/size of building-Single story, multilevel, square footage, number of stories. 
2.  Orientation of building-Above/below ground, line of sight. 
3.  Construction of the outer and inner walls-Plaster, drywall, brick, sheet metal. 
4.  Proposed equipment locations-Equipment rooms, cableways, conduits. 
5.  Building location-Longitude and latitude coordinates. 
6.  Local building code requirements and special requirements. 
7.  Building blueprints and drawings. 
b.  Existing system information. To be supplied by Harrison County Emergency Communications Commission. 
1.  Public safety radio network site location nearest to construction locations. 
2.  Donor channel frequency-Specific digital channel to enhance radio coverage. 
3.  Grade of service required to meet coverage requirements. 
4.  Type of subscriber unit. 
5.  Number of channels and their frequencies. 
6.  Signal strength of donor site at the building locations. 
With the information above, the following steps can establish the potential need for a building amplifier. 
c.  Needs determination-Signal strength measurements. 
1.  At the planned construction site, measure (or have measured) the signal strength of the donor control channel. 
2.  If the signal strength of the donor is -95 dBm or less on the outside of the building, the probability of additional in-building coverage is high. 
3.  If the signal strength of the donor is greater than 95 dBm, determine the expected signal strength of the donor by subtracting the sum of the interior losses due to walls, doors, and windows from the ambient signal outside the building. (See table 1.) 
4.  If a signal strength of -95 dBm or greater is calculated at the innermost point of the building, an in-building system may not be required. 
5.  If a signal strength is calculated at -95 dBm or less, an in-building system is warranted. 
6.  To determine signal strengths for specific areas and evaluate the impact of the proposed building on existing structures, consult the latest Harrison County Emergency Communications District RF Survey Report. 
7.  If determined that an in-building amplification system is required for either the proposed site or existing structures impacted by the proposed construction, provide placeholder in budget for cost of communication system based on results of the above. 
(c)  Acceptance test procedures. 
(1)  Acceptance testing for an in-building radio amplification system is required, upon completion of installation of the system is required, upon completion of installation of the system. It is the owner's responsibility to have the radio amplifier system functionally tested to ensure adequate two-way coverage provided on each floor of the building is in compliance with requirements as set forth in this division. 
(2)  A minimally acceptable test plan shall require that each floor of the building be divided into a grid of approximately twenty (20) equal areas. A maximum of two (2) nonadjacent areas will be allowed to fail the test. 
(3)  In the event that three (3) of the areas fail the test, in order to be more statistically accurate, the floor may be divided into forty (40) equal areas. In such event, a maximum of four nonadjacent areas will be allowed to fail the test. After the forty (40) area tests, and if the system continues to fail, the owner shall repair, replace, alter, or upgrade the system to meet the coverage requirements of this division. 
(4)  Talk-out and talk-back testing from the building site to the Harrison County Public Safety Radio Network shall use a three-watt portable transceiver without speaker/microphone and flexible antenna. 
(5)  A test location approximately in the center of a grid area will be selected for the test, then the radio will be keyed with a voice message used to verify two-way communication to and from the outside of the building. 
(6)  Once the test location has been selected, use of another test location within the grid area will not be permitted. Each test location will also require the capture of the actual signal strength (measured in units of dBm) at that location. 
(7)  Signal strength testing instruments are to be recently calibrated (within the past twelve (12) months prior to testing) and of a frequency selective type incorporating an antenna similar to the ones used on the hand-held transceivers. 
(8)  The gain values of all building amplifiers shall be measured and the results kept on file with the owner so that building amplifier performance measurements can be verified each year during the annual tests. 
(9)  In the event that the measurement results become lost, the owner will be required to rerun the coverage acceptance test to reestablish the gain values. 
(Ord. No. 2536, § 9.0, 5-9-07) 
Sec. 10-124. - Annual tests. 
(a)  Once an in-building radio amplifier system is installed, the building owner shall test all active components of the system including but not limited to amplifier, power supplies, and back-up batteries, a minimum of once every twelve (12) months. 
(b)  Amplifiers shall be tested to ensure that the gain is the same as it was upon initial installation and acceptance. 
(c)  Back-up batteries and power supplies shall be tested under load for a period of one hour to verify that they will operate during an actual power outage. 
(d)  All other radio signal radiating components shall be checked to determine that they are operating within the manufacturer's specifications for the intended purpose. 
(Ord. No. 2536, § 10.0, 5-9-07) 
Sec. 10-125. - Five-year test. 
(a)  In addition to the annual test, the owner shall perform a radio coverage test a minimum of once every five years to ensure that the radio system continues to meet the requirements of the ordinance at the time of original implementation. 
(b)  The procedure set forth above shall apply to such tests. 
(Ord. No. 2536, § 11.0, 5-9-07) 
Sec. 10-126. - Qualifications of testing personnel. 
(a)  All tests shall be conducted, documented, and witnessed by a person in possession of a current FCC general radiotelephone operator license or a manufacturer-authorized maintenance agent for the Harrison County Emergency Communications Commission radio system. 
(b)  All test records shall be retained at the inspected premises by the owner and a copy submitted to the Harrison County Emergency Communications Commission and the City of Gulfport within thirty (30) days of when the test has been conducted. 
(c)  In the event the test results fail to comply with the minimum requirements of the Harrison County Emergency Communications Commission and the City of Gulfport, appropriate repairs shall be made and additional tests conducted until tests meet the minimum requirements. 
(Ord. No. 2536, § 12.0, 5-9-07) 
Sec. 10-127. - Inspections. 
(a)  Harrison County Emergency Communications Commission and City of Gulfport personnel (or their representative), after providing reasonable notice to the owner or his representative, shall have the right to enter onto the property to conduct field verification to be certain that the required minimum level of radio coverage is present. 
(b)  The cost associated with this activity is the responsibility of the owner. 
(c)  Repairs or upgrades needed to correct identified amplifier system shortfalls, to bring failed systems into compliance with the technical and functional requirements of this division, are the responsibility of the Owner. 
(Ord. No. 2536, § 13.0, 5-9-07) 
Sec. 10-128. - Property owner maintenance responsibilities. 
(a)  Upon verification of coverage testing results as outlined above, the Owner shall be responsible for maintenance of the system. 
(b)  A copy of the owner's maintenance contract shall be provided to the Harrison County Emergency Communications Commission and the City of Gulfport with the name of contractor, who will supply a twenty-four-hour, seven-day a week emergency repair response within two (2) hours after notification by either the Harrison County Emergency Communications Commission and the City of Gulfport or the owner. 
(c)  The maintenance contract shall also contain appropriate information as to the contact personnel with phone numbers. 
(d)  The owner shall also be responsible for making any repairs, replacement or upgrades to the systems as directed by the Harrison County Emergency Communications Commission or the City of Gulfport, should the system fail or no longer work in the future. 
(Ord. No. 2536, § 14.0, 5-9-07) 
(a)  This division shall not apply to the following buildings provided they do not make use of any metal construction or any underground storage or parking areas. 
(1)  Buildings with a gross area less than five thousand (5,000) square feet; 
(2)  Any building zoned R2 constructed of wood frame. 
(3)  Any building zoned R1 constructed of either wood or metal frame. 
(4)  Any building thirty-five (35) feet high or less. 
(5)  Buildings or structures existing as of the effective date of this division. This exemption shall not apply to buildings or structures which have been modified, altered, or repaired as set forth in section 10-122 (Existing buildings and structures) after the effective date of this division. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, parking structures and stairwells are included in the definition of "building" and stair shafts and elevators are included in the definition of "all parts of a building". 
(Ord. No. 2536, § 15.0, 5-9-07) 
Sec, 10-130. - Failure to comply. 
    Failure to comply with this division shall be grounds for the director of building and code enforcement to revoke any previous issued Certificate of Occupancy for the building or structure. A written appeal may be taken in the manner set forth in the City of Gulfport's Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2536, § 16.0, 5-9-07) 
Sec. 10-130. - Authority. 
(a)  Section 101.4 of the 1997 Uniform Fire Code and section 104.1 of the 2003 International Fire Code authorize the fire chief to render interpretations of this code and to make and enforce rules and regulations in order to carry out the application and intent of its provisions. 
(b)  Section 101.3 of the 1997 Uniform Fire Code and section 104.1 of the 2003 International Fire Code authorize the Fire Chief to make and enforce rules and supplemental regulations in order to carry out the application and intent of its provisions. Section 1001.9 of the Uniform Fire Code and section 102.8 of the 2003 International Fire Code authorize the fire chief to require additional safeguards consisting of special systems suitable for the protection of the hazard involved. Therefore, the City of Gulfport requires that a public safety radio amplification system shall be installed within certain buildings and structures within the City of Gulfport to provide for emergency communications to and from the emergency communications center. 
(Ord. No. 2536, § 17.0, 5-9-07) 
Sec. 10-132. - Scope. 
    This division covers all new construction or building remodels in the City of Gulfport after the effective date. 
(Ord. No. 2536, § 18.0, 5-9-07)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 11-1. - Employees' right to enter, inspect premises. 
    The director of the department of public works and the director of finance, or their designees, shall have the right to enter all premises at intervals and within reasonable hours to inspect and to take proper census of all connections to the combined water and sewer system; and that such person shall state to the occupants of any such premises the purpose of such inspection before enter in the premises. 
(Code 1963, § 29-7; Ord. No. 2180, § 2, 6-8-99) 
Sec. 11-2. - Collection of service charges. 
(a)  The director of finance or his designee is hereby designated as the collector of all water and sewer service bills, and he shall give proper receipts to the person paying such bills and retain a duplicate copy thereof. All accounts or bills shall be prepared and may be adjusted by the collector. The meter reading, billing and similar services shall be performed by the director of finance or his designee, and proper records thereof shall be kept by him, including records of applications for service, maintenance of service, and discontinuance of service. 
(b)  The director of finance or his designee shall determine: 
(1)  When water service or sewer service is to be discontinued for nonpayment of bills; 
(2)  When there shall have been a failure to make application or contract for water service or sewer service, or otherwise; 
(3)  When water service or sewer service is to be reinstated after discontinuance. 
(c)  The director of finance or his designee is hereby authorized to cut off or to restore water service or sewer service whenever such service is to be cut off or to be restored under the terms of this chapter. 
(d)  The director of finance or his designee shall see that the employees of his office do perform their duties for the combined water and sewer system of the city. 
(e)  The director of finance or his designee shall assess a past due/delinquent charge as set forth in subsection 11-68(a). 
(Code 1963, § 29-8; Ord. No. 1860, § 1, 12-5-89; Ord. No. 1876, § 1, 4-17-90; Ord. No. 2180, § 3, 6-8-99; Ord. No. 2698, § 6, 9-14-10; Ord. No. 2704, § 2, 11-2-10) 
Sec. 11-3. - Notice, bond required for any work affecting system. 
    Any person undertaking any work whereby the combined water and sewer system or any of its parts, will likely be affected shall first notify the director of the department of public works as to location, nature and extent of such work, and, if deemed necessary by the director of the department of public works, a bond in a sufficient amount may be required to ensure the combined water and sewer system against damage; but in all cases such persons shall be held responsible for any and all damage which might result to the system by reason of the doing of such work. 
(Code 1963, § 29-9) 
Sec. 11-4. - Tampering with, using, obstructing fire hydrants prohibited. 
    No person except the employees of the department of public works and those of the department of fire and rescue, the authorized designees of the city, and those persons to whom the director of the department of public works may grant special permission, shall tamper with, make connections to, otherwise use or operate the fire hydrants attached to the water system; and no person shall place or install or cause to be placed or installed any thing or object which will impede free access to fire hydrants, but a distance of not less than five (5) feet shall be clear entirely around each of such hydrants. 
(Code 1963, § 29-12; Ord. No. 2297, § 2, 10-2-01) 
Sec. 11-5. - Discontinuance of service when premises vacated or on request. 
    In the event any premises shall become vacant or in the event that the owner thereof shall for any other reason want the water service discontinued from such premises, he, or his duly authorized agent, may order such service discontinued and also order such service restored by leaving proper written notice, on forms provided therefor, in the office of the water billing department, but this privilege shall be extended only to such premises as have been provided with proper shut-off valves. 
(Code 1963, § 29-13; Ord. No. 2180, § 4, 6-8-99) 
Sec. 11-6. - Notice required when water temporarily shut off; exception for emergencies. 
    In cases where it becomes necessary to close the valves on the water mains for the purpose of making repairs, connections, extensions, etc., so that customers will be temporarily deprived of water service, the person doing such work shall previously notify all of the customers affected whenever it is practicable so to do, but that in cases of emergency, or where the territory affected is too large to render the notification practicable, such valves may be closed for the purpose stated for such time as may be reasonably needed, without giving such notice. 
(Code 1963, § 29-14) 
Sec. 11-7. - Damaging, obstructing, introducing garbage or refuse into sewer fixtures. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to injure any sewer fixture or appurtenance to the sewer or to deposit or convey any garbage, offal or refuse material of any kind in or to any manhole or other fixture connected with the sanitary sewer system. 
(Code 1963, § 29-15; Ord. No. 2180, § 5, 6-8-99) 
Cross reference- Garbage, trash and weeds, § 4-141 et seq. 
Sec. 11-8. - Removing manhole covers without authority. 
    It shall be unlawful for any firm to open or remove any manhole cover from any of the sewer lines without having first secured permission from the superintendent. 
(Code 1963, § 29-17) 
Sec. 11-9. - Tampering with water system; penalties. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to tamper with any hydrant, water pipe, water meter, meter box, stopcock, standpipe, public fountain, or other fixture or appliance belonging to the city's water system. 
(b)  Any person who violates this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor which shall be punishable by a fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or by imprisonment not exceeding ninety (90) days or both. 
(Ord. No. 2622, § 2, 2-19-09; Ord. No. 2800 , § 2, 11-4-14) 
Secs. 11-10-11-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 11-26. - When connection to sewers is required. 
(a)  The owner of any improved premises located within three hundred (300) feet of any sewer pipe line constituting a part of the combined water and sewer system shall promptly connect such premises thereto. In the event of his failure to do so, it shall be the duty of the director of the department of public works to notify such owner in writing that a sewer line is available to his property and thereupon, if such connection be not made by such owner within a period of sixty (60) days from and after the date of such written notice, the owner or tenant shall nevertheless be billed for sewer service at the rate of the projected average consumption set forth in subsection 11-66(a) for residential and commercial uses. 
(b)  The owner of any improved premises located within three hundred (300) feet of any water line constituting a part of the combined water and sewer system shall promptly connect such premises thereto except in special cases where single-family residences are supplied water from a water well located on the premises. In these special cases it shall be the duty of the director of the department of public works to notify such owner in writing that a water line is available to his property and thereupon, if such connection be not made by such owner within a period of sixty (60) days from and after the date of such written notice, the owner or tenant shall nevertheless be billed for water service at the rate of the projected average consumption set forth in subsection 11-64(a) for residential and commercial uses. 
(Code 1963, § 29-28; Ord. No. 2594, § 4, 7-8-08; Ord. No. 2668, § 2, 3-16-10) 
Sec. 11-27. - Service connection application and contract required. 
    No permit shall be issued for water service connections or sewer service connections until the owner of the premises involved, or his duly authorized agent, shall have signed a proper application and contract therefor, stating that no plumber shall make any additions, alterations or do any other work whereby the prevailing rate for water service or sewer service will be changed until he shall have secured a written order from the owner of the premises affected, or his duly authorized agent, which order shall be filed by such plumber by attaching same to his report filed with the director of the department of public works. 
(Code 1963, § 29-30) 
Sec. 11-28. - Execution of contracts generally. 
    All contracts requested by the customer for tappage under the provisions of this article shall be signed for both water and sewer tapping requests. 
(Ord. No. 1771, § 3, 6-16-87) 
Sec. 11-29. - Connection fees required; terms of customers' contracts. 
    The owner of any premises, his tenant or his duly authorized agent shall pay to the city, before water service or sewer service is connected, fees as set out herein and in accordance with customer's contract covering water and sewer services. The city council shall, by resolution, fix the form of the customer's contract which may contain such pertinent facts as to this chapter, rates, fees, etc., as they deem proper and which may be changed from time to time by resolution as they may deem advisable. 
(Code 1963, § 29-31) 
Sec. 11-30. - Execution of customer's contracts by owners; liability for noncompliance. 
    All customers' contracts, whether for water or sewerage service shall be executed by the owner of the premises, by his tenant or by his duly authorized agent, and the applicant shall be responsible for service charges for water and sewer services to the premises and shall make a deposit thereon as a part of such application as hereinafter provided. 
(Code 1963, § 29-32) 
Sec. 11-31. - Execution of customers'contracts by tenants; deposit required. 
(a)  Water/sewer account deposits. Each tenant or customer applying for water and/or sewerage service from and after the effective date of the ordinance from which this provision derives shall place with the water department of the city or its designees a deposit as follows: 
(1)  For residential premises ..... $ 150.00 
(2)  For all commercial premises ..... 200.00 
(b)  Disposition of deposits. Deposits shall be held in trust to ensure payment of water and sewage charges and shall be applied toward a customer's account for water and/or sewerage services when the account becomes delinquent. Deposits shall not bear interest, and any amount remaining on deposit upon termination of the customer's contract shall first be applied to any final balance on the customer's account with any remaining amount refunded to the customer on request. Deposits shall be kept in a separate fund entitled "water and sewer deposit trust fund." Customers who continuously make payments on or before the appropriate due date for a period of one (1) year (twelve (12) consecutive months) shall have their deposit refunded upon request. The total amount of deposit within the "water and sewer deposit trust fund" for each customer account shall not exceed: 
(1)  For residential premises ..... $ 150.00 
(2)  For all commercial premises ..... 200.00 
(Code 1963, § 29-33; Ord. No. 1860, § 2, 12-5-89; Ord. No. 2151, § 1, 10-9-98; Ord. No. 2281, § 3, 5-8-01; Ord. No. 2344, § 2, 1-7-03; Ord. No. 2346, § 2, 1-9-03; Ord. No. 2622, § 3, 2-19-09; Ord. No. 2698, § 5, 9-14-10) 
Sec. 11-32. - Persons autborized to make water connections. 
    All connections to the water lines, and extensions thereof, shall be made by employees of the department of public works or the designees of the city, except for extensions or installations of unusual magnitude which may require materials, skill or equipment not possessed by or otherwise available to the department or the city, but in such cases such work must be done under the supervision of the director of the department of public works or his authorized representative or designee. 
(Code 1963, § 29-34; Ord.No. 2297, § 4, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 11-33. - Installation, repair of supply pipes, fixtures to be by plumbers; compliance with plumbing regulations. 
    All supply pipes, attachments, fixtures, and things of like character, and repairs thereof, shall be installed or made by duly authorized, bonded plumbers, as hereinafter provided. Before any plumber shall be allowed to do such work, he shall be required to submit acceptable evidence to the director of the department of urban development that he is properly licensed, bonded and qualified to do such work under Article III of Chapter 3 of this Code. The city may recover under such bond any damages that it may suffer by reason of negligence, lack of skill, or any disregard of the provisions of such article on the part of such plumber; and such recovery shall in no wise operate to release such plumber from prosecution in the proper courts for such violation. The permit or privilege granted to any plumber to do such work may be revoked for cause. 
(Code 1963, § 29-35; Ord. No. 2180, § 6, 6-8-99) 
Cross reference- Plumbing and gas, § 3-56 et seq. 
Sec. 11-34. - When property owners, tenants may do work on water connections, fixtures. 
    In the event any property owner or tenant shall possess the necessary skill, material and other essential things to install, repair or alter the connections, pipes and attachments to the water service lines on his own premises, he shall be allowed to do such work, provided that he shall first obtain the necessary permit and file the necessary reports as required of plumbers, but this section shall not be construed to permit irresponsible or incompetent workmen to do such work; and in no case shall such permit extend beyond the premises actually owned or occupied by the person to whom it is issued. 
(Code 1963, § 29-36) 
Sec. 11-35. - Connections from house sewers to sewer lines to be by owner or master plumber. 
(a)  Owners. Sewer line connections from sewer outlets or buildings to sewer lines of the sanitary sewerage system may be laid and connections made by the owners of property as to the property in which he actually resides, provided, that the requirements of Article III of Chapter 3 be followed as to the method of connecting, material used, proper venting and trapping, etc., and provided that said work be inspected and passed by the plumbing inspector of the city prior to use. 
(b)  Master plumbers. All connections of house plumbing with sewer lines except those personally made by the owner of property as to his own residence as provided in subsection (a) above must be made by or under the supervision of a master plumber. 
(Code 1963, § 29-37) 
Sec. 11-36. - Persons authorized to lay sewer line from building to sewer; special licenses. 
(a)  Sewer lines from the sanitary sewer mains to the point of connection with building plumbing shall be made only by or under the supervision of a master plumber, except as provided in section 11-35; except that such sewer lines may be laid but may not be connected, by persons holding special licenses from the city as provided hereinafter. 
(b)  The mayor and city council may issue special licenses to lay sewer lines, but not to make connections with building plumbing or waste lines, to qualified persons who: 
(1)  Make written application to the mayor and city council for such license setting forth their experience, training and qualifications; 
(2)  Receive the unanimous approval of each member of the mayor and city council; 
(3)  Furnish bond of not less than three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) conditioned as bonds of master plumbers in the city are conditioned; 
(4)  Make payment of privilege license required of master plumbers by law. 
(Code 1963, § 29-38) 
Sec. 11-37. - Plumbers to obtain permits for new connections. 
    Before any plumber may proceed to make any installation of new service connections, either for water service or for sewer service, he shall obtain from the department of public works a written permit on a form provided for that purpose, giving the location, the name of the person for whom such work is to be done, and such other essential information relative thereto as the director of the department of public works may require. Such permit shall be returned to the office of the superintendent within twenty-four (24) hours after the completion of such work, properly signed by the plumber to whom it was issued and contain a full and complete statement of the number, kind, and approximate location of all fixtures and outlets made to the combined water and sewer system of the city. 
(Code 1963, § 29-39) 
Sec. 11-38. - Plumbers to give notice and report of repairs, installations. 
    Before any plumber shall proceed to make any repairs, attachments, installations or alterations to any service connections or parts thereof already in use, he shall leave or file a notice at the office of the director of the department of urban development, giving the location of the premises and the name of the person for whom such work is to be done; and within twenty-four (24) hours after such work is completed he shall report to the director of the department of urban development, on a prescribed printed form, a complete list and description of the fixtures and attachments on such premises to which water is supplied at the time when such plumber shall have completed such work. 
(Code 1963, § 29-40; Ord. No. 2180, § 7, 6-8-99) 
Sec. 11-39. - Length of service connections. 
    All service connections made by the department shall extend only to a point not exceeding three (3) feet beyond the prevailing street curbline, or to the property line, and no employee of the department shall be allowed to lay any pipe, make any repairs, attachments, or perform any service in behalf of any tenant or property owner beyond such point because of or relating to such service connections. 
(Code 1963, § 29-41) 
Sec. 11-40. - Size of water taps; curb cock or cutoff required; separate connections required. 
    The size of all water service connections, or taps, shall not be less than five-eighths of an inch in diameter, except in special cases, in which event the director of the department of public works shall designate such size as the particular case may require. All water service connections shall be provided with suitable curb cock or cut-off valve, and a separate service connection shall be required for each premises, house, lot, or subdivision thereof, except as hereinafter provided. 
(Code 1963, § 29-42) 
Sec. 11-41. - Stop and waste cocks required; compliance with other regulations; work to be satisfactory to director. 
    All new water service connections shall be provided with substantial stop and waste cocks located at some convenient and conspicuous place within the boundaries of the premises supplied, and all plumbing work in connection with the water and sewer system shall be done in accordance with this Code and other ordinances, rules and regulations governing such work. All work done by such plumbers shall in every way be satisfactory to the director of the department of urban development. 
(Code 1963, § 29-43; Ord. No. 2180, § 8, 6-8-99) 
Sec. 11-42. - Separate water connections required. 
    Each premises shall be required to have a separate connection to the water main so that service to same can be discontinued without affecting any other customer; and in case any property owner shall have divided his premises so that two (2) or more customers can be served through one (1) connection to the water main, he shall provide a proper shut-off valve for each separate connection, so that service may be discontinued to one (1) customer without affecting any other. All such shut-off valves shall be so arranged or installed that they can only be operated by employees of the department or by authorized, bonded plumbers. 
(Code 1963, § 29-44) 
Sec. 11-43. - Operation of control cocks. 
    Except as provided in section 11-42, no person, except the director of the department of public works or the director of finance, or their duly authorized representatives, shall have the right to tamper with or operate the curb cocks, or to shut off the cock or valve through which water is supplied to any premises, except that authorized, bonded plumbers may be permitted to turn the water on temporarily for the purpose of testing their work, or to shut the water off temporarily for the purpose of making repairs, etc., but in all cases such plumbers shall leave the said curb cock or shut-off cock in the same position and condition in which it was found; provided, however, that any such plumbers shall first obtain the necessary permit and file the necessary report, as herein required. 
(Code 1963, § 29-45; Ord. No. 2180, § 9, 6-8-99) 
Sec. 11-44. - Cross-connection control policy adopted. 
    The cross-connection control policy, which is attached to ordinance 2179, is hereby adopted as the policy for the City of Gulfport, and is incorporated by reference into the city's general ordinances regulating water and sewers codified at Chapter 11 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Gulfport, Mississippi. 
    The city cross connection control policy in effect hereunder is specifically stated to cover all public water systems owned and operated by the City of Gulfport, including without limitation the systems recognized by the State of Mississippi Department of Health as Gulfport PWS #0240003, Orange Grove PWS #0240008, and Oakleigh PWS #0240064. 
    The city cross connection control policy is amended to incorporate and extend as applicable those certain deadlines for implementation of a cross connection control program for completing surveys and on-site visits, and for installation of approved backflow preventers for "high hazard cross connections" and for "low hazard cross connections" and such other statutory requirements or regulations as may be imposed under sections 41-26-14 and 41-26-15, Mississippi Code Annotated, as amended, and any subsequent amendments to said statutory or Mississippi State Department of Health requirements, regulations, or deadlines pertaining to the cross connection control program. 
(Ord. No. 2179, § 2, 6-8-99; Ord. No. 2215, § 2, 1-4-00; Ord. No. 2257, §§ 2, 3, 11-8-00; Ord. No. 2281, § 2, 5-8-01) 
Sec. 11-45. - Sewage pumping connection fees required for sewer connection and service within the one mile corridor outside of the city limits. 
(a)  Fees. The property owner or other proposed user of any premises outside of the city limits of the City of Gulfport desiring to connect to Gulfport sanitary sewer mains for collection and distribution of sewage to the Harrison County Wastewater District facilities shall before sewer service is connected, in addition to all other tap and service fees charged under city ordinances, pay the following sewage pumping connection fee: 
Category Sewage 
Pumping Fee Single-family residence $ 875.00 1-bedroom apartment   500.00 2-bedroom apartment   750.00 3-bedroom apartment  1,125.00 Other developments $2.50 per gallon per day, minimum $500.00  
Sewage flow for category of "other developments" shall be estimated by the city engineering department using accepted engineering parameters. 
(b)  Fees outside of the one mile corridor. Connections to Gulfport wastewater collection facilities shall not be allowed outside of the one (1) mile corridor from the Gulfport city limits until a sewage pumping connection fee is established by the governing authority and approval, if any required, by the Mississippi Public Service Commission, is obtained. 
(c)  Certificated areas excluded. Any area in which a private utility provider has in effect a certificate to serve issued by the Mississippi Public Service Commission is excluded from this section. 
(Ord. No. 2252, § II, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 11-46. - Mobile home parks and apartment complexes. 
(a)  A property owner, who owns or develops an apartment complex or mobile home park in compliance with city ordinances, shall have the option of providing a master meter at the property line to serve all apartments or mobile homes or providing separate meters for each apartment or mobile home. 
(b)  Where the owner desires to provide separate meters for each apartment or mobile home, the following procedures shall be followed: 
(1)  Existing apartment complex or mobile home park. 
a.  The property owner shall have the existing water line system surveyed by a professional engineer licensed in the state. 
b.  Said professional engineer shall verify that the existing system meets the minimum standards of the city as approved by the city engineer and shall certify same to the city. 
c.  If the existing system does not meet the minimum standards of the city, then the professional engineer shall design the improvements that will be necessary to meet the standards. If fire flow is required, the minimum water main size shall be determined by the city on a case-by-case basis. 
d.  Meter boxes and service lines with meter connections for each apartment or mobile home shall be required. 
e.  Once approved by the city engineer, the owner shall be responsible for funding all of the necessary improvements including, but not limited to provision of needed service lines with meter connections, meters, meter boxes and all other improvements required to comply with the minimum standards of the city. 
f.  Owner must provide a minimum fifteen-foot perpetual easement for all main water lines, up to each meter, located within the owner's property. A perpetual right of entry shall also be provided to the city for access. Both the perpetual easement and the perpetual right of entry shall be provided to the city at no cost to the city. 
g.  After all improvements are constructed, the city engineer shall perform a final inspection. Once all improvements are approved, the city shall assume perpetual maintenance of the water mains within the fifteen-foot easement up to the meter. The owner shall still retain ownership and maintenance responsibility for the service lines on the customer's side of the meter. 
2.  Proposed developments of apartment complex or mobile home park. 
a.  The property owner shall have the system designed by a professional engineer licensed in the state. 
b.  The professional engineer shall design the property's water system in accord with the minimum requirements of the city as approved by the city engineer. If fire flow is required, the minimum water main size shall be determined by the city on a case-by-case basis depending on the applicable fire codes for the size of the development and number of residences. 
c.  Once the water system design is approved by the city engineer, the owner shall be responsible for funding all of the necessary construction of the water system. 
d.  After construction of the water system is complete, the city engineer shall perform a final inspection. After the water system is approved, the city shall assume perpetual maintenance of the water mains within the fifteen-foot easement up to the meter. The owner shall retain ownership and maintenance responsibility for the service lines on the customer's side of the meter. 
e.  Owner must provide a minimum fifteen-foot perpetual easement for all main water lines located within the owner's property. A perpetual right of entry shall also be provided to the city for access. 
f.  Apartment complexes shall be designed with a meter bank to house all water meters for each building. 
(c)  [Exceptions.] Recreational vehicle parks are excluded from the provisions of this ordinance. 
(d)  Garbage pick up. 
1.  Apartment complexes over four (4) units must provide dumpster garbage pickup. 
2.  Mobile home parks may provide dumpster garbage pickup or curbside pickup. 
(Ord. No. 2385, § 3, 3-2-04) 
Secs. 11-47-11-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RATES AND CHARGES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Charges for using yacht basin, § 2-80. 
State Law reference- Power of city to prescribe water rates, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 21-27-7; testing of water meters, Miss. Code Ann. 1972, § 21-27-9. 

Sec. 11-61. - Separate meters required; rates when auxiliary premises rented. 
    A separate meter shall be required for each individual premises, house, lot or subdivision thereof, except nonrented auxiliary premises to the rear of the main building. In the event such auxiliary premises are rented, a separate meter shall be required for each such auxiliary premises so rented and the rate for water and sewer as set out in this article shall apply to each such premises or in the event such separate meter is not utilized, the minimum rate for water and sewer service shall be determined by multiplying the number of all such living units by the normal such minimum rate as established herein for one (1) individual premises of like character. 
(Code 1963, § 29-56) 
Sec. 11-62. - Classification of premises. 
    Every such premises, rented auxiliary premises, house, building, lot or subdivision thereof shall be classified according to the purpose for which it is used or operated, and in cases where classification is not herein specifically named, that classification which more nearly approaches such case shall be used. 
(Code 1963, § 29-57) 
Sec. 11-63. - Meter service; flat rates for automatic sprinkler systems; temporary service. 
(a)  Meter service. All water shall be furnished and sold through meter service, and all billings shall be on the basis of rates and charges hereinafter established. 
(b)  Flat rates for automatic sprinkler systems. Water service for automatic sprinkler systems shall be charged a minimum flat rate hereinafter fixed, which shall be payable irrespective of whether water is actually used through such automatic sprinkler systems. 
(c)  Temporary service. Rates for temporary water service via a municipal fire hydrant meter (hereinafter, "meter") shall be those rates established and set forth in section 11-64 with no minimum being applicable for private users. 
(1)  Deposit. Entities or persons requiring use of a meter for procurement of water from the City's water system, shall pay a deposit as follows: 
Commercial (as part of a service performed for compensation) ..... $ 2,650.00 
Private ..... 250.00 
Deposits shall be paid at the time the meter is procured from the city's water billing office (hereinafter, "city") and will be refunded, when the meter is returned for the final time, less any unpaid charges for water usage and/or cost of damage to meter, if any, when the meter is returned to the city on or before the scheduled return date. A deposit will be forfeited, in full, if the meter is not returned on the scheduled return date. 
(2)  Term. All meters are loaned by the city on a month-to-month basis. Thirty (30) days from the date of loan (including a three-day window before and after) (i.e., monthly read date), each loaned meter shall be returned to the city for reading and payment of any charges for water used during the preceding thirty-day period. At the time of loan from the city, the user shall identify to the city the number of months that the meter will be borrowed (no meter may be borrowed for more than six (6) months). The monthly read date for the final month shall be the scheduled return date. 
(3)  Hydrant usage. At the time of loan from the city, the user shall identify to the city the location of the fire hydrant(s) to be used for procurement of water. Use of a fire hydrant(s) other than one identified to the city shall be a violation of this section. Loan of a meter, after payment of the aforementioned deposit, to an entity or person shall create a rebuttable presumption that the said entity or person has been granted permission by the director of the department of public works to make connection to, or otherwise use or operate the identified fire hydrant(s). 
(4)  Violations. It shall be a violation of this section to fail to return a meter on the monthly read date or the scheduled return date. Each day late shall be a separate offense. 
(5)  Damage to meter. Any damage sustained by a meter and/or fire hydrant during the usage will be the responsibility of the user. The cost of damage will be deducted from the deposit and/or billed to the user when the deposit amount (less any water charges paid from the deposit at the scheduled return date) is not sufficient to cover the damage. 
(Code 1963, § 29-58; Ord. No. 2180, § 10, 6-8-99; Ord. No. 2297, § 5, 10-2-01; Ord. No. 2344, § 3, 1-7-03; Ord. No. 2346, § 3, 1-9-03; Ord. No. 2549, § 2, 8-21-07; Ord. No. 2725, § 2, 7-19-11) 
Sec. 11-64. - Water rates and charges established. 
(a)  Meter rates. The rate for water service delivered through a meter for each monthly period shall be as follows: 
October 1, 2015-September 30, 2016: 
Two dollars and forty cents ($2.40) per one thousand (1,000) gallons of water measured for the first three thousand (3,000) gallons, at the rate of two dollars and fifty cents ($2.50) per one thousand (1,000) gallons of water measured for four thousand (4,000) gallons through ten thousand (10,000) gallons, and at the rate of two dollars and sixty cents ($2.60) per one thousand (1,000) measured for the remainder exceeding ten thousand (10,000) gallons during a monthly period. 
October 1, 2016-September 30, 2018: 
Two dollars and fifty cents ($2.50) per one thousand (1,000) gallons of water measured for the first three thousand (3,000) gallons, at the rate of two dollars and sixty cents ($2.60) per one thousand (1,000) gallons of water measured for four thousand (4,000) gallons through ten thousand (10,000) gallons, and at the rate of two dollars and seventy cents ($2.70) per one thousand (1,000) measured for the remainder exceeding ten thousand (10,000) gallons during a monthly period. 
October 1, 2018-September 30, 2019: 
Two dollars and sixty cents ($2.60) per one thousand (1,000) gallons of water measured for the first three thousand (3,000) gallons, at the rate of two dollars and seventy cents ($2.70) per one thousand (1,000) gallons of water measured for four thousand (4,000) gallons through ten thousand (10,000) gallons, and at the rate of two dollars and eighty cents ($2.80) per one thousand (1,000) measured for the remainder exceeding ten thousand (10,000) gallons during a monthly period. 
October 1, 2019-September 30, 2020:

Sec. 11-65. - Water charges for fractional periods. 
    No assessment or charge for water service shall be less than the minimum prescribed unless it be for a fraction of a period, in which case the quantity used shall be included in the quantity consumed in the next following period and the assessment or charge made as if the total had been consumed in one (1) period. 
(Code 1963, § 29-60)

(c)  Premises not served by water, sewer system: 
(1)  In all cases where premises of any kind are not served by water supplied by the combined water and sewer system, but are nevertheless connected to the sewer facilities of the combined system, it shall be the duty of the owners of such premises to install their own water meter satisfactory to the director of the department of public works, to measure the quantity of water used on such premises and not supplied by the combined water and sewer system. The rate for sewer services for such premises shall be computed on the basis of the charge for water service, for the amount of water metered, as though such water had been supplied by the combined water and sewer system, and to that end all such privately installed and owned meters shall be subject to reading and inspection by the director of the department of public works or his authorized agent. 
(2)  Calculation of rates. 
a.  In all cases under this subsection (c) where meters have not been provided, or are out of service, or are not available for reading, the applicable sewage service fees as provided for in subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall be payable monthly calculated as a flat amount of the rate multiplied by 7.60 for all residential users. The multiplier is the average household consumption per one thousand (1,000) gallons according to available engineering reports. When consumption history is available the charge for sewage services will be calculated on a six-month average rather than a fixed amount. 
b.  Commercial rates shall be payable monthly calculated as a flat amount of the rate multiplied by 7.60 for all commercial users. The multiplier is the average commercial consumption per one thousand (1,000) gallons according to averages of businesses of like kind and size. The table of commercial rates is as follows: 
Type of Business Basis per

When consumption history is available, the charge for sewage services will be calculated on a six-month average rather than a fixed amount. 
(d)  Dumping wastes from septic tanks: The dumping of waste from septic tanks shall be at sites directed by the city and the charge for same shall be computed on the basis of five dollars ($5.00) per one thousand (1,000) gallons of waste dumped.

A user contemplating such an extension may request such extension with the user paying for materials and labor necessary to make such extension. If such extension shall be made on such agreement, all pipe and materials shall become and remain the property of the city and shall remain intact and subject to the exclusive control of the city, and additional users may be cut-in on such extension as may be necessary. The cost of additional cut-ins to the sewer mains, required by the division of existing lots or premises, when made by the city, shall be borne by the owners at the reasonable cost of labor and materials.
