If the organization is an Affordable Housing Trust, City Attorney and the Planning Official shall have approved the organization's operating policies, and the organization shall have agreed to annually report the compliance of every Certified Affordable Housing unit it provides as part of any agreement with the City with the rent and the resident qualification requirements of such agreements for a period of at least 30 years, or to donate the property to another Approved Affordable Housing Provider if the organization fails to maintain the required affordability on any Certified unit for a total of more than 8 months in any ten year period within that 30 year term of Certification. 
f.  The organization shall submit an application to the Planning Office attesting to its satisfaction of these requirements, and providing such other reasonable information as shall be deemed relevant by the Planning Official and City Attorney. 
g.  The Planning Official or City Attorney shall not have previously removed the organization from the list of Approved Affordable Housing Providers, unless whatever conditions which led to the removal of such organization shall have been addressed to the satisfaction of both the City Attorney and the Planning Official. 
1.7.1.2  Probation and Removal. The Planning Official shall regularly inspect the list of Approved Affordable Housing Providers, shall determine a probationary period for any organization added to the list and for any organization which has failed to meet the terms of its agreements with the City in a timely manner. An AAHP may be required to forfeit any properties acquired during its probation to another AAHP or to a public housing authority at the City's demand. The Planning Official and City Attorney shall rescind the designation of AAHP and remove from the list of Approved Affordable Housing Providers any organization which has misrepresented its compliance with agreements made with the City for provision of Certified Affordable Housing, or which the Planning Official and City Attorney agree has failed to abide by such agreements in good faith or to significantly correct such failures within a period of one year from the date on which the City has notified the organization of such failures. 
1.7.1.3  Affordable Housing Agreements. The City may enter into an Affordable Housing Agreement with an AAHP or with a public housing authority in conjunction with a developer, land owner, or builder for the creation of a specified number of Certified Affordable Housing units as part of a requirement for increase of allowed Density for a New Community through Density Transfer in accordance with Article 3, or as part of a Density Bonus program in accordance with Article 5. No AAHP shall be required to enter into any such an agreement in order to retain its status as an AAHP. The Planning Official shall keep a record of all Certified Affordable Housing units created as part of Affordable Housing Agreements, and any such unit may be counted as part of at most one Affordable Housing Agreement. The responsibility of the AAHP or public housing authority in such an Agreement with the City shall be to certify the management for affordability of the units according to 1.7.1.4 below; production of such units shall be the responsibility of the developer, land owner, or builder, with the exception that in a case where the AAHP guarantees production of such Certified Affordable Housing units with pre-existing units, not part of any previous Affordable Housing Agreement, owned or controlled by the AAHP, in such case the AAHP shall be held responsible for production of the required units, and after three years from the date of the Agreement if any required units remain unbuilt, the Planning Official shall claim the number of unbuilt units from those offered by the AAHP as guarantee as part of the Affordable Housing Agreement, and shall record such units as having been part of the original Agreement, and such units shall not be eligible for use as part of any such future Agreement. 
1.7.1.4  Certification of Affordable Housing units. A Certified Affordable Housing unit is defined to be an Independent Residential Housing unit certified to the City by an AAHP or public housing authority to be under the control or ownership of the AAHP or the public housing authority and to satisfy the following requirements: 
a.  The unit shall be managed in order to assure continuing affordability for at least 30 years from the date of certification. 
b.  If the unit is to be sold, the certifying AAHP shall be a Community Land Trust, and the first buyer of the unit shall be income-qualified to purchase Affordable Housing, with gross household income of no more than either of 80% of Area Median Income or of 100% of Area Median Income, as specified in the certification, for a household of size suitable for the unit in question. 
c.  If the unit is to be sold, the purchase cost for the first sale of the unit, including mortgage, amortization, taxes, insurance, and condominium or association fees, if any, shall constitute no greater than 30% of either of 80% of Area Median Income or of 100% of Area Median Income, as specified in the certification. 
d.  If the unit is to be rented, the certifier shall be an Affordable Housing Trust with AAHP status or shall be a public housing authority; and the lessee shall be income-qualified annually to rent Affordable Housing, with gross household income of no more than either of 80% of Area Median Income or of 100% of Area Median Income, as specified in the certification, for a household of size suitable for the unit in question. 
e.  If the unit is to be rented, the lease price for the unit shall constitute no more than 30% of either of 80% of Area Median Income or of 100% of Area Median Income, as specified in the certification. 
f.  A certified unit may at any time during the 30-year term of the certification be transferred to another AAHP for continued management subject to the affordability requirements of the original certification. A rental unit held or transferred to a Community Land Trust with AAHP status may be sold at any time subject to the original buyer-qualification and affordability requirements of the original certification. 
g.  A Certified Affordable Housing Unit within a designated Unbundled Parking Area on the applicable Official Community Plan may include an offer of a single parking space for lease at an annual cost of 3% of either of 80% of Area Median Income or of 100% of Area Median Income, as specified in the certification. 
1.7.2  Density Bonuses. Density Bonuses shall be managed by the following procedures: 
1.7.2.1 Certificates of Density Bonus shall be issued by the Planning Official in conjunction with the Office of the City Attorney to a developer, builder, or property owner having met the requirements of some Density Bonus program specified by this Code; each such Certificate shall be uniquely identified, shall indicate the specific lot or parcel through which the Bonus was generated, under what program the Bonus was generated, the number of Equivalent Housing Units awarded for the Bonus, whether the Bonus is transferable to a site other than the one from which it was generated, and shall specifically identify the fulfilled requirements of the Density Bonus program for which the bonus has been issued, and shall specify the date of expiration of such Certificate. 
1.7.2.2 Density Bonuses shall be valid for no more than ten years from date of issue. Within that period proof of Density Bonus shall be submitted with any application which makes use of such Bonus. No less than one-half unit of a Density Bonus may be redeemed at one time. The Planning Office shall keep records of all redeemed Density Bonuses and of the lots and parcels on which the Bonus is redeemed, and shall check each Bonus Certificate submitted for redemption against the list of previously redeemed Bonuses. Each fractional or whole redemption shall be recorded permanently on the Density Bonus Certificate. 
1.7.2.3 The Planning Official shall keep a record of all issued Density Bonuses, including indication of status as to redemption, lots and parcels where the Bonuses were redeemed, and any other facts necessary to the seamless administration of the Density Bonus programs described in this Code. The Planning Official shall annually compile a list of Density Bonuses issued and of structures constructed during the year with Density Bonuses, including tax parcel numbers and street addresses, and shall make such list available publicly. 
1.7.2.4 A Density Bonus shall not attach permanently to a lot or parcel. A Density Bonus Certificate may only be redeemed before its expiration for the permitting of a structure consistent with the requirements of the original Density Bonus program. Any structure completed using a Density Bonus shall not be considered non-conforming with the SmartCode and the Official Community Plan if it is otherwise compliant, and a Certificate of SmartCode Compliance may be issued for the structure. Such a structure may be added to or modified in Function. However, if the Function Volume associated with such a structure is increased after the expiration of the Density Bonus on which its original construction depended, that Density Bonus may not be counted for the purpose of figuring the compliance of the structure with the Density requirements of this Code after the increase in Function Volume. 
1.7.2.5 Density Bonuses shall be issued only after completion of all the requirements specified in the awarding Density Bonus program. However, in the case of Density Bonus programs requiring construction of Affordable Housing, the Bonus may be issued before completion of the required housing units under one or more of the following conditions: 
a.  All incomplete Certified Affordable Housing units required for the Density Bonus award are guaranteed by pre-existing Certified Affordable Housing units pledged and held by an AAHP which is party to the corresponding Affordable Housing Agreement with the City; and the land required for the required new units has been secured and is in possession of the AAHP. The units acting as guarantee may not have been produced in fulfillment of any Affordable Housing Agreement with the City, and may not be included as guarantee units in any other incomplete Affordable Housing Agreement during the period during which such units act as guarantee. Guarantee units need not be located in accordance with the requirements of the Affordable Housing Agreement for which they act as guarantee, nor do they in any way lessen the requirement for production of units required by the Affordable Housing Agreement. In the event that the required Certified Affordable Housing units have not been completed within three (3) years of the initial date of the Affordable Housing Agreement, the Planning Official shall record the pledged guarantee units as fulfilling the AAHP's requirement for certification of the unfinished units, but the developer, builder, or land owner shall nevertheless be obligated to complete the construction of the unfinished units. 
b.  Developer, builder, or land owner agrees in writing that no certificate of occupancy shall be issued for any structure depending in whole or in part on the awarded Density Bonus until all required Certified Affordable Housing units have either been completed, inspected, and received certificates of occupancy, or all incomplete such units are guaranteed by pre-existing Certified Affordable Housing units pledged by an AAHP. Land required for construction of the required units in the required locations shall be in possession of the AAHP before any Bonus may be awarded. Developer, builder, or land owner further agrees that until such certificate of occupancy is issued, the structure(s) shall remain unoccupied and in violation of zoning requirements. 
1.7.3  Density Transfers. Attachment and vacation of Density Rights shall be managed according to the following provisions. 
1.7.3.1  Sending and Receiving Areas. Density Transfer Sending Areas shall be determined by Official Community Plans, and by the Sector Plan for the City, if one has been adopted, in compliance with one of the Density Transfer programs described in this Code. Density Transfer Receiving Areas shall be determined by Official Community Plans, and by the Sector Plan for the City, if one has been adopted. 
1.7.3.2  Transaction Types and Procedures. Density Transfer transactions shall be conducted according to the specific type of transaction: 
a.  Building-Scale Density Transfer transactions shall require the vacation of Density Rights for the Density Donor lot or parcel according the requirements of 1.7.3.3 below, and shall additionally require the attachment of the detached Density Allowance from the Donor to the Density Recipient lot or parcel according to the requirements of 1.7.3.4 below. 
b.  Community-Scale Density Transfer transactions shall require the vacation of Density Rights from a Density Donor lot or parcel according to the requirements of 1.7.3.3 below and shall additionally require the disbursement of the extinguished Density Allowance throughout a New Community Plan in accordance with Article 3. 
c.  Alternatively the Density Rights extracted from a Density Donor in a Density Transfer transaction may be represented by a Certificate of Detached Density Rights prepared by the Planning Official in conjunction with the Office of the City Attorney in accordance with the requirements of 1.7.3.5 below. Such a Certificate may then be used at any later date to effectively replace the Density Donor site in a Density Transfer transaction, the extracted Density Rights being transferred from the Certificate to the Density Recipient site. 
1.7.3.3  Vacation of Density Rights. When Density Rights are extracted from a Donor lot or parcel as part of a Density Transfer, the Density Rights shall be permanently vacated from such lot or parcel according to the following procedure: 
a.  Application for Density Extraction shall be submitted to the Planning Office by the owner of the Density Donor property, along with a warranty deed and such additional documentation as the Planning Official shall deem necessary. The Planning Office shall determine the eligibility of the Donor property for the Density Transfer by determining whether the property lies within a Sending Area designated by an Official Community Plan or Sector Plan, whether the property meets the requirements of the designating Plan for the Sending Area, and whether the Density Rights have previously been extracted from the property. If the Donor property is designated as part of a Linked Sending Group of lots or parcels, the Planning Office shall determine that no other property within the Linked Sending Group has already had its Density Rights vacated. 
b.  The Planning Office shall determine the By-Right Density Allowance of the lot or parcel, or the Effective Density Allowance of the lot or parcel if it is part of an O-2 Sector Sending Area. For this purpose the Planning Office may require that the property owner submit a survey of the lot or parcel. 
c.  If the Donor property has been found to be eligible for Density Transfer, the Planning Official may issue a Notice of Intent to Extract Density Rights to the property owner acknowledging the eligibility, specifying the By-Right or Effective Density Allowance of the property, and describing requirements for completing the extraction, including the removal of any structures which would be non-conforming after the completion of the density extraction. 
d.  For a Donor lot or parcel which is part of a designated Conservation Density Transfer Sending Area, Density Rights shall be extinguished on the Donor property by the owner's granting of a perpetual conservation easement to an Approved Conservation Trust by deed restriction. The deed restriction shall prohibit any structures on the lot or parcel. Public access requirements shall be as specified by the designating Community or Sector Plan; public access shall not be required if unspecified by the designation plan. The deed restriction shall meet such other requirements as are set forth for the Conservation Density Transfer program in Articles 2, 4, and 5, and shall be of a form which has been approved by the City Attorney. 
e.  For a Donor lot or parcel which is part of a designated Civic Space Density Transfer Sending Area, Density Rights shall be extinguished on the Donor property by the owner's granting of a perpetual conservation easement to an Approved Conservation Trust by deed restriction. The deed restriction may permit a single structure for public restroom facilities, but shall otherwise prohibit all structures on the lot or parcel. The deed restriction shall explicitly permit unlimited public access. The deed restriction shall meet such other requirements as are set forth for the Civic Space Density Transfer program in Articles 4 and 5, and shall be of a form which has been approved by the City Attorney. The lot or parcel may further be dedicated to the City, but such dedication shall not be required. 
f.  For a Donor lot or parcel which is part of a designated Transit Grid Reserve Density Transfer Sending Area, Density Rights shall be extinguished on the Donor property by the owner's granting of a perpetual conservation easement to an Approved Conservation Trust by deed restriction. The deed restriction shall prohibit construction of any structures on the lot or parcel other than those related to the provision of public transit, and shall provide for the future use of the lot by the City for public right of way for any of public transit, a pedestrian or bike path, or a Thoroughfare. The deed restriction shall meet such other requirements as are set forth for the Transit Grid Reserve Density Transfer program in Articles 2, 4, and 5, and shall be of a form which has been approved by the City Attorney. If no Approved Conservation Trust can be found which will accept the required deed restriction terms, the lot or parcel may be instead dedicated to the City and deed restricted to public transit or public street usage. 
g.  For a Donor lot or parcel which is part of a designated Density Recovery Transfer Sending Area, the required Donor area shall be subdivided from the original lot or parcel and dedicated to the City for public use. The Donor property shall be deed restricted to the use for which the Density Recovery Transfer is granted. The deed restriction shall meet such other requirements as are set forth for the Density Recovery Transfer program in Articles 4 and 5, and shall be of a form which has been approved by the City Attorney. 
h.  After execution of the required deed restrictions, the Planning Office shall confirm that the restriction has been properly recorded. After such confirmation is obtained, the Planning Office shall attach the extracted Density Rights from the Donor property to a Density Recipient lot or parcel designated by the Donor property owner, or shall provide to the owner of the Donor property a Certificate of Detached Density Rights representing the extracted Density Allowance of the Donor property, as indicated on the Application for Density Extraction. Before the transfer is executed or the Certificate is issued, the Planning Office shall verify that no structures remain on the Donor property. 
i.  Density Donor properties shall, within one (1) year of having Density Rights extracted, be rezoned by the Planning Office according to the requirements of the particular Density Transfer program which designated the Sending Area of which the Donor property is a part. The Planning Office shall keep a record of all Donor properties from which Density Rights have been vacated so that a permanent development ban may be enforced. 
1.7.3.4  Attachment of Density Rights. Density Rights extracted from a Density Donor lot or parcel may be immediately transferred to Density Recipient lots or parcels, or may be transferred by way of a Certificate of Detached Density Rights. The procedure for attachment of Density Rights depends upon whether the intended Recipients are lots or parcels within designated Receiving Areas of Official Community Plans (Building-Scale Density Transfer) or entire Transect Zones which are part of a New Community Plan (Community-Scale Density Transfer); in any case the authenticity of the Density Rights to be transferred, whether directly from a Sending Area or by Certificate of Detached Density Rights, shall be verified by the Planning Office. 
a.  Building-Scale Density Transfer. A covenant between the City and the owner of the Recipient lot or parcel, running with the land, shall be executed and recorded specifying the amount and origin of the transferred Density Rights, and committing the City to recognize the addition of transferred Density Rights in perpetuity. Such covenant shall be of a form approved by the City Attorney. 
b.  Community-Scale Density Transfer. Certificates of Detached Density Rights representing the extracted Density Rights of Donors shall be referenced in any New Community Plan submitted for adoption in which Density Transfers are utilized. The transferred Density Rights shall be attached by means of increased Transect Zone density limits in accordance with Article 3, and the density increases for each Transect Zone resulting from the attachment shall be specified in the New Community Plan. If the developer of the New Community so requests, the City shall agree to the execution and recording of covenants specifying the increase of density by transfer for each Transect Zone and committing the City to recognize the addition of such transferred Density Rights in perpetuity. Such covenant shall be of a form approved by the City Attorney. 
1.7.3.5  Certificates of Detached Density Rights. Ownership of Density Rights extracted from a Density Donor may be retained indefinitely apart from the lot or parcel where they originated in the form of a Certificate of Detached Density Rights. There shall be no time limit for the redemption of Detached Density Rights, but re-attachment to a Density Recipient property shall require the provision of a valid Certificate and corroboration in the form of a deed restriction on the original Density Donor lot or parcel consistent with such Certificate. Certificates of Detached Density Rights shall include at a minimum the following information and requirements: 
a.  A unique identifier. 
b.  The date of extraction of Density Rights from the original Donor property. 
c.  A description uniquely identifying the Donor lot or parcel. 
d.  The area of the Donor parcel, and the By-Right or Effective Density Allowance extracted from the parcel, signifying the redeemable value of the Certificate. 
e.  The legal name of the owner of the Donor lot or parcel at the date of extraction. 
f.  The written signatures of the City Attorney and Planning Official on the date of extraction. 
g.  The written signature or mark of the owner of the Donor lot or parcel at the date of extraction. 
h.  A designated block of text, providing a description of the transaction including items a through e above, which is authenticated through a means of public-key encryption by the Planning Official and the City Attorney, whose public keys shall be kept on record by the Planning Office indefinitely. 
Issued Certificates shall also meet any other requirements deemed reasonable by the City Attorney or Planning Official in order to assure provable authenticity. The Planning Office shall maintain a secure record of all such Certificates issued and redeemed, and of the associated properties involved in issuance and redemption. The Planning Official and City Attorney shall establish and make available for public description procedures for the transfer of ownership of Certificates of Detached Density Rights. A single Certificate of Detached Density Rights may be exchanged for multiple Certificates representing in total the density value of the original Certificate; the resulting Certificates shall be required to include in addition to the above information the authenticated text block from the original Certificate. 
1.7.3.6  Approved Conservation Trusts. The Planning Official shall maintain a publicly available list of Approved Conservation Trusts which meet the requirements of the City for acceptance and enforcement of conservation easements to facilitate enforcement of vacated Density Rights. In order to be designated as an Approved Conservation Trust, an organization shall meet the following requirements: 
a.  The organization shall be recognized by the United States Department of Treasury's Internal Revenue Service as a tax-exempt non-profit organization. 
b.  The stated primary purpose of the organization as set forth in its charter shall include conservation of land, open space, green space, or ecology in an area which includes the City of Gulfport, MS. 
c.  The organization shall have previously been granted conservation easements to protect land within the State of Mississippi. 
d.  In cases where land owners arrange with the organization for the vacation of Density Rights for lots or parcels in order to implement Density Transfers under this Code, the organization shall have agreed to employ deed restrictions in order to secure perpetual conservation easements which the City Attorney has approved as sufficiently security the required prohibition of development intended by this Code for vacated Density Donor properties. 
e.  The organization has agreed to name the City as a secondary or tertiary enforcer of conservation easements for properties vacated of Density Rights for the purpose of Density Transfer under this Code. 
f.  The Mayor and City Council have approved the designation of the organization as an Approved Conservation Trust. 
1.7.3.7 The Planning Official or the City Attorney may establish such other reasonable procedural requirements as they see fit to assure the integrity of the Density Transfer process and the authenticity of Detached Density Rights Certificates. 
1.7.3.8 The Mayor and City Council may establish by ordinance a schedule of fees for the administration and processing of Density Transfers and for the issuance of Certificates of Detached Density Rights. 
1.8 - PRE-EXISTING AND POST-EMERGENCY CONDITIONS 
1.8.1  Damage Due to Emergency Conditions. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained or implied herein, if a building, structure, or other improvement is damaged or destroyed by any event resulting in the declaration of an emergency or disaster applicable to the City by the Mayor and City Council, the owner of record on the date of the event may repair or rebuild such building, structure or other improvement on the same building site and with the same building footprint by right. To qualify, the building, structure, or other improvement must have been legally permitted to have been built under this or other Codes, or have legally existed as a non-conforming building, structure, or other improvement prior to the causative event; neither the lot, use, building, improvement, structure nor condition shall be added to or altered in any way, except to remedy the effects of such damage or destruction, unless such additions or alterations cause the lot, use, building, improvement, structure or condition to conform more closely with the provisions of this Code; and permits for repair or replacement of such buildings, structures, or improvements shall have been issued within one (1) year of the causative event. 
1.8.2  Pre-Existing Non-Conformity. Without limiting the foregoing, any lot, parcel, use, building, improvement, structure or condition subject to an Official Community Plan under this Code that lawfully existed upon the adoption by the Mayor and City Council of that Community Plan shall be allowed to continue, and may be repaired to such pre-existing condition, provided that such lot, use, building, improvement, structure or condition may not be changed or added to after such date, except to conform more closely with the provisions of this Code, and provided that the use is not changed to another use prohibited by law. If the non-conforming use, condition, or feature ceases for a period in excess of one (1) year before either permitting is granted and reconstruction or repair commences or the use is resumed, the subsequent use, condition, or construction shall be fully compliant with this Code. 
1.9 - SUCCESSION 
1.9.1  Succession. Ten years after the approval is granted for a Community Plan, and every ten years thereafter, at the request of residents or property owners within the Community Planning Area, each Transact (sic) Zone, except the T1 Natural and the T2 Rural, shall be considered for rezoning in whole or in part to the successional (next higher numbered) Transect Zone through public consultation and at the recommendation of the Planning Commission through public hearing after 15 days advance published notice, and by approval of the Mayor and City Council. 
(Ord. No. 2600, § 2, 8-19-08) 
1.10 - GOVERNMENT PROPERTY 
1.10  Government property. Property owned by the United States of America, the State of Mississippi or Harrison County, and which is not subject to the police power of the City of Gulfport and property owned by the City of Gulfport or its urban renewal agency, are hereby declared to be exempt from all regulations of this ordinance. Such property is designated on the official zoning map as G.P. (Government Property). Transfer of such property to private ownership shall automatically subject it to the regulations of the district in which it is located. 
(Ord. No. 2674, § 1, 5-4-10) 
ARTICLE 2. - SECTOR-SCALE PLANS 

2.1 - GENERAL INSTRUCTIONS 
2.1.1 Sector Plans shall integrate the largest practical geographic area, overlapping property lines as necessary and municipal boundaries to the extent that the adjacent City or County can legally implement such Sector Plans. 
2.1.2 If requested by the Mayor and City Council, Sector Plans shall be prepared by the Planning Commission or, at the discretion of the Mayor and City Council, by consultants under its supervision, or, if requested by the Planning Commission, by the Planning Office. The process shall involve citizen participation and shall require consideration by the Planning Commission in public hearing after fifteen (15) days' public notice in compliance with state law; upon receipt of a recommendation and record from the Planning Commission, the Mayor and City Council shall approve or modify such Plan, or shall remand it to the Planning Commission for further consideration. 
2.1.3 The areas to be designated Preserved Open Sector (O-1) shall be mapped using the criteria listed in Section 2.3. The outline of this Sector is effectively the Rural Boundary Line (RBL), which is permanent. All other Sectors may qualify for development but conditional to the requirements of Sections 2.1.4 through 2.1.9. 
2.1.4 The areas to be designated Reserved Open Sector (O-2) shall be mapped using the criteria listed in Section 2.4. The boundary between this Sector and any adjacent Sectors G-1, G-2, G-3, or G-4 is effectively the Urban Boundary Line (UBL), which is to be adjusted by the permitting of Community Plans according to this Code. 
2.1.5 To the extent permitted under applicable state law, the City shall establish and administer a Conservation Density Transfer program and a Transit Grid Reserve Density Transfer program for the gradual transfer of development rights from the Reserved Open Sectors (O-2) to the G-2 and G-3 Growth Sectors and to select areas in the G-4 Infill Growth Sector. Conservation and Transit Grid Reserve Density Transfers shall be available to exceed the allocated densities of the New Communities (Section 3.4 and Table 14B) and to exceed the allowed buildable densities for designated areas of the Existing Communities within prescribed limits. The Reserve Sectors (O-2), which comprise Conservation Density Transfer Sending Areas and Transit Grid Reserve Density Transfer Sending Areas, thereby become part of the Preserve Sectors (O-1). Transit Grid Reserve Sending Areas (Future Transportation Corridors) included in the Reserve Sector (O-2) shall be explicitly designated on the Sector Plan. The Planning Office shall maintain a record of all such transfers from either Density Transfer program, updating the Sector map accordingly, and shall not permit development of parcels within the Preserve Sectors (O-1). Specific lots and parcels within Growth Sector G-4 may also be designated as Conservation Density Transfer Sending Areas or Transit Grid Reserve Density Transfer Sending Areas as part of an Official Community Plan if they are judged to correspond to the criteria of Section 2.3 or 2.4, to merit preservation for the betterment of the Community. On extraction of Density Rights such parcels shall be designated as Transect Zone T1, but shall not be included in the Reserve Sector (O-2). 
2.1.6 Infill Growth Sectors (G-4) shall be mapped as described in Section 2.8. These areas may be redeveloped according to Article 4 of this Code. 
2.1.7 Where transit service is planned or available, Regional Center Developments (RCD) shall be re-designated as Transit-Oriented Developments (TOD). 
2.1.8 Those areas that are justified for specialized uses but cannot or should not conform to one of the six Transect Zones shall be allocated to Special Districts (SD). 
2.1.9 All remaining areas are available for development as New Communities conditional to Article 3 of this Code. These areas shall be assigned to one of the three Growth Sectors G-1, G-2, and G-3 by factoring the existing zoning, the metropolitan transportation plans, parcel size and other criteria determined through a process of citizen participation, in accordance with the provisions of Sections 2.5, 2.6 and 2.7 hereof. Within these Growth Sectors, the corresponding Community Types of CLD (Conservation Land Development), TND (Traditional Neighborhood Development), and RCD (Regional Center Development), shall be permitted by right, to the extent set forth in Table 2. 
2.2 - [RESERVED] 
2.3 - (O-1) PRESERVED OPEN SECTOR 
2.3.1 The Preserved Open Sector shall consist of open space that is protected from development in perpetuity. The Preserved Open Sector includes areas under environmental protection by law or standard, as well as land acquired for conservation through purchase, by easement, or by past transfer of Density Rights. 
2.3.2 The Preserved Open Sector shall consist of the aggregate of the following categories: 
a.  Surface water bodies 
b.  Protected wetlands 
c.  Protected habitat 
d.  Riparian corridors 
e.  Purchased open space, including transfer of Special Flood Hazard Areas for the purpose of hazard mitigation 
f.  Conservation easements 
g.  Transportation corridors 
h.  Open space residual to a Hamlet (CLD) 
2.3.3 [RESERVED] 
2.3.4 The outline of the Preserved Open Sector shall be considered the Rural Boundary Line (RBL). 
2.4 - (O-2) RESERVED OPEN SECTOR 
2.4.1 The Reserved Open Sector shall consist of open space that should be, but is not yet, protected from development, as well as open space reserved for future development and inclusion within the Urban Boundary Line. 
2.4.2 The Reserved Open Sector shall consist of the aggregate of the following categories: 
a.  Undeveloped flood hazard areas, including Special Flood Hazard Areas not yet transferred to the Preserve for the purpose of hazard mitigation 
b.  Steep slopes and critical habitats 
c.  Open space to be acquired 
d.  Riparian corridors to be acquired 
e.  Buffers to be acquired 
f.  Legacy woodland, marsh, and swamp 
g.  Legacy farmland 
h.  Legacy Viewsheds 
i.  Future transportation corridors to be acquired 
2.4.3 To the extent permitted by applicable law, the Reserved Open Sector is a Conservation Density Transfer Sending Area, except for areas explicitly designated as Transit Grid Reserve Density Transfer Sending Areas; all of the Reserve Open Sector is available for the gradual transfer of development rights to New and Existing Communities in the four Growth Sectors. The Density Rights shall be available to be used to exceed the allocated Densities of the New Communities (Section 3.4 and Table 14B), and to increase buildable density limits of designated areas in Existing Communities. Areas where the Density Rights have been extracted from the Reserved Open Sector become integral to the Preserved Open Sector. 
2.4.4 Within the Reserved Open Sector, the Urban Growth Boundary (UGB) is subject to adjustment as New Community Plans are permitted. 
2.5 - (G-1) RESTRICTED GROWTH SECTOR 
2.5.1 The Restricted Growth Sector shall be assigned to areas that have value as open space but nevertheless are subject to development, either because the zoning has already been granted or because there is no legally defensible reason, in the long term, to deny it. 
2.5.2 Within the Restricted Growth Sector, Conservation Land Developments (CLD) shall be permitted by right. CLDs shall consist of no more than one Standard Pedestrian Shed with that portion of its site assigned to the T1 Natural or T2 Rural Zones as specified in Section 3.3.1. 
2.6 - (G-2) CONTROLLED GROWTH SECTOR 
2.6.1 The Controlled Growth Sector shall be assigned to those locations where development is encouraged, as it can support mixed-use by virtue of proximity to a Thoroughfare. 
2.6.2 Within the Controlled Growth Sector, Traditional Neighborhood Developments (TND) shall be permitted by right, as well as CLDs. TNDs shall consist of one or several Standard Pedestrian Sheds as specified in Section 3.3.2. 
2.7 - (G-3) INTENDED GROWTH SECTOR 
2.7.1 The Intended Growth Sector shall be assigned to those locations planned for high-capacity Thoroughfares or transit that can thereby support substantial commercial development. 
2.7.2 Within the Intended Growth Sector, communities in the pattern of Regional Center Developments (RCD) shall be permitted by right, as well as TNDs. Regional Centers shall consist of one Long Pedestrian Shed as specified in Section 3.3.3. Additional TNDs may adjoin a Regional Center without buffer requirements. 
2.7.3 Regional Center locations that are served by available or planned bus rapid transit or rail transit service shall be designated as Transit-Oriented Developments (TOD). 
2.8 - (G-4) INFILL GROWTH SECTOR 
2.8.1 The Infill Growth Sector shall be assigned to areas already developed, having the potential to be modified, confirmed or completed in the pattern of TNDs or RCDs. Such areas may include conventional suburban developments, Greyfield and Brownfield sites, and historic urban areas. 
2.9 - (SD) SPECIAL DISTRICT 
2.9.1 Special District designations shall be assigned to areas that, by their intrinsic Function, cannot conform to one of the Community Types specified in this Article. 
2.9.2 The provisions of the Existing Local Codes shall remain solely applicable to Special Districts, unless and until the standards and conditions of development for such Special Districts shall be determined in public hearing of the Mayor and City Council. Property owners within a Special District may submit to the City a Redevelopment Community Plan for consideration. Such a Plan shall comply generally with the requirements of a New Community Plan under Article 3 with the exception of minimum size requirements, and may be adopted by the City in accordance with the requirements of Section 1.4.6 for New Community Plans. 
2.9.3 The standards and conditions determined for Special Districts shall be recorded on Table 15. 
ARTICLE 3. - NEW COMMUNITY SCALE PLANS 

3.1 - GENERAL INSTRUCTIONS 
3.1.1 Article 3 shall be available as an option for development by right pursuant to the requirements set forth in Sections 3.2 and 3.3. The Existing Local Codes also shall remain available by right, except in certain districts of the City where by proper planning process in accordance with state law this Code is made mandatory. Though available as an option, once invoked in accordance with Section 3.12, this Article shall be applied in its entirety. 
3.1.2 Incentives for the use of this Code are listed in Section 1.6. 
3.1.3 New Community Plans may be prepared by or on behalf of an owner or developer, or on behalf of the Planning Commission. 
3.1.4 New Communities of the Types corresponding to the appropriate Sectors, if applicable, which are planned according to the provisions of this Code shall be approved through an expedited process combining rezoning and plat approval, to the extent possible under applicable law as described in Section 3.12. 
3.1.5 The owner or developer may request a New Community Type other than one that is allowed by the designated Sector on the Sector Map, if applicable, through the rezoning process. 
3.1.6 If a Sector Plan is adopted pursuant to Article 2 hereof, Growth Sectors G-1, G-2 and G-3 (described in Article 2) designate the potential geographic locations of three Types of New Communities: Conservation Land Development (CLD), Traditional Neighborhood Development (TND) and Regional Centers (RCD) or Transit-Oriented Development (TOD). These Community Types are prescribed in Section 3.3. If a Sector Plan has not been adopted, the extent to which any of the three Types of New Communities may be developed in a given location shall be subject to determination by the CRC in accordance with the limitations of Section 3.3. Each New Community Plan shall clearly indicate which Type of New Community is proposed under the Plan. 
3.1.7 Each New Community Plan shall respond to the existing conditions of the site, to adjacent developments, to connecting Thoroughfares, to natural features and to man-made Traces, as determined by the CRC. 
3.1.8 Each New Community Plan, according to its Type and responding to existing conditions, shall be structured as one or several Pedestrian Sheds as specified in Section 3.3. 
3.1.9 Each New Community Plan shall allocate the Transect Zones and Densities as specified in Sections 3.2 and Tables 2 and 14. 
3.1.10 Remnants of the site outside the Pedestrian Sheds may be designated as Natural Zones (T1), Rural Zones (T2), Sub-Urban Zones (T3) or as Civic Space (CS). However in no case shall the total area of the New Community devoted to T3 Zones exceed 40% (See Section 3.3) 
3.1.11 Each New Community Plan shall lay out the Thoroughfare network according to the provisions of Section 3.6 and Tables 10A and B. 
3.1.12 Each New Community Plan shall allocate Civic Functions according to Section 3.7. 
3.1.13 Each New Community Plan shall be detailed with the Special Requirements described in Section 3.10. 
3.1.14 Each New Community Plan shall incorporate the incentives available according to Section 1.6. 
3.1.15 Each New Community Plan shall include a set of building standards prepared in accordance with the requirements of Article 5. 
3.1.16 Each New Community Plan shall establish density requirements as described in Section 3.4. 
3.1.17 Each New Community Plan shall comply with the environmental requirements described in Section 3.5. 
3.1.18 Each New Community Plan shall address parking accommodation requirements as described in Section 3.8. 
3.1.19 Application of this Code shall be mandatory within the Community Planning Area established by a New Community Plan once approved, without recourse to the Existing Local Codes where they conflict with this Code or with the Community Plan. 
3.1.20 Names employed for New Communities and for Thoroughfares and natural features therein shall reflect inasmuch as is possible the local history of the site or of the immediate area including the site. Thoroughfare and New Community names shall not duplicate nor phonetically approximate the names of existing Communities or subdivisions within the county. 
3.1.21 Where it conflicts with requirements and design standards of the City's Subdivision Ordinance, this Code shall take precedence. 
3.2 - TRANSECT ZONES 
3.2.1 Transect Zones shall comprise the elements described in Table 1 and the standards summarized in Table 14 and described in Article 5. Transect Zone districts shall be laid out in a New Community Plan in accordance with the requirements of Section 3.3 for the particular Community Type. 
3.2.2 Transect Zones shall be laid out within a New Community Plan so that zone boundaries do not lie along Thoroughfares with the exception of Service Alleys and Lanes, except by Warrant, so that Facades of one Transect Zone generally face Facades of the same zone. 
3.3 - COMMUNITY TYPES 
Conservation Land Development (CLD) 
3.3.1  a.  A Hamlet or Conservation Land Development (CLD) may be permitted at the discretion of the CRC with approval of the Planning Commission in rural areas of the City; provided, however, that if a Sector Plan has been adopted under Article 2 hereof, CLDs shall be permitted by Right within the G-1 Restricted Growth Sector and with Planning Commission approval within O-2 Reserved Open Sector. 
b.  A Conservation Land Development (CLD) shall consist of no more than one standard Pedestrian Shed (1/4 mile radius) including T2, T3 and T4 Zones in the areal proportions specified in Table 14A. The developed area (T3 and T4 Zones) shall include a minimum of 10 acres but not more than 40 acres, and an area equal to or greater than that of the developed area shall be permanently allocated to Natural and Rural Zones (T1 & T2) to provide a natural conservation buffer. 
3.3.2 Traditional Neighborhood Development (TND) 
a.  Traditional Neighborhood Developments (TNDs) shall be permitted by right throughout the City for New Community Plans of at least 80 contiguous acres for Greenfield, and of at least 40 contiguous acres in infill areas, except for those parts of the City designated as Open, Reserved, Preserved or protected space, or zoned as Special District on the Sector map; provided, however, that if a Sector Plan has been adopted under Article 2 hereof, TNDs shall be permitted by right only within the G-2 Controlled Growth Sector, the G-3 Intended Growth Sector, and the G-4 Infill Growth Sector. The simultaneous planning of larger and adjacent parcels is encouraged. 
b.  A TND may comprise a partial or entire Standard Pedestrian Shed (1/4 mile radius) or more than one Standard Pedestrian Shed, each with the various Transect Zones in the areal proportions specified in Tables 2 and 14A for a TND. 
c.  A TND shall only be located in the vicinity of a major existing or planned Thoroughfare. 
3.3.3 Regional Center Development (RCD) 
a.  Regional Center Developments (RCD) shall be permitted at the discretion of the CRC with approval of the Mayor and City Council; provided, however, that if a Sector Plan has been adopted under Article 2 hereof, RCDs shall be permitted by right within G-3 Intended Growth Sector and G-4 Infill Growth Sector. 
b.  The minimum developable area of a site to be planned as an RCD shall be 160 acres for Greenfield, and 80 contiguous acres for Infill areas. The simultaneous planning of larger and adjacent parcels is encouraged. 
c.  An RCD shall be limited to one Long Pedestrian Shed (1/2 mile radius) including T4, T5, and T6 Zones in areal proportions as specified in Table 14A, and may be adjoined without buffers by one or several partial or entire Standard Pedestrian Sheds, each with the individual Transect Zone requirements of a TND as specified in Tables 2 and 14A. 
d.  An RCD shall only be located in the vicinity of important existing or planned intersections of major Thoroughfares. 
3.3.4 Transit-Oriented Development (TOD) 
An RCD that is on an existing or projected transit network shall be redesignated as a TOD and allowed the additional Density shown in Table 14A and calculated in accordance with Section 3.4. 
3.4 - DENSITY REQUIREMENTS 
3.4.1 The Developable Areas of the site shall be considered the Net Site Area. The Net Site Area shall be allocated to the various Transect Zones according to the parameters specified in Table 14A for the type of New Community being developed. 
3.4.2 The initial Density Allocation for the area of each Transect Zone shall be calculated in terms of Equivalent Housing Units (EHU) in accordance with the Gross Equivalent Density limits of Table 14B. For the purposes of Gross Equivalent Density calculations, the Transect Zone areas include the Thoroughfares but not land allocated to Civic Functions. The By-Right Density Allocation for a Transect Zone is then the Gross Area mapped to that Zone multiplied by the By-Right Gross Equivalent Density limit for that Zone from Table 14B. 
3.4.3 The Density Allocation for a Transect Zone may be increased by the use of Community-Scale Density Transfers, up to the effective By-Transfer Gross Equivalent Density limit specified for each Zone by Table 14B. For each Transect Zone district with Density Allocation so increased, no less than fifteen percent (15%) of the increase by Density Transfer shall be designated for Affordable Housing accessible to buyers at the 100% AMI level, to be distributed throughout such district. Alternatively the developer may choose to replace any three (3) such designated Affordable Housing units with one Certified Affordable Housing unit provided through an Approved Affordable Housing Provider in accordance with Section 1.7.1 and two market-rate units. 
3.4.4 For each Transect Zone district, a portion of the final Density Allocation consistent with Table 14B shall be exchanged for other Functions at the following rates: 
a.  For Lodging: 2 bedrooms for each Equivalent Housing Unit exchanged. 
b.  For Office or Retail: 1000 square feet for each Equivalent Housing Unit exchanged. 
c.  The number of Equivalent Housing Units exchanged shall be approved by Warrant. 
3.4.5 The housing and other Functions for each Transect Zone shall be further adjusted at the building scale according to Article 5. 
3.4.6 After Thoroughfares, Civic Functions, and lot lines have been laid out, Maximum Building-Scale Densities shall be calculated for each Transect Zone from T4L to T6. The Maximum Building-Scale Density for each Zone shall be determined so that the Density Allowances for the individual lots within that Zone sum to at most the total Density Allocation for the Zone. The Maximum Building-Scale Densities for Transect Zones T4L through T6 shall be designated as part of the New Community Plan. Maximum Building-Scale Density for Zone T3 is always one (1) EHU per lot, independent of the area of the lot. Maximum Building-Scale Densities shall be uniform across all instances of a given Transect Zone within a New Community Plan. 
3.4.7 Community-Scale Density Transfers may be used to transfer by-right density from any O-2 Reserve Sector area or from any parcels or lots designated in the corresponding Official Community Plan as a Density Sending Area to one or more Transect Zones within the New Community Plan in accordance with Table 14B. 
3.4.8 A New Community Plan shall not designate lots, parcels, or portions of lots or parcels as Density Sending Areas. Areas to be preserved should be zoned accordingly. 
3.4.9 A New Community Plan may designate Receiving Areas for building-scale Density Transfers and for building-scale Density Bonuses in accordance with Section 4.4. If any such Receiving Areas are designated or anticipated for the future, the New Community Plan shall establish Absolute Maximum Building-Scale Densities and Additional Height Allowance guidance for each Transect Zone in accordance with Section 4.4, and in such a way that the By-Transfer Gross Equivalent Density limits of Table 14B are not exceeded in any Transect Zone district. 
3.5 - ENVIRONMENTAL REQUIREMENTS 
3.5.1  General 
a.  Transect Zones manifest a range of natural and urban conditions. In case of conflict, to the extent not inconsistent with applicable state or federal law, the natural environment shall have priority in the more rural zones (T1-T3) and the built environment shall have priority in the more urban zones (T4-T6). 
b.  New Communities shall be planned so that no T4, T5, or T6 Zones are located within any Special, Community, or Advisory Flood Hazard Area specified in the City's Flood Damage Prevention Ordinance. This provision shall not be modified by Warrant. 
3.5.2  Specific to Natural and Rural Zones (T1-T2) 
a.  Within T1 and T2 Zones, the encroachment and modification of natural conditions listed in Sections 2.3.2 and 2.4.2 shall be limited according to applicable local, state and federal law. 
b.  The Public Frontage (Tables 4A and 14D) shall include trees of various species, naturalistically clustered, as well as understory. Sod shall be permitted only by Warrant. The introduced landscape shall consist primarily of native species requiring minimal irrigation, fertilization and maintenance (Tables 4B and 6). 
c.  Impermeable surface shall be minimized and confined to the ratio of lot coverage by building specified in Table 14H. 
d.  To the extent not inconsistent with applicable state or federal law, storm water management on Thoroughfares shall be primarily through retention and percolation, channeled by curb-side swales wherever feasible. 
e.  Any required stormwater detention areas shall be naturalistically shaped and disposed, and shall be planted with native wetland species. 
3.5.3  Specific to Sub-Urban Zones (T3) 
a.  Within T3 Zones, the continuity of the urbanized areas shall be subject to the precedence of the natural environmental conditions listed in Sections 2.3.2 and 2.4.2. The alteration of such conditions shall be limited according to local, state and federal law. 
b.  The Public Frontage (Tables 4A and 14D) shall include trees of various species, naturalistically clustered, as well as low-maintenance understory. Sod in excess of 25% of the area of the Private Frontage shall be permitted only by Warrant. The introduced landscape shall consist primarily of native species requiring minimal irrigation, fertilization and maintenance (Tables 4B and 6). 
c.  Impermeable surface shall be minimized and confined to the ratio of lot coverage by building specified in Table 14H. 
d.  To the extent not inconsistent with applicable state or federal law, storm water management on Thoroughfares shall be primarily through retention and percolation, channeled by curb-side swales wherever feasible. 
e.  Any required stormwater detention areas shall be naturalistically shaped and disposed, and shall be planted with native wetland species. 
3.5.4  Specific to General Urban Zones (T4, including T4+ and T4L) 
a.  To the extent not inconsistent with applicable state or federal law, within T4 Zones the continuity of the urbanized areas should take precedence over the natural environmental conditions listed in Section 2.4.2. The alteration of such conditions, where necessary and to the extent not inconsistent with applicable state or federal law, may be mitigated off-site, and the determination for modification and mitigation shall be made by Warrant. New Community Plans shall not locate any T4 Zone in any Special, Community, or Advisory Flood Hazard Area specified in the City's Flood Damage Prevention Ordinance. 
b.  The Public Frontage (Tables 4A and 14D) shall include trees planted in a regularly-spaced Allee pattern of single or alternated species of a height exceeding three stories at maturity, but with shade canopies remaining predominantly clear of the first Story of building Frontages. The New Community Plan may include a street tree planting schedule to provide for quick shade production in the near term and for eventual staged replacement with more desirable long-lived species. The introduced landscape shall consist primarily of durable species tolerant of soil compaction (Tables 4B and 6). Regular spacing of street trees in T4+ Zones shall not exceed 30 feet, with layout adjusted to accommodate necessary physical interruptions. 
c.  Impermeable surface shall be confined to the ratio of lot coverage by building specified in Table 14H. 
d.  To the extent not inconsistent with applicable state or federal law, city ordinance, or overlay district requirements, storm water management on Thoroughfares and lots shall be primarily through underground storm drainage channeled by raised curbs, and there shall be no retention or detention required on the individual lots. 
3.5.5  Specific to Urban Center Zones (T5) 
a.  To the extent not inconsistent with applicable state or federal law, within T5 Zones the continuity of the urbanized areas shall take precedence over the natural environmental conditions listed in Section 2.4.2. The alteration of such conditions, where necessary and to the extent not inconsistent with applicable state or federal law, may be mitigated off-site, and the determination for modification and mitigation shall be made by Warrant. New Community Plans shall not locate any T5 Zone in any Special, Community, or Advisory Flood Hazard Area specified in the City's Flood Damage Prevention Ordinance. 
b.  The Public Frontage (Tables 4A and 14D) shall include trees planted in Allees of a single species, or of alternating species if one is chosen for quick shade production and the other for longevity, of a height exceeding three stories at maturity, but with shade canopies remaining predominantly clear of the first Story of building Frontages. The New Community Plan may include a street tree planting schedule to provide for quick shade production in the near term and for eventual staged replacement with more desirable long-lived species. The introduced landscape shall consist primarily of durable species tolerant of soil compaction (Tables 4B and 6). Regular spacing of street trees in Mandatory or Recommended Shopfront areas of T5 Zones shall not exceed 30 feet, with layout adjusted to accommodate necessary physical interruptions. 
c.  Impermeable surface shall be confined to the ratio of lot coverage by building specified in Table 14H. 
d.  To the extent not inconsistent with applicable state or federal law, city ordinance, or overlay district requirements, storm water management shall be primarily through underground storm drainage channeled by raised curbs, and there shall be no retention or detention required on the individual lot. 
3.5.6  Specific to Urban Core Zones (T6) 
a.  To the extent not inconsistent with applicable state or federal law, within T6 Zones the continuity of the urbanized areas shall take precedence over the natural environmental conditions listed in Section 2.4.2. The alteration of such conditions, where necessary and to the extent not inconsistent with applicable state or federal law, shall not require off-site mitigation, and the determination for alteration of such conditions shall be made by Warrant. New Community Plans shall not locate any T6 Zone in any Special, Community, or Advisory Flood Hazard Area specified in the City's Flood Damage Prevention Ordinance. 
b.  The Public Frontage (Tables 4A and 14D) shall include trees planted in Allees of a single species, or of alternating species if one is chosen for quick shade production and the other for longevity, of a height exceeding three stories at maturity, but with shade canopies remaining predominantly clear of the first Story of building Frontages. The New Community Plan may include a street tree planting schedule to provide for quick shade production in the near term and for eventual staged replacement with more desirable long-lived species. The introduced landscape shall consist primarily of durable species tolerant of soil compaction (Tables 4B and 6). Regular spacing of street trees in T6 Zones shall not exceed 30 feet, with layout adjusted to accommodate necessary physical interruptions. 
c.  Impermeable surface shall be confined to the ratio of lot coverage by building specified in Table 14H. 
d.  To the extent not inconsistent with applicable state or federal law, city ordinance, or overlay district requirements, storm water management shall be primarily through underground storm drainage channeled by raised curbs, and there shall be no retention or detention required on the individual lot. 
3.6 - STREETSCAPE REQUIREMENTS 
3.6.1  General 
a.  Thoroughfares are intended for use by vehicular and pedestrian traffic and to provide access to lots and open spaces. 
b.  Thoroughfares consist of vehicular lanes and Public Frontages (Table 16A). The lanes provide traffic and parking capacity, and include a variety of widths for parked and for moving vehicles. The Frontages contribute to the character of the Transect Zone. They include the Types of sidewalk, curbing, planter, and street tree. 
c.  Thoroughfares should be designed in context with the urban forms and desired design speeds of the Transect Zones through which they pass. Thoroughfares that pass from one Transect Zone to another shall adjust their Public Frontages accordingly or, alternatively, the Transect Zone may follow the alignment of the Thoroughfare to the depth of one lot, retaining a single Public Frontage throughout its trajectory. 
d.  Within the more rural Zones T1 and T2, pedestrian comfort shall be a secondary consideration of the Thoroughfare. Design speeds may be higher than in denser Zones, and design conflict between vehicular and pedestrian movement shall be generally decided in favor of vehicular mobility. 
e.  Within the more urban Transect Zones (T4 through T6) pedestrian comfort shall be a primary consideration of the Thoroughfare. Design speeds shall be lower, and design conflict between vehicular and pedestrian movement shall be decided in favor of the pedestrian. Traffic calming features including, but not limited to, curb extensions, traffic circles, and medians should be used to encourage slower traffic speeds and provide for pedestrian safety and comfort. 
f.  Sidewalks and other public space in Transect Zones T5 and T6 shall be designed using street trees, awnings, and other shade-generating devices to provide as nearly continuous shade cover to pedestrians as possible along Primary Grid streets. 
3.6.2  Thoroughfares 
a.  The standards for vehicular lanes shall be as shown in Table 3. 
b.  The Thoroughfare network shall be designed to define blocks not exceeding the size prescribed in Table 14E. The size shall be measured as the sum of lot Frontage Lines. 
c.  All Thoroughfares shall terminate at other Thoroughfares, forming a network. Internal Thoroughfares shall connect wherever possible to those on adjacent sites. Cul-de-sacs shall be permitted only when necessitated by natural site conditions and when a fully connected Thoroughfare plan is impossible; approval by Warrant shall be required for certification of such necessity. In no case shall a street segment ending in a cul-de-sac have a length greater than 250 feet. Thoroughfares may terminate in stub streets when such streets act as connections to future phases of the development. 
d.  Lots shall Enfront a vehicular Thoroughfare, except that 20% of the lots within each Transect Zone may Enfront a pedestrian passage. This fraction may be increased to up to 50% by Warrant. 
e.  Thoroughfares along a designated Secondary Grid (Section 3.8.1a) may be exempted from the specified Frontage requirements. 
f.  A bicycle network consisting of Trails, Routes and Lanes should be provided throughout as defined in Article 7 Definitions of Terms and allocated in Table 14E. The community bicycle network should be connected to existing or proposed Sector networks wherever possible. 
g.  Mid-block pedestrian and bicycle paths shall be incorporated in the most pedestrian-intensive areas in conjunction with Service Lanes and Service Alleys to keep pedestrian-route block face lengths to 400 feet or less. 
h.  Metered Curb Parking shall be provided wherever possible in T4+, T5, and T6 Zones. 
i.  Designated Taxi Stands shall be provided within RCDs. 
j.  Service Lanes and Alleys shall be paved to Driveway standards using pervious materials of a kind readily distinguished from the materials used to pave other Thoroughfares. 
3.6.3  Public Frontages 
a.  Public Frontages shall be designed as shown in Table 4 and allocated within Transect Zones of New Communities as specified in Table 14E. 
b.  Within the Public Frontages, the prescribed Types of street trees and landscaping shall be as shown in Tables 4 and 6. The spacing may be adjusted by Warrant to accommodate specific site conditions. 
c.  Within the Public Frontages, streetlights shall utilize Luminaires which are Fully Shielded or Nearly Fully Shielded, and shall be of a general type illustrated in Table 5. Streetlights shall be employed on both sides of streets in Transect Zones 4, 5, and 6. 
e.  Utilities shall be routed underground, or via Rear Alleys, Rear Lanes, Service Lanes, and Secondary Grid Roads where available. Above-ground utilities shall not be routed along Primary Grid Roads except by Warrant. 
3.6.4  Specific to Special Districts 
The standards for Thoroughfares and Public Frontages within Special Districts shall be determined by Warrant. 
3.7 - CIVIC FUNCTIONS 
3.7.1  General 
a.  Places for public use shall be required for each New Community and designated on the Community Plans as Civic Space (CS) and Civic Building (CB). 
b.  Civic Spaces are public sites permanently dedicated to open space. 
c.  Civic Buildings are sites dedicated for buildings generally operated by not-for-profit organizations dedicated to culture, education, government, transit and municipal parking, or for a use approved by the Mayor and City Council. 
d.  A Civic Function requiring more than 20% of a Pedestrian Shed shall become its own Special District, with provisions written as necessary. (See Table 15.) 
3.7.2  Civic Space (CS) Specific to T3-T6 Zones 
a.  Each Pedestrian Shed shall have at least 5% of its urbanized area designated as Civic Space. 
b.  Civic Spaces shall be designed as generally described in Table 13, shall be approved by the CRC and shall be allocated to Transect Zones as described in Table 14F. 
c.  Each Pedestrian Shed shall contain at least one Main Civic Space. The Main Civic Space shall be within 800 feet of the geographic center of each Pedestrian Shed, unless topographic conditions, pre-existing Thoroughfare alignments or other circumstances prevent it. 
d.  Within 800 feet of every lot in Residential use, a Civic Space designed and equipped as a Playground or Pocket Park shall be provided. 
e.  Each Civic Space shall have a minimum of 40% of its perimeter Enfronting a Thoroughfare. 
f.  Civic Spaces may be permitted within Special Districts by Warrant. 
g.  Parks are permitted in Transect Zones T2 and T3 by right, and are permitted in Transect Zones T4, T5, and T6 by Warrant (Table 14F). 
3.7.3  Civic Buildings (CB) Specific to T3-T6 Zones 
a.  The developer shall covenant to construct a Meeting Hall or a Third Place in proximity to the Main Civic Space of each Pedestrian Shed. Its corresponding Public Frontage shall be equipped with a shelter and bench for a transit stop or for ride sharing. 
b.  One Civic Building lot shall be reserved for an elementary school, community center, or other future Civic Building. Its area shall be 1 acre for each increment of 100 dwelling units provided by the New Community Plan. The site may be within any Transect Zone, but any playing fields should be outside the Pedestrian Shed. The lot may be used as Civic Space until its use is required for a Civic Building. 
c.  One Civic Building lot suitable for a childcare building shall be reserved within each Pedestrian Shed. The developer or a homeowners' association or other Community Council may organize, fund and construct an appropriate building as the need arises. 
d.  Civic Building sites shall not occupy more than 20% of the area of any Pedestrian Shed. 
e.  Civic Building sites should be located within or adjacent to Civic Spaces, or at the axial termination of significant Thoroughfares. 
f.  Civic Buildings shall not be subject to the standards of Article 5. The particulars of their design shall be determined in each case by the Planning Commission under advisement of the City Architect and the Urban Design Center, if one has been established. 
g.  Parking for Civic Buildings shall be adjusted by Warrant. Civic parking lots may remain unpaved if graded, compacted and landscaped. 
h.  Civic Buildings may be permitted within Special Districts by approval of the Planning Commission. 
i.  Civic Building lots suitable for public parking garages shall be reserved in sufficient number and so located that at least one such structure lies within one-quarter mile (1/4 mi) of every part of any T5 or T6 Zone. 
m.  A Civic Building lot suitably sized and located for a future Transit station shall be reserved within every RCD. 
3.7.4  Civic Functions Specific to T1 & T2 Zones 
a.  Civic Buildings and Civic Spaces related to education, recreation and culture may be erected within T1 Natural Zone only by Variance and within T2 Rural Zones by approval of the Planning Commission. 
b.  Those portions of the T1 natural and T2 Rural Zones that occur within a development parcel are an integral part of the Civic Function allocation and should conform to one or more of the Types specified in Table 13. 
3.7.5  Civic Space as Hazard Mitigation 
Lands in any Special Flood Hazard Area that are designated for buyout by FEMA or any other state or federal agency for the purpose of hazard mitigation by precluding building there shall become permanent Civic Space by right regardless of size, subject to the Special District provision herein (Section 3.7.1d). These CSHM areas shall count toward the required Civic Space allotment for each Pedestrian Shed. Areas too small to be coded as Special District shall conform to the Civic Space standards of Table 13 for one or more of any adjacent habitable Transect Zone(s). 
3.8 - PARKING ACCOMMODATION REQUIREMENTS 
3.8.1 Except where explicitly noted within this Section, parking accommodation requirements shall appear on the Street and Parking Map of a New Community Plan. 
3.8.2 Civic Building lots suitable for eventual construction of Public-Parking Facilities shall be reserved in such number and so sited that every point within a T5 or T6 Zone lies within one-quarter mile of such a lot. If screened or provided with Liner Buildings as required under Article 5, these lots may be used for publicly accessible surface parking until such time as larger parking structures are required. Such lots may be dedicated to the City or may be privately held. If privately held, guarantees shall be made of operation as Public-Parking Facilities for at least 30 years, subject to approval by Warrant. 
3.8.3 Streets in T5 and T6 Zones shall provide curb parking wherever possible, shall be designated on the New Community Plan for Metered Curb Parking , and shall be equipped with meters allowing remote adjustment of fee schedules. 
3.8.4 The New Community Plan shall designate Parking Benefit Districts in all T3, T4L, and T4+ Zones which are within one-half mile of any T6 Zone or within one-quarter mile of any T5 Zone and which have unmetered curb parking. 
3.8.5 Streets in T4L and T4+ Zones shall provide curb parking wherever possible. Areas near planned intensive mixed use and important intersections shall be designated on the New Community Plan for Metered Curb Parking and shall be equipped with meters allowing remote adjustment of fee schedules. 
3.8.6 Parking spaces shall be Unbundled from interior floor space in all T4+, T5, and T6 Zones within RCDs. A New Community Plan may also delineate and designate other areas as Unbundled Parking Areas. In areas so designated parking spaces shall be sold or leased independently of interior floor space. All intensive mixed-use areas should be designated as Unbundled Parking Areas. 
3.8.7 At least one-half (1/2) of the parking requirement for planned uses in T5 and T6 zones within RCDs or designated Unbundled Parking Areas shall be provided off site in Public-Parking Facilities within one-quarter mile (1/4 mi) of the use which generates the requirement. The distance limit may be increased to one-half mile (1/2 mi) by Warrant. 
3.8.8 In T4+, T5, or T6 Zones within an Unbundled Parking Area or within an RCD, all on-site parking shall be provided as part of a Public-Parking Facility. 
3.8.9 Wherever physically possible, two or more surface parking facilities located in adjacent lots shall provide direct vehicular access via two or more Driveways connecting the facilities. 
3.8.10 Certified Affordable Housing units shall be subject to reduced parking requirements of one (1) parking space per dwelling unit. Within Unbundled Parking Areas including T4+, T5, and T6 Zones in RCDs, the parking requirement for Certified Affordable Housing may be altogether waived, subject to approval by Warrant. 
3.9 - ARCHITECTURAL REQUIREMENTS 
3.9.1 New Community Plans may incorporate and recommend or require compliance with Community Architectural Guidelines supplemental to the Community Plan and stipulating additional architectural standards specific to the Community, beyond those required by this Code. 
3.9.2 [RESERVED] 
3.9.3 A New Community Plan may impose a requirement, within designated overlay districts, or generally across the entire Community Planning Area, for architectural review of any proposed buildings or structures, or of their exterior improvement, alteration, or addition, for determination by the City Architect of compliance with such Community Architectural Guidelines, in accordance with the City's Architectural Review Ordinance, if such exists. 
3.9.4 A New Community Plan may require specified Stepbacks in Facades above specified heights along Frontage lines. 
3.9.5 A New Community Plan may require Buildout-at-Height Limits limiting the blockage by buildings of light and breeze passage parallel to one or more lot lines or Frontage lines at several specified heights. 
3.10 - SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS 
3.10.1 A New Community Plan may include any of the following special requirements: 
a.  A differentiation of the Thoroughfares into a Primary Grid (P-Grid) and a Secondary Grid (S-Grid). Buildings along the P-Grid shall be held to the highest standard of this Code in support of pedestrian activity. Buildings along the S-Grid may be more readily considered for Warrants and Variances allowing automobile-oriented standards. The Frontages assigned to the S-Grid shall not exceed 30% of the total length within a Pedestrian Shed. 
b.  A designation for Mandatory or Recommended Retail Frontage requiring that a building provide a Shopfront at sidewalk level along the entire length of the Frontage. The Shopfront shall be no less than 70% glazed in clear glass and provided with an awning, gallery, or arcade overlapping the sidewalk as generally illustrated in Table 7. The first floor shall be confined to Retail use through the depth of the Second Layer. (See Table 16D) 
c.  A designation for Mandatory or Recommended Gallery/Arcade Frontage, requiring that a building provide a permanent cover over the sidewalk, either cantilevered or supported by columns. The Gallery or Arcade Frontage may be combined with a Retail Frontage as shown in Table 7. 
d.  Designation of an outside area for Sidewalk Retail, allowing use in the specified area by pushcart peddlers, outdoor restaurants, and other open market uses without additional Planning Commission approval, and requiring provision on abutting lots for future leasable open-market services including associated restaurant space or general Retail space with dedicated access to the sidewalk, secure storage space within parking structures for pushcarts, and coordinated design of Public and Private Frontages within the area to accommodate Sidewalk Retail usages. 
e.  A designation of Coordinated Streetscape Frontage, requiring that the Public and Private Frontages be coordinated as a single, coherent landscape and paving design. 
f.  Specific Facade alignment requirements for streets where Frontage Lines and side lot lines are not orthogonal. 
g.  A designation of Shaded Pedestrian Way, requiring that Public and Private Frontages are coherently planned and planted with a combination of fast-growing and of more long-lived shade trees, so arranged in combination with awnings, galleries, and arbors as to provide nearly continuous shade cover for pedestrians along Frontages, sidewalks and pedestrian paths so designated. 
h.  A designation for Cross Block Passages, requiring a minimum 8-foot-wide ground-level pedestrian access be reserved between certain buildings. 
i.  A designation of Terminated Vista for a site, requiring that any building located at that site be provided with architectural articulation of a Type and character that responds to the location as approved by the CRC. 
j.  A designation of Buildings of Value, requiring that such buildings and structures may be altered or demolished only in accordance with preservation standards and protocols established by the Planning Commission. 
3.11 - SPECIAL TREE PROVISIONS 
    This Code requires tree protection measures additional to those of the City of Gulfport Tree Protection Ordinance. The provisions of this section shall not amend or repeal any portion, part, or provision of the Gulfport Tree Protection Ordinance. In the event of conflict between the provisions of this section and those of the Gulfport Tree Protection Ordinance, the stricter shall apply. 
3.11.1  Tree Protection Plan. Each plan submitted under this Code shall include a Tree Protection Site Plan showing and describing generally wooded areas of the site and any specimens of 16-inch caliper or greater, measured at 3 feet above grade, on the site. The plan shall also show in detail by species and size all existing trees over 12 inches caliper, measured at 3 feet above grade, within 20 feet of areas where street construction or other improvement is planned. Clusters of more than 5 such trees within a 15-foot radius may be represented in group on such plan, however every tree of 16-inch caliper measured at 3 feet above grade must be indicated individually. Such plan shall indicate all trees 12-inch caliper or greater which are proposed to be removed. The plan shall also similarly depict the area within 100 feet of each tree of 16-inch caliper or greater which is to be removed within the construction zone, identifying all trees 12-inch caliper or greater within that 100-foot radius so that potential alternate routes can be evaluated. No trees shall be removed before initial plan approval, under penalty of replacement according to the stricter requirements of Section 5.13. 
3.11.2 Tree removal for construction of streets and improvements shall be allowed only on written notice of SmartCode Planning Approval by the Planning Commission subject to the following requirements: 
a.  Street layout shall be adjusted whenever possible to preserve larger trees and rare species. 
b.  No tree over sixteen-inch (16") caliper measured 3 feet above grade shall be removed except by Warrant. 
c.  All tree removals shall be subject to the requirements of the City of Gulfport Tree Protection Ordinance where they are stricter than those of this Code.
