d.  No trees more than 10 feet beyond the planned right-of-way for streets and improvements shall be removed except in accordance with the requirements of Article 5. Trees within the blocks and future lots defined by planned streets shall not be removed or damaged except in accordance with the requirements of Article 5. 
e.  Every tree 16-inch caliper or greater which is removed shall be replaced with minimum 3-inch caliper trees of the same species in sufficient number that the total caliper measurement of the replacement trees shall equal or exceed the caliper measurement of the removed tree. Trees of species described in 3.11.2h are exempt from the replacement requirement. 
f.  For rare, unusual, or otherwise valued trees of 12-inch caliper or greater but less than 16-inch caliper the CRC may require replacement with the same species in sizes and numbers to be determined by Warrant. 
g.  All replacement trees shall be planted in planned Civic Spaces or on lots planned for Civic Buildings. Replacement trees may be placed on planned Private Frontages by Warrant. Subject to approval by Warrant, where sites are heavily wooded or suitable permanent sites are not available, replacement trees may be planted in other Community Planning Areas within the City having Official Community Plans as street trees or in Civic Spaces, with substitution of species to accommodate the requirements of the relevant Official Community Plan approved by Warrant. 
h.  Notwithstanding 3.11.2a, b, c, d, e, and f, any trees or scrub of any size of the following species, or of species included on a list approved and maintained by the City Arborist, are deemed undesirable and shall be removed on account of their invasive or otherwise problematic character: Sabium sebiferum (Chinese Tallow Tree, Popcorn Tree), Cinnamomum camphora (Camphor Tree), Quercus nigra (Water Oak), Ligustrum sinense (Chinese Privet). 
3.11.3 Removal of trees contrary to the provisions of this Code shall require replacement at the rate of 2 caliper inches of in-kind replacement, measured at 3 feet above grade, for every caliper inch inappropriately removed, measured at the top of the residual stump or 3 feet above grade or as estimated by the City Arborist, with replacement trees of at least 2-inch caliper, to be adjusted by Warrant. 
3.11.4 It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, organization or society to violate the provisions of this article. The removal or destruction of each protected tree shall constitute a separate offense under this article, and said violation or violations, if deemed by the City Arborist to be willful, may in addition to the penalties provided by 3.11.3 be prosecuted and punishable in accordance with Section 1-9 of the City of Gulfport Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2558, § 1, 10-17-07) 
3.12 - PROCEDURAL REQUIREMENTS 
3.12.1  Approval Process for New Community Plans. The approval process for New Community Plans shall comprise three parts: 
a.  Informal meetings with the Planning Official and Consolidated Review Committee leading to preparation of a SmartCode Development Application. 
b.  Submission of SmartCode Development Application for CRC review and SmartCode Planning Approval hearing. 
c.  Submission of a completed New Community Plan for hearing for adoption as an Official Community Plan. Adoption includes final plat approval and final rezoning. 
3.12.2\ Informal meetings with the CRC. It is recommended that developers and property owners interested in developing a New Community begin with informal meetings with the City's Planning Official and Consolidated Review Committee. While strongly recommended for guidance, such meetings are not mandatory. 
3.12.3  SmartCode Planning Approval Hearing. 
a.  In order to qualify for the New Community approval process, the designated New Community Planning Area shall not be a part of any existing Official Community Plan unless the included portion of the site meets the minimum Infill size requirement for the type of proposed community. Smaller areas subject to an Official Community Plan may be handled by means of Infill Plans in accordance with Section 4.12. 
b.  A completed SmartCode Development Application shall be submitted along with required Warrant requests for review by the CRC. During the initial review the CRC shall check for compliance with this Code and relevant Existing Codes and shall respond to the applicant with a review of the application including a list of detected deviations from this Code, including any unmet requirements for Warrants and Variances. If the application, including all approved Warrants and Variances, is found acceptable, the CRC shall notify the applicant of a finding of No Objections, and shall issue a review to both the applicant and the Planning Commission summarizing the evaluation, describing any concerns, and indicating whether any unapproved deviations were found in the application. 
c.  The applicant may at any time submit a complete SmartCode Development Application to the Planning Official to schedule a hearing for SmartCode Planning Approval by the Planning Commission. On receipt of a complete and accurate application, a CRC review of the application shall be provided to the Planning Commission along with the application within a reasonable period of time; public notice shall be given in accordance with Section 1.4.7 and with state law; notice shall be mailed to owners of property within 160 feet of the site; and public hearing before the Planning Commission shall be scheduled. At the public hearing the Planning Commission may approve or deny the application. If denied the Planning Commission shall provide explanation in writing of the reason(s) for denial. The Planning Office may rely on a list provided and certified to by an applicant, or as shown by the latest tax assessor's records of property owners and mailing addresses within 160 feet for mailing purposes. Notice by publication according to state law shall be mandatory to approval. 
d.  SmartCode Development Application submission requirements shall be as per Section 3.12.5, and shall include such other reasonable requirements as the Planning Office shall establish. 
e.  On rejection by the Planning Commission, an applicant may resubmit the application after making changes, or may appeal the rejection. On resubmission the CRC shall only be required to address changes made to the application in its review, and the change review and original review shall both be submitted to the Planning Commission with the application for a second public hearing. 
f.  On acceptance the Planning Commission shall notify the applicant in writing of its decision, including any conditions of acceptance. In the case of conditional acceptance, the Commission shall also specify changes required, the character and extent of required improvements, and the amount of the surety bond which will be required in lieu of the completion of required improvements. 
g.  On acceptance by the Planning Commission, the applicant shall be given 30 days to accept or deny the Commission's decision. If the applicant accepts, the Community Planning Area described in the submitted application shall be designated on the City's official zoning map as a SmartCode Planning Area, and the land owner shall be deemed to have elected to exercise the SmartCode zoning option. Once the applicant has agreed in writing to accept the designation, the Community Planning Area shall be mandatorily subject to this Code. Existing Local Codes shall apply within such Community Planning Area only to the extent that they do not conflict with this Code. 
3.12.4  New Community Plan Adoption Hearing. After completion of the New Community Plan, the applicant may submit the plan with final plat for adoption. 
a.  A New Community Plan shall first be submitted for review by CRC. The CRC shall check for compliance of the plan with this Code, request clarifications, and respond to applications for Warrant. The applicant may at any time request a final assessment from the CRC. On request for hearing the CRC shall prepare a final assessment for the Planning Commission pointing to any questions of compliance, detailing any unresolved objections, or issuing a finding of No Objection. A copy of the final assessment shall be provided to the applicant. 
b.  The applicant may at any time after requesting final assessment from the CRC submit the New Community Plan for adoption hearing. Public notice shall be given consistent with Section 1.4.7 and with state law; owners of property within 160 feet of the site shall be notified by mail, and public hearing shall be held before the Planning Commission. Planning Commission shall review and make recommendation to the Mayor and City Council for acceptance, may refuse approval, or may conditionally recommend approval contingent on specific changes. If rejected the applicant may appeal to the Mayor and City Council, or may rework and resubmit to the Planning Commission. The Planning Commission shall communicate its decision in writing, along with any reason(s) for disapproval, to the Mayor and City Council and to the applicant. The Planning Office may rely on a list provided and certified to by an applicant, or as shown by the latest tax assessor's records of property owners and mailing addresses within 160 feet for mailing purposes. Notice by publication according to state law shall be mandatory to approval. 
c.  On a recommendation of acceptance by the Planning Commission, the Mayor and City Council shall approve or disapprove adoption of a New Community Plan. Adoption of a New Community Plan includes acceptance of the final plat and approval of the final rezoning described in the approved Community Plan. 
d.  Failure on the part of the applicant to have the final plat recorded in the records of the chancery clerk within ninety (90) days after the date of approval unless granted an extension by Mayor and City Council shall render the approval of the New Community Plan and the associated final plat null and void. 
e.  Submission requirements for a New Community Plan adoption hearing shall be as per Section 3.12.6, and shall include such other reasonable requirements as the Planning Office shall establish. 
f.  On successful adoption by the City, a New Community Plan shall be incorporated by reference into the official zoning map of the City of Gulfport as an Official Community Plan, and shall act as the governing document for land use within the designated Community Planning Area in conjunction with this Code. 
3.12.5  Submission Requirements for SmartCode Development Applications. The SmartCode Development Application constitutes a subset of the New Community Plan requirements in combination with the submission requirements for a General Subdivision Plan under the City's Subdivision Ordinance. Submissions of applications for SmartCode Development approval shall include the following: 
a.  Maps of the Community Planning Area and supplementary information as required by the City's Subdivision Ordinance for General Subdivision Plan submission. 
b.  A list of names and mailing addresses of all owners of property within 200 feet of the site, together with a certificate signed by the applicant stating that the list is believed to be true and correct based upon a search and inquiry of public records information. 
c.  A Tree Protection Site Plan in accordance with Section 3.11. 
d.  A Partial Regulating Plan, including a map showing the boundaries of the proposed Community Planning Area; the Transect Zone districts and Special Districts assigned within the Community Planning Area; RCD, TND, and CLD community type designations; any Special, Advisory, and Community Flood Hazard Areas within the Community Planning Area; and Civic Functions. 
e.  Other supporting documentation including the By-Right Gross Equivalent Densities and the anticipated final Gross Equivalent Densities after any planned Density Transfers for each of the various Transect Zones. 
3.12.6  Submission Requirements for New Community Plans. Submissions of proposals for New Community Plans shall include the following: 
a.  A final plat of the Community Planning Area, including all of the requirements of a final plat submission indicated in the City's Subdivision Ordinance, with the exception that conveyances to the City of Civic Space shall allow provision of third-party conservation easements, and that Civic Space and Civic Buildings and their lots need not be dedicated to the City if secured with appropriate conservation easements allowing unlimited public access. 
b.  A list of names and mailing addresses of all owners of property within 200 feet of the site, together with a certificate signed by the applicant stating that the list is believed to be true and correct based upon a search and inquiry of public records information. 
c.  Statement of Tree Protection Plan Compliance from the City Arborist indicating that terms of Section 3.11 and of the City's Tree Protection Ordinance have been met. 
d.  A Regulating Plan, including a map showing the boundaries of the proposed Community Planning Area; the Transect Zone districts and Special Districts assigned within the Community Planning Area; RCD, TND, and CLD community type designations; Density Transfer Receiving Areas; any Special, Advisory, or Community Flood Hazard Areas; Density Bonus Receiving Areas; and Civic Functions. The Regulating plan also shall include total Gross Equivalent Densities and Maximum Building-Scale Densities for the various Transect Zones. 
e.  A Special Requirements and Options Plan, comprising a map showing reserved Public-Parking Facility sites; the Civic Functions; and any other Special Requirement designations. 
f.  A Street and Parking Plan, comprising a map showing Unbundled Parking Areas, including T5 and T6 Zones within RCDs; Parking Benefit Districts; reserved Public-Parking Facility sites; reserved Transit Station sites; street tree planting requirements; Metered Curb Parking designations; and Taxi Stand designations. 
g.  Other supporting documents and articles, potentially including explanatory notes; an article invoking architectural review; an adoption article; an applicability article stating that the Community Plan shall be mandatory within the Community Planning Area, without recourse to the Existing Local Codes; an article defining any overlay districts; Community Architectural Guidelines; specific streetlight requirements; and any other supporting recommendations or requirements permitted under this Code. Such documents may additionally include Absolute Maximum Building-Scale Densities, Absolute Height Limits for Transect Zones within the Community Planning Area, and a formula or table relating Additional Height Allowances to Acquired Density Allowances if Density Receiving Areas of any kind are designated. 
3.12.7  Amendment of an Official Community Plan. An Official Community Plan which has been approved under this Code may be amended through public notice and hearing consistent with state law. The procedure for amendment of an Official Community Plan shall be as specified by the Existing Local Codes for a Zoning Ordinance Amendment, with the exception that the Planning Official shall also provide notice to persons and organizations on the Notification List in accordance with Section 1.4.7, and that the City shall also make reasonable efforts to provide public notice through the mass communications means readily and inexpensively available to it. Official Community Plans may only be amended so as to remain compliant with this Code. Amendments to Official Community Plans, in order to be approved, shall be based on conserving, completing, or creating Transect-based Pedestrian Sheds and urban structure. Proposed amendments which damage or weaken the structure of Pedestrian Sheds within the Community Planning Area, or of the Community as a whole, shall be rejected. 
3.12.8  Succession. Ten years after the approval is granted for a Community Plan, and every ten years thereafter, at the request of residents or property owners within the Community Planning Area, each Transect Zone, except the T1 Natural and the T2 Rural, shall be considered for rezoning in whole or in part to the successional (next higher numbered) Transect Zone through public consultation and at the recommendation of the Planning Commission through public hearing after 15 days advance published notice, and by approval of the Mayor and the City Council. Until such rezoning is complete, zoning for each Transect Zone shall remain unchanged. 
ARTICLE 4. - INFILL COMMUNITY SCALE PLANS 

4.1 - GENERAL INSTRUCTIONS 
4.1.1 This Article pertains to areas within the G-4 Infill Growth Sectors of the Sector Plan (Article 2), or in the absence of a Sector Plan, to areas including or surrounded by substantial pre-existing development as determined by the CRC and the Planning Commission. In such areas further development shall be guided by adoption of Existing-Community Plans through proper planning process, in compliance with state law. Such Existing-Community Plans for a designated area may be prepared, at the request of the Mayor and City Council or of the Planning Commission, by the Planning Office or by a planner selected by the Planning Commission with approval by the Mayor and City Council. Such Existing-Community Plans may also be prepared for a designated area at the request of and on behalf of residents and property owners of that area by a planner of their choosing at their expense. All Existing-Community Plans shall be prepared in accordance with the provisions and intent of this Code. 
4.1.2 Existing-Community Plans shall be prepared in a process of public consultation, and shall be subject to public hearing, review and recommendation of the Planning Commission, and to approval by the Mayor and City Council, in accordance with state law. Once approved, an Existing-Community Plan shall be designated the Official Community Plan for the associated Community Planning Area. The requirements imposed by such a Plan shall be binding within the associated Community Planning Area. 
4.1.3 For any site which lies in a G-4 Sector, or in an area with substantial existing development in the absence of a Sector Plan, and which is greater than 40 contiguous acres under ownership or control of a single landowner or developer, such landowner or developer may initiate the preparation of a New Community Plan subject to the provisions of Article 3, including the minimum acreage requirements specified therein for infill areas. 
4.1.4 For smaller sites within a Community Planning Area subject to an Official Community Plan, developers and landowners shall use only Articles 1, 5, 6 and 7, and Sections 4.11 and 4.12 of this Article as necessary, in accordance with the Transect Zones and other requirements of that Official Community Plan. 
4.1.5 An Existing-Community Plan shall identify, assign, and follow the requirements of the Community Types described in Section 4.3. 
4.1.6 An Existing-Community Plan shall assign Transect Zones and associated density limits according to the provisions of Sections 4.3 and 4.4, and shall assign Civic Functions within each Community Type as described in Sections 4.7, with detailed provisions for site and building development as described in Article 5. 
4.1.7 Existing-Community Plans shall include three maps: the Regulating Plan shall show the City Centers, the Neighborhoods, and the Special Districts within the Community Planning Area with their various Transect Zones and density limits, designating the various Density Transfer Sending and Receiving Areas as provided in Section 4.4, and delineating any overlay districts. The Special Requirements and Options Plan shall, to the extent applicable, assign the Special Requirement designations as provided in Section 4.10, and indicate the various other recommendations and requirements of Sections 4.6, 4.8, and 4.11. The Street and Parking Plan shall include requirements and recommendations predominantly concerning the public realm, as laid forth in Section 4.12. 
4.1.8 Existing-Community Plans may optionally specify additional overlay districts within the Community Planning Area and stipulate additional requirements for those overlay districts. Any such overlays shall comply with the intent of this Code. 
4.1.9 An Existing-Community Plan shall specify the applicability of such Plan to areas within the associated Community Planning Area, in particular determining whether participation within the Community Planning Area shall be mandatory, without recourse to the Existing Local Codes; whether participation shall be optional; or whether participation shall be mandatory within certain districts and optional without. Where participation is optional the Existing-Community Plan shall specify at what scale and by what means areas within the Community Planning Area may opt into the Community Plan. 
4.1.10 The Official Community Plan for each Community Planning Area may be regularly considered for adjustment through public hearing according to the provisions of Section 4.12.6. 
4.2 - TRANSECT ZONES 
4.2.1 Existing-Community Plans shall render the subject Community Planning Area in terms of Neighborhoods (TNDs) and City Centers (RCDs) composed of Transect Zones as described in Tables 1, 2, and 14. Transect Zones shall comprise the elements described in Table 1 and the standards summarized in Table 14 and described in Article 5. All areas shall be planned as parts of Pedestrian Sheds. Existing-Community Plans shall be based on conserving, completing or creating Transect-based urban structure, and shall be reflective of such structure where it exists, prescriptive of such structure where there is none, and corrective of structure inappropriate to the urban fabric. 
4.2.2 Wherever practical, Transect Zones shall be laid out within an Existing Community Plan so that zone boundaries lie along side and rear lot lines or Service Alleys and Lanes, so that Facades of one Transect Zone generally face Facades of the same zone across Thoroughfares. 
4.3 - COMMUNITY TYPES 
    Existing development shall be planned according to the following Community Types, including and assigning, to the extent applicable, the designations of Neighborhood and City Center to existing development patterns. 
4.3.1  Neighborhoods (TNDs Traditional Neighborhood Development) 
Neighborhoods shall be urbanized areas of at least 20 acres that are primarily Residential. A Neighborhood shall be based upon a partial or entire Standard Pedestrian Shed. The physical center of the Neighborhood should be located at an important traffic intersection associated with a Civic or Commercial institution, and the edges of the Neighborhood should blend into an adjacent Neighborhood or City Center without buffer. A Neighborhood shall meet the requirements for a TND as set forth in Tables 2 and 14. 
4.3.2  City Center (RCD or Regional Center Development) 
City Centers (downtowns) shall be urbanized areas of at least 40 acres that are primarily mixed use. A City Center shall be defined by a Long Pedestrian Shed oriented around an important Commercial corridor. City Centers should be the location of large Commercial and Retail uses as well as government and other Civic institutions of regional importance. The edges of a City Center should blend into adjacent Neighborhoods without buffer. A City Center shall meet the requirements for an RCD as set forth in Tables 2 and 14. 
4.3.3  Special Districts (SD) 
Special Districts shall be areas dedicated for certain uses that, by virtue of size or Function, cannot meet the requirements for any Transect Zone or combination of Zones. The use of Special Districts within an Existing-Community Plan shall be subject to review and recommendation of the Planning Commission in the process of preparing an Existing-Community Plan. 
4.4 - DENSITY REQUIREMENTS 
4.4.1 The Community Plan shall establish a Maximum Building-Scale Density and an Absolute Maximum Building-Scale Density for each of the Transect Zones T4 through T6 employed within the Community Planning Area from the range of allowed values in Table 14. All areas within the Community Planning Area sharing the same Transect Zone designation shall be limited by the same Maximum and Absolute Maximum Building-Scale Densities. For Transect Zones T1 and T2, no Building-Scale Density limits shall be defined. 
4.4.2 For each lot within a T4 or higher Transect Zone in the Community Planning Area, the Maximum Building-Scale Density multiplied by the area of the lot yields the Density Allowance for that lot. For Transect Zone T3 the Density Allowance for lots is always one (1) unit per lot. With the exception of cases described in provisions 4.4.3, 4.4.5, and 4.4.6 below, structures built on a lot shall be limited to a number of Equivalent Housing Units which is less than or equal to the By-Right Density Allowance. Equivalent Housing Units represent a combination of mixed use space, lodging bedrooms, and Independent Residential Units according to the following conversation schedule: 
a.  One Independent Residential Unit constitutes one Equivalent Housing Unit. 
b.  One thousand square feet of office or retail space constitutes one Equivalent Housing Unit. 
c.  Two lodging bedrooms constitute one Equivalent Housing Unit. 
4.4.3  Density Transfer Receiving Areas; Density Bonus Receiving Areas. The Existing-Community Plan may designate Building-Scale Areas. The By-Right Density Allowance may be exceeded for a lot within a designated Density Transfer Receiving Area or Bonus Receiving Area on the Existing-Community Plan by an amount equal to the Acquired Density Allowance for the lot, so long as the sum of By-Right and Acquired Density Allowances does not exceed the Absolute Maximum Density Allowance for that lot. 
a.  Density Transfer Receiving Areas are chosen for their ability to support localized additional density, without a net increase of the City's overall density and with lesser ill effects on public welfare and goals of the Comprehensive Plan than if that density increment had not been transferred. 
b.  Density Bonus Receiving Areas are chosen to minimize the impact of slight increases of density to achieve improved urban structure and other goals benefiting community welfare as set forth in the Comprehensive Plan, and to offset any ill effects of an increase in density with advantages accruing from the density placement or the action which led to the granting of the bonus. 
c.  Density Bonuses and Transfers notwithstanding, in no case may the number of Equivalent Housing Units incorporated into a lot exceed the Absolute Maximum Density Allowance for such lot. 
d.  For lots in T3 Zones, the Absolute Maximum Density Allowance is one (1) Equivalent Housing Unit per lot. 
e.  Acquired Density may originate from any Density Sending Area in the City of Gulfport which is designated by any Density Transfer program described in this Code, so long as the restrictions of both the designating program and the limits of the Transect Zone of the Density Recipient property are observed. 
4.4.4  Density Transfer Sending Areas. Existing-Community Plans shall designate Sending Areas for Civic Space Density Transfer, Conservation Density Transfer, and Transit Grid Reserve Density Transfer programs. 
a.  Civic Space Density Transfer Sending Areas are sites of particular value or interest to the Community for their prospective use as Civic Space. Such sites shall be chosen to help achieve the goal of a minimum of 5% Civic Space within a Community Planning Area with an eye to preserving places of unique or unusual beauty which would be damaged or destroyed by development and to correcting planning errors or omissions of the past. Accessibility, availability of other Civic Space within the Community district, proximity to high-density areas, and value as buffer between non-sequential abutting Transect Zones may also be considered in designating Civic Space Density Transfer Sending Areas. After extraction of Density Rights, Civic Space Density Transfer Sending Areas within a Community Planning Area shall be re-zoned as Transect Zone T2. Any area, lot, or parcel designated as a Density Transfer Receiving Area in an Official Community Plan may receive Density Rights acquired from Civic Space Density Transfer Sending Areas. The Existing-Community Plan may include explanation for the designation of a parcel as CSDT Sending Area and may place conditions on the Sending Area Designation which are consistent with the reason for designation. In addition, under the CSDT Program, multiple parcels within a single pedestrian shed may be designated as a Linked Sending Group. In such a case once one parcel has had its Density Rights extracted for use as a Civic Space, the remaining Linked Sending Group parcels are no longer eligible to become Density Donors, and their designation as CSDT Sending Areas expires. 
b.  Conservation Density Transfer Sending Areas are sites worthy of conservation due to scenic beauty, unsuitability for building, critical habitat, riparian buffer alongside streams, open space needed as a result of planning errors or omissions of the past, or inclusion in the categories of Sections 2.3.2 or 2.4.2. After extraction of Density Rights, Conservation Density Transfer Sending Areas within a Community Planning Area shall be re-zoned as Transect Zone T1. Any area, lot, or parcel designated as a Density Receiving Area in an Official Community Plan may receive Density Rights acquired from Conservation Density Transfer Sending Areas. The Existing-Community Plan may include explanation for the designation of a parcel as Conservation Sending Area and may place conditions on the Sending Area Designation which are consistent with the reason for designation. The Conservation Density Transfer program also includes as Sending Areas all O-2 Sector lands other than those explicitly designated as Sending Areas for the Transit Grid Reserve Density Transfer program, if a Sector Plan has been adopted. 
c.  Transit Grid Reserve Density Transfer (TGRDT) Sending Areas are anticipated future transportation corridors. After extraction of Density Rights, TGRDT Sending Areas within a Community Planning Area shall be re-zoned as Transect Zone T1. Any area, lot, or parcel designated as a Density Transfer Receiving Area in an Official Community Plan may receive Density Rights acquired from TGRDT Sending Areas. Thoroughfares eventually constructed on former TGRDT Sending Areas shall be consistent with this Code. 
d.  Designation as a Density Transfer Sending Area provides a lot's owners additional options for land use which support broader Community goals but which are entirely voluntary. In the creation of an Existing-Community Plan, all such Sending Areas shall be assigned to Transect Zones for development according to the methods of Transect-based urban structure to provide seamless urban fabric in the event Density Transfer options go unused. 
4.4.5  Density Recovery Transfers. Density Recovery Transfers are transfers of Density Allowance intended to compensate a property owner for the public dedication of a portion of a parcel or lot which has been recommended for public use in the Existing-Community Plan. As the area of the land to be dedicated is lost to the property owner, a Density Allowance equal to the Maximum Building-Scale Density for the lot multiplied by the area of the portion of land to be dedicated is permanently attached to the remaining lot so that the total Density Allowance of the lot before and after the dedication is unchanged. The following recommendations on the Special Requirements and Options Map of the Existing-Community Plan entitle a lot to a Density Recovery Transfer should the dedication be executed: 
a.  Through Street Recommended 
b.  Service Lane Recommended 
c.  Any recommendation accompanied by the designation Density Recovery Transfer Applies. 
4.4.6  Density Bonuses. Density Bonuses may be generally available throughout a Community Planning Area, may be limited to the designated Density Bonus Receiving Areas on an Existing-Community Plan, or may be restricted to lots specially designated on an Existing-Community Plan, according to the details of the particular Density Bonus Program. In no case may the Absolute Maximum Density Allowance for a lot be exceeded by a receiving lot. Once awarded, a Density Bonus is valid for up to 10 years from the date of award; if not used within that period the Bonus becomes null and void. 
a.  Transit Site Density Bonus. This Density Bonus may be attached to any lot within any Density Bonus Receiving Area within the City and requires the dedication to the City of a site within an area designated on the Street and Parking Plan for a Public-Parking Facility or for a future Transit station. The dedication may reflect that the site must be used to provide Public-Parking Facilities or Transit station. The amount of the Bonus is the By-Right Density Allowance of the site, and the recipient lot of the Bonus may be designated by the owner of the property to be dedicated. 
b.  Street Dedication Bonus. This Density Bonus shall only be available to lots marked on the Special Requirements and Options Plan with the designations Through Street Recommended or Service Lane Recommended. In order to be eligible for the bonus the lot owner must construct and dedicate the recommended Thoroughfare, Service Lane or Service Alley to the City, and the designed and completed Public Frontages of resulting Streets must comply with the requirements of this Code. The amount of the Bonus is one (1) Equivalent Housing Unit for each of the two new lots resulting from a Thoroughfare dedication, or one (1) Equivalent Housing Unit for one of the two new lots, as designated by the lot owner, resulting from a Service Lane or Service Alley dedication. The Street Dedication Bonus shall not exceed four (4) units per increment of two hundred feet of dedicated Street, nor one (1) unit per increment of one hundred feet of Service Lane or Alley length. A Street Dedication Bonus accruing for a Thoroughfare, Service Lane or Alley dedication in a T3 Zone may be applied to any lot in a Density Bonus Receiving Area in the City designated by the owner of the original lot or parcel. The CRC may award a partial Street Dedication Bonus for dedication of right-of-way and/or completed construction of the Public Frontage by Warrant. 
c.  Affordable Housing Density Bonus. The Affordable Housing Density Bonus program is a building-scale bonus available generally to any lot within a designated Density Bonus Receiving Area. It is described in Article 5. 
d.  Affordable Housing Height Bonus. The Affordable Housing Height Bonus program is a building-scale bonus available generally to any lot within a designated Density Bonus Receiving Area. It is described in Article 5. 
4.4.7  Additional Height Allowances and Acquired Density Allowance. The acquisition of Density Allowance units by Density Transfers and Bonuses may entitle a lot to an Additional Height Allowance in excess of the Maximum Height otherwise allowed within the assigned Transect Zone, according to the details of the Density Bonus or Transfer Program. The Existing-Community Plan shall include a formula or table to determine the Additional Height Allowance associated with a particular total Acquired Density Allowance for each Transect Zone. Additional Height Allowances may further be limited to designated City Centers, Density Receiving Areas, or other designated areas. The relationship between Additional Height Allowances and Acquired Density Allowance specified in the Existing-Community Plan shall be guided by the following provisions: 
a.  The number of additional Acquired Density Allowance units required for eligibility for an additional story of Height Allowance shall be proportional to the area of the site. 
b.  The number of additional Acquired Density Allowance units per site acre required for eligibility for an additional story of Height Allowance shall be no less than the quotient of the Maximum Building-Scale Density for the Transect Zone and the Maximum Height for the Transect Zone in which the site is located. 
c.  The number of additional Acquired Density Allowance units required for an additional story of Height Allowance after the second should generally increase with total Height Allowance in order to reflect the added toll on surrounding areas exacted by a structure of greater height, however. 
d.  The minimum number of Acquired Density Allowance units required to qualify for the first additional story of Height Allowance may be greater than the additional number of Acquired Density Allowance units required to qualify for the second additional story and for subsequent additional stories of Height Allowance. 
4.5 - [RESERVED] 
4.6 - STREETSCAPE REQUIREMENTS 
4.6.1  General 
Within Zones T4 through T6 pedestrian comfort and safety shall be a primary consideration of all Thoroughfare design, rehabilitation and renovation projects, and an important objective of Existing-Community Plans. The following methods shall be used to achieve this objective: 
a.  Streetscape related designations, recommendations, and requirements shall be indicated on the Street and Parking Plan of the Existing-Community Plan. Designations, recommendations, and requirements that directly affect lot and property owners shall also be indicated on the Special Requirements and Options Map of the Existing-Community Plan. 
b.  In and near Neighborhood centers and City Centers, and in general throughout T4, T5, and T6 Zones, Existing-Community Plans shall recommend retrofit of street Traffic Calming designs as necessary to accommodate pedestrian use and to slow traffic to pedestrian-safe speeds by the designation Traffic Calming Recommended on the Street and Parking Plan. Problematic areas may be designated Traffic Calming Redesign Required in the Street and Parking Plan to recommend future street design requirements. 
c.  Existing-Community Plans may require placement of signage warning drivers of pedestrian primacy along specified routes by the designation Pedestrian Primacy Warnings. 
d.  Existing-Community Plans may require curb parking and street tree plantings as Traffic Calming mechanisms. 
e.  An Existing-Community Plan shall indicate suggested sites for the potential locations of Transit Stations within or near City Centers. The plan may also indicate such suggested sites near extensive T5 Zones away from City Centers. Such designated sites shall qualify for a Transit Site Density Bonus. 
4.6.2  Thoroughfares 
a.  Creation, completion, and restoration of a regular, connected grid of streets to provide dispersed traffic capacity and multiple alternative routes through a Community Planning Area shall be a guiding objective in the preparation of Existing-Community Plans. 
b.  Connection and extension of existing Thoroughfares through blocks may be recommended through the designation Through Street Recommended, and may be incentivized through implicit Density Recovery Transfer, through explicit Street Dedication Bonuses, and through Conditional Transect Zone Adjustments as designated on the Special Requirements and Options Map of the Existing-Community Plan, in accordance with Section 4.11. The Existing-Community Plan in such cases shall indicate the recommended street connections and an approximate route across the block. 
c.  Addition of Service Alleys or Service Lanes to a block, or extension of an existing Rear Alley or Lane through a block, may be recommended through the designation Service Lane Recommended, and may be incentivized through the included Density Recovery Transfer, and through explicit Street Dedication Bonuses as designated on the Special Requirements and Options Map of the Existing-Community Plan. Recommended routes of the Service Lanes and Service Alleys through the block shall be indicated in such cases. 
d.  Rights-of-way for future recommended transit corridors shall be designated as Transit Grid Reserve Density Transfer Sending Areas on the Community Plan and shall entitle parcels through which the corridors are routed to recover otherwise-lost Density Rights in exchange for dedication of the rights of way. The Existing-Community Plan may also designate portions of such parcels resulting from a potential corridor dedication to Conditional Transect Zone Adjustments or to Street Dedication Bonuses. Transit Grid Reserve Density Transfers shall be used within Existing Communities for grid enhancement for particularly critical routes and for redundancy of critical routes, and Thoroughfares constructed on them shall be consistent with this Code. 
e.  Existing-Community Plans shall designate streets in T5 and T6 zones for Curb Parking wherever possible, and may recommend future redesign to accommodate curb parking where existing street conditions do not allow. Plans shall designate curb parking areas wherever possible in areas within T3 and T4 Zones served by Rear Alleys and Rear Lanes. Curb parking may be allowed wherever existing street widths consistent with Table 3 allow. 
f.  Curbside locations for Taxi Stands may be designated within City Centers. 
g.  Routes suitable for a bicycle network should be designated throughout as defined in Article 7 Definitions of Terms and allocated in Table 14E. The community bicycle network should be connected to existing or proposed Sector networks wherever possible. 
4.6.3  Public Frontages 
a.  Existing-Community Plans shall specify street tree plantings in accordance with the requirements of Article 5 and with Table 6 on the Street and Parking Plan. In order to facilitate the quickest possible restoration of the peculiar benefits of shade-bearing street trees, alternating quick-growth species with more desirable but slower-growing species shall be allowed in all Zones; an Existing-Community Plan employing such alternate plantings should also stipulate a schedule for replacing quick-growth species with more desirable and long-lived species after the original planting has sufficiently matured to provide shade cover, in accordance with the requirements of Article 5. Landscaping requirements may be specified for designated areas if in accordance with Table 4B. 
b.  Shade being critical to attracting pedestrian traffic in the local climate, the Frontage along at least principal Thoroughfares of intensive mixed-use areas, including Neighborhood centers and City Centers, may be designated in the Existing-Community Plan for coordinated pedestrian shade cover by means of the Special Requirement designation Shaded Pedestrian Way. Regular spacing of street trees in T4+, T5, and T6 Zones in City Centers shall not exceed 30 feet, with layout adjusted to accommodate necessary physical interruptions. 
c.  Streetlights consistent with the requirements of Table 5 shall be selected for each Transect Zone and specified for consistent use throughout the Community Planning Area on the Streets and Parking Plan of the Existing-Community Plan. 
4.6.4 [RESERVED] 
4.7 - CIVIC FUNCTIONS 
4.7.1  General 
a.  An Existing-Community Plan shall designate Civic Space (CS) and Civic Buildings (CB) on all three maps of the Plan, and may additionally allow their creation by Warrant or by Planning Commission Approval according to the requirements of Table 10. 
b.  Civic Functions may only be Warranted so long as they do not occupy more than a total of 20% of the area of each Pedestrian Shed. A Civic Function requiring more than 20% of the Pedestrian Shed shall require the creation of a Special District with its own standards (see Section 2.9.2) by planning process in accordance with state law. 
c.  Parking for Civic Functions shall be determined by Warrant. 
4.7.2  Civic Space (CS) 
a.  Within Infill Communities, Civic Spaces may be approved by Warrant in any Transect Zone. 
b.  Civic Spaces shall be generally designed as described in Table 13. 
4.7.3  Civic Building (CB) 
a.  Civic Buildings shall be approved by Planning Commission or by Warrant according to the requirements of Table 10 in any Transect Zone on sites reserved for Civic Buildings. 
b.  Civic Buildings shall not be subject to the Requirements of Article 5. The particulars of their design shall be determined by Planning Commission in consultation with the City Architect and the Urban Design Center, if one has been established. 
4.8 - PARKING ACCOMMODATION REQUIREMENTS 
4.8.1 Except where explicitly noted within this Section, parking accommodation requirements shall appear on the Street and Parking Map of an Existing-Community Plan. 
4.8.2 An Existing-Community Plan shall indicate suggested sites for the locations of Public-Parking Facilities near City Centers, with sufficient sites so indicated that any T5 or T6 Zone which is part of a City Center lies within one-quarter mile of at least one such site. The plan may also indicate such suggested sites near extensive T5 Zones away from City Centers. Such designated sites shall qualify for a Transit Site Density Bonus. 
4.8.3 The Existing-Community Plan shall designate streets within T5 and T6 Zones for Metered Curb Parking wherever possible. 
4.8.4 The Existing-Community Plan shall delineate Parking Benefit Districts throughout T3 and T4L Zones near Neighborhood centers or at least those within one-quarter mile of T5 and T6 Zones which are part of City Centers. 
4.8.5 All streets in T4+ Zones where curb parking is available shall be designated as either Metered Curb Parking areas or as part of an adjacent Parking Benefit District. Other intensive mixed-use areas should also be considered for Metered Curb Parking designation and a surrounding Parking Benefit District. 
4.8.6 Parking spaces shall be Unbundled from interior floor space in all T4+, T5, and T6 Zones within areas designated as City Centers on the Existing-Community Plan. The Plan may also delineate and designate other areas as Unbundled Parking Areas. In areas so designated parking spaces shall be sold or leased independently of interior floor space. All intensive mixed-use areas should be designated as Unbundled Parking Areas. 
4.8.7 At least one-half (1/2) of the parking requirement for planned uses in T5 and T6 Zones within City Centers or within Unbundled Parking Areas shall be provided off-site in Public-Parking Facilities within one-quarter mile (1/4 mi) of the use which generates the requirement. The distance limit may be increased to one-half mile (1/2 mi) by Warrant. 
4.8.8 In T4+, T5, or T6 Zones within an Unbundled Parking Area or within a City Center, on-site parking spaces shall be provided as part of a Public-Parking Facility. 
4.8.9 In Neighborhood Centers and in T4+ and T5 Zones outside Unbundled Parking Areas and City Centers, the Existing-Community Plan shall require that surface parking lots which are located in adjacent lots without intervening buildings must provide direct vehicular access between lots. 
4.8.10 Certified Affordable Housing units shall be subject to reduced parking requirements of one (1) parking space per dwelling unit. Within Unbundled Parking Areas, including T5 and T6 Zones in City Centers, the parking requirement for Certified Affordable Housing may be altogether waived, subject to approval by Warrant. 
4.9 - ARCHITECTURAL REQUIREMENTS 
4.9.1 Existing-Community Plans may incorporate and recommend or require compliance with Community Architectural Guidelines, adopted as supplemental to the Community Plan and stipulating additional architectural standards specific to the Community, beyond those required by this Code. 
4.9.2 A Community may choose to create Community Architectural Guidelines after approval of an Existing-Community Plan, and to incorporate such Guidelines into the Official Community Plan by amendment as stipulated in Section 4.12. 
4.9.3 A Community Plan may impose a requirement, within designated overlay districts, or generally across the entire Community Planning Area, for architectural review of proposed buildings or structures, or of their exterior improvement, alteration, or addition, for determination by the City Architect of compliance with such Community Architectural Guidelines, in accordance with the City's Architectural Review Ordinance, if such exists. 
4.9.4 A Community Plan may require specified Stepbacks in Facades above specified heights along Frontage lines. 
4.9.5 A Community Plan may require Buildout-at-Height Limits limiting the blockage by buildings of light and breeze passage parallel to one or more lot lines or Frontage lines at several specified heights. 
4.10 - SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS 
4.10.1 To the extent applicable an Existing-Community Plan may include the following special requirements on the Special Requirements and Options Map: 
a.  A differentiation of the Thoroughfares into a Primary Grid (P-Grid) and a Secondary Grid (S-Grid). Buildings along the P-Grid shall be held to the highest standard of this Code in support of pedestrian activity. Buildings along the S-Grid may be more readily considered for Warrants and Variances allowing automobile-oriented standards. The Frontages assigned to the S-Grid shall not exceed 30% of the total length within a Pedestrian Shed. 
b.  A designation for Mandatory or Recommended Retail Frontage requiring that a building provide a shopfront at sidewalk level along the entire length of the Frontage. The shopfront shall be no less than 70% glazed in clear glass and provided with an awning, gallery, or arcade overlapping the sidewalk as generally illustrated in Table 7. The first floor shall be confined to Retail use through the depth of the First Layer. For cases where the Minimum Building Elevation is more than 5 feet above grade, this requirement may be satisfied through the creation of an elevated sidewalk, the substitution of a Sidewalk Retail area in accordance with 4.10.1d, or some combination of these requirements subject to approval by Warrant. 
A designation for Recommended Retail Frontage shall qualify the designated property for a Density Bonus of 1 EHU per 50 feet of frontage built out in compliance with a Retail Frontage requirement. 
Once the Density Bonus is issued, the Recommended Retail Frontage requirement shall become binding on the property. A designation for Mandatory Convertible Retail Frontage shall require that a building be constructed so that the frontage may be converted through minor reconstruction without structural modification to be compliant with the Mandatory Retail Frontage requirement. Conversion to full compliance with a Mandatory Retail Frontage designation may be required as a condition of approval for any future interior or exterior building permit by the CRC. 
c.  A designation for Mandatory or Recommended Gallery/Arcade Frontage, requiring that a building provide a permanent cover over the sidewalk, either cantilevered or supported by columns. The Gallery or Arcade Frontage may be combined with a Retail Frontage as shown in Table 7. 
d.  Designation of an outside area for Sidewalk Retail, allowing use in the specified area by pushcart peddlers, outdoor restaurants, and other open market uses without additional Planning Commission approval, and requiring provision on abutting lots for future leasable open-market services including associated restaurant space with dedicated access to the sidewalk, secure storage space within parking structures for pushcarts, and coordinated design of Public and Private Frontages within the area to accommodate Sidewalk Retail usages. 
e.  A designation of Coordinated Streetscape Frontage, requiring that the Public and Private Frontages be coordinated as a single, coherent landscape and paving design. 
f.  Specific Facade alignment requirements for streets where the Facade alignments are traditionally not parallel to the street, or where Frontage Lines and side lot lines are not orthogonal. 
g.  A designation of Shaded Pedestrian Way, requiring that Public and Private Frontages are coherently planned and planted with a combination of fast-growing and of more long-lived shade trees, so arranged in combination with awnings, galleries, and arbors as to provide nearly continuous shade cover for pedestrians along Frontages, sidewalks and pedestrian paths so designated. 
h.  A designation for Cross Block Passages, requiring a minimum 8-foot-wide ground-level pedestrian access be reserved between certain buildings with the goal of limiting pedestrian-route block face lengths to less than 400 feet. 
i.  A designation of Terminated Vista for a site, requiring that any building located at that site be provided with architectural articulation of a Type and character that responds to the location as approved by the CRC. 
j.  Without limiting any provision hereof relating to the Historic District or a Historic Structure or Historic Site, a designation of Buildings of Value, requiring that such buildings and structures may be altered or demolished only when in accordance with preservation standards and protocols adopted by the Planning Commission. 
k.  A designation of Infill Plan Required for blocks which deviate significantly from the block or lot size requirements for the Transect Zone(s) assigned in the Community Plan, as specified in Section 4.11. 
(Ord. No. 2558, § 1, 10-17-07) 
4.11 - NON-CONFORMING CONDITIONS 
4.11.1  Damage Due to Emergency Conditions. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained or implied herein, if a building, structure, or other improvement is damaged or destroyed by any event resulting in the declaration of an emergency or disaster applicable to the City by the Mayor and City Council, the owner of record on the date of the event may repair or rebuild such building, structure or other improvement on the same building site and with the same building footprint by right. To qualify, the building, structure, or other improvement must have lawfully existed prior to the causative event and neither the lot, use, building, improvement, structure nor condition may be added to or altered in any way, except to remedy the effects of such damage or destruction, unless such additions or alterations cause the lot, use, building, improvement, structure or condition to conform more closely with the provisions of this Code; and repair or replacement of such buildings, structures, or improvements shall be completed within one (1) year of the causative event. 
4.11.2  Pre-Existing Non-Conformity. Without limiting the foregoing, any lot, parcel, use, building, improvement, structure or condition subject to an Official Community Plan under this Code that lawfully existed upon the adoption by the Mayor and City Council of that Community Plan may continue to exist as it did, and may be repaired to such pre-existing condition. The lot, use, building, improvement, structure or condition may not be changed or added to after such date, except to conform more closely with the provisions of this Code. If the use or condition ceases for a period in excess of one (1) year, subsequent use or condition shall be fully compliant with this Code. 
4.11.3  Oversized Parcels. An Existing-Community Plan may recommend that large parcels and lots included in Transect Zones whose maximum lot dimensions such parcels significantly exceed should be subdivided in order to be made compliant with this Code by the designation Subdivision Recommended or Subdivision Required, according to the severity of the dimensional mismatch. The Existing-Community Plan should assign such a parcel to a single Transect Zone. If such a parcel would more appropriately be subdivided and assigned to more than one Transect Zone, the Existing-Community Plan may designate the parcel as Infill Plan Recommended or Required, and may include on the Special Requirements and Options Map a Conditional Transect Zone Adjustment (CTZA) recommendation which maps the parcel into multiple Transect Zones. The CTZA may be adopted through an abbreviated process. 
4.11.4  Oversized Blocks. Existing-Community Plans should address blocks which exceed the maximum block perimeter length of the assigned Transect Zone(s) according to whether such blocks are largely developed or undeveloped and according to the compatibility of any existing development with the Community Plan. 
a.  Undeveloped parcels which are too large to meet requirements of the assigned Transect Zone and which are located on such oversized blocks, but which are too small to meet the requirement for submitting a New Community Plan in infill areas, should be designated Infill Plan Required on the Special Requirements and Options Map, and may include a recommended block layout plan and Conditional Transect Zone Adjustment recommendations appropriate to the proposed layout on the Special Requirements and Options Map. 
b.  Parcels too large to meet requirements of the assigned Transect Zone, located on such oversized blocks, and developed with uses or structures which are incompatible with the surrounding Community may continue according to Section 4.11.2; but the Existing-Community Plan should designate such parcels Infill Plan Required on the Special Requirements and Options Map, and may include a recommended block layout plan and Conditional Transect Zone Adjustment recommendations appropriate to the proposed layout on the Special Requirements and Options Map. 
c.  Oversized blocks comprising primarily lots and parcels developed compatibly with the surrounding Community should be addressed in the Existing-Community Plan through use of Through Street and Service Lane Recommendations incorporating Street Dedication Bonuses with Density Recovery Transfers on the Special Requirements and Options Map (in accordance with Section 4.6.2), and may additionally include Conditional Transect Zone Adjustments on the Special Requirements and Options Map. 
4.11.5  Infill Plans. Infill Plans shall be submitted and approved prior to development of parcels designated on the Community Plan as 'Infill Plan Required.' Additionally any parcel owner may submit an Infill Plan for redevelopment of a parcel or a contiguous cluster of parcels subject to a Community Plan. Submission requirements and approval process for Infill Plans shall be in accordance with Section 4.12. 
a.  Infill Plans are submitted and approved through a process similar to that for New Community Plans, but to the extent that the areas they describe are already governed by the requirements of an existing Official Community Plan, the application requirements are reduced. 
b.  For plans which adhere closely to any recommended street routes and Conditional Transect Zone Adjustments included in an Official Community Plan, as determined by the CRC, Infill Plans may be approved by an abbreviated process including a single public hearing for approval of block, street, and lot layout and Transect re-zoning. Infill Plans differing substantively from the recommendations of the Existing-Community Plan shall require separate public hearings for the Transect re-zoning and for approval of the street, block, and lot layouts subject to the ultimate Transect Zones. 
c.  Approval of any Infill Plan shall be determined based on the consistency of the plan with the Community Plan and with the surrounding area. An Infill Plan shall design a parcel as part of the surrounding existing Pedestrian Shed, blending Transect Zones at edges seamlessly. An Infill Plan may not create a new Neighborhood center if an existing Neighborhood center lies within 1/4 mile of the parcel unless the Infill Plan creates by connection of Thoroughfares an intersection of sufficient importance to merit such a new center. 
d.  An Infill Plan shall demonstrate consistency with the requirements and character of the governing Community Plan. 
e.  Density Recovery Transfers shall be available where designated in the Community Plan for Infill plans which include recommended through-street connections or preserve recommended Transit Grid Reserves. 
4.11.6  Conditional Transect Zone Adjustments. Except for rare cases the Existing-Community Plan should map a single lot or parcel to a single Transect Zone. In cases the Pedestrian Shed layout would be better served by mapping a subdivided oversized parcel into multiple Transect Zones, the Existing-Community Plan may include a recommended plan for the oversized parcel on the Special Requirements and Options Map showing recommended through street and alley routings and a recommended allocation amongst several Transect Zones. Designating the recommended zone assignment for the parcel as a Conditional Transect Zone Adjustment allows the parcel owner to utilize a simplified application and approval process if the proposed Infill Plan adheres closely to the recommendations. 
4.11.7 Submission and implementation of plans for new Thoroughfares and blocks as part of an Infill Plan implementation or in response to Through Street or Service Lane Recommendations according to Section 4.11 shall be subject to the Special Tree Requirements of Article 3, Section 3.9. 
4.12 - PROCEDURAL REQUIREMENTS 
4.12.1 Approval Process for Existing-Community Plans 
a.  Preparation of an Existing-Community Plan shall commence after approval of the Mayor and City Council of a request by the Planning Commission, by the Mayor, by a City Council member, or by residents and property owners in the subject area. 
b.  Public consultations shall be held and the information so gathered shall be used to steer the design of the Existing-Community Plan. 
c.  The completed proposed Existing-Community Plan should be submitted to the Planning Office for evaluation as to compliance and form. The remainder of the approval process shall be handled in accordance with state law and with the Existing Local Code's provision for zoning ordinance amendment. 
4.12.2 Submission Requirements for Existing-Community Plans 
Submissions of proposals for Existing-Community Plans shall include the following documents: 
a.  A Regulating Plan, including a map showing the boundaries of the proposed Community Planning Area; the Transect Zone districts and Special Districts assigned within the Community Planning Area; Neighborhood and City Center community type assignations, including boundaries of any City Center districts; any overlay districts created within the Community Planning Area; Density Transfer Receiving Areas, Density Bonus Receiving Areas, and any Density Transfer Sending Areas; and Civic Functions. 
b.  A Special Requirements and Options Plan, comprising a map showing recommended Public-Parking Facility locations; the Civic Functions; Through Street and Service Lane Recommendations, including approximate routes; Infill Plan recommendations including Conditional Transect Zone Adjustment mappings where present; and any other Special Requirement designations. The recommended mappings associated with any Conditional Transect Zone Adjustments may be incorporated as addenda. 
c.  A Street and Parking Plan, comprising a map showing Unbundled Parking Areas including T5 and T6 Zones within City Centers; Parking Benefit Districts; recommended Public-Parking Facility sites; recommended Transit Station sites; Through Street and Service Lane Recommendations, including approximate routes; Transit Grid Reserve Recommendations; Traffic Calming recommendations and requirements; Pedestrian Primacy Warning Signage recommendations; street tree planting requirements; curb parking additions; Metered Curb Parking designations; and Taxi Stand designations. 
d.  Other supporting documents and articles, potentially including explanatory notes; an article invoking architectural review; an adoption article; an applicability article; an article defining any overlay districts; Community Architectural Guidelines; Absolute Maximum Building-Scale Densities and Absolute Height Limits for Transect Zones within the Community Planning Area; a formula or table relating Additional Height Allowances to Acquired Density Allowances; specific streetlight requirements; and any other supporting recommendations or requirements permitted under this Code. 
4.12.3 Approval Process for Infill Plans 
a.  Infill Plans which represent only re-subdivision of parcels or lots with no street additions or changes to Transect Zone assignment from those imposed by the Community Plan, or subdivision plans filed in response to Subdivision Recommended or Subdivision Required recommendations, may be approved administratively by the CRC subject to the following requirements: the resulting lot widths and block-perimeter lengths shall lie within the limits permitted in the assigned Transect Zones; the Infill Plan shall include Rear Alleys or Rear Lanes for all lots, or provision for future dedication of such Service Lanes where adjacent properties make such Service Lanes presently impossible; and no changes in the Transect Zones assigned by the Official Community Plan are required. 
b.  Infill Plans shall be evaluated by the CRC if a Conditional Transect Zone Adjustment with recommended plan was indicated on the original Community Plan. If the CRC determines that the Infill Plan adheres closely to the CTZA recommendation, the plan may proceed, subject to final public hearing before the Planning Commission after the required public notice is given. Otherwise the owner may appeal to the Planning Commission, or apply for a Variance or Variances. 
c.  In the absence of a CTZA, or on appeal from the CRC, the Planning Commission shall hold a public hearing after the required public notice to determine whether a proposed Infill Plan satisfies the intent of the Official Community Plan and to determine approval of the proposed maps as with a SmartCode Planning Approval for a New Community. An Infill Plan found to meet the intent of the governing Official Community Plan may be scheduled for a second public hearing for approval of the final plat and the final Transect Zone assignments as for a New Community. Otherwise the plan initiators may appeal or apply for a Variance or Variances. 
d.  If ruled consistent by the CRC or Planning Commission, the Infill Plan proceeds to public hearing for approval by Mayor and City Council with advisory comments by Planning Commission or CRC. 
e.  The Planning Official shall make such additional procedural requirements as necessary to facilitate the evaluation and approval process. 
4.12.4 Submission Requirements for Infill Plans 
a.  Plat submission requirements for Infill Plans are substantially similar to those for New Community Plans. Requirements for the CRC review and/or first Planning Commission hearing (if required) corresponds to the SmartCode Planning Approval hearing for a New Community Plan as described in Section 3.12.5 with the exception of 3.12.5e; requirements for the final hearing for an Infill Plan corresponds to the New Community Plan Approval hearing and is subject to the relevant requirements of Section 3.12.6 with the exception of 3.12.6g. 
b.  Infill Plan submissions shall include a Regulating Plan for the infill area comprising a map showing Transect Zone districts, Density Transfer and Density Bonus Receiving Areas, and City Center district boundaries running through the infill area. 
c.  Infill Plan submissions shall include a Special Requirements Plan showing any Special Requirement designations. Recommended Public-Parking Facilities, Through Street and Service Lane recommendations, Infill Plan Required designations, and Conditional Transect Zone Adjustments are not permitted within an Infill Plan. Secondary Grid designations are only permitted for the extension of streets so designated in the Existing-Community Plan. 
d.  Street tree planting requirements and metered curb parking requirements may be included in the Special Requirements Plan for Infill Plan submissions. 
e.  Infill Plans may not change Transect Zone parameters including density or height limits from those set by the Official Community Plan, and may not include any of the optional documents described in Sections 3.12.5e or 3.12.6g. 
4.12.5  Amendment or Rezoning to an Official Community Plan 
A community plan which has been approved under this Code may be amended or rezoned through public notice and hearing consistent with state law. Procedure for amendment or rezoning of an Official Community Plan shall be as specified by the Existing Local Codes, with the exception that the Planning Official shall also provide notice to persons and organizations on the Notification List in accordance with section 1.4.7. The City shall also make reasonable efforts to provide public notice through the mass communications means readily and inexpensively available to it. Official Community Plans may only be amended so as to remain compliant with this Code. Amendments to Official Community Plans, in order to be approved, shall be based on conserving, completing or creating Transect-based Pedestrian Sheds and urban structures. Proposed amendments which damage or weaken or violate the structure of Pedestrian Sheds within the Community Planning Area, or of the Community as a whole, shall be rejected. The public hearing process under Existing Local Codes shall be adhered to for any amendment or rezoning request to an official community plan. 
(Ord. No. 2600, § 3, 8-19-08) 
4.12.6  Succession. Ten years after the approval is granted for a Community Plan, and every ten years thereafter, at the request of residents or property owners within the Community Planning Area, each Transect Zone, except the T1 Natural and the T2 Rural, shall be considered for rezoning in whole or in part to the successional (next higher numbered) Transect Zone through public consultation and at the recommendation of the Planning Commission through public hearing after 15 days advance published notice, and by approval of the Mayor and the City Council. Until such rezoning is complete, zoning for each Transect Zone shall remain unchanged. 
ARTICLE 5. - BUILDING-SCALE PLANS 

5.1 - INSTRUCTIONS 
5.1.1 Lots and buildings located within a Community Plan subject to this Code shall be subject to the requirements of this Article. 
5.1.2 An owner or a developer shall have site and building plans prepared on his or her behalf and submit the same for consideration for administrative approval by the CRC, and to the extent required under applicable subdivision law, by the Mayor and City Council. 
5.1.3 All site and building plans shall be subject to approval by the CRC, and to the extent required by applicable subdivision law, the Mayor and City Council, prior to any work being commenced or other action being taken by the owner or developer with respect to such plans. 
5.1.4 The requirements described in this Article shall control the Disposition, Configuration and Function of buildings, as well as their architectural, landscape, parking, signage and ambient standards. 
5.1.5 Building and site plans submitted under this Article shall show the following, in compliance with the standards described in this Article: 
a.  For preliminary site and building approval: 
 building Disposition 
 building Configuration 
 building Function 
 parking standards 
 Flood Hazard Areas 
 layout of existing trees 
b.  For final approval, in addition to the above: 
 architectural standards 
 landscape standards 
 signage standards 
 ambient standards 
 Special Requirements 
 compliance with any other requirements of the governing Community Plan 
5.1.9  Parking Standards General to All Transects 
a.  Parking requirements imposed on individual structures shall reflect the requirements of Tables 11 and 12, in addition to special requirements in certain T5 and T6 Zones and in designated Unbundled Parking Areas. For any use covered in the Existing Local Code's parking requirements table, the parking requirement shall be the lesser of the Existing Code's parking requirement and that required for the appropriate category in this Code in Zones T2 and T3. In Zone T4 the parking requirement shall be the lesser of three-quarters (3/4) of the Existing Code's requirement and the requirement specified in this Code for the appropriate category. In Zones T5 and T6 the parking requirement shall be the lesser of one-half (1/2) of the Existing Code's requirement and the requirement specified in this Code for the nearest appropriate category. If the use falls into no appropriate category under this Code but is classified under the Existing Local Code, the requirement shall be computed as above, but with the stipulation that the derated Existing Local Code requirement would be the lesser. 
b.  Parking requirements shall be waived for any usage associated with Liner Buildings of twenty-five (25) foot depth or less used to screen Public-Parking Facilities. 
c.  Parking requirements for Certified Affordable Housing units shall be the lesser of the parking requirement for ordinary Independent Residential Units and one (1.0) space per dwelling unit of Affordable Housing. Parking requirements for Certified Affordable Housing units within Unbundled Parking Areas, including T5 and T6 Zones in RCDs or City Centers, may be altogether waived, subject to approval by Warrant. 
d.  Parking requirements for Assembly Functions of buildings used for regularly scheduled events of less than 14 hours per week may satisfy any fraction of the parking requirement associated with the Assembly Function by lease, securing the corresponding number of parking spaces within one-quarter mile (1/4 mi) of the Assembly site for the scheduled hours of assembly. 
e.  Any parking space used to satisfy a parking requirement shall be a minimum of 8 feet wide and a minimum of 15 feet deep. Design and layout of parking facilities, including size and arrangement of spaces, shall be otherwise governed only by applicable building codes, and by any applicable state and federal laws. 
f.  Parking spaces within designated Unbundled Parking Areas, including T4+, T5, and T6 Zones within City Centers or RCDs, shall be Unbundled with the exception of single-family Residential uses within T4+ Zones. 
g.  Parking requirements for a proposed building or renovation may be satisfied by construction of the required spaces, by proof of ownership of existing spaces, appropriately located and not designated by the Planning Office as satisfying the parking requirement of another site, or by payment to the City's Public-Parking Fund of In-Lieu Fees in accordance with the City's Parking Reform Ordinance, if one exists. 
h.  Parking requirements associated with a particular usage of a structure at a particular site designated by an Official Community Plan for Unbundled parking, including both designated Unbundled Parking Areas and T5 and T6 Zones within designated City Centers or RCDs, may be satisfied by lease during the hours of business operation, or by ownership of the required spaces, or by payment to the City's Public-Parking Fund of an annual In-Lieu Fee in accordance with the City's Parking Reform Ordinance, if one exists. 
5.2 - SPECIFIC TO NATURAL AND RURAL TRANSECT ZONES (T1 & T2) 
    The following shall be applicable to Zones T1 and T2: 
5.2.1 Buildings in the T1 Zone require a Variance, and may be built in the T2 Zone by Warrant, subject to the density limits put forth in Table 14B. Permission to build, Disposition, Configuration, and Function, and parking, architectural, environmental and ambient standards within T1 Zones shall be determined concurrently as Variances in public hearing in accordance with Section 1.5, with the Zoning Board determining the extraordinary need for such buildings and with the Planning Commission weighing consistency with the intent of this Code and determining standards of building design and construction under the advisement of the City Architect and the Urban Design Center (UDC). In T2 Zones the Planning Commission shall determine standards of building design and construction under the advisement of the City Architect and the UDC. 
5.2.2  Environmental Standards 
The modification of the natural conditions shall be according to Local, State and Federal regulations and guidelines. 
5.2.3 No area within a T1 or a T2 Zone shall be eligible as a Density Receiving Area for Density Transfers or Bonuses of any kind. 
5.3 - SPECIFIC TO SUB-URBAN TRANSECT ZONE (T3) 
5.3.1  Building Disposition (T3) 
a.  Newly platted lots shall be dimensioned according to Section 5.3.11. 
b.  Buildings shall be disposed in relation to the boundaries of their lots according to Section 5.3.11. 
c.  One Principal Building at the Frontage and one Outbuilding to the rear of the Principal Building may be built on each lot as shown in Table 16C. In addition a second Outbuilding is permitted in the Third Layer if one of the Outbuildings is a detached garage, if its Disposition is compliant with requirements of this Article, if such detached garage is accessed via a Service Alley or Lane, and if the Principal Building, detached garage, and other Outbuilding are each separated one from the other by at least 10 feet. 
d.  Lot coverage by building shall not exceed that shown in Section 5.3.11. 
e.  Facades shall be built parallel to a rectilinear Principal Frontage Line, parallel to the tangent of a curved Principal Frontage Line, or perpendicular to side lot lines. Facade alignment shall comply with any requirements indicated in the Community Plan. 
f.  Setbacks for Principal Buildings shall be as shown in Table 14I. In the case of an Infill lot, front Setbacks shall match one or the other of the existing adjacent Setbacks, or shall match an intermediate value between the two, unless the resulting Setbacks would violate the requirements of Table 14I. Setbacks may otherwise be adjusted by Warrant. 
g.  Rear Setbacks for Outbuildings shall be a minimum of 15 feet measured from the centerline of the Alley or Rear Lane easement. In the absence of a Rear Alley or Lane, the rear Setback shall be as shown in Section 5.3.11. 
h.  Building Types shall be as shown in Table 9. 
i.  [RESERVED] 
5.3.2  Building Configuration (T3) 
a.  Private Frontage types shall conform to and be allocated in accordance with Table 7 and Section 5.3.11. 
b.  [RESERVED] 
c.  [RESERVED] 
d.  Building Heights shall conform to Table 8 and be as shown in Section 5.3.11. 
e.  [RESERVED] 
f.  Building Height shall be measured from the Height Baseline appropriate to the site: outside Flood Hazard Areas regulated by the City's Flood Damage Prevention Ordinance, the Height Baseline shall be the average grade at the primary Frontage Line for the lot; inside Flood Hazard Areas regulated by the City's Flood Damage Prevention Ordinance, the Height Baseline shall be the Minimum Buildable Elevation. The vertical offset between the Height Baseline and the finish surface of the first floor above the Height Baseline shall not exceed four (4) feet. 
g.  No Story shall exceed 14 feet in height, measured from floor to ceiling. 
h.
