Pocket Parks are generally quite small and should include more intensive landscaping and public art than other forms of Civic Space. 
    Porch & Fence: A private Frontage Type characterized by a Facade set back from the Frontage line with an attached porch and a fence at the Frontage Line delimiting the yard. 
    Podium: An apparent continuous base or pedestal under a building, commonly comprising a crawl space or filled chain wall. 
    Primary Grid or P-Grid: Thoroughfare designation appearing on the Regulating Plan. Buildings on the Primary Grid (P-Grid) are subject to all of the provisions of this Code. See Secondary Grid. 
    Principal Building: The main building on a lot, usually located toward the Frontage (see Table 16). 
    Principal Frontage Line: The Frontage Line of a lot abutting the street on which the lot is addressed, or toward which the primary entrance of the building opens. A lot may have only one Principal Frontage Line, but may have several Secondary Frontages. See also Secondary Frontage Line. 
    Private Frontage: The privately held layer between the Frontage Line and the principal building Facade. The structures and landscaping within the Private Frontage may be held to specific standards. The variables of Private Frontage are the depth of the setback and the combination of architectural elements such as fences, stoops, porches and galleries (see Table 7). 
    Public Frontage: The area between the curb of the vehicular lanes and the lot lines (Frontage Lines) on a public street or road. Rear Alleys and Rear Lanes do not have Public Frontage. Elements of the Public Frontage include the type of curb, walk, planter, street tree and streetlight (see Table 4). 
    Public-Parking Facility: A parking structure or surface parking lot which offers parking spaces to the general public for a fee on an as-available basis. A Public Parking Facility as described herein need not be publicly owned and operated. The parking spaces in Public Parking Facilities are Unbundled: that is, they are freely available for lease on the open market, rather than being permanently associated with one business, with one building, or with one dwelling unit. 
    Public-Parking Fund: A fund administered by the City to pay for the construction and maintenance of Public-Parking Facilities; contributions to the fund include In-Lieu parking fees paid to the City by developers and businesses. 
    Rear Alley (AL): A vehicular driveway located to the rear of lots providing access to service areas and parking, and containing utility easements. Alleys typically extend from building face to building face, with drainage by inverted crown at the center or with roll curbs at the edges. Syn.: Service Alley. 
    Rear Lane (LA): A Service Lane located exclusively to the rear of lots, providing access to parking and outbuildings and containing utility easements. A rear lane may be paved according to driveway standards, unlike typical public streets. Its streetscape consists of gravel or landscaped edges, no raised curb, and drainage by percolation. Pervious paving materials should be used where possible. See Service Lane. 
    Rearyard Building: A building that occupies the full Frontage Line, leaving the rear of the lot as the sole yard. This is a more urban type, as the continuous Facade spatially defines the public thoroughfare. For its residential function, this type yields a rowhouse. For its commercial function, the rear yard can accommodate substantial parking. 
    Receiving Area: A lot, parcel, or area which is either a Density Bonus Receiving Area or a Density Transfer Receiving Area. 
    Redevelopment Community Plan: a building (sic) 
    RCD or Regional Center Development: A Community Type based upon a partial or entire Long Pedestrian Shed, oriented toward a strong Town Center. With transit existing or proposed, it becomes a TOD (Transit-Oriented Development). The minimum developable area of an RCD/TOD is 160 acres for Greenfield or 80 acres for infill. This Community Type is permitted by right within the G-3 Intended Growth Sector (see Section 3.3.3) and the G-4 Infill Growth Sector (see Section 4.3.2) RCD/TOD may be adjoined without buffers by one or several Standard Pedestrian Sheds that meet the individual Transect Zone requirements of an RCD as specified in Tables 2 and 14A. 
    Regulating Map: One of the three maps included in an Existing-Community Plan or New Community Plan. The Regulating Map includes, at a minimum, a delineation of the Transect Zone districts within the Community Planning Area. Syn: Regulating Plan. 
    Represented Community: A district subject to an approved Community Plan, whether New or Infill, which is represented on the CRC. Any Community subject to an approved Plan under this Code may request representation on the CRC by petitioning the Mayor and City Council. On receipt of such a petition, the Council member for the ward in which the majority of the Community is located shall nominate a resident of such Community, and on approval of the Mayor and City Council such resident is appointed Community Representative to the CRC. 
    Residential: Premises available for long-term human dwelling. 
    Retail: Premises available for the sale of merchandise and food service. Entertainment uses including assembly of more than 20 persons (not including dining) shall not be counted as Retail Functions, though ticket sales associated with such usage may be counted as a separate Retail Function and may be included in required Shopfront areas. 
    Retail Frontage Line: Frontage Lines designated on a Community Plan that require the provision of a Shopfront, causing the ground level to be available for Retail use. 
    Road (RD): A local, rural and suburban thoroughfare of low vehicular speed and capacity. Its public Frontage consists of swales drained by percolation and a walking path or bicycle trail along one or both sides. The landscaping consists of multiple species composed in naturalistic clusters. This type is allocated to the more rural Transect Zones (T1-T3). 
    Rowhouse: A single-family dwelling that shares a party wall with another of the same type and occupies the full Frontage Line (Syn: Townhouse; see Rearyard Building ). 
    Rural Boundary Line (RBL): The extent of potential urban growth as determined by existing geographical determinants. The Rural Boundary is permanent. 
    Second Layer: A range of depth of a lot starting at the rearmost portion of the structure's front Facade and extending 20 feet toward the rear of the lot. Within the Second Layer certain elements are permitted and others forbidden (see Table 16). See also First Layer, Third Layer, Fourth Layer. 
    Secondary Frontage Line: A Frontage Line of a lot other than its Principal Frontage. Typically a Secondary Frontage is the side street Frontage for a corner lot. A lot may have only one Principal Frontage, but may have several Secondary Frontages, each corresponding to a different street bounding the lot. See also Principal Frontage. 
    Sector: A neutral term for a geographic area. In the SmartCode there are six specific Sectors that establish the legal boundaries for several kinds of development. Two Sectors represent unbuildable open space (Preserve and Reserve) and the other four are Urban Growth Sectors of varying intensity (Restricted, Controlled, Intended and Infill Growth Sectors). Sectors address the legal status of place at the regional scale while Transect Zones address the physical character of communities. Sectors contain Community Types (CLD, TND, RCD, TOD), which contain Transect Zones, which contain design standards appropriate to those T-Zones. 
    Service Boundary Line: The extent of potential or feasible urban growth as determined by the extension of infrastructure, principally sewer. 
    Secondary Grid or S-Grid: Thoroughfare designations appearing on the Regulating Plan. Buildings on the Secondary Grid are potentially exempt from certain provisions of this Code, allowing for Warranted open parking lots, unlined parking decks, drive-throughs and hermetic building fronts. See Primary Grid. 
    Sector Plan: Planning document approved by the Mayor and City Council according to proper planning procedures and state law which classifies each area in the City into one of 6 Sectors: O1 Open Preserve, O2 Open Reserve, G1 Growth Limited, G2 Growth Controlled, G3 Growth Intended, G4 Growth Infill. 
    Sending Area: See Density Transfer Sending Area. 
    Service Alley (AL): Synonym for Rear Alley. 
    Service Lane (LA): A vehicular driveway providing access to the center of a block for parking, or providing general access to the rear of lots for parking, outbuildings, and utility easements. The most common form of Service Lane is the Rear Lane. 
    Setback: The area of a lot measured from the lot line to a building Facade or elevation. This area must be maintained clear of permanent structures with the exception of: galleries, fences, garden walls, arcades, porches, stoops, balconies, bay windows, terraces and decks (that align with the first Story level) which are permitted to encroach into the Setback (see Section 5.2.1 and Table 141). 
    Shared Parking Policy: An accounting for parking spaces that are available to more than one function. The requirement is reduced by a factor, shown as a calculation. The Shared Parking ratio varies according to multiple functions in close proximity which are unlikely to require the spaces at the same time (see Tables 11 and 12). 
    Sharing Factor: A coefficient greater than or equal to 1.0 representing the degree to which a single physical parking space may provide needed parking for two distinct Functions, if freely shared. For example, a Sharing Factor of 1.4 for a pair of Functions indicates that ten parking spaces shared between those functions serve as effectively as would seven spaces dedicated to each Function in isolation. Sharing Factors for Function Pairs are tabulated in Table 12. 
    Shopfront & Awning: A private Frontage Type characterized by a Facade aligned close to the Frontage Line with the building entrance at sidewalk grade, a substantial amount of glazing at sidewalk level, and an awning that may overlap the full extent of the sidewalk. 
    Sideyard Building: A building that occupies one side of the lot with a setback to the other side. 
    Sidewalk: The paved layer of the public Frontage dedicated exclusively to pedestrian activity. 
    Sidewalk Retail: Open-air retail uses including pushcart peddlers, outdoor cafes and restaurants, and open-air markets. Also, a Special Requirements designation on a Community Plan requiring coordination of the Public and Private Frontages so as to accommodate Sidewalk Retail (in the first sense), allowing the use of the designated area by licensed vendors of such retail, and requiring abutting lots to plan for the possibility of future provision of open market services, including secure storage areas for pushcarts in parking structures and retail space on the first floor with dedicated sidewalk access to accommodate possible outdoor restaurant usage. 
    SmartCode Development Application: Application for SmartCode Planning Approval, the first of two approvals for a New Community or Redevelopment Community Plan. Requirements of the application are set forth in Section 3.12. 
    SmartCode Governed Lot: A lot or parcel in a Community Planning Area in which SmartCode is optional and which has elected to invoke the SmartCode and to be subject to the Official Community Plan. The election becomes irrevocable except by rezoning once a structure, lot, or improvement which is compliant with SmartCode but not with the Existing Local Code is created on the lot or parcel. The Planning Official shall keep a record of all such lots or parcels in areas where an Existing-Community Plan is optionally available in parallel with the Existing Local Code. 
    SmartCode Overlay District: The designation assigned on the City of Gulfport Zoning Map to a Community Planning Area optionally subject to an Official Community Plan. The Official Community Plan is incorporated by reference into the Zoning Map for every SmartCode Overlay District. 
    SmartCode Planning Area: The designation assigned on the City of Gulfport Zoning Map to a Community Planning Area or portion of a Community Planning Area mandatorily subject throughout to an Official Community Plan. The Community Planning Area of every New Community Plan which is approved becomes a SmartCode Planning Area. The Official Community Plan is incorporated by reference into the Zoning Map for every SmartCode Planning Area. 
    SmartCode Planning Approval: First stage of the approval process for a New Community or Redevelopment Community Plan. An initial Transect Zoning scheme, including expected Zone Density Allocations, a corresponding street and Block layout are accepted, and construction may commence subject to the terms of the approval. 
    SmartCode Variance: See Variance. The term 'SmartCode Variance' is used to distinguish a Variance under this Code from a variance under the Existing Code. 
    Specialized Building: A building that is not subject to Residential, Commercial, or Lodging classification. Most specialized buildings are dedicated to manufacturing and transportation, and are distorted by the trajectories of machinery. 
    Special District (SD): Special District designations shall be assigned to areas that, by their intrinsic function, disposition, or configuration, cannot or should not conform to one of the six normative Transect Zones or four Community Types specified by this Code. Typical Districts may include large parks, institutional campuses, refinery sites, airports, etc. 
    Special Flood Hazard Area: One of several Flood Hazard Areas which may be identified and regulated by the City of Gulfport's Flood Damage Prevention Ordinance. See the Flood Damage Prevention Ordinance for a detailed description. 
    Special Requirements: Explicit, site-specific requirements of an Official Community Plan which are in addition to the basic requirements of the assigned Transect Zone. Available Special Requirement designations are listed for New Community Plans in Section 3.10 and for Existing-Community Plans in Section 4.10. 
    Special Requirements and Options Map: One of the three maps included in an Existing-Community Plan or New Community Plan. The Special Requirements and Options Map includes any Special Requirement designations assigned by the Community Plan. 
    Square: An open space available for unstructured recreation and civic purposes. A Square is spatially defined by building Frontages. See Table 13 for a more complete description. 
    Standard Pedestrian Shed: An area, roughly circular, that is centered on a Common Destination. A Pedestrian Shed is applied to determine the approximate size of a Neighborhood. A Standard Pedestrian Shed is 1/4 mile radius or 1,320 feet, about the distance of a five-minute walk at a leisurely pace. The Standard Pedestrian Shed is based on the fact that, provided with a pedestrian environment, most people will walk this distance rather than drive. The outline of the shed must be refined according to actual site conditions, particularly along thoroughfares. (Sometimes called a "walkshed" or "walkable catchment.") See Pedestrian Shed. 
    Stepback: A horizontal offset of a building Facade as measured at two different Heights. The offset must move the Facade away from the Frontage or Lot Line it faces with increasing height. A Stepback requirement may be monolithic, as in a requirement for a 24-foot Stepback at the eighth-ninth Story transition, or cumulative, as in a requirement for a 24-foot Stepback between the top of the fourth Story and the bottom of the ninth Story. 
    Stoop: A private Frontage type characterized by a Facade aligned close to the Frontage Line. A first Story elevated from the sidewalk sufficiently to secure privacy for the windows, and typically an exterior stair and landing leading to the entrance. 
    Story: A level within a building defined by a floor and ceiling. In most Transect Zones a Story may be no more than 14 feet in height from finished floor to finished ceiling. Unused vertical space above the Height Baseline of no more than 4 feet, raised Basements, and Attics are not considered Stories for the purposes of determining Building Height. (See Table 8.) 
    Streamside Corridor: The zone within which a waterway flows, its width to be variably interpreted according to the Transect Zone. 
    Street (ST): A local urban thoroughfare of low speed and capacity. Its public Frontage consists of raised curbs drained by inlets and sidewalks separated from the vehicular lanes by a planter and parking on both sides. The landscaping consists of regularly placed street trees. This type is permitted within the more urban Transect Zones (T4-T6). 
    Streets and Parking Map: One of the three maps included in an Existing-Community Plan or New Community Plan. Syn: Streets and Parking Plan. 
    Streetscape: The urban element that establishes the major part of the public realm. The streetscape is composed of thoroughfares (travel lanes for vehicles and bicycles, parking lanes for cars, and sidewalks or paths for pedestrians) as well as the visible private Frontages (building Facades and elevations, porches, yards, fences, awnings, etc.), and the amenities of the public Frontages (street trees and plantings, benches, streetlights, etc.). 
    Streetscreen: Sometimes called Streetwall. A freestanding wall built along the Frontage Line, or coplanar with the adjacent Facade, often for the purpose of masking a parking lot from the thoroughfare. Streetscreens should be between 4 and 8 feet in height and constructed of a material matching the adjacent building Facade. The streetscreen may be a hedge or fence by Warrant. Streetscreens shall have openings no larger than is necessary to allow automobile and pedestrian access. In addition, all streetscreens over 4 feet high shall be 30% permeable or articulated to avoid blank walls. A single length of streetscreen along a Frontage, including any pedestrian and vehicle openings, may be no longer than 50 feet maximum. 
    Substantial Modification: Alterations to a building that are valued at more than 50% of the replacement cost of the entire building, if new. 
    Subzone: A zone which shares many of its requirements with one or more other zones. The zones are referred to as Subzones of a Zone which represents the entire class. 
    Terminated Vista: A location at the axial conclusion of a thoroughfare. A building located at a Terminated Vista designated on a Community Plan is required to be designed in response to the axis. 
    Terrace: A private Frontage Type characterized by a Facade set back from the Frontage Line by an elevated terrace. 
    Third Layer: A range of depth of a lot starting 20 feet behind the rearmost portion of the structure's front Facade and extending to the rear lot line. Within the Third Layer certain elements are permitted and others forbidden (see Table 16). See also First Layer, Second Layer, Fourth Layer. 
    Third Place: A private building that includes a space conducive to unstructured social gathering. Third Places are usually pubs, cafes, or corner stores. 
    Thoroughfare: A vehicular way incorporating moving lanes and parking lanes within a right-of-way (see Tables 3 and 16). 
    Tier: Synonym for Sector. 
    TND or Traditional Neighborhood Development: A Community Type based upon a Standard Pedestrian Shed oriented toward a Common Destination consisting of a mixed-use center or corridor, and having a minimum developable area of 80 acres for Greenfield and 20 acres for Infill. This Community Type is permitted by right within the G-2 Controlled Growth Sector, the G-3 Intended Growth Sector (see Section 3.3.2) and the G-4 Infill Growth Sector (see Section 4.3.2). A TND may be comprised of a partial or entire Standard Pedestrian Shed or more than one Standard Pedestrian Shed. (Syn.: Village, Urban Village). 
    TOD or Transit-Oriented Development: Transit-Oriented Development. TOD is Regional Center Development (RCD) with transit available or proposed. This Community Type is permitted by right within the G-3 Intended Growth Sector and G-4 Infill Growth Sector. 
    Town: RCD. A Community Type consisting of at least one Long Pedestrian Shed with a strong mixed-use center, or more than one TND sharing a center. 
    Town Center: The mixed-use center or main Commercial corridor of a community. A Town Center in a hamlet or small TND may consist of little more than a meeting hall, corner store, and main civic space. A Town Center for RCD or TOD communities may be a substantial downtown Commercial area, often connected to other Town Centers by transit. 
    Townhouse: Syn. Rowhouse. (See Rearyard Building. ) 
    Trace: A feature of a site, either natural or resulting from historic usage by man, which gives the undeveloped land its character. Traces include paths, roads, ponds, woods, meadows, slopes, streams, and wetlands. 
    Transect: A system of ordering human habitats in a range from the most natural to the most urban. The SmartCode is based upon six Transect Zones which describe the physical character of place at any scale, according to the density and intensity of land use and urbanism. 
    Transect Zone (T-Zone): Transect Zones are administratively similar to the land-use zones in conventional codes, except that in addition to the usual building use, density, height, and setback requirements, other elements of the intended habitat are integrated, including those of the private lot and building and the Enfronting public streetscape. The elements are determined by their location on the Transect scale. The T-Zones are: T1 Natural, T2 Rural, T3 Sub-Urban, T4 General Urban, T5 Urban Center, and T6 Urban Core (see Table 1). 
    Transect Zone district: Term used to designate a delineated area which is a physical instance of a Transect Zone. The term is used where it is necessary to distinguish the district from the abstract Zone itself. 
    Transition Line: A horizontal line spanning the full width of a Facade, expressed by a material change or by a continuous horizontal articulation such as a cornice or a balcony. 
    Tree Protection Site Plan: Site plan for a proposed development showing location of protected trees and trees proposed to be removed. The Tree Protection Site Plan shall be created in accordance with the Special Tree Provisions 3.11 and 5.13 of this Code. 
    Type: A form category determined by function, disposition, and configuration, including size or extent. For example, there are community types, street types, civic space types, and others. (See also: Building Type. ) 
    UDC (Urban Design Center): An organization which is part of or affiliated with the Planning Office and is assigned to advise on the use of this Code and to aid in the design of the communities and buildings based on it. 
    Unadvertised Secured Entry Door: A direct entry to a building from a parking structure or lot which requires a key or passcode, which is identified by a sign of no larger than 12 inches width by 6 inches height, which includes a plainly visible warning sign against use by unauthorized personnel, and which is maintained only for the use of residents and employees of the building to the exclusion of the general public. 
    Unarticulated Facade: A length of Facade is Unarticulated at street level if it is devoid of doors, windows, shopfront glass, niches, or other ornament and variation intended to keep the interest and attention of typical pedestrians by means of architectural detail, availability of access, or continuation of the public market. 
    Unbundled Parking Area: An area designated on the Community Plan as requiring that all parking spaces be Unbundled. Parking is always Unbundled within T5 and T6 Zones in City Centers and RCDs in addition to within designated Unbundled Parking Areas. 
    Unbundled parking space: A parking space which may only be sold or leased independently of interior floor space rather than being bundled in a package transaction. Unbundled parking spaces create a free market for parking in which pricing may vary to accommodate supply and demand. 
    Unobstructed Courtyard Width: The composite width, measured parallel to the Frontage Line, of the common-use landscaped area at the center of a Cottage Court which is free of any built structure, including porches, stoops, stairways, or Gazebos. The Unobstructed Width as defined herein may incorporate any number of trees, shrubs, or other natural objects or obstacles. 
    Urban Boundary Line (UBL): A boundary representing the extent of potential urban growth as determined by the projected demographic needs of a region. The urban boundary may be adjusted from time to time. Synonym: Urban Growth Boundary. 
    Urban Village: A TND Community Type within an urbanized area. See: TND. 
    Utilities: Physical plant, including wire, cable, and pipe, used to provide communications, electric power, or other service connections to buildings and routed along easements generally in the pubic right of way. Utilities as used herein provide services which require a physical medium connecting the service provider's equipment and the customer's building. 
    Variance: A ruling that would permit a practice that is not consistent with a provision of this Code, but is consistent with the overall the intent of this Code and the Comprehensive Plan in light of unique conditions on the site. Also referred to as a SmartCode Variance to distinguish it from a variance under the Existing Local Code, which may require a different procedure. 
    Viewshed: An area within, or critical to the provision of, a scenic or valued view from a Civic Space, transit corridor, or another space within the public realm. 
    Village: A Village is usually a TND Community Type standing isolated in the country-side, but with a stronger center than a hamlet due to its proximity to a transportation corridor. See: TND. 
    Ward Representative: A member of the CRC representing one of the Wards of the City of Gulfport. A Ward Representative shall be appointed by the Mayor from a list of candidates provided by the Council member for the particular ward, and shall be confirmed by the City Council. Each ward shall have a Representative on the CRC. 
    Warrant: A ruling that would permit a practice that is not consistent with a specific provision of this Code, but is justified by its Intent. Warrants may be granted administratively through the CRC. 
    Warrantable deviation: A deviation which may be approved by Warrant in compliance with this Code. 
    Work-Live: A fee-simple mixed-use unit with a substantial Commercial component that may accommodate employees and walk-in trade. Work-Live units allow more intensive non-residential usage and are therefore allowed only in Zones T4, T5, and T6, subject to the combined requirements of both the residential and the non-residential uses. In particular this subjects Work-Live units to ADA requirements and parking requirements more stringent than those imposed on Live-Work units. See Live-Work.

CODE COMPARATIVE TABLE - ORDINANCES
